DOC.HEAD: Attacker Beats Governing Party Candidate
DOC.TEXT: A prominent candidate seeking re-election to Japan's Parliament was attacked and injured near the capital on Tuesday evening by an assailant wielding a steel rod. Koichi Hamada, 61, of the governing Liberal Democratic Party, was struck repeatedly on the head with a 16-inch rod as he left a hall after a campaign rally in Kimitsu, a police official said Wednesday. A suspect, 27-year-old Minoru Uzawa, was arrested at the scene in Chiba Prefecture, 20 miles east of Tokyo. It was the third attack directed at a Japanese politician in a month, and the second on a conservative candidate in three days. After the attack, Hamada was taken to a nearby hospital for treatment of head injuries, which were described as requiring 10 days to heal, said the police official, who declined to be named. Uzawa is a member the Inagawa-kai, one of the nation's largest criminal syndicates, the official said. Police booked him on charges of inflicting bodily injury. Uzawa was quoted by police as saying he had attacked Hamada because he ``disliked him.'' Investigators were looking into his motives, the official said. Hamada, who is seeking to be returned to the House of Representatives for a seventh time, has held such posts as director-general of the Defense Agency and chairman of the party's Public Relations Committee. A 1980 gambling scandal led Hamada to resign from Parliament for one term, but he was re-elected to his seat in 1983. Tuesday's attack followed an apparently unrelated shooting incident at the campaign office of former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone in Takasaki, 60 miles northwest of Tokyo, on Sunday. A 23-year-old member of a rightist group was arrested on the spot. No injuries were reported. In another attack, Mayor Hitoshi Motoshima of Nagasaki was shot in the back Jan. 18 as he left City Hall. A member of a rightist group has been charged with attempted murder in the case. Rightist groups, which often include gang members, have been criticizing Nakasone and other governing party leaders for their alleged involvement in the massive bribery and influence-peddling scandal known as the Recruit affair. Motoshima has been the target of right-wing death threats for remarks he made about the late Emperor Hirohito's war role.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Drexel Parent Expected To File For Bankruptcy Court Protection
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 101 grafs to UPDATE with bankruptcy petition filed, CORRECT that parent company's board, sted subsidiary's, authorized petition, edit to conform; picks up 12th graf, `Few on ...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Drexel-Impact, Bjt
LaserPhotos NY30,49
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s parent company filed for bankruptcy court protection late Tuesday, signaling the demise of the Wall Street firm that came to symbolize quick riches and scandal in the 1980s. Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc.'s board of directors authorized the move to seek protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy code. The Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. broker-dealer subsidiary and Drexel Government Securities Inc. were not included in the filing. The step climaxed one of the most tumultuous periods in Wall Street history for the cocksure investment house, which pioneered the use of risky, high-interest ``junk bonds'' to finance billions of dollars worth of corporate takeovers under now-indicted executive Michael Milken. It also could have broad effects far from Wall Street, on companies that have invested in Drexel's junk bonds, pension funds that hold the securities and businesses attempting to pay off junk debt. Drexel was crippled by the government's insider trading investigation, in which it pleaded guilty to six felonies and paid $650 million to settle fraud charges. Milken's subsequent departure amid criminal allegations against him and the collapse of the junk-bond market which Drexel still dominates contributed to the firm's troubles. ``This means the end of Drexel Burnham as a viable entity,'' said a former executive at Drexel, which used its junk bond business to catapult from a third-tier brokerage to the nation's fifth-largest in under a decade. Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. said Tuesday it had defaulted on about $100 million in loans and a lack of cash threatened other defaults. Drexel was turned down for bank financing it sought to avert the filing. Drexel said in a statement that the petition for reorganization cites liabilities exceeding $3 billion and assets exceeding $3.6 billion. The bankruptcy filing was made late Tuesday at the home of a U.S. Bankruptcy Court clerk outside New York, the firm said. Chief Executive Frederick Joseph told employees Tuesday morning the parent company and certain subsidiaries would file for Chapter 11, which would protect Drexel from creditors' claims while it attempted to deal with its shattered finances. Workers later were told they would be paid Thursday but Drexel could guarantee nothing more. Few on Wall Street believe Drexel will survive. Many stock and bond traders refused outright to do business with Drexel on Tuesday, and stock exchange specialists said Drexel brokers were openly soliciting jobs on the New York Stock Exchange floor during the day. The firm began liquidating its positions in billions of dollars worth of government bonds, mortgage-backed securities and other financial instruments; negotiated to transfer customer accounts to Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co.; withdrew as a market maker in more than 200 over-the-counter stocks; and put entire business units up for sale. Wall Street professionals said shock waves from Drexel's disclosure were muted because its crippling financial problems had been anticipated, and the decline of its junk bond business known for months. Also, Drexel said Monday it was seeking an investor or merger partner to help prevent its collapse. Wary of the broader impact of Drexel's possible collapse, the Securities and Exchange Commission, Federal Reserve Board and NYSE coordinated plans on how to prevent a financial panic over the firm's troubles. The SEC said it had moved to protect the assets of the broker-dealer subsidiary by barring it from transferring net capital to the parent without specific approval. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said it would monitor Drexel's decision to liquidate its government securities positions. Drexel's downfall may have been sudden, but so was its rise during the bullish 1980s. The high-flying firm made gargantuan profits in its heyday _ close to $1 billion before taxes in 1986 _ and paid its employees accordingly. Milken personally made more than $1 billion from 1983-87. Its attitude toward financing was embodied by brash letters telling clients it was ``highly confident'' it could raise hundreds of millions of dollars during corporate takeover battles, and by its annual junk-bond conference known as the ``Predators' Ball.'' But the luster began fading in 1986, when the SEC arrested Drexel investment banker Dennis Levine on insider-trading charges in a highly publicized investigation that later snared Drexel, other employees and an investment firm it did business with, Princeton-Newport Partners. In late 1988, Drexel agreed to plead guilty to criminal activity rather than face a crippling racketeering indictment. Milken was indicted last year on 98 counts of fraud and racketeering and forced to leave the firm. Some Wall Street professionals _ not all Drexel supporters _ contend the critical factors that crippled Drexel were the criminal settlement and the departure of Milken, who almost singlehandedly managed the $200 billion junk bond market. ``They're going bankrupt not because of economics but because of politics,'' a Milken associate said. ``They made a deal _ ultimately a deal they weren't able to survive.'' Drexel also agreed to unprecedented government supervision in settling civil securities fraud charges and paid more than $40 million to settle claims with states, although it still faces civil litigation nationwide. In a cost-cutting restructuring following its settlements, Drexel quit the retail brokerage business and cut its work force to 5,300 from a peak of 10,700. The firm had a net loss of about $40 million last year.

DOC.HEAD: Three Arrested in School Bus Hostage Incident ^Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to move up information on arms, ADD time of arrest; picks up 7th graf, `It was ...'
DOC.TEXT: Three men took 11 students on a school bus hostage Tuesday, but were arrested after releasing all but one of the youngsters and leading authorities on a brief chase, police said. The hostages were unharmed, officials said. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police supplied the three with a getaway car, and allowed them to take one of the students with them, police said. One of the men was armed with a .303-caliber rifle, and another had a .22-caliber semiautomatic rifle, police said. The trio drove north out of this city about 300 miles north of Vancouver, then turned off the main highway onto a side road, where police surrounded and arrested them around 6:50 p.m., police said. The school bus was parked for more than an hour after the incident began at 4:30 p.m. in a downtown car dealership parking lot. It was believed the students were from Prince George Secondary School, the news agency Canadian Press reported. After the bus was seized, police sharpshooters were sent to the scene, but no shots were fired by either police or the gunmen, authorities said. Traffic downtown was cordoned off.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Kidnap Americans to Protest Bush Visit; Other Demos
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Medellin Cartel saying it is giving up three biggest cocaine labs. Pickup 4th graf `Donnelly and...'
DOC.TEXT: Leftist guerrillas kidnapped two Americans Tuesday to protest President Bush's visit for a drug summit and said they would put their captives on trial, police said. One was later released. Also Tuesday, anti-Bush demonstrators took to the streets in Cartagena, where about 1,000 leftist union members marched, and in the capital Bogota, where police fired tear gas at rock-throwing students as about 100 marched downtown. No injuries were reported. On Tuesday night, members of the powerful Medellin drug cartel said in a statement that they will give up their three largest cocaine laboratories with a combined monthly production capacity of 21 tons. A Caracol radio network report said The Extraditables told a group of journalists in Medellin where the laboratories and chemicals are located, but as of early Wednesday, none of the facilities was reported found. The Americans, abducted in Medellin, were identified as David Kent, a 40-year-old teacher from Indianapolis, and James Archer Donnelly, a 65-year-old businessman from Detroit who was kidnapped his Colombian wife, police said. Donnelly and his wife were released unhurt at 10:30 a.m., said Lt. Eusabio Guerrero, a police spokesman from Medellin. They were released about three hours after their kidnapping, said an official at the school where Kent teaches. The official at the government-funded Colombo American Institute, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Donnelly was told by his captors that they were leftist guerrillas and had taken the action to protest Bush's visit Thursday for a four-nation drug summit. The kidnappings were certain to fuel concerns, already high, over Bush's security during the summit. Two U.S. ships are patrolling off the Colombian coast: the USS Nassau, an 820-foot amphibious assault ship that carries helicopters and an 1,700-man Marine landing team, and the USS Sampson, a 437-foot destroyer, according to the Pentagon. In Washington, the State Department confirmed the kidnappings but said Donnelly was kidnapped Monday night. It had no immediate confirmation on his reported release. The Colombian radio network Caracol said its Medellin station received a telephone call from an anonymous man, claiming to be a spokesman for leftist guerrillas, who claimed responsibility for the abductions. The caller said the men would be put on trial and would be released in five days, Caracol said. He did not explain why there would be a trial or why the men would be released. Police said Kent he has lived in Medellin for several years. Donnelly runs a company called Exco that manufactures hydraulic equipment, the police spokesman said on condition of anonymity. He said he had no further details on the men. The spokesman said the kidnappers were from the National Liberation Army, a leftist guerrilla group, known by its initials in Spanish as the ELN. There was no way to confirm if the kidnapppers really are leftist guerrillas. Drug traffickers have been found in the past posing as leftist insurgents. Colombian police, who have fought nearly a six-month war with drug traffickers, said Monday night they had seized more than three tons of dynamite and almost $5 million in raids on traffickers' hideouts. The dynamite was seized near Medellin in raids on two trafficking hideouts, the director of Colombia's national police, Gen. Miguel Gomez, told the news conference. Since the government declared war on traffickers Aug. 18, the drug lords have committed 262 terrorist acts, mostly bombings, that have killed 209 people. The bombings include the downing of a Colombian airliner in which 107 people were killed. In the past month, the traffickers have claimed in communiques that they want a truce with the government and are willing to dismantle their drug business if the government will stop extraditing them to the United States. Fourteen suspected traffickers have been extradited to the United States in the last five months. U.S. Ambassador to Colombia Thomas McNamara, speaking at a news conference Tuesday in Cartagena, would not comment on possible negotiations with the traffickers. He said such talks, proposed by the traffickers, are an internal matter for the Colombian government. President Virgilio Barco has said repeatedly he will never negotiate with the drug lords. During his news conference, McNamara bristled at repeated questions over Bush's security. Speaking of the Colombian government, he said, ``I think what they resent is the fact ... that they seem not to be able to get you to come off the security aspect and to address the real substance of the summit.'' But U.S. officials have decided there is so much danger that Bush must fly into Barranquilla, 85 miles away, then helicopter into a heavily guarded navy base and spend only six hours in Cartagena. There has been little violence by traffickers in Cartagena, but it has been enough not only to alarm Bush's aides but to turn away thousands of American tourists who usually come each winter. A bomb exploded Oct. 26, killing two tourists in their hotel room. Eight years ago, two men posing as hotel workers forced two U.S. drug agents out of the Cartagena Hilton at gunpoint, took them into the countryside, shot them and left them for dead. The agents survived.

DOC.HEAD: Salmon Farmers Plow Into Profits of Northwest Fishermen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The history of salmon-fishing in the stormy North Pacific is filled with tales of brave fishermen riding the wild seas, but its future is being shaped in calmer waters. Thousands of salmon in this sheltered arm of Puget Sound are captives in sunken pens the size of basketball courts. Crowded fin to fin, they swim endless laps, gobbling feed pellets and being fattened toward the day they'll be scooped up and whisked to market. Yet while the crenulated coastline and pristine waters that stretch from Washington's Puget Sound to southeastern Alaska might be ideal for fish farming, the political climate is not so welcoming. In Alaska, where commercial fishermen are a powerful lobby, bumper stickers in fishing towns proclaim ``Real Fish Don't Eat Pellets,'' and the Legislature is considering a permanent ban on fish farms when a two-year moratorium expires in July. In Washington state, salmon farmers have the official blessing of the Legislature, but that has helped little in the face of challenges from fishermen and environmental groups, which have defeated several proposed farms. The fish waste produced by a two-acre salmon farm is equivalent to the sewage produced by a town of 5,000 people, claims a Washington citizens group called the Marine Environmental Consortium. Environmentalists also fear introduced species such as Atlantic salmon _ favored because they fetch a higher price and are more docile than Pacific salmon _ will corrupt the local gene pool and spread disease. Wealthy owners of shoreside homes, meanwhile, don't want fish farms spoiling their views. Promoters call fish farming an efficient way to help meet the world's growing appetite for fish. Not only does it provide a year-round supply of fresh salmon to supplement the seasonal wild catch, they say, it also creates jobs free of the hazards of commercial fishing, one of the nation's most dangerous occupations. They also contend salmon-farming provides an economic incentive to preserve clean water. ``We're the best environmentalists of all, because we're dependent on it,'' said Jerry Polley, site manager for Global Aqua, the nation's largest salmon farm. ``If something's wrong with the water quality, we're going to be the first to complain.'' Production of farmed salmon, here and abroad, has boomed in five years, flooding markets traditionally held by wild salmon and driving down prices. ``For the first couple of years, as more salmon was around on a year-round basis, the farmed fish seemed to help the wild market,'' said commercial fisherman Randy Babich. ``Now it's a battle at the retail counter.'' Fish farming, or aquaculture, is hardly a new concept. For years, farmers have raised oysters in the Northwest, rainbow trout in Idaho and catfish in the Southeast. But techniques have developed more slowly in domesticating salmon, the mainstay of fisheries off Oregon, Washington, British Columbia and Alaska. For years, it was practiced only by the Norwegians, forced into salmon farming by their declining wild fish populations. But interest has spread quickly since 1985, after Norway refined methods to raise salmon cheaply enough to compete with the wild catch. In 1983, world production of farmed salmon was 23,500 metric tons, just 3 percent of the 670,000-ton wild salmon catch. By last year, farmed salmon production had soared to an estimated 202,000 tons, or 30 percent of the relatively constant wild catch. Norway still leads the pack, producing about 75 percent of the world's farmed salmon, but other places, including Scotland, Chile, Canada and Iceland, are catching up. The United States, with 50 fish farms in Washington state and Maine, lags far behind, producing 1 percent of the total. Many of the U.S. salmon farms are run by Norwegian companies, including Global Aqua's four-acre operation in Rich Passage, 10 miles west of Seattle. Global Aqua's farm is fairly typical: a huge raft anchored offshore holds 40 pens, each lined with a net holding up to 15 tons of fish, which range from finger-size smolts to fat-bellied salmon 2 feet long. A half-dozen workers tend the pens from metal walkways, filling automatic feeders and mending nets. At harvest, workers herd fish into one end of the pens, scoop them out with an oversize dipnet and load them onto a boat. The salmon are still kicking when they reach a Seattle processing plant 30 minutes away. In the three years it takes to raise salmon to harvest, farmers contend with prowling otters, hungry sea lions and diseases that can wipe out whole farms if left unchecked. Aquaculturists say their operations will never be a major blot on the coastline. ``It would take just 40 acres of farms to produce all of the salmon that was imported into the United States in 1988,'' said Chris Gibson of Sea Farm Washington in Port Angeles. ``The industry does not need a lot of space.'' It may need even less space in coming months. Worldwide growth of salmon farming and recent overproduction in Norway have glutted the market with fish. Prices have plunged, and many farms are selling below cost just to keep cash flowing. In British Columbia, lax regulation and a surge of Norwegian investment capital helped the number of fish farms soar from five to 135 in the last six years. But now many are in trouble. Nineteen have filed for receivership in the past year, and small businesses are being bought out by large investors better able to outlast the lull in prices. Aquaculture boosters profess confidence in their long-term place in the salmon trade. Declining stocks of wild salmon already have forced Northwest fishermen to rely more heavily on fish that are started in shoreside hatcheries and released to sea. About 23 percent of Alaska's ``wild'' catch now comes from hatcheries, while some salmon populations off Washington's coast are 60 percent hatchery-reared. ``We're not going to re-establish the wild resource. You just don't have the habitat for them to come back to,'' said John Pitts, who promotes aquaculture for the Washington Department of Agriculture. ``Future generations will become more dependent on aquaculture.'' Perhaps, but as long as any wild salmon remain, some independent-minded fishermen will take their chances on the high seas rather than turn in their rain slickers for bags of fish chow. ``It's the Cro-Magnon in us,'' said Randy Babich. ``Fishing is one of the last hunting-gathering professions in the world. Tossing feed into a pond just doesn't provide the same adventure.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: David Foster is the AP Northwest regional reporter, based in Seattle.

DOC.HEAD: AP Announces Test of Turnkey Audiotex Service
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press has announced plans for test-marketing an audiotex service that will allow AP member newspapers to provide readers with voice information services without any capital costs. The test of the new nationwide 900-number service was announced Tuesday at the Talking Newspapers Audiotex Conference. The AP will set up a centralized computer operation that will allow member newspapers to make stock quotes and business headlines available to their readers over a nationwide pay-per-call network. Newspapers will not have to buy a computer or acquire phone lines for the system. The service will be test-marketed with a limited number of newspapers during the spring, and, if successful, will be offered to all AP members. For the past five years, AP has been providing audiotex services to members who operate stand-alone audiotex systems. These services include stock quotes, sports scores, weather and audio briefs covering general, business, sports and agricultural news from AP. Those services will still be available to members of the news cooperative. ``With audiotex, newspapers can broaden their coverage in their local communities,'' said Chris Pederson, AP's sales manager for information services. ``In essence, newspapers become a 24-hour, seven-day-a-week information source, only a phone call away from their readers.'' In the new service, newspapers will pay an initial set-up fee and agree to promote the service through house ads in their publication. Newspapers will receive a royalty check monthly for calls made to the service by their readers. Each service will be customized to carry the name of the participating newspaper.

DOC.HEAD: Man Requests His Guilty Plea Be Withdrawn
DOC.TEXT: A sex offender has asked for permission to withdraw a guilty plea that prompted a judge to recommend that the man be castrated before being granted early release from prison. Samuel E. Powell, 42, of Bell Township, also filed a request Monday for a change in his sentence if his withdrawal request were rejected. There was no indication when a ruling on his requests would be made. Judge Gilfert Mihalick recently sentenced Powell to 30 to 60 years in prison and recommended that he undergo medical or surgical castration before being granted early release. The recommendation is not binding. On Monday, Powell testified he was mentally incompetent when he pleaded guilty in October to 25 sex offenses involving a girl, now 9, between 1986 and 1988. Powell was committed to Fairview State Hospital last week.

DOC.HEAD: College Student Enrolls in Royalty 101
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: What does it take to become a princess? It takes class. Lots of them, nearly every day. During the next month, 13 carefully selected tutors will try to instill a royal aura in Kiko Kawashima, a college student who will wed Emperor Akihito's younger son in June. With a notebook clutched to her chest and her hair pulled back in a ponytail, Miss Kawashima arrived at the palace Tuesday morning in a black, chauffeur-driven limousine to begin her ``princess studies.'' The first class on the agenda was religious rites and coronation ceremonies. The teacher was Torahiko Nagazumi, a former chamberlain and classmate of the late Emperor Hirohito. Miss Kawashima's curriculum, worked out by the Imperial Household Agency, will cover eight topics: classical poetry, calligraphy, Japanese history, palace rituals, laws related to the imperial family, the imperial system, the constitution and religious ceremonies. The quiet 23-year-old, who already has won over the nation with her shy smile, is to attend 28 hours of classes spread out over the next month. Many Japanese women also attend classes before getting married, but for most, flower arrangement, cooking and the tea ceremony are the popular subjects. The palace timed the classes to coincide with spring vacation at the prestigious Gakushuin University, where Miss Kawashima is a graduate student of psychology and where her father teaches economics. The briefness of her royal studies _ Empress Michiko's lasted nearly twice as long _ reflects the omission of English, since she learned that language while living in the United States as a child. And as the wife of Prince Aya, who is second in line to the throne, less will be required of her than of the woman who marries Aya's elder brother, Crown Prince Naruhito. The government plans to spend roughly $1 million on the June 29 wedding for Miss Kawashima and Aya, who is 24. Naruhito has said he would like to marry by the age of 30, but he will reach that landmark later this month and is having trouble finding a suitable mate. A recent article in a conservative weekly magazine, Shukan Shincho, expressed fear that because of Miss Kawashima's lack of noble background, 28 hours will not be enough time to prepare her for the highly organized and tradition-bound life of a princess. Tabloids, meanwhile, have warned Miss Kawashima to be wary of members of the old nobility, who reportedly have made life in the palace difficult for Empress Michiko. Michiko, the magazines report, is seen as an outsider because she was the first commoner to marry into the royal family. Miss Kawashima will be the second. But a palace source said changes in the curriculum were made to suit the times. The substitution of constitutional studies for etiquette has been heralded by Japan's media as a reflection of a promise Emperor Akihito to uphold the often controversial document. Akihito made the promise shortly after succeeding Hirohito, who died last year. Under the constitution, written mainly by U.S.-led occupation authorities after World War II, Japan's monarch is a ``symbol'' with little more than a ceremonial role. Right-wing extremists, who revere the monarch as a living god, have demanded that the constitution be rewritten to restore prewar clauses that referred to the emperor as divine. Leftists insist that the postwar basic law should have abolished the monarchy altogether.

DOC.HEAD: Relief Efforts in Ethiopia Halted by Eritrea Fighting
DOC.TEXT: U.N. food relief operations in northern Ethiopia have been suspended due to the fighting between Eritrean rebels and government forces around the strategic port of Massawa, an official said. Rebels of the Eritrean People's Liberation Front last week claimed to have captured control of Massawa, the larger of two ports on Ethiopia's Red Sea coast. Relief organizations ship most of their food aid to Massawa for eventual distribution by land to northern Ethiopia, where an estimated 4 million people are afflicted by drought, mostly in the war-ravaged provinces of Eritrea and Tigre. ``We don't know what will happen in the long term,'' said Paul Mitchell of the Rome-based World Food Program. ``That would only be speculation.'' He said WFP headquarters has been unable to make contact with its 200 staff members in Eritrea in the past few days. He said about 50,000 tons of food is currently stored in Massawa awaiting distribution. About 20,000 tons came from the World Food Program and the rest from various donors and government organizations. Getting food supplies to drought victims was a problem even before the new round of fighting began in Massawa, Mitchell said. ``It wasn't possible to reach all the people affected, but we did reach some,'' he said. ``But now this situation has caused, for the moment, even a suspension of that.'' Fessahazion Petros, representative of the Eritrean rebels in Rome, said the group had attacked the port because Ethiopia uses it to ship arms to government troops in the area. He said the rebels, who have been fighting for independence for their former Italian colony since 1962, could distribute the relief supplies themselves. ``If the food aid has not been destroyed in the fighting, I think our combatants can distribute it to the population,'' Petros said.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Surrounded by Dozens of Bodyguards
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Like an important head of state, Nelson Mandela has been surrounded by dozens of beefy bodyguards in smart suits and sunglasses since he emerged from prison. The African National Congress has taken responsibility for Mandela's safety, publicly rejecting government offers of assistance. ANC activists have been mobilized to provide security for Mandela despite short notice and little if any formal training. When Mandela addressed a wildly cheering crowd of about 120,000 people on his return Tuesday to his home town of Soweto, he was guarded by about 30 big, powerful-looking guards. As Mandela called for a new South Africa, the guards intently watched the crowd with binoculars for any threat. The only sign of government security Tuesday for Mandela was a group of black municipal police on motorcycles who escorted his motorcade. Black, green and gold ANC flags fluttered on the police motorcycles. It is an ironic turnabout for the man who until Sunday was watched over by prison guards. Mandela was released after 27 years in some of South Africa's toughest jails for fighting the white-minority government. Mandela faces serious threats both from white, right-wing extremists and from rival black groups unhappy about his more moderate politics, according to government security officials. White extremists have been making threats against Mandela for years and his safety is a major concern now that he is free, said the officials, who spoke on condition they not be identified. Some 2,000 militants of the neo-Nazi Afrikaner Resistance Movement, armed with guns, whips and knives, marched through Pretoria Saturday, yelling, ``Hang Mandela.'' ``We are going to kill Mandela and all his kind,'' said one man brandishing a leather whip. Some left-wing black groups are reported to be unhappy with Mandela's desire to end white rule peacefully through negotiation and South African intelligence has detected possible threats to his life, the government officials said. ANC officials refuse to discuss arrangements for Mandela's security, saying that would compromise his safety. They also declined to say where the phalanx of bodyguards came from and whether or not they are armed. But security appears to be a major problem in the scenes of wild jubilation that greet Mandela wherever he goes. Crowd control arrangements often break down and one person was killed and scores injured Sunday in fighting in Cape Town as Mandela made his first speech after leaving prison. ``It has been a real nightmare,'' said a marshall trying to control the crowd Tuesday in Soweto. About 1,000 marshals, young men who belong to groups that support the ANC, controlled the crowd Tuesday and also were involved in security. Marshals frisked people and searched vehicles coming into the stadium. Once marshal displayed a pistol and two knives he had taken from spectators. Mandela announced plans Tuesday to visit colleagues in Zambia and Sweden as soon as possible. There was no word on who will provide security when Mandela leaves South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Justice Wins First Bess Truman Award
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor has been named winner of the first Bess Wallace Truman Award. The Junior Service League of Independence established the award this year in honor of the former first lady, who was born in Independence 105 years ago Tuesday. The award is intended for women who have chosen a role appropriate to their time and place in history. Margaret Truman Daniel, daughter of President and Mrs. Truman, will present the award in a ceremony May 3 during Truman Week. In 1981, Mrs. O'Connor became the first woman to serve on the U.S. Supreme Court.

DOC.HEAD: Life Sentence for Mother Who Beat Son to Death
DOC.TEXT: A woman who pleaded guilty to beating her 22-month-old son to death because of his constant crying received a life prison sentence and a stinging lecture from the judge. ``Perhaps the greatest blessing is that you will not be able to bear more children,'' Circuit Judge Lynn Tepper told Mary Lee Collins after her plea Monday to a first-degree murder charge in the death of her son Joshua. Tepper said she reviewed photographs of Joshua's emaciated and battered body, and told Ms. Collins she thought a jury would likely have recommended the death penalty had the case gone to trial. Ms. Collins will instead spend at least 25 years behind bars before becoming eligible for parole. Later in a jailhouse interview, Ms. Collins maintained she is not the baby-killer she is made out to be. ``I don't want people thinking of me as a monster that killed her son,'' she said. ``That's not who I am. I love my kids. ... I don't want anybody to think I'm saying, `Oh I never hurt my kid ... I was Mother Teresa.' I'm not.'' When she was arrested for killing Joshua, she already was on probation for abusing him. His death put the state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services under fire for sending Joshua back to his mother less than a month before he died. The case was the first of a series in which children died of abuse despite being under the supervision of agency caseworkers. The cases include the much-publicized potty-training death of 2-year-old Bradley McGee of Lakeland last July. His parents face first-degree murder charges. Joshua died from a massive head injury Nov. 25, 1988, just hours after Ms. Collins gave birth to a third boy. The 22-year-old Zephyrhills woman told police she kicked Joshua two days before he died. She told police she had had enough of his constant crying. Ms. Collins also received 15 years for child abuse and five years for probation violation to be served at the same time.

DOC.HEAD: The Southern California Oil Spill at a Glance
With PM-Oil Spill
DOC.TEXT: The Southern California oil spill at a glance: Oil spilled: 400,000 gallons. When: 4:30 p.m. Wednesday, Feb. 7. Where: Two miles off Huntington Beach, 35 miles southeast of Los Angeles. How: Investigators believe the tanker ran over its own anchor, puncturing the bow. Tanker: American Trader, built in 1969, is 811 feet long and 125 feet wide. It can carry 23 million gallons of crude oil and has a draft of 42 feet. Destination: Offshore moorings at Huntington Beach. It was moved to Long Beach Harbor and it unloaded its remaining crude oil cargo at the Arco dock Tuesday. Ship owner: American Trading Transportation Co. of New York. Chartered by: BP America, a subsidiary of British Petroleum Co. PLC, which is coordinating the cleanup. Cleanup crew: 1,120-worker crew along a 20-mile stretch from Bolsa Chica State Beach to Laguna Beach. Victims: 86 birds of varying species found dead, 261 fowl rescued and taken to decontamination facility. Beaches: Huntington Beach and state beaches south of Anaheim Bay were closed until at least March 2. The 5{ miles of Newport Beach were closed indefinitely. Size of slick: The traveling slick, carried by shifting winds and tides, was 14 miles long and 3 miles wide at one point, but thinned out to a sheen Monday and was no longer being measured by the Coast Guard.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Teachers March for Better Pay, Jeer Governor
DOC.TEXT: Angry teachers boycotted classrooms by the thousands across the state Tuesday, and staged a mass nighttime rally in which they jeered Gov. Booth Gardner when he rejected their call for higher salaries. ``This is not the session to talk about additional salaries,'' the Democratic governor told teachers who packed the rotunda of the state Capitol. About 13,000 teachers walked off their jobs in 35 of the state's 296 school districts, giving an estimated 200,000 students a play day, the Washington Education Association said. Teachers are getting a 10 percent pay boost over two years, but insist that $225 million of a $611 million budget surplus should be used to double the increase. New state tax revenue estimates to be released Wednesday are expected to boost the surplus by more than $100 million. Teachers and supporters staged rallies in Seattle, Everett, Spokane, Vancouver, Tri-Cities, Yakima and elsewhere around the state. They included another 8,000 teachers who worked all day. In most districts, the walkout was cleared with administrators in advance and the day will be made up at the end of the school year. But in other schools, some teachers walked off the job and left their classrooms to substitutes. ``I'll be docked $200, but I don't care,'' said Randy Walden, a social studies teacher at Rogers High School in Puyallup who traveled to Olympia for the rally. ``We felt so strongly, we walked out.'' ``We're tired of promises,'' said another teacher Jeff Page, who teaches at Lake Stevens High School north of Seattle. ``I've been teaching 12 years and they keep saying we'll do better when times are better. Well, Booth has the money and we're still last in line.'' In Washington, basic education is fully funded at the state level, and teachers are paid according to a state salary schedule. Local property taxes may be used only to pay teachers for extra duties. The average teacher is paid about $31,000 a year, plus a supplemental contract of about $2,000 and benefits worth about $9,100, according to the state budget office. Senate budget Chairman Dan McDonald, a Republican, said it would be too dangerous to use one-time windfall revenue as the basis of a long-term financial obligation. Gardner wants to use about one-third of the surplus as a reserve, one-third for children's programs and one-third for unexpected agency budget increases.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Publisher of ``Satanic Verses'' Attacked by Angry Moslem
DOC.TEXT: An Italian announcing plans to publish a Japanese translation of Salman Rushdie's novel ``The Satanic Verses'' was attacked by an angry Moslem while giving a news conference, police said. Adnan Rashid, a 30-year-old Pakistani, was arrested after trying to hit publisher Gianni Palma with a microphone at the Foreign Correspondents Club on Tuesday, a police official said. Palma ducked and assailant was subdued by security officers and journalists covering the news conference, the official said. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said another Pakistani also was arrested after a scuffle broke out nearby. After that scuffle, an ambulance was called to treat a slightly injured woman, said press club manager Nobuyoshi Yamada. Raaes Siddiqui, vice president of the Association of Pakistanis in Japan, said the trouble broke out just before the conference was to end. ``We tried to protest to him that the book blasphemes Islam, and told him not to challenge 1 billion Moslems around the world,'' Siddiqui said. ``I told him that if he publishes the book, the 1 billion Moslems will not allow him to live.'' The book is to go on sale this week. Many Moslems consider the book's depictions of the prophet Mohamed and his wives blasphemous and, a year ago, the late Iranian leader Ayatollah Khomeini called on Moslems to kill Rushdie. Rushdie, a naturalized British citizen, has been in hiding since.

DOC.HEAD: Hasty Pudding Honors Glenn Close as Woman of the Year
LaserPhoto BX2
DOC.TEXT: Glenn Close played a scheming marquise in ``Dangerous Liaisons'' and a dangerously scorned lady in ``Fatal Attraction,'' but she was the soul of humility during a lampooning by Harvard students. Surrounded by men dressed in drag, Ms. Close paraded through Harvard Square Tuesday in the back seat of a 1947 Lincoln Continental convertible as the university's Hasty Pudding Theatricals made her their 40th Woman of the Year. At the Hasty Pudding Theater, theatricals president Michael Starr and vice president Jon Blackstone began their roast of Ms. Close's career, which has included five Academy Award nominations. ``We tried to call you, you weren't there,'' Blackstone said, quoting Ms. Close as the character she portrayed in the 1988 film ``Fatal Attraction.'' ``We hate that,'' Blackstone and Starr said in unison. ``After all, we're not going to be ignored, Glenn,'' said Blackstone, appropriating another line from Close's role in the film. The pair also gave a review of Ms. Close's career, including recorded quotes from her appearance in the 1970's Broadway hit ``Barnum.'' Blackstone disappeared briefly backstage to get what he said would be a sampling of the traditional pudding recipe. But when he lifted the top from a steaming pot, some rabbit ears popped out, another gag from ``Fatal Attraction.'' When it came time for her to honor tradition by delivering a five-minute, comedic monologue, Ms. Close began beating Blackstone and Starr with a bouquet of flowers. ``We were joking,'' the students said. ``You've made a joke about just about everything I could possibly joke about,'' said Ms. Close. Later she said: ``I'm just thrilled to be here, to be part of this wonderful event, and very, very honored that you considered my work worthy of Woman of the Year. I actually take it quite seriously.'' Past winners include Kathleen Turner, Lucille Ball, Cher, Mamie Eisenhower and Bette Midler. Kevin Costner, star of ``Field of Dreams,'' ``Bull Durham'' and other films was to be honored as Man of the Year on Feb. 20.

DOC.HEAD: Government to Require More Legible Health Warnings
DOC.TEXT: Beer cans and liquor bottles soon will bear a more readable health warning label directed at drivers and pregnant women. The warning has been required since last November but the initial regulations by the Treasury Department's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms were criticized for allowing use of small, hard-to-read type. So, after receiving 13,000 comments from the public, the ATF is publishing in the Federal Register today new regulations effective in nine months designed to make the warning more legible. Breweries and distilleries unable to meet the deadline may apply for a 120-day extension. ``The complaints involved readability and that's what we think we have resolved with the new regulations,'' Dot Koester, an ATF spokeswoman, said in an interview. ``We're pleasantly surprised,'' said Christine Lubinsky, a spokeswoman for the National Council on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence, which mounted a letter-writing campaign among its members for the changes. ``Given what we were seeing on bottles, particularly beer, there was a real need for the changes because most of labels were really bad,'' Ms. Lubinsky said. ``There had been some really creative efforts to make the labels as illegible as possible.'' ``Obviously our industry will comply with it,'' said James Sanders, president of the Beer Institute, although it ``will require changing hundreds of labels on various containers.'' Labels on many cans and bottles already comply with the new, ``more restrictive'' requirements, Sanders said. One change, Ms. Koester said, is a requirement that the words ``GOVERNMENT WARNING'' be printed using both capital letters and bold type. Other changes involve larger type on larger containers and a limit on the number of characters per inch. The warning reads: ``GOVERNMENT WARNING: (1) According to the Surgeon General, women should not drink alcoholic beverages during pregnancy because of the risk of birth defects. (2) Consumption of alcoholic beverages impairs your ability to drive a car, to operate machinery and may cause health problems.'' Type sizes for one- and two-liter containers remain the same: one millimeter for capital letters on the former, and two millimeters _ about the size of newsprint _ on the latter. The ATF increased the size of the type on three-liter containers to 3 millimeters, or about one-eighth inch. Ms. Lubinsky said the ATF rejected two other proposed changes that would require the labels to be placed in a box on the front of the containers. The regulations permit the warning to be placed virtually anywhere on a bottle or can. Sens. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., and Albert Gore, D-Tenn., were among those criticizing the initial regulations last November. ``It's almost impossible to read,'' Gore had said. ``The ATF has purposely allowed the industry to come up with a label that is illegible.'' Thurmond and Gore said the first part of the warning is especially necessary because many Americans remain unaware that alcohol is the leading recognizable cause of mental retardation in infants. Sanders, however, said, ``we still feel that the information in the message is common knowledge and thus the public won't be surprised by the information nor will sales be affected.''

DOC.HEAD: Group Backs Limit on Terms in Congress
DOC.TEXT: While Ronald Reagan criss-crosses the country speaking for the abolition of the limit on presidential terms, one of his former White House aides is spearheading a drive to impose such a limit on members of Congress. Former one-term Rep. James K. Coyne of Pennsylvania, who became a special assistant to then-President Reagan after being defeated for re-election in 1982, announced the formation of Americans to Limit Congressional Terms at a news conference on Tuesday. The group wants state legislatures to pass resolutions seeking a constitutional convention to adopt an amendment limiting senators to two six-year terms and representatives to six two-year terms. A similar 12-year limit is proposed in an amendment introduced in Congress by Sen. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H., with the backing of Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., and others. Rep. Bill Frenzel, R-Minn., has introduced a measure in the House calling for a limit of 20 years, or 10 terms, for House members and three six-year terms for senators. It is similar to proposals he has introduced since 1971. Meanwhile, the Cato Institute is issuing a study on the subject and the libertarian think tank's president, Edward H. Crane III, says he favors a limit of six years, or three terms, for representatives. ``I'd like to see one term in the Senate, but I'm less concerned about the Senate,'' Crane said in an interview. ``The House is really the body that is supposed to be closest to the people, most representative, and therefore should have the highest turnover.'' As president, Reagan often spoke against the two-term limit on presidents, imposed by the 22nd Amendment, and said he would like to campaign for its repeal after he left office. At the former president's office in Los Angeles, spokesman Mark Weinberg said the proposal ``is still part of his standard speech'' but he knew of no organized campaign for repeal. Weinberg said Reagan has been asked about proposals to limit terms of members of Congress and ``has said he believes people should be allowed to elect whoever they want as often as they want.'' Thirty-four state legislatures, or two-thirds of them, must pass a resolution before a constitutional convention would be called. Any constitutional amendment approved by a convention, or by Congress, would require approval of three-fourths of the legislatures. Noting that 98 percent of the House incumbents on the 1988 ballot were re-elected, Coyne said, ``Serving in Congress has indeed become a career job, one with addictive qualities.'' Similar arguments often are made by Republicans in their effort to wrest control from the Democrats, who now dominate both houses of Congress, but Coyne and others said their movement is bipartisan. ``I am not going to stand here and say the Democrats are going to embrace this,'' said Cleta Mitchell, a former Democratic state legislator from Oklahoma. However, she said, ``I am convinced this may be the long-term salvation of the Democratic party and not the contrary.'' The group said a poll it commissioned by the Gallup Organization last year showed 57 percent of Americans favoring the concept, with 34 percent opposed. It said Republicans, Democrats and independents showed essentially the same level of support. The announcement came a day after Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., announced he will seek a seventh term. Thurmond, in a statement issued by his office, said as long as the Constitution allows unlimited terms, ``a member's seniority greatly influences both his effectiveness and ability to meet the needs of the people of his state.''

DOC.HEAD: Famine Threatens Millions in Africa
DOC.TEXT: Famine caused by drought and aggravated by civil wars threatens millions of African peasants and refugees this year, the Food and Agriculture Organization says. The Rome-based U.N. agency said Ethiopia and Sudan in eastern Africa and Mozambique and Angola in the south urgently need food assistance. It said favorable weather last year led to satisfactory harvests elsewhere, but 20 countries would need help to distribute food within their borders or to export surpluses. According to an agency report on food supply and crop prospects in sub-Sahara Africa, Ethiopia needs 1.1 million tons of emergency food, including 770,000 tons to feed about 4.4 million people in the stricken north. About 685,000 Sudanese and Somali refugees fleeing fighting in their countries would require the remaining 330,000 tons. The report said donors have pledged 400,000 tons to Ethiopia and there was an ``urgent need to expedite their delivery and for new allocations.'' The FAO expressed concern about getting relief food behind rebel lines in Ethiopia's rebellious Tigre and Eritrea provinces. In Mozambique, an estimated 2 million people need 800,000 tons of food, and only four fifths of the 500,000 tons pledged has arrived. In Sudan, the report said 200,000 tons of emergency food are needed in southern Equatoria province and its neighbors, Kordofan and Dafur. An estimated 2.6 million Angolans need 300,000 tons of food, and only 29,000 tons of the pledged 150,000 tons have arrived, the FAO said. Most of the needy there have been displaced by fighting between the rebel Union for Total Liberation of Angola and the Marxist government.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Nothing can reproduce the thrill of the launch pad, but former astronaut Sally Ride is finding satisfaction in the quiet of the university campus. Ride, America's first woman in space, joined the faculty at University of California, San Diego, last fall. She teaches physics and directs the California Space Institute, which coordinates space research among the state's eight UC campuses. Ride said she thrives on hours spent in her research _ the design of free electron lasers _ and in meeting with students. ``It's working out very well because it's giving me a way to stay involved with the space program and use some of the expertise and contacts that I developed while I was at NASA.'' She added: ``I have to admit the only times I'm sorry I left NASA are the days of shuttle launches and landings.'' Ride, 38, who holds a doctorate in physics from Stanford University, was a crew member aboard the 1983 space shuttle Challenger flight. She served on the presidential commission that investigated the January 1986 Challenger explosion. Ride resigned from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in 1987 to become a science fellow at Stanford's Center for International Security and Arms Control. She remains a member of two NASA advisory committees, but admits she gave up some of her influence on the nation's future course in space when she left NASA. ``If you really want to have an impact on the space program and its direction, you have to work within the system,'' Ride said. ``I wanted to do physics research again and be associated with a university.''

A federal judge dismissed a lawsuit against rock star David Bowie that claimed he sexually assaulted a fan and told her he had AIDS after spending the night with her. Wanda Lee Nichols said that Bowie assaulted her after inviting her to his hotel room on Oct. 9, 1987, during a concert tour stopover in Dallas. Bowie conceded he had spent the night with Ms. Nichols, but denied he had assaulted her. A grand jury declined to indict Bowie on Nov. 18, 1987. Ms. Nichols said she would continue to press for monetary damages despite the decision by U.S. District Judge Sam Cummings on Monday. Ms. Nichols earlier had asked that Bowie be tested for AIDS, although her attorney said she tested negative for exposure to the virus herself. Bowie subsequently tested negative for AIDS. Attorney Daniel P. Callahan, who represented Bowie, called Ms. Nichols' action a ``nuisance suit.''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Super Bowl MVP Joe Montana is endorsing a new line of sports shoes and jeans that will put millions in his pocket. L.A. Gear Co. plans to release a signature line of men's jeans called ``The Montana'' this fall. Montana's name also will appear on cross-training shoes, the company announced Monday. Montana's contract is estimated to be worth between $3 million and $5 million. Entertainer Michael Jackson, former Los Angeles Lakers star Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Houston Rockets center Akeem Olajuwon also advertise for L.A. Gear. Montana, 33, who led the San Francisco 49ers last month to their second straight National Football League championship, told reporters that barring injury, he plans to play four to five more years. ``You never know,'' he said. ``My football career could end tomorrow.''

He doesn't have a television, movie or recording contract, but Tony Orlando keeps belting out the tunes. ``The show is part of my heart and soul,'' said Orlando, who is appearing at the TropWorld Casino this weekend with his group, Dawn. ``I always try to put in the show some kind of acting moment where I not only sing but bring the song alive.'' ``My first hit was in 1961, `Halfway to Paradise.' That's going on 29 years ago and I'm still here,'' said Orlando, 45. Orlando's professional career began when he was 15 and Don Kirshner hired him to sing demos in a New York City office that represented the likes of Bobby Darin, Neil Diamond, and Phil Spector. In 1972, Orlando recruited Telma Hopkins and Joyce Vincent to go on the road with him as Dawn. The group had hits with ``Gypsy Rose,'' ``He Don't Love You,'' and ``Tie a Yellow Ribbon.'' Their TV variety show aired from 1973 to 1977. Hopkins has been replaced by Vincent's sister, Pam Vincent, in the current incarnation of the group.

Country singer Rudy Gatlin is getting married May 12 to the woman he has been dating since last spring. The ceremony will take place in Dallas, hometown of the bride-to-be, 29-year-old Kim Harmon, said a publicist for the Gatlin Brothers. Rudy Gatlin is 37; his brothers, Larry and Steve, are married. Among the groups' hits are ``All The Gold In California,'' ``Broken Lady'' and ``Houston.''

DOC.HEAD: Whites Join Mandela's Welcome Home Celebration
With PM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela says whites who abandon apartheid will be welcome in the non-racist South Africa he seeks to build, and some have already made the transition. Terry Soller, a 26-year-old white, sang and danced Tuesday along with the 120,000-strong, mostly black crowd that welcomed the African National Congress leader back to his hometown of Soweto after 27 years in prison. ``This is the first time I've felt part of the future of this country,'' said Ms. Soller. ``We are all Africans.'' She waited for hours to get a glimpse of Mandela, and her T-shirt expressed her support for his movement: ``ANC Lives, ANC Leads.'' There were several hundred whites scattered among the crowd Tuesday at Soccer City, the stadium on the edge of Soweto, the huge black township outside Johannesburg. Soweto is less than 12 miles from Johannesburg and the residents are quick to offer their friendship to white visitors. But the overwhelming majority of whites in Johannesburg have never seen Soweto, and they know little about the circumstances of the 2.5 million people there. There are, however, growing numbers of whites who reject apartheid and sympathize with, or even embrace, black-led organizations. The anti-apartheid Democractic Party won slightly more than 20 percent of the vote in last year's white elections and most leading opposition groups, including the ANC, have some white members. ``This is an amazing experience,'' said Pippa Kapelus, 27. ``We have got to be exposed to this. We are just as much part of the history of this country as anyone else in this stadium.'' Most of the whites who identify with black organizations are of English descent and live in the cities. However, some Afrikaners, the Dutch-descended settlers who control the government and account for about 3 million of South Africa's 5 million whites, also are joining in.

DOC.HEAD: Business Plane Crashes, Killing Two
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf, `The plane ...,' to UPDATE with identities of dead; picks up 5th graf, `The flight ...' DELETES now-redundant 11th graf, `The pilot ...' SUBS 12th graf, ``Police Lt. ...,' to DELETE now-redundant first reference to Fender.
DOC.TEXT: A business airplane crashed in a wooded field in this city Tuesday evening, killing the two people aboard and narrowly missing several homes, officials said. The eight-seat Beech King Air twin-engine turboprop went down about a mile from Interstate 85 around 6:30 p.m., said police Sgt. Vickie Saunders. The Holt Manufacturing Co. plane was en route from New York to Burlington Municipal Airport when it crashed, officials said. An earlier report had said the craft was a commuter plane. The plane went down in a field about 150 feet across the street from a row of houses, said an official with Alamance County Emergency Management who refused to give his name. The aircraft did not burn on impact. Killed were Frank S. Holt Jr., 52, president and treasurer of the textile manufacturing company, and pilot Bill McBride of Greensboro, said police Lt. Jim Fender. McBride was in his late 30s or early 40s. The flight had gone smoothly, and the plane had been cleared to land when it suddenly crashed about three miles from the airport, officials said. ``I thought it was a glider or something because I didn't hear any noise. The propellers were not turning,''said Greg Booker, 17, who lives in an apartment complex near the crash site. ``The plane started making noises like it was out of gas or something,'' said another witness, Tamica Vanhook, 12. ``I screamed and fell on the ground and looked up and saw the plane flying sideways and making noises. Then it hit.'' Booker said the plane appeared to attempt a turn. ``Instead of turning, it went into a nose dive. It hit the ground, we heard a boom and that was it.'' He and another witness, Efrem Mitchell, 18, said the nose of the plane and one wing had broken off. ``The pilot had blood everywhere. He appeared to be dead at the scene,'' Booker said. Police Lt. Jim Fender said the plane apparently left Burlington in the morning for New York and was returning to North Carolina. He said the National Transportation Safety Board was expected on the scene shortly. Holt, a textile manufacturing company based in Burlington, would not confirm whether its plane was involved in the crash, said a company official who refused to give his name. Burlington is nearly 20 miles east of Greensboro.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Traffickers Target US Territories, Seeking Mainland Access
DOC.TEXT: U.S.-controlled Pacific islands are convenient gateways to the United States for heroin and other drugs from Asia and the southwest Pacific, and the mail often is the last link in the smuggling chain, a government document says. Federal drug interdiction on the islands is virtually non-existent because of manpower shortages and cuts in anti-drug aid to the local governments, according to an internal Interior Department report and interviews with government officials. ``Access to the U.S. postal and transportation system often contribute to making these U.S. islands transshipment points for illegal drugs,'' said the Interior document, calling the islands ``major concerns with regard to drug trafficking.'' In American Samoa, for example, commercial fishing boats bring in marijuana and heroin from Australia and other Pacific nations for mailing to U.S. residents, said the report, obtained this week through the Freedom of Information Act. A local official said the island's greatest drug problem was with marijuana, and although use of the port for heroin smuggling has long been suspected, there has never been a heroin seizure. ``We hear about (heroin) from intelligence sources, but we have nothing concrete,'' said Michael Sala, deputy public safety commissioner in American Samoa and executive director of a regional law enforcement organization. The Drug Enforcement Administration has just one agent responsible for the four Pacific jurisdictions _ American Samoa, the Northern Mariana Islands, Palau and Guam. The agent is based in Guam. ``There is a need for additional agents,'' the report said. American Samoa, Guam and the Virgin Islands, a Caribbean territory also cited in the report, are U.S. territories; the Northern Marianas and Palau have compacts of free association with the United States that include Interior Department assistance. ``Nobody knows how much'' drugs are smuggled through the islands, said Larry L. Morgan, director of legislative and public affairs for Interior's territorial and international affairs branch. ``But from our perspective it's a serious problem.'' DEA officials concurred the area was ripe for smuggling, although one said he believed a significant dent was made late last year in heroin traffic through Palau and Guam. A DEA spokesman, Ralph Lochridge, said the area was unlikely to get additional DEA personnel soon because other areas, particularly South America and Mexico, have been deemed higher priorities for interdiction efforts. ``If you only have so many bodies, it's a matter of priorities _ you've got to get the most bang for your buck,'' said Lochridge, who is based in Los Angeles, the office that supervises Guam. ``Obviously if we had more agents we'd increase our staffing everywhere.'' Aid for local drug enforcement in the four Pacific jurisdictions was cut by nearly $1 million in the drug law passed by Congress in 1988. Sala, in a telephone interview, said the cutbacks forced island governments to scale back their plans. ``When all of a sudden things are cut you cannot expect miracles,'' he said. President Bush included the Interior Department's request to restore the $1 million in his proposed fiscal 1991 budget. The report praised local governments for developing anti-drug plans but said those efforts have been hurt by shortages in money, equipment and people. Enforcement in the Virgin Islands is not as big a problem because of DEA help from Puerto Rico and Miami, according to law enforcement officials. The Bush administration's revised drug war strategy, issued last month, made no direct reference to the use of the four island nations for smuggling. But it said more broadly that the Pacific Ocean ``is virtually unrestricted for maritime smuggling, and relying on random patrols in such a vast body of water is inefficient and ineffective.'' Because of that, the report said, interdiction depends heavily on intelligence and inspections of ships when they reach U.S. ports. The source of the U.S.-bound drugs entering Guam usually is Asia, with Palau often serving as a stop before Guam, the report said. ``This heroin has been found in some cases to be 60 percent pure,'' it said. The report also said drug use is increasingly blamed for local problems, particularly in the Virgin Islands. In those islands, identified as a transshipment point for South American cocaine bound for the United States and elsewhere, ``widespread addiction to crack in numerous housing projects exists and has led to increasing violence and crime. ... (The) number of murders, many directly involving the sale and use of narcotics, tripled last year.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: From Wimp to Macho Man
DOC.TEXT: President Bush clearly relishes his metamorphosis from wimp to what he calls ``macho man,'' even though he insists his trip Thursday to violence-torn Colombia should not be seen as an act of bravado. ``I'm not going to do something stupid or macho,'' Bush reassured a recent audience. Although White House officials claim the president has no surprises up his sleeve for the drug summit, even these assurances are being greeted with some skepticism. Bush in the past has proven adept at springing forth with surprise proposals and agendas. His decision to ignore the concerns expressed by top aides and to attend the four-nation conference in Cartagena, Colombia, is just the latest in a series of bold strokes taken by a president who at times has been criticized by Democrats as being overly cautious. Bush says his decision to go to Cartagena, amid what may be the tightest military and Secret Service security ever assembled for a U.S. president, is an important symbolic gesture of solidarity with host president Virgilio Barco in his fight against the Colombian drug cartels. It's been nearly two years since anyone seriously leveled the ``W'' word at Bush, but putting to rest the old ``wimp factor'' is still a recurring theme in the president's off-the-cuff remarks. ``I love this,'' he told the Commonwealth Club in San Francisco last week. ``The guy they used to call timid is now macho man or something.'' And last December, the day after his storm-tossed Mediterranean summit with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Bush was asked at a news conference if it hadn't been too risky for him to venture out in a small boat. ``Don't tell me that that little chop was risking anything. Frankly, I haven't had that much fun in a long time. ... It was sheer pleasure,'' said the president. ``You know these charismatic, macho, visionary guys. They'll do anything,'' he said. On an $11 dare from his grandchildren, Bush stripped to his trousers last August and jumped into the chilly Atlantic from the pier at his oceanfront home in Kennebunkport, Maine. He fishes and boats in driving rainstorms, races through games of golf, jogs in all kinds of weather and otherwise keeps up a wearying pace that has taken him so far to 35 states and 15 countries. On the policy front, Bush also has been known for sudden, preemptive strikes: his decision to invade Panama, his secret dispatching of top aides to China, his springing of a major troop reduction proposal at last May's NATO summit, and a further unexpected call for troop reductions in last month's State of the Union address. The ``wimp factor'' dogged Bush early in his presidential effort. Long operating in the shadow of President Reagan, Bush had become the classic No. 2 man and came across to many as a bland figure given to gaffes and sometimes prissy remarks. And, although the image did not follow Bush into the general election, on the campaign trail he was always reliving the ``tension city'' of his on-air combat with CBS anchorman Dan Rather in early 1988 _ which some political analysts saw as a defining event of the campaign, one that helped dispel the ``wimp'' tag. And the vice presidential candidate who in 1984 was raked over the coals by women's groups for bragging about having ``kicked a little'' of Democratic opponent Geraldine Ferraro's behind, is still adept at showing flashes of verbal machismo. Last week, after climbing into the cockpit of a B-1 bomber, Bush addressed forces of the U.S. Strategic Air Command by radio and joked to crews at underground intercontinental ballistic missile silos to remember to keep the ``pointy end up.'' After speaking to combatants in military exercises in the Mojave Desert, he cracked, ``And now, back to war.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Ministers Resign, Reducing Communists In Coalition Government
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel has replaced two Cabinet ministers, reducing the number of Communists in the coalition government to three out of 20, the official CTK news agency said. Slavomir Stracar, who has the support of the Slovak group ``Public Against Violence,'' was appointed head the Ministry of Metallurgy, Engineering and Electrical Engineering on Tuesday. The Slovak group is a sister organization to the ``Civic Forum,'' the opposition group that spearheaded the peaceful November revolution and is considered to wield the most political power in Czechoslovakia. Stracar replaces Ladislav Vodrazka, a Communist Party member and one of the holdovers from the Communist-dominated government ousted in December. Jaroslav Suva, a Communist, becomes chief of the Fuel and Energy Ministry, an area where most reform aimed at streamlining outdated and overgrown heavy industry is expected. He replaces Communist Frantisek Pinc. ``Vodrazka and Pinc in fact resigned already last week, but their resignations were accepted only today,'' Ivana Rezkova of the government press office said in an interview. Despite demands by several hundred demonstrators last week for the ouster of one of the government's oldest Communist hard-liners, reports proved false that Transport Minister Frantisek Podlena might also resign. ``Podlena has not resigned and is still a member of the government,`` Ms. Rezkova said.

DOC.HEAD: Voice of America Director Remains, Seeks to Restore Language Services
DOC.TEXT: The White House says ``all is calm'' at the U.S. Information Agency, but only after administration officials stepped in to restore order in a struggle with the Voice of America. The dispute that saw USIA director Bruce Gelb try to fire VOA Director Richard Carlson was resolved with the VOA saying it will try to keep broadcasting the six language services it ordered cut two weeks ago because of a budget crunch. VOA, the government's radio network which is under USIA control, had said it would fire 57 people and trim $3 million from its budget by cutting its Uzbek, Swahili, Lao, Slovenian, Greek and Turkish services. Officials of USIA and VOA are trying to deal with a budget crunch that has left the radio network with a budget of about $170 million annually but growing operating costs. The decision to cut the six services was approved by Gelb with a signature, ``but he wasn't comfortable with it,'' said Gelb's spokesman, Frank Johnson. Johnson said Gelb was out of town the day Carlson announced the decision two weeks ago. When Gelb returned and read news accounts of the decision, ``he was very upset,'' said a senior USIA official who spoke on condition of anonymity. Gelb convened the top agency officials and he ``went wild,'' according to a participant at the meeting. ``He claimed he knew nothing about it (the decision). He was almost hysterical. He claimed we tricked him,'' said the source, who also spoke on condition of anonymity. Gelb suggested money be taken from VOA's construction account to save the six language services, said Johnson. But senior aides objected said that budget already was squeezed and Carlson said Congress already had rejected such a solution. Gelb berated Carlson for failing to support him and told the VOA chief last Thursday he was fired, the source said. Gelb also told aides to cancel Carlson's departure for Israel on Sunday for talks with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir about the controversial construction of a $300 million VOA transmitter, the source said. Environmentalists object to the project, which would amplify U.S. transmissions to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. White House personnel chief Chase Untermeyer met with Gelb and Carlson and said Tuesday, ``All is calm at USIA'' since the meetings. The White House moved in because both men are presidential appointees approved by the Senate. Gelb is a friend of President Bush and a campaign fundraiser. Carlson was held over from the Reagan administration, ``proof that he has our support,'' said Untermeyer. ``It was agreed they would try and work out their differences,'' said another source. ``Gelb and Carlson enjoy a professional and worklike relationship,'' Johnson said. Carlson left for Israel on Tuesday, meeting with VOA employees before his departure to address rumors that he'd been fired. ``He has not resigned and he has not been fired,'' said VOA spokeswoman Beth Knisely.

DOC.HEAD: Ag Department Sees U.S., Soviet Crops Under Similar Strains
DOC.TEXT: Global crop watchers say there are some disturbing similarities in some of the major breadbasket areas of the United States and Soviet Union. The government's Joint Agricultural Weather Facility said Tuesday that dry soil conditions and lack of snow cover in parts of the Great Plains continue to threaten the winter wheat crop. The same goes for parts of the Soviet winter wheat area. ``Portions of the southern Great Plains received some moisture but more was needed,'' the report said. ``Most of the central and northern Great Plains remained dry, but above normal temperatures helped to maintain crop condition.'' In its international section, the report said January brought above normal precipitation in the Baltic states, Belorussia, Central Region, Volga Vyatsk, western Black Soils Region, the eastern Ukraine and parts of the North Caucasus. ``In contrast, there was below normal precipitation in the western and southern Ukraine, the eastern Black Soils region and the Volga,'' the report said. ``Unusually mild weather covered the entire region during most of January.'' Although the warm weather ``provided generally favorable conditions for winter grain,'' it left crop areas over a wide expanse of the Soviet Union ``without a protective snow cover and caused winter grains to lose hardiness, making them more susceptible to potential winterkill.'' In assessing the U.S. situation, the report noted ``lack of snow cover has left the (winter wheat) crop vulnerable to freeze damage.'' The facility is operated by the departments of agriculture and commerce. The weekly reports cover soil and crop conditions but do not project yields. Looking at some other crops, the report said the sugarcane harvest continued in Florida, but ``unseasonably hot, dry weather forced citrus producers to continue irrigating.'' The warm weather also continued over the major Florida vegetable areas where spring plantings were under way. In Georgia, tobacco plant beds were reported in ``good to excellent'' condition and that North Carolina farmers continued to seed their beds. ``Rain and wet field conditions again limited field work in the Delta,'' the report said. ``Land preparation for the 1990 cotton crop continued in Arizona and California.'' Livestock pastures were helped by rain and mild temperatures in the Delta and Southeast, the report said. ``In the Great Plains and Corn Belt, mild temperatures and the lack of snow cover reduced the amount of supplemental feeding necessary (for livestock),'' the report said. ``Mild weather provided ideal conditions for calving, which was under way in many areas.''

China and the United States lead the world in grain production, but their mix of crops is significantly different, according to an Agriculture Department report. Total U.S. grain output in the 1989-90 season is estimated at 281.8 million metric tons, second only to China's 307.6 million tons, according to the department's Foreign Agricultural Service. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds and is equivalent to 36.7 bushels of wheat or 39.4 bushels of corn. China's wheat production of 91 million tons leads the world, edging the Soviet Union's 90.5 million tons, while U.S. output was 55.4 million tons. India was close behind the United States with 54 million tons. It is in the category of ``coarse grains,'' however, that U.S. muscle pulls ahead. Those include corn, oats, barley, sorghum and rye. Total U.S. production was 221.4 million tons, more than double the Soviet Union's 107 million tons, which ranked second. China's coarse grain output was 91.3 million tons. But China led in rice, with 125.3 million tons, milled equivalent, against 4.9 million tons for the United States and 1.8 million for the Soviet Union.

Italians are hooked on American walnuts, even as their own production rises, according to an Agriculture Department report. ``Although Italy produces walnuts, they are a smaller variety than the large California variety the United States exports,'' the report said. ``An increase in Italy's production this year is not expected to affect the import level, since consumers prefer the larger-sized imports.'' The United States provides about 92 percent of the walnuts imported by Italy, said the report, which was written by Frank J. Piason, U.S. agricultural counselor in Rome. Walnuts are eaten by Italians at the end of meals, particularly during the Christmas season, and are ``increasingly consumed as a snack food and used in confectionery products,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: ``Videos'' Soar, Elvis Snores In Ratings
DOC.TEXT: ``The Cosby Show'' took the top of the A.C. Nielsen Co. ratings and two mid-season newcomers, ``Elvis'' and ``The Bradys,'' failed to leave viewers all shook up. In the second week of February's sweeps period, ABC's ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' took fifth place at the expense of the long-running ``Murder, She Wrote'' on CBS, also under attack by Fox's best-rated ``The Simpsons.'' ``Murder, She Wrote'' finished 15th last week. In most markets it faces the ABC video show for its first half and the cartoon family from Fox in its second. ``The Simpsons'' was rated No. 32 _ the highest ``fourth network'' numbers for the week. Here are last week's top 10 prime-time shows: ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC; ``Cheers,'' NBC; ``Roseanne,'' ABC; ``A Different World,'' NBC; ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC; ``Golden Girls,'' NBC; ``The Wonder Years,'' ABC; ``The NBC Sunday Night Movie: Blind Faith, Part 1,'' NBC; ``Who's the Boss?'' ABC; ``60 Minutes,'' CBS. NBC once again dominated, scoring an average prime-time rating of 14.7, followed by ABC's 13.2 and CBS' 12.5. Networks try to clean up during sweeps weeks because advertising rates are based on ratings during those periods. NBC leads for the season, with a 14.8 average to ABC's 13.0 and CBS' 12.3.
