Each ratings point represents the percentage of the nation's 92.1 million television homes tuned into a show. ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' first broadcast Jan. 14, relies on home videos contributed by viewers. The show ``is attracting very sizable numbers of all the key demographic groups of 18 to 49, as well as kids and teens,'' said ABC director of prime-time audience analysis Larry Hayns. ``It's the type of show that people can tune into at any time. ... You don't really have to get involved in characters and plot line, there'll be another video any second.'' There were two ``Elvis'' sightings on ABC last week, but neither a special showing Tuesday night following ``Roseanne'' nor a broadcast in its regular 8:30 p.m. Sunday slot yielded impressive figures. ``Elvis'' on Tuesday had a 16.0 rating for 20th place, but ``Roseanne'' had a 22.5 rating in the earlier time slot. For Sunday, the series about the early life of ``The King of Rock 'n' Roll'' had a 12.6 rating and 47th place even though it followed ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' which garnered a 21.4 rating. The network wants to build a ratings block with the video show and ``Elvis,'' a musical drama. ``The Bradys,'' with most of the cast from the original ``The Brady Bunch,'' moved back into the television neighborhood on CBS with a two-hour movie Friday night to introduce new generations and situations. ``The Bradys,'' with an overall ratings average of 12.7, claimed the No. 44 spot in the lineup. In head-to-head faceoff, Valerie Harper's new CBS show ``City'' tied for 54th place while her former show ``The Hogan Family'' on NBC, finished in a tie for 32nd. Among the evening news shows, ABC was in first place with 11.0, CBS followed with 9.9 and NBC had 9.6.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Chooses Jail Over Testifying on Barry
DOC.TEXT: A woman who sources say had a personal relationship with Mayor Marion Barry is staying in jail rather than testify before a federal grand jury investigating alleged drug use by the mayor. U.S. District Judge John Garrett Penn ordered Maria McCarthy of Greensboro, N.C., jailed for civil contempt of court after she refused to testify Tuesday, said her attorney, Leslie Scherr. Penn granted McCarthy immunity from prosecution after she initially refused to testify Tuesday, but she still wouldn't talk to the grand jury and was sent to jail, Scherr said. Prosecutors are reportedly close to requesting the grand jury to indict Barry, who was arrested Jan. 18 on a cocaine possession charge, on new charges. Scherr said McCarthy told him, ``I have to live with myself, whether he was a friend or enemy, we had a relationship that doesn't need public scrutiny.'' The attorney wouldn't tell reporters whether McCarthy was referring to Barry, but two city government sources familiar with Barry's social life said Barry and McCarthy had a personal relationship. ``It's not really loyalty'' that kept her from testifying, said Scherr, ``but some kind of moral code she lives by.'' Scherr said McCarthy knows Rasheeda Moore, the woman who cooperated in the FBI sting operation that resulted in Barry's arrest at a Washington hotel. Scherr declined to comment further on McCarthy's relationship with Moore or the mayor. Under law, McCarthy can be held in jail as long as the grand jury hearing evidence in the case remains in session. Grand juries are normally empaneled for 18 months at a time, but can be extended if the case continues. The grand jury is investigating Barry's ties to former city employee Charles Lewis, who has cooperated with the panel after pleading guilty to two cocaine conspiracy charges. Lewis, who has also been convicted of cocaine distribution charges in his native Virgin Islands, testified in open court that he supplied Barry with crack cocaine. Barry, who is enrolled in a Florida substance abuse treatment center, has denied using drugs with Lewis. The federal probe began in December 1988 after city police aborted an undercover drug purchase from Lewis when they learned Barry was in Lewis' downtown Washington hotel room. McCarthy is the second woman jailed for refusing to testify about Barry. Convicted cocaine dealer Karen Johnson served eight months in jail in 1984 after refusing to tell authorities whether she gave drugs to Barry or who her drug supplier was. Scherr said that as far as he knew, McCarthy had no contracts with the city government or any involvement in companies doing business with the city.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalist Says White House Cleanup Targets Him
DOC.TEXT: An environmental activist preparing to begin a White House policy job isn't getting the post because of what he says are ``strong forces within the administration'' and Congress. Dan W. Reicher, a senior attorney with the Natural Resources Defense Council, a liberal environmental group, said he was told his appointment was being canceled Tuesday, the same day The Washington Post reported he was taking the job. ``I was canned this morning ... a week and a half before starting,'' Reicher said. He said he had been told he would begin Feb. 26 as assistant deputy counsel for the Council on Environmental Quality. Reicher has criticized Bush and Reagan administration efforts to comply with federal environmental laws, particularly in the cleanup of problems at nuclear weapons production facilities. He said pressure from ``strong forces within the administration and on Capitol Hill'' prompted council Chairman Michael R. Deland to reverse his decision to hire him. Deland, Bush's appointee as chairman of the council, said he decided not to hire Reicher after realizing ``the degree to which he's perceived to be a persistent critic of the administration.'' ``It was my decision, my decision alone,'' Deland said. ``I have apologized to Dan.'' White House spokesman Steve Hart denied there was any White House pressure applied to Deland against the appointment. ``It was Deland's decision,'' Hart said. ``It was a policy difference that he felt could not be rectified to a satisfactory point.'' Reports last week said there was a serious internal dispute in the White House over environmental policy after White House chief of staff John Sununu softened a Bush speech on global warming. National Audubon Society vice president Brooks Yeager said the Reicher move raises more questions about the administration's commitment on the environment. ``We're a little bit concerned that if someone with his knowledge and his integrity can't sustain political scrutiny within the administration ... a lot of high sounding promises made to us by the administration don't mean a lot,'' he said. The Council on Environmental Quality diminished in size and importance under the Reagan administration, but environmentalists said they were promised by the Bush administration that it would be upgraded.

DOC.HEAD: Foundation Seeks U.S., Soviet Cooperation on Missile Prevention
DOC.TEXT: The world's two nuclear superpowers should move to prevent the accidental or unauthorized launch of nuclear weapons by placing sensors in each other's missile fields and destruct systems on strategic missiles, a U.S.-Soviet foundation says. The proposal Tuesday by the Moscow-based International Foundation for the Survival and Development of Humanity _ founded by the late Soviet physicist and political activist Andrei Sakharov _ was made as an alternative to the Strategic Defense Initiative under research by the United States. The foundation's report has been submitted to Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, together with the proposal that its recommendations be debated jointly by the House panel and the Supreme Soviet's defense committee. Former President Reagan billed Star Wars, as SDI is informally called, as a continent-spanning protective umbrella to foil a Soviet missile attack, but the Bush administration endorses a more modest research concept. Although tensions between Washington and Moscow are being sharply reduced, some administration officials maintain a missile defense system could fend off a missile launched by accident or fired by terrorists or a hostile Third World nation. Andrei Kokoshkin, deputy director of the Soviet Institute of USA and Canadian studies, said at a news conference Tuesday that the report is aimed at countering this argument for Star Wars. At the Pentagon, an official who commented on condition he not be identified, said some of the report's recommendations could be discussed at arms control negotiations. But he said the United States already has in place a range of effective measures designed to prevent accidental or unauthorized launches of nuclear weapons. And he said there are legitimate concerns a radical Third World nation could develop or obtain nuclear weapons and launchers. Existing technology probably could fashion a defense against a nuclear attack on the United States by such a state, even though the means are not in hand to counter a full-scale Soviet missile attack. The report says installing sensors on the missile silos and launchers of each side would eliminate the danger that a missile strike could be launched because of a false alarm. ``The sensor systems would continually transmit pre-programmed, continually changing coded signals via relay sensors as long as no missiles were launched and the sensors were not tampered with,'' it said. It said if an early-warning satellite or radar indicated an enemy missile was launched, ``the absence of a corresponding indication from the sensors would be evidence that the warning was a false alarm.'' The report also called for greater central controls over nuclear weapons, including installation of so-called permissive action links on nuclear weapons to prevent their use without secret authorization codes. The Pentagon official said most new U.S. nuclear weapons have such devices. The authors of the report called on both the United States and the Soviet Union to begin urgent studies by all the nuclear powers on the possibility of placing destruct devices on ballistic missiles to destroy or disarm them before they hit their targets. This would enable the destruction of a missile launched by mistake or without proper authority. The Pentagon official said the United States did not put destruct devices on ballistic missiles because their reliability was uncertain. ``I think it is easier to prevent something from being launched than to destroy it after it is already gone,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Keating Official Says Regulators Were ``Playing Games'' With Thrift
DOC.TEXT: The chief aide to Phoenix millionaire Charles H. Keating Jr. describes federal regulators who seized Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan Association last year as ``kids playing games.'' Testifying on Keating's suit to overturn the takeover of the $5.5 billion S&L last April, Judith Wischer said the government put junior auditors in charge of reviewing the thrift's assets when Keating was trying to sell the institution in late 1988 and early 1989. ``We found that at this very serious time in our lives, we were assigned to kids who were playing games with us,'' Mrs. Wischer, president of Lincoln's parent company, American Continental Corp., said in U.S. District Court Tuesday. ``But they had the upper hand.'' For several hours Tuesday as Keating sat with his attorneys in the courtroom, Mrs. Wischer recounted with frustration various events between 1985 and the government takeover of Lincoln four years later in what she described as an ``escalating battle of experts.'' In May 1988, when American Continental and the bank board signed a ``memorandum of understanding'' calling for a new audit, she said, ``We thought for the first time since that we had a settlement ... that was binding on both sides.'' That memorandum was widely criticized in hearings before the House Banking Committee last fall. Among the provisions was the removal of jurisdiction over Lincoln from San Francisco regulators who in May 1987 recommended seizing the thrift then. Regulators now in charge of the S&L bailout contend the two-year delay in closing Lincoln could cost taxpayers up to $2 billion. Only four months after signing the May 1988 memorandum, however, Lincoln officials became disillusioned again when regulators raised new complaints about tax-sharing and other agreements that had been approved earlier, Mrs. Wischer said. ``We became very, very scared after that meeting,'' she said. As regulators began imposing new supervisory order on Lincoln, ``it got to be that the only thing we could do was open the branches in the morning and close them at night,'' she added. As a result, Mrs. Wischer said, Keating and his top advisers concluded they could never operate Lincoln successfully because of what he and some bank board officials have called a vendetta against them. American Continental later pursued three different deals for leveraged buyouts of Lincoln but all were disapproved by regulators, who concluded little real new capital was being invested in each. In addition to a bankruptcy court proceeding over American Continental, Keating is now embroiled in several lawsuits, as both a plaintiff and defendant, with the government and investors in his enterprise. Besides the suit here seeking recovery of Lincoln, he is suing the government in federal court in Phoenix on charges of illegally leaking confidential information about the thrift in 1986 and 1987. The government has named Keating, Mrs. Wischer and other American Continental officials in a civil suit seeking $1.1 billion on charges of fraud and racketeering in their operation of Lincoln. Keating also is under criminal investigation by a federal grand jury in Los Angeles, according to regulators. And he is the focal point of a congressional ethics scandal involving five senators for whom he raised $1.3 million in political contributions and who, in turn, interceded on Lincoln's behalf with federal regulators in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 37,155.89, up 48.86 points, or 0.13 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Aspen Residents Appear to Reject Ban On Fur Sales
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 19 grafs to UPDATE with voters approving highway widening, bond measure for employee housing, quotes from Katharine Thalberg, fur store manager, DELETE outdated material, EDIT to conform; picks up 18th graf, `Thalberg believes ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos ASPX100, DX3
DOC.TEXT: Residents of this tiny, trendy ski resort town on Tuesday rejected by nearly 2-1 an ordinance that would have made it the nation's first furrier-free zone. With all eight precincts counted, the fur-ban ordinance lost, 1,701 to 898. Residents also voted for growth, defeating by 1,561 to 1,051 a measure to reduce the size of a luxury hotel by 25 percent, and approving measures to widen the highway leading into town and a bond measure to build employee housing. ``People seem more concerned with business and monetary gain than other values,'' said Katharine Thalberg, who with her husband, Mayor Bill Stirling, led the fight for the fur ban. ``They want a larger hotel, a bigger highway ... there does seem to be a value shift here in town,'' she said. Revillon Furs manager Mark Kirkland said, ``The big winners are the people of Aspen. We can get back to business and welcome our guests back who've been staying away because of all this.'' The election, which drew international attention, attracted about 70 percent of Aspen's 3,700 registered voters, said City Clerk Kathryn Koch. Like ski lifts, there was a 20-minute wait at polling places, deputy city clerk Kathy Strickland said earlier. ``We had three booths at the precincts last time, and now we have four, and they still are waiting in line. ... So the turnout is going to be good,'' she said. The chief growth-and-development measure was the one on whether to stop construction of the $70 million luxury hotel and build in its place a smaller one favored by the City Council, Other ballot measures were tied to the dilemma of growth in the celebrity haven _ a picturesque town fat with wealthy buyers and short on building space. Voters approved a widening of Colorado 82 into Aspen from two lanes to four and a straight route into town over an ``s'' curve. The highway carries more than 22,000 cars a day, according to state figures. Several ballot proposals involved employee housing. Most shop, government and ski slope workers cannot afford to live in Aspen, where the average single home sold for more than $1 million in 1989. Voters approved 1,363 to 1,203 an ordinance to raise the city's sales tax by 0.45 of a cent, bringing the total sales tax to 7.9 percent, in order to finance affordable housing and day care. The fur fight polarized the town, with Stirling and his wife leading animal-rights activists in demanding the ban and furriers leading the charge against it, claiming it would drive away tourists. Some considered the election a dress rehearsal for a March 13 recall election for Stirling and three other members of the city council. The fur issue drew national and international attention. ``The real issue is whether it is all right to kill animals to make fur coats,'' said Katharine Thalberg, co-founder of the Aspen Society for Animal Rights. Thalberg believes fur sales amount to making profits on cruelty to animals. Opponents, led by fur retailers, framed it as a freedom of choice issue, saying the government should not tell people what to wear or not wear. The small old mining town has four fur shops, and more than 100 other businesses also sell furs. Financial disclosure statements showed the various special interest groups had spent about $250,000 _ $67 per voter. The other big attention-getter on the ballot was the proposal to reduce the size of the luxury hotel already under construction. The developer, Mohamed Hadid, purchased the land from New York billionaire developer Donald Trump. Hadid planned a 292-room, 66-foot-tall building. Stirling and his supporters on the council, spurred by complaints that the hotel would block views of Aspen Mountain's ski slopes and would just be too big for the town space and services, wanted to scale it back by 25 percent, and down to 44 feet high. Hadid's spokesmen said the council approved the project in November 1988 and should not be changing the rules while construction is under way. Trump re-entered the fray in the weeks preceding the election, reminding people he sold the land because the town would not let him build a hotel the size he wanted _ which would have been close to the Council proposal.

DOC.HEAD: US-Soviet Trade Agreement Possible by June
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Soviet trade negotiators, working under orders to wipe away nearly a half-century of trade friction between the two superpowers, say they are on schedule to get the job done by June. Both sides expressed satisfaction with the progress made after an initial two days of talks aimed at drawing up a treaty to normalize trade between the two nations. President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev would like to sign such an agreement at their next summit meeting in June. The Bush administration believes freer trade between the two nations would provide an important economic boost to the political reforms Gorbachev is making. Deputy U.S. Trade Representative Julius Katz, the top U.S. negotiator in the talks, said the next meeting has been tentatively scheduled for later this month in Europe with a third bargaining session to be held in mid-March in Vienna. ``I don't have any doubt that we can get the job done,'' he told reporters after the talks ended Tuesday. ``There was nothing that came up that presents an insuperable obstacle.'' Chief Soviet negotiator Yuriy Chumakov, saying that the opening discussions had gone ``fairly well,'' indicated that one key sticking point could be the terms under which the treaty might be suspended. The U.S. side is insisting that language be included giving the United States the right to suspend the treaty if the Soviets are found, after an annual presidential review, to be violating requirements for open emigration policies. The Soviets want to negotiate a three-year trade treaty without the threat of suspension, arguing that the assurance of trade stability is needed to attract U.S. business investment. ``Would you invest $1 billion if you knew the agreement was valid for only one year?'' Chumakov asked reporters. Annual review of Soviet emigration policies is required by the Jackson-Vanik amendment, which Congress passed in 1974 in retaliation for the Soviet government's refusal at that time to allow free emigration for Soviet Jews and other dissidents. Katz said the U.S. negotiating position on this matter cannot change unless Congress changes the law, something not likely to occur in the immediate future. Negotiation of a wide-ranging trade agreement was a primary goal established during the Bush-Gorbachev summit last December in Malta. American officials predict that two-way trade between the two countries could double or even triple over the next three years once the high tariffs imposed by Jackson-Vanik are lowered. In the first 11 months of 1989, U.S. exports to the Soviet Union, primarily grain shipments, totaled $3.82 billion, while Soviet sales in the United States, primarily of petroleum and consumer items such as vodka and furs, totaled $658 million. The trade treaty would be used to grant the Soviet Union ``most favored nation status,'' qualifying it for the lowest tariffs available to any other country. Soviet exports into the United States currently bear duties as much as 10 times higher than imports from other nations. By one estimate, the price of Soviet vodka could drop by $1.25 per bottle with the lower tariffs. American farmers also are watching the trade talks with keen interest because the Soviets have said they will not sign a new grain pact until agreement is reached on a wide-ranging trade treaty. The current negotiations likely will serve as a prototype for similar agreements to lower tariffs for other East European nations. Poland and Hungary already have received ``most favored nation status'' and the United States is considering granting similar low tariffs for Czechoslovakia, Romania, Bulgaria and East Germany. Katz said the pace of negotiations with other nations would depend on when free elections are held, with Czechoslovakia ``a good bet'' to be next in line to receive the lower tariffs.

DOC.HEAD: Fast-Developing Agreements Give Structure for Changed World
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The past week's dramatic moves by the United States, the Soviet Union and their chief allies establish a framework for the most sweeping East-West changes since World War II. The agreements open the way for the reunification of Germany, the reduction of superpower forces in Europe and the expansion of U.S.-Soviet trade. Last week in the Soviet Union, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev won approval from the Communist Party Central Committee to give up the party's monopoly on power for the first time in about 70 years. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who visited Moscow last week, made major progress with Gorbachev toward an agreement for deep cuts in the superpowers' long-range nuclear arsenals. The swiftly moving talks culminated in Ottawa on Tuesday with the announcement of a framework for German unification _ agreed upon by the United States, its major European allies, the Soviet Union and East Germany _ and a U.S.-Soviet agreement to limit their troops in central Europe. Germany, divided since the defeat of Adolf Hitler in 1945, still hosts more than a half-million foreign forces who have faced each other through the Cold War. ``This (reunification) agreement shows everybody has seen German unity will happen, and they have agreed to a process that will provide stability and peace for Europe,'' said a West German diplomat in Washington who asked not to be identified. The German reunification agreement announced in Ottawa sets up a two-step process to start after the March 18 elections in East Germany. Moscow has insisted that Germany remain neutral after reunification and the United States demands that Germany remain part of the Western alliance. Under the agreement, the two Germanys first would settle internal details, then they would work with Britain, France, the Soviet Union and United States _ the four main victorious allies in World War II _ to establish agreements assuring peace and stability for Europe. Such an approach is aimed at assuring the Soviets and other Europeans that Germany, seen as the source of the two world wars in this century, would never again threaten its neighbors. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher offered assurances of a reunited Germany's peaceful intentions, saying, ``We tell all our neighbors what we want to unite: The Federal Republic of Germany, the German Democratic Republic and the whole of Berlin _ no less, and no more. We do not have territorial claims against any of our neighbors.'' Moves by leaders of East and West Germany matched the pace of the other countries. On Tuesday, West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and East German Premier Hans Modrow agreed to begin talks next week to make the West German mark the official currency of East Germany. The U.S.-Soviet troop cuts, announced by Canadian External Affairs Minister Joseph Clark at the end of an East-West meeting in Ottawa, would allow the United States and the Soviet Union to have 195,000 soldiers each on Europe's central front. That would be a cut from 275,000 for the United States and from 565,000 for the Soviets, and the United States would be allowed to have another 30,000 troops elsewhere in Europe. U.S. and Soviet trade negotiators also said Tuesday they expect to complete a treaty to normalize trade between the two nations in time for signing during the June summit meeting in Washington. The Bush administration believes freer trade between the two nations would provide an important economic boost to Gorbachev's political reforms. During his eight-day trip Baker not only met with the Soviets and NATO allies, but also visited Czechoslovakia, Romania and Bulgaria to encourage their moves toward democracy and free-market economies. However, some East-West issues still remain, such as differences over regional conflicts in Afghanistan _ where the United States supports guerrillas fighting the Soviet-backed government _ and Central America, where the United States says the Soviets have been supporting the Nicaraguan government and guerrillas in El Salvador.
EDITORS' NOTE: Alexander Higgins, a former foreign correspondent in West Germany and Eastern Europe, covers foreign policy in Washington.
Here are the major points of the three agreements announced at the joint meeting of foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact.
DOC.HEAD: GERMANY
DOC.TEXT: _Officials of East Germany and West Germany will meet after the March 18 East German elections to discuss the legal, political and economic issues of reunification. The two Germanies agreed separately Tuesday to discuss merger of their currencies. _Outside powers may not interfere with decisions of the two Germanys in those talks. _Afterward, foreign ministers of the two Germanys and the four major victors over Nazi Germany of World War II, the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union, will meet to discuss ``external aspects of the establishment of German unity, including the issues of security of the neighboring states.'' A major ``external aspect'' is Germany's ties to NATO. West Germany is now a full participant in NATO's unified military structure. The Soviet Union has proposed a neutral Germany, objecting to a unified Germany in NATO's military structure. President Bush has said he believes a Germany in NATO would allay fears among Germany's neighbors.

The agreement represents acceptance of a proposal by President Bush in his State of the Union speech last month. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev countered with an offer of equal levels for U.S. and Soviet troops Europe-wide of 195,000 or 225,000 each, but he did not insist. _The United States and the Soviet Union agreed to a limit of 195,000 troops that each may station on foreign soil in Central Europe. Another 30,000 U.S. troops could be stationed in Europe outside the central zone. _The Soviets, with 565,000 soldiers in East Germany, Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia, will have to make the largest cut, about 370,000. _The United States has about 305,000 troops in Europe, of which about 275,000 are on the central front, and would cut about 80,000.

The idea was first proposed by President Eisenhower in 1955 and revived by President Bush last May. _The North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact each may mount an annual quota of reconnaissance flights over countries in the other alliance. The quotas for each country still must be agreed upon. _Aircraft must be unarmed and use equipment to be decided upon jointly. _Other countries, notably the European neutrals, will be invited to participate. _Details are to be settled in time for a May 12 signing ceremony in Budapest. The chief unsettled detail is a Soviet proposal for joint use of aircraft.

DOC.HEAD: Winds Send More Goo Onto California's Oil-Stained Beaches
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `Gov. George ...,' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with state officials finding no need for state of emergency; picks up 11th graf, `Waves of ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LA6
DOC.TEXT: Blustery winds pushed more goo onto California beaches Tuesday as reinforcements joined the battle to sop up the oily onslaught a week after a tanker spill fouled the coast. The cleanup crew was tripled to 1,120 workers on six miles of oil-stained beach and another 300 workers were being trained to handle the crude oil invasion. Fifteen miles of beach in Southern California remained closed. Meanwhile, the 811-foot tanker American Trader docked for repairs. A Newport Beach man filed one of the first lawsuits in connection with the spill. The class-action lawsuit, filed by Chet Holifield in federal court in Los Angeles, seeks damages and money for economic losses. Among the defendants are the ship's owner and the company that chartered the tanker. Winds combined with increasing surf to push new bands of thick crude ashore, threatening wildlife sanctuaries. The 400,000-gallon spill has killed 86 birds and coated 261 others with oil. The National Weather Service said onshore winds to 40 mph could develop by Thursday. Up to 1,000 grunion have also been killed by the spill, state Department of Fish and Game spokesman Pat Moore said. The tiny fish died during a weekend ``run'' along the Orange County coastline, Moore said. Grunion come to the edge of the shore during such runs to lay eggs in the soft sand. Any eggs left behind in the oil-soaked sand were not expected to hatch, he said. Huntington Beach Mayor Tom Mays had asked Gov. George Deukmejian to declare a state of emergency. But Eileen Baumgardner, assistant director of the Office of Emergency Services, said the declaration was not immediately necessary because the cleanup was being handled by private industry. ``As far as we can tell, there are no needs that are not being met,'' she said late Monday. Huntington Beach is about 35 miles southeast of Los Angeles. Waves of grimy crude oil spilled by the American Trader rolled onto Bolsa Chica State Beach, leaving the beach coated with a layer of crude 2 inches thick in some areas. ``I'm disgusted,'' surfer Bill Casper said while watching the black tide roll in at his favorite surf spot near Huntington Beach Pier. ``It's going to affect the beach for years. There will be tar on the beach for years.'' On a bike path further north near Bolsa Chica, Lee Buratti, 40, of Dana Point was taking a break in training for the wheelchair race in next month's Los Angeles Marathon. He complained of the petroleum stench. ``The fumes were much too much. I could feel it in my lungs. It actually hurt a little and it slowed my pace,'' said Buratti. But Buratti said spills were the price of the Los Angeles lifestyle. ``Let's face it, our life revolves around oil. We have to have it.'' The oily pads, absorbent pompons and truck loads of gooey sand were taken to a seven-acre site near the Newport Beach sewage treatment plant, said Tony Kozlowski of British Petroleum America Inc., which owns the Alaksa North Slope oil and chartered the ship. He said the muck can be picked up easier once it's on the beach. ``When it gets on shore we can deal with it and clean it up. When it's out there it's just a waiting game,'' Kozlowski said. ``It's awful,'' said Robert August, who starred in the surfing movie ``Endless Summer'' and now owns a surf shop in Huntington Beach. ``It's pretty lousy for business. All that's there now are reporters and politicians.'' Businessman Ross Roberts, 48, visiting from Yakima, Wash., for a boat show, speculated that tourism would likely take a beating just as it did after the Mount St. Helens eruption in his state a decade ago. ``It's not going to be good for the area, all this advertising about oily beaches,'' Roberts said. ``There was the same effect in Washington after Mount St. Helens because of all the ash that came down. The patched-up American Trader moved from a Long Beach Harbor anchorage and tied up at an Arco dock on Tuesday morning to unload its remaining cargo of crude oil and to begin repairs of hull punctures. The oil leaked from the vessel on Feb. 7 when the ship apparently ran over its own anchor while mooring in shallow water at an oil pipeline mooring two miles offshore. The slick meandered away from the beaches for five days with the help of offshore winds and calm seas. Containment booms and sand berms kept the oil out of marinas and the ecologically sensitive Bolsa Chica Wetlands. But potential damage to the reserve, home for the endangered California brown pelican and a stop for thousands of migratory birds and marine life, was still a concern. ``Birds are leaving the wetlands and going to the ocean and bringing the oil back to the estuary,'' said Patrick Moore of the state Department of Fish and Game. Oily residue on the birds could kill eggs.

DOC.HEAD: Support for Sihanouk Violates Law, US Activists Claim
DOC.TEXT: A scientists' peace activist group says the United States is violating the treaty against genocide and its own laws by aiding Cambodian Prince Norodom Sihanouk while he cooperates with the communist Khmer Rouge. Sihanouk has been reported to be sending money to Khmer Rouge guerrilla units in the Southeast Asian country, Jeremy J. Stone, president of the Federation of American Scientists, said Tuesday. The treaty, ratified by the Senate in 1988, obligates participating countries to undertake prevention of ethnic-based mass killing known as genocide, and punishment of those accused of genocide. Stone said that would include the Khmer Rouge, blamed for more than a million deaths during their bloody 1975-78 rule over the southeast Asian country. Also violated, he said, were provisions of the U.S. Foreign Assistance Act that since 1985 has forbidden use of American aid funds to ``directly or indirectly'' sustain or augment operations of the Khmer Rouge. President Bush's administration has declared a major objective of its Cambodian policy is to block return to power of the Khmer Rouge. But the administration has also accepted Sihanouk's alliance with the Khmer Rouge guerilla fighters, describing their presence as ``a fact of life.'' Last year's pullout of Vietnamese occupation forces intensified Cambodia's civil war and heightened world anxiety about a Khmer Rouge comeback. Khmer Rouge guerrillas and those of two noncommunist factions claim territorial gains at the expense of the Vietnam-installed Cambodian government of Premier Hun Sen. Published reports say the anti-government factions have been cooperating with each other and that Western-supplied weapons have been captured from Khmer Rouge forces. The United States and other major powers support a Cambodian peace plan based on a U.N.-supervised interim government and elections. But Stone said the Khmer Rouge would continue fighting if they lose such elections and that his organization of 4,000 members wants to end ``the killing of Cambodians now, as fast as we can.'' He called for a cutoff of arms deliveries to all Cambodian factions and for Thailand to halt the flow of Chinese weapons to the Khmer Rouge over the Thai border. Official American aid has been limited to nominal humanitarian assistance while the two non-communist factions in the anti-government alliance have been reported to be drawing more than $20 million worth of Western covert aid a year.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: After years of adapting its games for Hispanics by slipping a set of Spanish instructions into the box, Milton Bradley Co. is really going bilingual. Its board game, ``Sabado Gigante,'' based on a popular Hispanic network television show, was unveiled this week. ``This is the first time that in this industry I've seen a product that's adapted to the market rather than asking the market to adapt the product,'' said George R. Ditomassi, the company's president, in a telephone interview from New York, where the game made its debut at the 87th American International Toy Fair. The $23 game, with printing in both Spanish and English, is based on the 3{-hour cable television show of the same name, broadcast on the Univision network on Saturday nights. Milton Bradley, the 130-year-old maker of such board games as ``Chutes and Ladders,'' decided to develop a Hispanic game after research showed an estimated 20 million Hispanics in the U.S. game-buying market. In addition, Ditomassi said, studies indicate Hispanic parents tend to spend more per capita on their children than the average U.S. parent.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto JF3
DOC.TEXT: Legislators are hee-hawing about a photograph in the state's official manual identifying a furry four-legged critter as a ``typical Missouri mule.'' Nay, bray the lawmakers _ the color picture does not show the state's sleek-haired symbol of stubbornness. It shows Mindy, a 6-year-old Sicilian donkey. ``Everybody's heard of the world-famous Missouri mule, and this isn't one,'' state Sen. Mike Lybyer said Tuesday, pointing to the picture on page 31 of the guide to state government, published by the secretary of state. ``Sen. Lybyer is absolutely right. The picture on Page 31 is clearly a burro, not a mule,'' Secretary of State Roy Blunt said in a statement. ``While this is bad, it's not as bad as the year we identified a fruit fly as the honey bee,'' the official state insect. Lybyer told Blunt it would be too late and too costly to recall hundreds of thousands of copies of the hardbound manual.

The South Carolina National Guard removed part of a recruiting sign outside its armory when the message was mistaken for an advertisement for Stinger missile sales. The sign read, ``Stinger Missiles, $2,000 cash, 224-2862.'' What it meant was that the National Guard was offering a $2,000 bonus for recruits who enlist to be Stinger crewmen, Maj. Jim Culp said. ``No, we're not selling Stingers,'' Culp said. ``And if we were, we wouldn't sell them for $2,000. We could get at least $50,000 in Miami.'' Sgt. Harris Clark said Monday that the sign had been up for two weeks before anyone noticed that it was misleading.

DOC.HEAD: Agreement Gives Internat'l Acceptance to a Process Already Under Way
By KEVIN COSTELLOE
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: The Ottawa agreement on German unification provides the decisive international acceptance for a process that is already well under way inside the two neighboring countries. From business ventures to television programming and vacation travel, the two states have been coming closer together in hundreds of ways each day. ``What belongs together will grow together,'' former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt is fond of saying. And Germans in both east and west have accepted the inevitability of a rapid unification since the Berlin Wall opened Nov. 9. Serious obstacles remain in making a single nation, with its citizens carrying the same passports, paying with the same currency and serving side-by-side in the same armed forces. From an international standpoint, the most serious obstacle may be the military stance of a united Germany. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has said NATO membership for a united Germany is ``not acceptable,'' the official East German news agency ADN said. ADN stressed that discussions about unification ``will also include the questions of security of neighboring states.'' Still mindful of the horrors of the Nazi aggression, East Germany's Communists are seeking assurances that conservatives in Bonn have given up any designs on former lands that now belong to Poland. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl said his country has no intention of seeking to regain any lands that were part of prewar Germany. The Ottawa agreement sets the stage for a virtual revolution _ the first redrawing of European national boundaries since World War II. It was a step that only recently many had never expected could happen. Internally, there are still numerous questions to be answered. ``Socialism and capitalism can no more be united than fire and water,'' then-East German leader Erich Honecker said during a 1987 visit to Bonn. While much of what the now-disgraced hard-liner did and said has been ridiculed, there may be a good deal of truth in his metaphor. East German industry _ the part that is still running _ is a product of heavy-handed central planning from East Berlin. West Germans say that leads to inefficiency and slowness to change, even in such simple ways as adapting to the latest fashions. Most East Germans are also accustomed to a cradle-to-grave socialism that up until very recently has left very little to individual choice. Housing, clothing and public transportation at rock-bottom prices are almost a compensation for the hundreds of daily sacrifices East Germans have had to make. Meshing the economies will be a daunting task and will cost billions of dollars. West Germany has one of the most efficient economies in the world, but East Germany's economy has been going downhill since the 1960s. West Germany has strict factory safety measures and a vocal Greens Party to help enforce environment regulations. Much of coal-dependent East Germany is an ecological nightmare, dangerously polluted. Other problems loom as well. ``These East Germans come over here and get a lot of handouts from the government,'' grouses one businesswoman in the prosperpous Frankfurt suburb of Koenigstein. ``But they never saw that much money in their life.'' Many East Germans, the elderly especially, also worry that the thousands of marks they stashed away in bank accounts will be worthless once the mighty West German mark swallows up its weak neighbor. West German leftists and union leaders warn that East Germany cannot be a source of low-wage labor. Still, the Germans on both sides seem determined to work out the problems, which in many cases will simply require some time and patience. With virtually all major groups and political parties in East Germany and West Germany in favor of unification, the main question for weeks has been when rather than whether. Every day has brought new ties. West German businesses have been gearing up to move into East Germany. West Germany's Dresdner Bank has opened an office in its founding city of Dresden, with other financial institutions following the trail to East Germany. East German TV shows have been shown on West German television. West Germany's two networks have been broadcasting election information programs into East Germany in advance of the country's first free balloting on March 18. Newspapers from each country are now sold in the other, and West German tour companies are promoting trips east. While some of these steps seem minor taken individually, they add up to a revolution for a people long separated from family and loved ones. The reuniting of the two countries' Olympic teams is considered likely and will provide a broad symbolic move for two countries proud of their athletic prowess. Germans are waiting for Berlin to become the capital of a united country. ``Now that the Berlin Wall has fallen, it's also necessary for the walls in our heads to come down,'' West Berlin planning chief Michaela Schreyer said Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Senator Criticizes ``Pension Raiding'' By Corporations
DOC.TEXT: Congress must provide greater safeguards to retirees because of ``pension raiding'' by corporations that terminate employee retirement funds to take control of surplus assets, says the chairman of a Senate committee. Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, said Tuesday that Congress needs to approve legislation imposing stricter standards on pension terminations, especially because the retirement plans often are replaced with annuities purchased from insurance companies heavily invested in high-risk ``junk'' bonds. ``Pension raids leave workers and retirees with frozen pension checks while their employers laugh their way to the bank with millions of dollars,'' said Metzenbaum. Annuities are contracts that pay fixed monthly benefits to retirees. Surplus pension assets have become a popular target for corporate raiders who acquire a company and use its overfunded retirement programs as a source of cash. Metzenbaum said ``sound pension plans are wrung dry of their cash and replaced with annuities offering fixed benefits and no chance of cost-of-living adjustments.'' Most pension plans are federally insured by the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp., but the subcommittee was told there is no similar federal backing of retirement annuities of insurance companies. A few states have special funds to guard against insurance company defaults. However, Metzenbaum complained the insurance industry was poorly regulated and said that increased the risk for retirees in pension terminations.
DOC.HEAD: Hispanics Left Out Of Job Training Program
DOC.TEXT: Federal job training programs fail to serve enough Hispanics because of income and documentation barriers, says a government report. The National Commission for Employment Policy, an independent agency that reports to Congress and the presidnt, said Tuesday the federal Job Training Partnership Act needs to be amended so more Hispanics will participate. The report, based on a 12-month study, called on Congress to ease income requirements. It also asked the Labor Department to urge states to loosen documentation requirements needed to get into job training programs. While Hispanics account for between 13 percent and 14 percent of those eligible for job training programs, they make up only between 10 percent and 11 percent of those who take part, the report said. The commission blamed part of the discrepancy on federal requirements that mandate candidates for the program be receiving food stamps. Many Hispanics refuse to accept public assistance and therefore miss out on job training opportunities, the report said. ``Because of their cultural heritage of self-sufficiency and attendant distaste for government assistance programs, many Hispanics would rather forego JTPA training than accept food stamp assistance just to qualify for the program,'' the agency said. The report recommended that Congress change the law so that candidates merely be ``eligible'' for food stamps rather than actually accepting the assistance.
DOC.HEAD: All But One Vehicle Test Show Possible Injuries
DOC.TEXT: Six of the seven 1990-model autos tested so far appear unlikely to protect drivers from head injuries in a 35-mile-per-hour crash, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said Tuesday. Only the Acura Integra four-door sedan appears able to protect from driver head injuries, the agency said. The Toyota 4-Runner four-door truck ranked worst among models tested. Besides the Acura and Toyota models, tests have been conducted on the Chevrolet Lumina, the Mazda Miata, the Nissan Stanza, the Lexus ES250 and the Mitsubishi Eclipse. Some carmakers have criticized the government's testing, which uses instrument-equipped dummies. The manufacturers contend the tests to not accurately reflect highway crash conditions. The safety agency continues testing throughout the year until all models are covered. Each car is given a head-injury rating. Scores below 750 indicate that head injury is unlikely, between 750 and 1,250 that it is possible and above 1,250 that it is likely. Here are the models tested so far and their head injury scores: Toyota 4-Runner four-door, 1,306; Chevrolet Lumina four-door, 1,200; Nissan Stanza four-door, 1,105; Lexus ES250 four-door, 992; Mazda Miata two-door convertible, 920; Mitsubishi Eclipse two-door hatchback, 772; Acura Integra four-door, 585.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Drops, Stocks Up Slightly
DOC.TEXT: The dollar moved lower against the Japanese yen in Tokyo Wednesday, while the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rose slightly. The dollar closed at 144.35 yen, down 0.13 yen from Tuesday's 144.48-yen finish. It opened at 144.30 yen and ranged between 144.20 yen and 144.40 yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average gained 48.86 points, or 0.13 percent, ending the day at 37,155.89. It shed 181.11 points on Tuesday. ``Nothing was happening except for a bit of buying by the investment trust companies and some selling by Morgan Stanley,'' said Satoru Nagayoshi, a dealer with New Japan Securities Co. He said trading was mixed and directionless as most market players stayed on the sidelines ahead of Japan's parliamentary election scheduled for Sunday. ``Trading is extremely thin, and it will be like this for the rest of the week, because of the election on Sunday,'' Nagayoshi added. In foreign exchange dealings, the dollar-yen rate moved little in Tokyo after the U.S. currency opened lower, following a similar drop overseas. Drexel Burnham Lambert announced Wednesday its parent company has filed protection from creditors under federal bankruptcy laws, because of financial problems stemming from its dealings in risky high-interest ``junk bonds'' and a scandal involving its former executive, Michael Milken. Dealers said they expected the filing would depress U.S. stock prices and discourage Japanese investment in the United States. The dollar also weakened in Tokyo against European currencies, including the West German mark, traders said.

DOC.HEAD: Toys Clear Red Tape, Finally Take Off For Panama
DOC.TEXT: While many people are celebrating Valentine's Day, some Panamanian children are opening Christmas presents delayed almost two months by U.S. government red tape. Patricia Gehri, 45, has been working since just after the Dec. 20 invasion of Panama to gather toys for children she said never had a Christmas. But until Tuesday, she could not get them delivered. Then, Tuesday afternoon, a U.S. Marine plane took off from MacDill Air Force Base with the toys. ``It could have been worse,'' she said. ``It could have been Easter bunnies.'' Gehri amassed between 8,000 and 10,000 toys along with the Marines through their Toys for Tots program. The teddy bears, games, tea sets and dolls had been gathering dust in Marine warehouses in Tampa, Orlando, Miami and Gehri's garage. ``I wish we could paint a big red nose on that airplane,'' Gehri said, just like Rudolph the red-nose reindeer. The Marines picked up all the toys Gehri had stored, along with those in Miami and took them to MacDill where they were loaded on a C-130 cargo plane from Illinois. The toy delivery was initially delayed because the Marines had difficulty getting permission to land a plane in war-torn Panama. But the State Department approved the mission last week, and the government of Panama approved it Friday. Gehri said she obtained permission by using the ``Denton Amendment'' which allows airlifting items for humanitarian efforts. She had a little trouble convincing government officials that teddy bears were humanitarian. ``They didn't take it seriously because it's toys and not food or medicine,'' she said. ``But a teddy bear is medicine to me.'' Once the toys arrive in Panama, officials will work with the Marines to distribute the items to children in refugee camps, hospitals and orphanages, she said. ``An ex-Marine gave me a big, giant raccoon today that will go to special little girl in the hospital from me,'' she said. ``She lost her arm when the PDF (Panamanian Defense Forces) opened fire during the invasion.'' Gehri, a former flight attendant, was disabled in 1988 from a head injury so severe it impaired her speech. After recovering most functions, her therapist suggested she take on a project to help her feel good about herself. When she decided to send toys to Panama, she had no idea it would become such an involved effort, but she has nothing but praise for the Marines and the Panamanian government. ``Considering everything that has happened, it's a miracle,'' Gehri said. ``I would never have had so many toys if they had gone off on time.''

DOC.HEAD: Cocaine Use By Men May Diminish Fertility, Study Suggests
DOC.TEXT: Cocaine use may lower sperm counts and create other abnormalities that diminish male fertility, a new study suggests, but the effect apparently begins to disappear after drug use stops. The study focused on men from couples who were consulting an infertility clinic at Yale University. It appears in this month's issue of Fertility and Sterility, the official journal of The American Fertility Society. A specialist in male infertility cautioned Tuesday that the study does not show that cocaine use caused infertility in the men. ``This is provocative but by no means evidence of cause and effect,'' said Richard Sherins of the Genetics and IVF Institute of Fairfax, Va. Researchers studied 40 men with low sperm counts, 77 who had sperm with low motility, which essentially means too few sperm were swimming correctly, and 75 who had high concentrations of abnormally shaped sperm. Each of these problems can contribute to infertility. Cocaine use by these men was compared to that of 284 other male partners of couples who consulted the Yale clinic but did not have these problems. Researchers found that men who had low sperm counts were twice as likely as men in the comparison group to have used cocaine within the previous two years. They were five times as likely to have used it once a month or more and within the previous two years, or to have used it once a month or more and for two to four years. Men with the motility problem were twice as likely as the comparison group to have used cocaine for five or more years. Men with high concentrations of abnormally shaped sperm were seven times as likely to have used cocaine for five years or more and two years or longer ago, and four times as likely to have used it once a month or more and for two to four years. Male infertility plays some role in almost two-thirds of couples who have trouble conceiving, the researchers said. Given that research shows cocaine use to be quite prevalent among men ages 26 to 34, and given the drug's apparent effect in the new study, ``I think one can conclude that it may be a significant risk factor for infertility,'' said study co-author Michael Bracken, professor of epidemiology, obstetrics and gynecology at Yale University. But Sherins said the statistical association between cocaine and infertility in the study was weak. The research ``whets your appetite for doing the study right,'' he said. The proper approach would include medical diagnosis of what was causing infertility in the couple, he said, or a demonstration of how sperm quality changes as a person starts or stops taking cocaine. The researchers did not explore how cocaine could affect fertility. They suggested it may affect early sperm development by disrupting hormonal patterns, or harm testicular functioning by reducing blood flow.

DOC.HEAD: Security Tight For Drug Summit
With PM-Colombia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Cartagena normally is a lazy beach town with crowded beaches and a lively night life, but this week the Caribbean coastal town looks like a city after a military coup. Military vessels ply Cartagena Bay and marines patrol streets and set up checkpoints for searching cars and passengers. The tight security is for President Bush and the presidents of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia, who meet in Cartagena on Thursday for a summit on strategies for ending the lucrative and lethal trade in cocaine. They are to gather at a 17th-century Spanish fort, part of the Colombian Naval Academy's base, that lies on the tip of a half-mile finger of land jutting out into Cartagena Bay. Helicopter gunships manned by Americans and Colombians are patrolling the bay and surrounding area, a Colombian frigate is anchored a few hundred yards from the fort and high-speed patrol boats stop and search other vessels. Further offshore, two U.S. ships were on patrol: the USS Nassau, an 820-foot amphibious assault ship that carries helicopters and an 1,700-man Marine landing team, and the USS Sampson, a 437-foot destroyer. Most hotels are requiring that guests not only show their passports or other official identification, but that they leave their fingerprints on file in the event there is a bombing or other violence. While Cartagena has not been a major battlefield in the war between Colombia's government and the nation's cocaine barons, it has been the site of enough attacks to seriously harm Cartagena's tourism. Only a few local people are at the beaches, which usually are jammed with thousands of people from Canada, the United States and Europe at this time of the year. The foreigners have not been coming to the city since a bomb exploded at the Cartagena Hilton on Oct. 26, killing two people in their room. Another bomb exploded harmlessly in the tourist district a short time later, and a third device was found at another hotel. Eight years ago, two U.S. drug agents were abducted from the Cartagena Hilton by two gunmen posing as room service employes. The agents were taken into the countryside, shot several times and left for dead. But one crawled to a hospital several blocks away for help and both survived. On Dec. 15, national police tracked the country's second-biggest trafficker, Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, to a banana plantation just 75 miles south of Cartagena. He was killed by a burst of gunfire from a helicopter gunship as he heaved hand grenades and fired an assault rifle. U.S. Ambassador Thomas McNamara complained Tuesday that American reporters are creating an atmosphere of tension by emphasizing security measures for the summit. He said Colombians resent such reports and brushed aside reporters' suggestions that it is the White House that is creating the drama and aura of danger for Bush's visit. According to one report from the United States, the U.S. Secret Service had found that drug traffickers have shoulder-fired, surface-to-air missiles, and it was feared they might be used to disrupt the summit. Also, it has been reported for several weeks that Bush's aides opposed the president coming to Colombia because of the danger. Since the Colombian government declared war on traffickers Aug. 18, there have been 262 terrorist acts blamed on drug bosses, Mostly bombings, they ahve claimed 209 lives. While there appeared to be a great show of military force in Cartagena, security measures appeared to be lax at the gate to the navy base where Bush will meet with the Latin American leaders. An Associated Press photographer watching the gate to the base saw 20 cars, many carrying civilians, go in during a half-hour period. Only two of the vehicles were searched.

DOC.HEAD: Friends Mourn Victim of Bowling Alley Massacre
LaserPhoto AQ1
DOC.TEXT: A 13-year-old girl was buried with her teddy bear and library cards, a memento of her tardy book-borrowing habits and a spare touch of humor to lighten grim memories of the massacre that claimed her life. Classmates and friends of Amy Houser huddled and cried Tuesday in a windy gravesite ceremony attended by more than 800 people. The girl was among four people who were herded together and shot to death during a robbery Saturday at a bowling alley. The other victims _ Steve Teran, 26, his stepdaughter, Paula Holguin, 6, and daughter, Valerie Teran, 2 _ were to be buried today in nearby Silver City. Three others were wounded and remained hospitalized, two in serious and one in good condition, hospital spokeswoman Terri Read said. ``Shock, outrage, disgust, anger, pain are but a few of the words that describe the emotions that all of us here, indeed the entire city of Las Cruces, are experiencing,'' the Rev. Tom Beggane said during Tuesday's funeral at Immaculate Heart of Mary Cathedral. But Beggane told the mourners, ``Allow your love and your memory of your friend Amy to help you to plant the seed of justice, the seed of love.'' The girl, a part-time employee at Las Cruces Bowl, and six other people were ordered at gunpoint into the bowling alley office, forced to lie on the floor and shot in the back of the head. Police are looking for two gunmen who fled with $5,000. ``I have seen this week much pain in the people I love. So much pain that I could hate, but I will not,'' said Ben Saenz, Amy's uncle. Family members placed stuffed toys, Amy's favorite perfume, a soccer trophy, library cards and poems written by friends on her linen-draped casket. Amy won the trophy in 1982 when she was the only girl on the church soccer team. The library cards were a humorous reminder that Amy always returned her library books late, Saenz said. ``A piece of our heart has been broken and shattered into millions of pieces,'' said Saenz, reading a poem written by one of Amy's cousins. As the motorcade passed from the cathedral to the cemetery, a man standing on a corner removed his hat.

DOC.HEAD: Three Arrested in School Bus Hostage Incident
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with 14 hostages, sted 11, age of hostage-takers, police quotes, additional details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Three teen-agers took 14 hostages on a school bus Tuesday and were arrested after releasing all but one of their captives and leading authorities on a brief chase. The hostages _ 13 secondary school students and the driver _ were released unharmed although one girl was later taken to a hospital for treatment of shock, said Royal Canadian Mounted Police. The three Prince George youths who seized the bus were armed with two sawed-off rifles, a .303-caliber and a .22-caliber semiautomatic, said Inspector Merv Harrower. The youths, two 18-year-olds and a 14-year-old, were due to appear Wednesday in provincial court. Their names were not released. ``We've got a rather large choice,'' Harrower told a news conference after declining to say exactly what charges would be filed. There was no indication drugs or alcohol was involved in the hijacking, which began about 4:30 p.m., police said. The youths commandeered the bus as it was taking students home from Prince George Secondary School. They boarded before other students, telling bus driver Syl Meise, 55, they had something to give to one of the students, said Staff Sgt. Elles Peleskey. After some students left the bus south of Prince George, the three produced their weapons and ordered the driver to drive back to the city to a car dealership, Peleskey said. After the bus was seized, police sharpshooters were sent to the scene, but no shots were fired by either police or the gunmen. Downtown traffic was cordoned off. About 2{ hours after the incident began, police supplied the three with a getaway car and allowed them to take one of the male students with them. The three drove north out of Prince George, about 300 miles north of Vancouver, then turned off the main highway onto a side road in an attempt to elude police cars, Harrower said. The car went out of control on the slippery side road and veered into a snowbank. By the time the youths got the car out of the snow, police had surrounded it and the three surrendered, Harrower said. Harrower said the three told police they had intended to head for Dawson Creek near the British Columbia-Alberta line _ a 250-mile drive.

DOC.HEAD: Short & Sweet
DOC.TEXT: During World War I, young lovers exchanged small candy hearts emblazoned with ``Skidoo'' and ``Oh You Kid'' on Valentine's Day. Now, conversation hearts announce ``Luv ya'' and ``Let's Rock.'' It's Valentine's Day year-round at the New England Confectionery Company, or Necco, which originated ``conversation hearts'' at the turn of the century. Production ceased in 1920. Necco revived the small, brightly-colored candies six years ago when company officials decided they had become popular again. ``People are crazy for them,'' said Anthony Staropoli, 62, of East Boston, ``When they hear I work here, I have to give bags to everyone.'' Though managers say the average employee tires of eating candy after two or three weeks on the job, Necco veteran Staropoli gave a different story. ``I've been eating candy in this place for 43 years,'' he said.

Oklahoma City's Post Office has come up with a sweet way to say ``I love you'' this Valentine's Day: chocolate bars embossed with a dove insignia that's on the current love stamp. After an initial order of 1,500, the post office has sold hundreds of the bars in the past month, said spokesman Larry Flener. By early Tuesday, about 60 were left and those were expected to be gone by the end of the day. ``We started with a limited supply as a test to see if it was successful,'' said Flener. ``They've been selling absolutely as fast as we can get them.'' The bar has been an easy way to let the mailman take care of Valentine's Day obligations, he said. The package deal includes the chocolate, a message and guaranteed overnight express delivery within the city area. The bars cost $5, and if they are sent Express Mail, the entire cost is $12, Flener said. The post office also has T-shirts, lapel pins and coffee mugs that say ``love,'' postal style. But if they're too expensive, there's the love stamp, on or off a valentine _ still 25 cents.

To folks at Kissimmee's post office, the postmark each envelope gets is an ordinary, everyday thing. But to lovers in Grand Prairie, Tacoma and Chicago, it says ``Kiss-a-me.'' Cupid has entered Kissimmee postal workers again this year, as they hand-stamp about 1,000 cards with the town's name. ``To us, it's plain old Kissimmee,'' postal secretary Linda Latino said of the black-ink stamp that each piece of mail gets in this town just south of Orlando. ``When other people look at it, they think it's `Kiss-a-me.'' Kissimmee doesn't advertise, or claim any connection to St. Valentine, so 1,000 cards is modest compared with some 250,000 letters and packages sent every December to its neighbor down the road, Christmas, Fla. And Loveland, Colo., will stamp a special Valentine's Day postmark and a poem on 28,000 pieces of mail. Chris Tye-Coleman of Kansas City, Mo., has sent her husband's valentine cards to Kissimmee for the postmark for several years after she learned of it in a magazine listing of cities with names that reflected love. In 1982, when the couple stayed in Kissimmee for their honeymoon, they learned that ``Kiss-a-me'' is really pronounced kih-sim'-mee. ``I don't care,'' Mrs. Tye-Coleman said Monday over the telephone. ``I'll just keep doing it.''

Forget the candy and flowers. The Knoxville Zoo is offering a different Valentine's Day present for that special someone today _ a red-ribboned cockroach. For $10 dollars, the zoo is offering patrons Valentine's Day adoption papers for a pair of cockroaches aptly named Romeo and Juliet in a benefit for the hands that feed more than 800 zoo animals, including its cockroaches. The zoo has 70 giant, hissing, Madagascar cockroaches that are best left in the zoo's reptile exhibit. ``They tend to be much larger and much more disgusting'' than your average, run-of-the-mill cockroach, said zoo spokeswoman Julie Wood. ``They are definitely not anything you would want to find in your home, by any means.'' Barbara McDaniels placed orders for her three nephews and her brother-in-law, although she's never seen the zoo's roaches. ``That's close enough for me with cockroaches,'' she said Tuesday. Alicia Miller, 23, placed another order, reportedly for a boyfriend. ``I just thought it sounded kind of off-the-wall. It sounded like a good gift,'' she said. The idea was borrowed from Chicago's Brookfield Zoo. The adoption papers include a card, a T-shirt iron-on, a car window sticker saying ``zoo parent,'' and a 3-inch long, black plastic bug with a red bow around its neck.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Cartel Says It Will Surrender Biggest Cocaine Labs For Peace
DOC.TEXT: On the eve of a U.S.-Latin American drug summit, the powerful Medellin cocaine cartel declared that it would surrender its three largest cocaine-processing laboratories to authorities. Earlier Tuesday, leftist guerrillas kidnapped two Americans to protest President Bush's planned visit this week to the coastal resort city of Cartagena and said they would put their captives on trial, police said. One was later released. Anti-Bush demonstrators took to the streets in Cartagena, where about 1,000 union members marched, and in Bogota, where police fired tear gas at about 100 rock-throwing students. No injuries were reported. The drug traffickers said they would turn over three labs that have produced 21 tons of cocaine monthly as a ``contribution to our decision to fight for peace and strenghtening of democracy in Colombia.'' They said they would also surrender 15,000 55-gallon drums of ether, acetone and other chemicals used to refine cocaine. The offer, in a written statement Tuesday night in the cocaine trafficking center of Medellin, appeared to be another effort to force the government to end its war on drugs and stop extraditing traffickers to the United States. The communique was signed by ``The Extraditables,'' as the members of the Medellin cartel call themselves, and distributed to radio stations and newspapers. It did not give a location for the chemicals or the three laboratories. A report by the Caracol radio network said the traffickers had given the locations to a group of journalists in Medellin. The report from Medellin provided no additional details, and it could not be immediately confirmed. The communique made no reference to Bush's visit. Extradition reportedly is high on the agenda of the summit. Bush is scheduled to arrive in Cartagena on Thursday. Security is tight; there have been reports the Medellin cartel might try to assassinate him. Presidents Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia and Alan Garcia of Peru are to arrive in Cartagena later today and briefly meet with President Virgilio Barco. The two Americans abducted Tuesday were identified as David Kent, a 40-year-old teacher from Indianapolis, and James Archer Donnelly, a 65-year-old businessman from Detroit. Donnelly was kidnapped with his Colombian wife and the two were released unhurt about three hours later in Medellin, said Lt. Eusabio Guerrero, a police spokesman from the city. An official at the school where Kent teaches, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Donnelly was told by his captors that they were leftist guerrillas and had taken the action to protest Bush's visit. The kidnappings were certain to fuel concerns, already high, over Bush's security. Two U.S. ships are patrolling off the Colombian coast: the USS Nassau, an 820-foot amphibious assault ship that carries helicopters and an 1,700-man Marine landing team, and the USS Sampson, a 437-foot destroyer, according to the Pentagon. Caracol said its Medellin station received a telephone call from a man who said he was a spokesman for leftist guerrillas and claimed responsibility for the abductions. The caller said the men would be put on trial and would be released in five days, Caracol said. He did not explain why there would be a trial or why the men would be released. A police spokesman said the kidnappers were from the National Liberation Army, a leftist guerrilla group. There was no way to confirm the claim; drug traffickers have in the past posed as leftist insurgents. The traffickers' move for peace is only the latest in a series since the government declared all-out war on the country's cocaine barons in August. The drug bosses have been blamed for 262 terrorist acts since that have clamed 209 lives. Most have been bombings. The bombings include the downing of a Colombian airliner in which 107 people were killed. Fourteen suspected traffickers have been extradited to the United States in the last five months. In December, an army unit killed Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, considered number two of the cartel. Barco has said repeatedly he will never negotiate with the drug lords.

DOC.HEAD: Hurdles Facing German Union
DOC.TEXT: Before the two Germanys can merge as one nation, they must overcome divisions that have grown out of radically different political and social systems and four decades of bitter rivalry. Here are some of the main issues the sides must resolve: _ Security. The United States has insisted that a reunited Germany remain in NATO. The Soviet Union has called for a neutral Germany. There is no decision yet whether a reunited Germany would even have armed forces. At present, the Soviet Union has 380,000 troops in East Germany under the Warsaw Pact military alliance. The United States, France, Belgium, Britain and Canada have more than 300,000 soldiers in West Germany under the NATO alliance. U.S. and Soviet forces in Europe will be reduced under an agreement announced Tuesday. But the two German states also have formidible forces of their own: nearly 400,000 troops in the West German Bundeswehr and about 200,000 in the East German armed forces. _ Borders. In the aftermath of World War II, Germany lost considerable territory to Poland and the Soviet Union. These countries have insisted that the territorial changes have been formalized. But there is considerable sentiment in both Germanys to recover these lands at the bargaining table. _ Economy. West Germany, with a population of 61 million, is the largest country in the European Economic Community and the most powerful manufacturing nations in the trading group. East Germany, with more than 16 million residents, is a crucially important member of the Moscow-led Comecon trading group. But its economy, once a model of central planning, has been devastated in recent months by the exodus of tens of thousands of skilled workers to the West. It has also polluted the environment. Under reunification, West Germany would probably bear the brunt of financial responsibility for East Germany. So far, however, the East German has rejected the West German proposal for a swift monetary union _ with the West German mark becoming the currency in the east. Instead, East Germany has appealed for $9 billion in bailout loans. Yet it has been unwilling to release basic economic data demanded by West Germany as a condition for emergency aid. _ Government. West Germany is a parliamentary democracy with a stable and vibrant political system. Chancellor Helmut Kohl, a Christian Democrat, faces a challenge from the left-leaning Social Democrats in national elections Dec. 8. East Germany has been ruled by the Communist Party since its formation in 1948 out of the Soviet occupation zone, but its political system is now in great flux. The party's power has badly eroded since the Berlin Wall was opened in November. Communist Premier Hans Modrow faces the country's first free elections on March 18, and the Communists are expected to be defeated. The new Social Democratic Party of East Germany is likely to emerge as the largest party, but nearly a dozen other groups could win seats in parliament. _ Culture and outlook. East Germany's tightly controlled Communist system and West Germany's freewheeling capitalism have produced different character traits in many citizens. East Germans have come to expect zero unemployment from their socialist system. If the two countries are unified, there may be disillusionment in store for citizens on both sides.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Stocks Slightly Higher in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The dollar inched down against the yen today, while the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index gained slightly despite some selling in connection with the bankruptcy filing of the parent of a major U.S. securities firm. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average gained 48.86 points, or 0.13 percent, closing at 37,155.89. It fell 181.11 points Tuesday. Dealers attributed the small size of the index's rebound to the bankruptcy filing of the parent company of Drexel Burnham Lambert. Investors sold issues related to finance and investment companies that might hold risky, high-interest junk bonds, they said. Drexel Burnham Lambert announced Wednesday that its parent company has filed for protection from creditors under federal bankruptcy laws because of financial problems stemming from its dealings in junk bonds and a scandal involving a former executive, Michael Milken. Masahiro Umemori, an analyst with Nomura Securities Co., said the news raised uncertainties among Japanese investors, although ``the negative impact will affect investors more seriously in the longer term rather than right now.'' Trading was ``extremely thin'' as most investors stepped to the sidelines to await Sunday's parliamentary elections, said Satoru Nagayoshi, a dealer with New Japan Securities Co. An estimated 350 million shares changed hands on the first section, up from Tuesday's 300 million. In currency dealings, the dollar closed at 144.35 yen, down 0.13 yen from Tuesday's 144.48-yen finish. It opened at 144.30 yen and ranged between 144.20 yen and 144.40 yen. The dollar now has fallen 1.15 yen in three trading days. Traders attributed the dollar's decline Wednesday to its overnight drop on overseas markets in the wake of the Drexel news. ``The dollar weakened mainly in the early session as market players sold it against the yen and the (West German) mark, following the other markets overseas,'' said Masato Hayashi, a Bank of Tokyo trader. But investors bought the U.S. currency whenever it fell close to the 144-yen level, he added. The yen also failed to strengthen because market players expected a sharp decline in the nation's trade surplus in January, he said. ``Some even had predicted the trade figure would be in the red,'' Hayashi added. After the market closed, the Finance Ministry announced that Japan posted a trade surplus of $342.4 million in January, down sharply from $3.25 billion a year earlier. January marked the ninth consecutive month of year-to-year decline in the country's merchandise trade surplus.

DOC.HEAD: Senior Citizens Perturbed by Hellions on Supermarket Wheels
DOC.TEXT: Some denizens of this citadel for senior citizens fear their tranquil marketing is about to be marred by armadas of miniature shopping carts, pushed along by sugar-crazed 3-year-olds. Mothers say the carts are ``really great'' at keeping kids out of their hair, and children call them fun. A straight-faced spokesman for Publix Supermarkets has proclaimed the carts ``educational tools'' for ``shopping techniques.'' But some older people think the kiddy carts are hell on wheels. ``This is a grocery store, not a playground,'' said 68-year-old Sylvie Aronowitz. ``I don't want them under my feet.''
