Publix introduced the tiny shopping carts in the fall, but the company looked at demographics before deciding which of its 370 Florida stores would be equipped with them, said company spokesman Bill Shroeder. ``The stores we have identified as having a majority of retirees will not get any carts,'' Schroeder said. For many of Miami Beach's senior citizens, shopping is a daily ritual that allows them to visit with neighbors while picking up a few items they can easily carry home. Carol Green, 70, said she wouldn't mind the little carts _ which haven't been introduced to her neighborhood store _ except that the market is usually filled with older shoppers and the children would probably ``get lost in the shuffle.'' But in larger, suburban Publix stores, a small child pushing the tiny replica of a regular grocery cart and tagging after an adult has become a common sight. ``I think they're really great,'' said Lourdes Dergan, while her 4-year-old son, Joseph, pushed his mini-cart up and down the cereal aisle in a store in a western section of Miami. ``It helps keep him quiet while I shop.'' Joseph placed a box of Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles cereal on top of the cookies, chocolate pudding and fruit already selected for his little cart. Mother approved. ``He does all his own shopping,'' Dergan said. ``I think it really teaches him to make decisions.'' When asked if he liked having his own cart, Joseph said ``Yea, it's fun.'' But Barbara Palladino, a 43-year-old mother of five, has written two letters complaining about the carts and says she won't shop at Publix stores. ``I saw a mother with two children, each with a little cart, blocking the entire aisle and it took three minutes for her to get out of there,'' Palladino said. ``It's impossible for a mother to control a situation like that. ... ``If they really wanted to help out mothers, they should put little playgrounds in their store.'' But Schroeder said there are usually only about 10 kiddy carts in each of the stores, not enough to cause kiddy gridlock. More than half the company's stores have the carts. They have become so popular that a little girl threw a tantrum after she discovered all the carts were in use at one store. Thieves make off with many of the carts, said Israel Reyes, the dairy manager at a store in suburban Kendall. Publix is not the first supermarket chain to offer the kiddy carts. They are in use at stores in Houston and other U.S. cities. Schroeder insists the carts are educational objects, not toys. ``The carts are teaching them to imitate their mother in shopping techniques,'' Schroeder said. ``A number of mothers have called to thank us for this.'' ``We haven't observed any shopping with carefree abandon by children,'' he said. ``The parents control what the child selects and that's why the mothers perceive them as an educational tool.'' Some senior citizens approve of the idea of child shoppers. ``We don't mind them at all,'' said May Jones, 67, who was shopping with her husband, Mack Jones. ``I think they are fun tools that can teach.'' Mrs. Jones, who has seven grandchildren, said kids will probably grab candy and cookies off the shelves and throw them in their personal cart. ``Sure they'll try to get bad stuff,'' she said. ``That's when you teach.''

DOC.HEAD: Germany Became United Under Bismarck, Split After Hitler's Fall
DOC.TEXT: The Germany that was split into two after the May 1945 downfall of Adolf Hitler's Third Reich had been a unified nation for less than 75 years. It was a loose confederation of principalities in the 17th century, but under Frederick II (1740-86), Prussia began emerging as a European power. Prussia and Bavaria were expanded and many states were eliminated by the Congress of Vienna following Napoleon's defeat. Otto von Bismarck, a Prussian, was bent on fashioning a ``little Germany,'' one free from domination by the Austro-Hungarian Empire. After victories in the Austro-Prussian war of 1866 and the Franco-Prussian war of 1870-71, William I was proclaimed the German emperor and Germany became the chief European power. Europe's old order came crashing down in World War I, and Germany, the loser, became the weak Weimar Republic in the turbulent years that followed the Allied victory in November 1918. Hitler rose to power in 1933 and began his quest for world domination that led to the 1939-45 cataclysm of World War II. Nazi Germany surrendered unconditionally to the Allied forces in May 1945. Germany was divided into zones occupied by the four Allied powers. The region that is now East Germany came under Soviet control. Here is a look at major events that followed: 1946 _ The Communist Party becomes the ruling political force in East Germany. 1949 _ The Allied powers form the Federal Republic of Germany, or West Germany. The German Democratic Republic, or East Germany, is officially founded as an independent state in the Soviet zone of occupation. 1953 _ East Germany puts down a workers' uprising with the help of Soviet tanks. 1961 _ Faced with an exodus of highly skilled East German workers to the West, East Germany erects the Berlin Wall. Dissatisfaction in East Germany persists in following years, while West Germany becomes an economic powerhouse. August-September 1989 _ Tens of thousands of East Germans seeking passage to West Germany pour into West German embassies in Hungary, Poland and Czechoslovakia. Thousands slip into Austria through Hungary. October _ Huge protests coincide with official commemorations of the 40th anniversary of Communist rule in East Germany, and on Oct. 18 Egon Krenz replaces hard-line party chief Erich Honecker. November _ The Berlin Wall opens. December _ East German Prime Minister Hans Modrow urges closer ties with West Germany and allows visa-free travel between the Germanys. January _ Modrow meets Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Moscow and says Gorbachev is now more open to unification. Feb. 1 _ Modrow urges talks with West Germany toward an eventual ``united fatherland'' independent of military blocs and governed by a joint parliament in Berlin. Feb. 2 _ West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher says he's seeking support from the four World War II Allies _ the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France _ for German unification. Kohl meets Modrow the following day. Tuesday _ The Allies and the two Germanys agree on a process aimed at German reunification. After the two Germanys confer on settling legal, political and economic issues all six foreign ministers will meet to discuss security issues.

DOC.HEAD: Valentine's Day: Bachelors on the Auction Block at YWCA
LaserPhoto NY6
DOC.TEXT: If the traditional Valentine's Day cards, flowers and candy fail to satisfy, follow the example of the women who brought their checkbooks and sought their holiday sweeties direct from the auction block. The women, with their hearts in their wallets, bid for eligible bachelors who strolled before them on a runway Tuesday night in an auction to raise money for the YWCA. The rose-toting, tuxedo-clad fellows on display included a Wall Street banker, lawyers and businessmen. The Y hoped to raise $10,000 with the event; no figures were avilable at the close of the night. The bidding for the 34 certifiably unattached males was loud, fast and punctuated with laughter. Some of the men were nervous _ and some hammed it up. The bidders and their chattel were committed by contract to go on a date before May 15. Many could be seen taking each others' phone numbers after the bids were secured. Fun aside, ``the idea is to draw young women into the Y,'' said New York YWCA executive director Lenore Parker. Bob Saslawsky, co-owner of an auto leasing company, said he was glad to raise money for a charity but felt humiliated. ``You actually feel like a piece of meat. It's a total role reversal,'' Saslawsky said. Bob Chandler, his business partner, raised his hands to the ceiling in celebration when a striking young woman wrote out her $450 check for him. ``Thank you, God!'' he screamed. ``Thank you, God!'' The mystery woman declined to be interviewed. Gordon Ogden, a bond salesman at Bear Stearns & Co., opened his coat to show off his slender frame and twirled his red rose to the squealing delight of the bidders. A strip show it wasn't, but ``it's the closest I'll ever get to the stage at Chippendale's,'' said Michael Advocate, an attorney. Advocate, who topped off his tuxedo with a black cowboy hat, drew the highest bidder _ a commitment of $1,100. He also landed last year's high bid of $675. ``Maybe it's the hat,'' he quipped. Bachelor after bachelor paraded in front of the women, who laughed, smirked, drank and bid for dates. Only single or legally separated people over age 21 could participate. Many of the bachelors also fortified themselves at the bar before taking the stage, and some even took their drinks on with them. Stacey Cronin, a real estate assistant, said she wouldn't bid more than $200, but when the gavel came down on bachelor number two, Ms. Cronin smiled triumphantly _ then gasped when the auctioneer announced her winning bid was $375. ``Oh my God! I can't believe I did it!'' Ms. Cronin said to no one in particular. Later, she said: ``You know, it all happened so fast. But I'm happy. It's fine. It's for charity.'' Told that Ms. Cronin had gone above her spending limit, her catch, Wayne W. Wales, grinned and said jokingly: ``Basically, I'm worth it. Actually, I thought I'd go for more.''

DOC.HEAD: Romantics Flock to Nevada ``Quickie'' Chapels to Tie the Knot
DOC.TEXT: Valentine's Day means candy, flowers or kisses for most people, but hundreds are flocking to Nevada's ``quickie'' wedding chapels today to tie the knot on one of the busiest days of the year for nuptials. At the Chapel of the Bells early today, Scott Carlson, 23, and Moon Yo Young, 21, _ were married 14 seconds after midnight as the Reno couple sought to be the state's first newlyweds on Valentine's Day, said Colleen Loftis, a chapel employee. Chapel owner George Flint said Tuesday many couples come to his chapel on Valentine's because they're ``more romantic.'' ``They plan this for months. It's a tradition,'' he said. ``I've been in this business since the '60s and hadn't really realized until about 10 years ago that it was a big deal to get married on Valentine's Day.'' At Las Vegas' Candlelight Wedding Chapel, owner Gordon Gust had 100 wedding ceremonies scheduled Tuesday and 160 planned for today. His 24-hour record is 315 wedding ceremonies performed by five ministers on a Valentine's Day that fell on a weekend. The Clark County Marriage Certificate Bureau in Las Vegas sold 302 marriage certificates on Valentine's Day last year. On a normal weekday, 200 couples marry, and the number will double on a Saturday or Sunday. In Reno, marriage bureau supervisor Marietta Draeger said up to 500 couples have married on the romantic holiday. ``It just depends on the day. If Valentine's falls on a weekend and the weather is nice you get a lot more people,'' she explained. ``The weather has a lot to do with how many people come in.'' An unromantic cold front moved across the Sierra Nevada on Tuesday, scattering snow across the mountains overnight. Today was expected to be clear with temperatures below freezing. Flint said 1,600 weddings are performed in Las Vegas in a typical week, 600 in Reno and 300 in the Lake Tahoe-Carson City area. Eighty percent of the couples are from California, 5 percent from Nevada and the remainder from other states. Three-day holiday weekends also are busy as are the final days of the year when couples are looking for a tax break, Flint said. Beside the quick ceremony, wedding chapels are popular with the cost-conscious. Big weddings run several thousand dollars compared to the chapels dotting many downtown Reno streets, decorated in red hearts and bearing names like the Hitching Post and Cupid's Chapel of Love. Add-ons such as flowers, video or audiotape, garters, tuxedos, wedding gowns and even rings can run up the tab. ``We can get you in and out for $34.50, our cheapest package,'' Flint said. ``That doesn't include the $27 license fee. But it goes up from there.''

DOC.HEAD: Buster Declared Champ; Rematch Shaping up
DOC.TEXT: A rematch is in the works between Mike Tyson and Buster Douglas, who has been crowned undisputed heavyweight boxing champ after three days of bickering over the long count. Tyson said Tuesday he was ``still one of the best fighters in the world'' and would prove it in a rematch being sought by his promoter, Don King. King said he was trying to wrap up the rematch for Atlantic City, N.J., around June 18. ``We don't have a rematch right now, but we're trying to get one,'' said King. It was King who started the controversy by protesting that the referee counted too long over Douglas when he was knocked down in the eighth round in Sunday's fight in Tokyo. The International Boxing Federation recognized Douglas as champion immediately after his 10-round knockout, and the World Boxing Council extended recognition Monday night after King dropped his protest. The World Boxing Association became the last of the sport's three major governing bodies to recognize him. Douglas took the news calmly at his home in Columbus, Ohio, saying the ``main thing for me is that I am now looked upon as the heavyweight champion of the world. It was a lifelong dream come true, and I thank God for that.''

DOC.HEAD: Cellist-Conductor Ends Exile in Triumphant Moscow Concert
DOC.TEXT: Mstislav Rostropovich returned to the Soviet concert stage after 16 years of exile, leading his U.S. orchestra in a rousing version of John Philip Sousa's ``Stars and Stripes Forever.'' Asked how he chose that bit of defiance, Rostropovich said later, ``From my heart.'' The late Leonid Brezhnev had banished Rostropovich for refusing to renounce his principles and denounce his friend, exiled author Alexander Solzhenitsyn. But the cellist and conductor came back to a homeland where Brezhnev, and not he, was discredited. Rostropovich returned as the world-renowned director of the national symphony of the Soviet Union's rival superpower. Among those who attended the concert was President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's wife, Raisa. Washington's National Symphony Orchestra responded to Rostropovich's emotional return with a brilliant performance in which every song was a symbol _ from Tchaikovsky's ``Pathetique'' Symphony No. 6, the last piece he conducted in the Soviet Union in 1974 _ to the ``Stars and Stripes.'' Flanked by baskets of carnations and the U.S. and Soviet flags, Rostropovich and the National Symphony held the audience rapt. Clutches of army recruits who had been helping with crowd control listened intently. Rostropovich, 62, began with ``Barber's Adagio for Strings'' and moved on to the Tchaikovsky symphony. He finished the main concert with the wildly varying emotions and styles of the Symphony No. 5 of Dmitri Shostakovich, whose grave he had visited immediately on arrival in Moscow. After five bows to cries of ``Bravo!'' and tumultuous applause, Rostropovich moved into an encore of a brief Shostakovich polka, and was drawn back for three more encores. After the concert, he plowed through fans, musicians, instruments and trunks stuffed into the narrow backstage corridors of the Moscow Conservatory, and emerged in a light snowfall a few blocks from the Kremlin. As he climbed into an official car to drive to a reception in his honor at the U.S. ambassador's residence, a young woman ran up and cried, ``Marvelous! Simply marvelous!'' At the Spaso House party, he tossed off vodkas in true Russian style and enveloped longtime friends with hugs. Rostropovich and his wife, soprano Galina Vishnevskaya, left the Soviet Union in 1974 after years of harassment for their unwavering support for Solzhenitsyn, the Nobel Prize-winning author of the ``Gulag Archipelago,'' which documented the Soviet political prison camps. Four years later, the Soviets took the Rostropovichs' citizenship away for being ``ideological degenerates.'' Rostropovich had become an internationally famous cellist by age 30 and lived a life of luxury and world travel. But all that changed when he became friends with Solzhenitsyn in the late 1960s. At a time when dozens of prominent Russians joined in a chorus of derision of the author, Rostropovich housed Solzhenitsyn at his dacha for four years. He sent a letter to four newspapers in 1970 saying Solzhenitsyn had suffered for speaking the truth. All refused to publish it. The Presidium of the Supreme Soviet legislature restored the citizenship of Rostropovich and his wife just a month ago, and nullified the decree that stripped them of all their medals and honors. Rostropovich's four-concert tour was arranged within days. The new Soviet Minister of culture, Nikolai Gubenko, apologized in an article in the journal New Times for the injustice of stripping the couple of citizenship. ``The deplorable violation of human dignity should never be repeated,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Cubans Who Twice Floated to Freedom Recount Harrowing Story
LaserPhoto MH1
DOC.TEXT: A refugee who twice floated to freedom from Cuba said he will never return to his homeland again _ unless it's to battle the government of Fidel Castro. Jorge Diaz and Fransisco Gomez Rodrigues, who arrived here the first time in August, went back to Cuba secretly in January to fetch their families. But they were taken into custody and imprisoned for a month before they were dispatched in the same 16-foot boat they arrived in _ this time flooded with gasoline, and lacking a working engine, oars or even food, according to Diaz. ``If I go back again it will be in an invasion force,'' he said. ``That's the only way I'm going back to Cuba _ when Fidel falls.'' The voyage of Diaz and Gomez is apparently the first time Cuban refugees have repeated the hazardous journey across the Florida Straits, immigration officials said. At the start of the second crossing, Diaz didn't believe he'd ever make it to Miami. Cuban border guards abandoned them in their boat 30 miles offshore and tossed the engine key into the boat, but it bounced into the water, Diaz said Tuesday as he sat in the Krome Avenue Detention Center in Miami. ``I asked them why they didn't just shoot us and save the trouble,'' the 37-year-old Diaz said. ``They said they were under orders from the Interior Minister.'' The longtime friends believed they would die at sea, with their families in Miami and Cuba never knowing their fate, Diaz said. Gomez, 31, could not be interviewed Tuesday. He was hospitalized with a kidney stone condition aggravated by the boat ride, Immigration and Naturalization Service officials said. INS officials have interviewed the two men, said Vincent Intenzo, deportation supervisor at Krome. ``I believe them _ they have been interviewed several times and their stories are consistent,'' he said. In their first voyage from Cuba, they traveled with four others in a small plastic boat. But the engine failed and their one-day food supply was quickly exhausted, Diaz said. The boat drifted for five days, until the group was rescued by the Coast Guard about 95 miles off the Florida Keys. They spent two weeks in an INS processing center, then worked in restaurants and odd jobs until they had bought a Volkswagen and saved $250. They began to make plans to bring their families from Cuba, including Diaz's wife, who gave birth last month to their first child. They traded the car and the money for a 16-foot boat, outfitted it with an outboard motor and gas tanks and early Jan. 6 left the Keys' city of Marathon. Just off Havana, bad weather blew them off course, marooning them on a small rock island, Diaz said. The next morning a fisherman _ an acquaintence of Diaz's _ spotted them, and the Cuban border patrol boat showed up. The two were taken to a prison in Matanzas province, east of Havana, Diaz said. They begged to inform their families, but the guards refused. ``At one point, they told me don't worry _ our families would never know we were in Cuba,'' Diaz said. ``I thought they were going to shoot us right there, because that was the only way my family would never know.'' But early Feb. 5, they were taken by a Cuban patrol vessel about 30 miles offshore, told to get into their boat, and left. Their only sustenance on the second trip was a little water left in a tank filled the month before. Three days out, a Cuban freighter approached them but the captain said he had been warned not to pick them up, Diaz said. On the seventh day, by now semi-delirious, they spotted a vessel in the darkness and desperately signaled with a flashlight. The U.S. tanker Chestnut Hill rescued them and called the Coast Guard. When the Coast Guard arrived, Diaz said they had a surprise. ``It was one of the same crewmen who picked us up the first time _ I talked to him and he remembered us,'' Diaz laughed. Diaz and Gomez are renewing their requests for political asylum. Usually, Cuban refugees are released while their cases are pending.

DOC.HEAD: Aspen Voters Defeat Fur Ban, Favor Growth Proposals
DOC.TEXT: Voters rejected by a 2-1 margin an attempt to make this Alpine resort the nation's first furrier-free town despite a campaign that attracted animal rights activists from as far away as Sweden. Residents also voted Tuesday for growth, defeating by 1,561 to 1,051 a measure to reduce the size of a luxury hotel by 25 percent, and approving measures to widen the highway leading into town and a bond measure to build employee housing. The winners hailed the results as a victory for free enterprise. The losers conceded that the mood in the town, home to ``gonzo'' journalist Hunter S. Thompson and other eccentrics, had taken a lurch beyond the bourgeois. ``People seem more concerned with business and monetary gain than other values,'' said Katharine Thalberg, who with her husband, Mayor Bill Stirling, led the fight for the fur-sale ban. ``They want a larger hotel, a bigger highway ... there does seem to be a value shift here in town.'' ``The big winners are the people of Aspen. We can get back to business and welcome our guests back who've been staying away because of all this,'' said Mark Kirkland, manager of Revillon furs, one of Aspen's four fur shops. The results set the stage for a recall election next month for Stirling and three city councilmen who backed the ban. While furriers gave live interviews on national television networks Tuesday night, anti-fur activists heckled them and waved ``Go to Vail'' signs, much to the chagrin of Aspen business operators fearing a lose of customers to the neighboring ski resort. Despite losing by 1,701 to 898, Stirling and Thalberg claimed victory by attracting attention to the issue. ``In terms of public opinion and world opinion, we won,'' Thalberg said. Animal-rights activists said furs are made from creatures that have been raised and slaughtered under cruel conditions. Kirkland, who represented the furriers' interests, had little to say about any national impact. ``I'm glad we won. I'm glad it's over,'' he said. The fur-fighting campaign brought animal rights activists from England, Sweden and the Netherlands, adding more spice to the brew of beautiful people who swing in and out of the chic, expensive mountain town. Aspen has 3,700 registered voters and a population said to dip from a peak of 20,000 in the winter to 7,000 in the summer. Many property owners don't live here full time, and real estate prices have skyrocketed during the past decade. ``This hotel and the other growth issues decide whether Aspen will be a town of eclectic people or eccentrics like me, or a big money machine,'' said Nick de Wolf, a retired engineer and inventor. ``I'm afraid the results are pretty clear.'' Aspen was the first U.S. community to pass a tough anti-smoking ordinance and the first to declare itself a nuclear-free zone.

DOC.HEAD: Attacks on Controversial Politicians Mar Election Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Attacks on two politicians and threats to at least two others have marred the campaign for parliamentary elections Sunday and led to tightened security for the 953 candidates. An anonymous caller said a bomb was planted today on a flight carrying opposition Socialist Party leader Takako Doi, police reported. No bomb was found, and police refused comment on the motive for the hoax. On Tuesday, Koichi Hamada of the governing Liberal Democratic Party was beaten over the head with a steel rod following a campaign rally east of Tokyo. He suffered moderate injuries. Police said they arrested Minoru Uzawa, 27, a member of one of Japan's largest crime syndicates, on suspicion of assault. They said Uzawa, 27, told them he attacked Hamada because he ``disliked him.'' On Sunday, a member of a rightist group entered former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone's campaign office in Takasaki, 60 miles northwest of Tokyo, and fired shots at a television set, a campaign poster and a doll symbolizing good luck, police said. None of the 11 people in the office was injured. The assailant, 23-year-old Koji Konishi, reportedly told police he didn't intend to kill anyone, but disliked Nakasone and wanted to ``create a ruckus'' to show the rest of Japan how the politician ``had made a fool of the Japanese people.'' On Jan. 18, another right-wing extremist shot and severely wounded Mayor Hitoshi Motoshima of Nagasaki, who had angered right-wing groups by suggested the late Emperor Hirohito might share some responsibility for Japan's aggression in World War II. Twenty-seven important politicians in postwar Japan have been assaulted, police say. Most were controversial figures who angered right-wing fringe groups. Ultrarightists have grown increasingly violent in the past month after keeping a low profile during a year of mourning following Hirohito's death on Jan. 7, 1989. Although guns are outlawed in Japan, rightist extremists are believed to use their ties with criminal syndicates to procure weapons. Rightist groups are believed angered by links of Nakasone and other governing party leaders to the Recruit influence-buying scandal. Many conservative politicians were known to have profited in the scandal while Nakasone was prime minister. Nakasone, who resigned from the Liberal Democrats last year over the scandal, is seeking re-election to the 512-seat lower house as an independent. Police said they were investigating the motive behind the attack on Hamada, a senior Liberal Democrat who also is seeking re-election to the lower house. A former member of a criminal gang and vehement anti-communist, Hamada was forced to resign from his post as chairman of Parliament's Budget Committee two years ago after he refused to apologize for calling then-Japan Communist Party leader Kenji Miyamoto a ``murderer.'' Following the attack on Motoshima, police offered protection to any candidate who might face a threat _ an offer not extended beyond party leaders in past elections. Hundreds of uniformed and plainclothes polices have appeared at rallies attended by Ms. Doi, the Socialist leader. On Tuesday, they seized a drunken man and led him away after he tried to approach her at a rally in northern Japan.

DOC.HEAD: Two Men Acquitted on Illegal Log Export Charges
DOC.TEXT: Two men were acquitted on charges of illegally exporting to Japan logs cut from federal land in what was believed to be the first time anyone had been tried for violating the law. A federal court jury Tuesday acquitted log dealer John J. Tortorelli of Bellevue, Wash., and part-time dealer Winston Bentley of Spokane, Wash., of all charges. Tortorelli and Bentley were accused of having the logs' federal markings sawed off because they knew they were for export. Federal law prohibits the export of raw logs cut from national forests. The logs must be processed in U.S. mills, where prices are much less than foreign mills. Jack Davis, a U.S. Forest Service investigator, said he was surprised that the men were acquitted, but said the fact the jury chose to believe the defendants is ``indicative of the complexity of investigations of that type.'' Preparation of the case took two years, he said. Tortorelli was accused of buying truckloads of logs cut on Forest Service land in western Montana, northern Idaho and eastern Washington in 1987 and 1988, and then selling them to Japanese exporting companies on the West Coast. Bentley, a church janitor, helped inspect and handle some of the timber at a processing center in Mead, Wash., prosecutors said. Prosecutors believed the case was the first time anyone was prosecuted for violating the export ban. The defense argued that any export of the logs handled by Tortorelli and Bentley was accidental, and that the men should not be punished for any unintentional violations of federal law. The government gave immunity to truck drivers Duane Farmer and Roger Britz, of Emunclaw, Wash., in exchange for testimony that was expected to substantiate the charges. However, their testimony largely supported the defense's version of events.

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys Seek to Dismiss Flag-Burning Charges on Constitutional Grounds
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Hearing begins at 12:30 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys representing four people accused of burning an American flag want a judge to strike down the new federal flag-desecration law, saying it violates the free-speech guarantees symbolized by Old Glory. A hearing today before U.S. District Judge Barbara Rothstein is the first constitutional challenge of the Flag Protection Act of 1989, according to David Cole, a defense attorney. Congress passed the law in October in response to the U.S. Supreme Court decision that burning the Stars and Stripes is protected under First Amendment guarantees of free speech. In that case, the court struck down a Texas law that banned burning of the flag. ``Congress' new flag law is just as unconstitutional as the statute struck down,'' Cole said. ``If we are to have freedom of expression, people must be just as free to burn the flag to express dissent as they are free to wave the flag to express approval of the government.'' Mark Haggerty, Carlos Garza, Darius Allen Strong and Jennifer Campbell are charged with burning a flag outside a Seattle post office shortly after midnight on Oct. 28, the day the law went into effect. They have pleaded innocent and have moved to have those charges dismissed on grounds the act violates the First Amendment to the Constitution. Cole said Tuesday he planned to cite Texas vs. Johnson, the Supreme Court ruling last June that overturned a Texas conviction against Gregory Lee Johnson, who burned a flag at the 1984 Republican National Convention. Assistant U.S. Attorney Mark Bartlett, who was handling the government's case, did not immediately return telephone messages Tuesday for comment. Cole said the U.S. House and Senate have filed friend-of-the-court briefs and attorneys for both legislative bodies were expected to speak. Cole said he did not expect the judge to issue a ruling today. If she denies the motion, he said, the defendants would appeal directly to the Supreme Court, as provided under the act. The trial for the four is set for Feb. 26. In addition to the flag-desecration counts, each is charged with one count of depredation of government property. Conviction on the flag-desecration and destruction-of-property counts each carries a maximum penalty of one year in prison and a $100,000 fine. President Bush had sought a constitutional amendment to ban flag burning, but that was rejected by Congress, which passed the flag statute instead. Bush administration officials have said they doubt the flag-desecration law would withstand a court challenge.

DOC.HEAD: Approved for Work-Release; Details Still Not Finished
DOC.TEXT: Imprisoned soul singer James Brown has been approved to participate in a work-release program, but details still must be worked out, officials say. Several radio stations and the Benedict College music department are interested in the singer's talents. But the ``Godfather of Soul'' is leaning toward educating young people about the evils of drugs, said his attorney, Richard Crane of Nashville, Tenn., who was busy fielding numerous job offers for Brown on Tuesday. ``Radio stations in Columbia, Charleston and North Augusta are interested in him as a disc jockey,'' Crane said, and Benedict College ``has expressed interest in James working in the music department.'' Corrections Department spokesman Bennish Brown confirmed Tuesday that Brown's application for work release had been granted. Crane said, ``Now all he needs is a bed and a job.'' The spokesman said there are waiting lists for beds at the department's seven work-release centers, including those in Richland and Aiken counties, where Brown has expressed a preference. ``We're now down to a different waiting game,'' he said. ``We need to match a job with a work-release center.'' Participation in the program will require him to stay overnight in a work-release center while working. He also would be banned from any out-of-state employment. Brown is serving a six-year sentence in State Park Correctional Center in Columbia for failing to stop for police, aggravated assault and weapons violations in connection with a 1988 two-state car chase that began in Georgia. Brown, who becomes eligible for parole May 5, 1991, applied for work release in December.

DOC.HEAD: Rough Seas, High Winds Halt Cleanup
DOC.TEXT: High winds and rough waves today blew ashore a gooey black tide from an oil spill, halting cleanup efforts as officials feared shoreline workers might get swept to sea. Officials tripled the size of cleanup crews to 1,120 as the worst accumulation of crude oil from last week's spill swept onto miles of beach. But treacherous seas, with waves up to 7 feet high, brought a nighttime halt to cleanup efforts that had been around the clock since just after the 400,000-gallon spill from the tanker American Trader. Crews were sent home Tuesday as high tide approached and onshore winds began gusting to 30 mph, said Coast Guard Lt. Richard Booth. ``The winds were kicking up a lot of sand and it was just impossible for people to work,'' Booth said. Offshore, 13 of the 16 oil skimming boats also temporarily suspended cleanup work because of choppy seas, he said. The patched-up American Trader moved into Long Beach Harbor this morning and tied up at an Atlantic Richfield Co. dock to unload the remaining 21 million gallons of crude oil in its tanks and begin hull puncture repairs. Waves of grimy crude fouled six miles of sand along a 12-mile stretch of beach southeast of downtown Los Angeles _ at Huntington Beach, Newport Beach and Bolsa Chica State Beach. The oil has killed 86 birds and coated 261 in oil. ``I'm disgusted,'' surfer Bill Casper said, watching the black tide roll in at his favorite surf spot near Huntington Beach Pier. ``It's going to affect the beach for years. There will be tar on the beach for years.'' About 1,000 grunion, small silver fish resembling sardines, died during a weekend ``run'' along the Orange County coastline, said state Department of Fish and Game spokesman Patrick Moore. Grunion spawn with frantic dashes onto the beach at high tide to lay eggs in the soft sand. Any eggs left behind in the oil-soaked sand were not expected to hatch, Moore said. The daily price tag for the beach cleanup is $750,000, with the bill through Tuesday reaching $4 million, said James H. Ross, president and chief executive of British Petroleum American Inc., which chartered the ship. The oil leak Feb. 7 came as the tanker tried to moor at an oil pipeline delivery point about two miles offshore. Eric Bush, a 19-year-old deckhand on the American Trader, said Tuesday that oil poured from the hull after he let down the 12-ton starboard anchor. Bush said the anchors were being lowered ``just the way we always do'' when he felt two sharp jolts a few minutes apart. He first thought the 811-foot ship had plowed an undersea mud bank, but a look overboard proved otherwise. ``The water was just boiling with crude,'' Bush said. British Petroleum is coordinating most of the cleanup but is not expected to pay for final costs, which likely will come out of the insurance of the ship's owner, American Trading Transportation Co., Ross said. Gov. George Deukmejian held off on a request by Huntington Beach Mayor Tom Mays to declare an emergency since he said most of the cleanup was being handled privately. ``As far as we can tell, there are no needs that are not being met,'' said Eileen Baumgardner, assistant director of the state Office of Emergency Services. Cleanup crews grew Tuesday to 1,120 workers, and 300 others were being trained. One of the first lawsuits in connection with the spill has been filed by an 86-year-old former congressman. The class-action lawsuit, filed Tuesday by Chet Holifield in Los Angeles federal court, seeks compensation for damage and economic losses caused by the spill and the alleged failure to properly clean up the oil. Among the defendants named are British Petroleum and American Trading.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed in early European trading today, and gold prices fell. Foreign currency dealers said the market was trying to position itself for the latest set of U.S. trade figures due out on Friday. Barring any news events, they predicted trading would settle into a narrow range. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 0.13 yen to a closing 144.35 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 144.45 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: _1.6757 West German marks, down from 1.6760 _1.4965 Swiss francs, up from 1.4960 _5.7005 French francs, up from 5.6995 _1.8895 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8980 _1,244.50 Italian lire, down from 1,248.00 _1.2038 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1995 In London, the dollar fell against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.6928, compared with $1.6907 late Tuesday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $417.30 a troy ounce, down from $418.65 bid late Tuesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $416.00. In Zurich, the bid price was $415.90, down from $419.75 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $3.93 to close at a bid $415.65. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.32 a troy ounce, from Tuesday's $5.35.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Teachers March for Higher Pay, Jeer Governor
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of angry teachers left their classrooms for a day of rallies calling for better pay, and hooted the governor when he told them the state's $700 million budget surplus was already committed. About 13,000 teachers walked off the job Tuesday and another 8,000 or more colleagues and supporters packed rallies in various cities. Gov. Booth Gardner was hecked and jeered by hundreds of teachers in the capitol rotunda when he gave his bottom line _ ``This is not the session to talk about additional salaries.'' The surplus funds are going to children's programs, unexpected increases in school enrollments, welfare caseloads and other programs, Gardner said. A Seattle rally attracted at least 3,500 teachers and supporters. Afterwards, the throng marched through downtown, handing out leaflets that said state teachers' salaries had plunged in a decade from fourth to 21st in the nation. Teachers on average earn about $31,000 a year, plus a supplemental contract of about $2,000 and benefits worth about $9,100, according to the state budget office. West Virginia's 22,000 teachers, whose average salary of $21,904 ranks them 48th nationally, planned a statewide walkout Thursday to demand a raise. Gov. Gaston Caperton said the money is unavailable. Washington teachers are getting a two-year, 10 percent pay boost but have demanded that $225 million of the surplus be used to double their salary hikes. The teachers' action provided about 200,000 students a winter play day, according to teacher-union estimates. The walkout had been cleared with administrators in most districts, but in two districts, teachers walked off the job and left their classrooms to substitutes. ``I'll be docked $200, but I don't care,'' said Randy Walden, a social studies teacher in Puyallup, east of Olympia. ``We felt so strongly, we walked out.'' ``We're tired of promises,'' said Jeff Page, a teacher in Lake Stevens, north of Seattle. ``I've been teaching 12 years and they keep saying we'll do better when times are better. .. ``We have a Democratic governor who calls himself the education governor and Democrats in charge of the House and they haven't done a thing to help us. I'm irate. There is a possibility of a real strike next year.''

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``We seek a European Germany, not a German Europe.'' _ Hans-Dietrich Genscher, West Germany's foreign minister, seeking to reassure the world that a unified Germany will not pose a threat to peace.

``If there's one place in the world where as secretary of defense I get up in the morning worried about the possibility you could have a short-warning or a no-notice attack against U.S. forces, it's in Korea.'' _ Defense Secretary Dick Cheney.

``I'm disgusted. It's going to affect the beach for years. There will be tar on the beach for years.'' _ Bill Casper, surfer, watching the black tide roll in on part of six miles of sand southeast of downtown Los Angeles fouled by the American Trader oil spill.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Offers Valentine's Day Discount Rates
DOC.TEXT: AT&T sweetened Valentine's Day for long-distance lovers by cutting its rates by a third for the day. The discount was announced as a peace offering to customers shortly after the Jan. 15 outage that kept millions of long-distance calls from being completed. The company is offering an average of 33 percent off regular daytime rates for calls within the United States between 8 a.m. and 5 p.m, said spokeswoman Lynn Newman, with discounts averaging about 37 percent off for overseas calls. In some states where local utility regulators have given the company permission, discounts also will apply to intra-state calls handled by AT&T, she said. A programming error in AT&T's call switching network partially knocked out long distance service nationwide for about nine hours in last month's outage. On Valentine's Day last year, the company recorded 107.9 million telephone calls. In 1988, when it fell on a weekend, AT&T registered 48.9 million calls.

DOC.HEAD: Three Arrested in Canadian School Bus Hijack
DOC.TEXT: Three teen-agers who took 14 hostages on a school bus were arrested after releasing all but one of their captives and leading authorities on a brief chase. The hostages included 13 secondary school students and the bus driver. All were released unharmed although one girl was later taken to a hospital for treatment of shock, said Royal Canadian Mounted Police. The youths who seized the bus Tuesday in this town 300 miles north of Vancouver were armed with two sawed-off rifles, a .303-caliber and a .22-caliber semiautomatic, said RCMP Inspector Merv Harrower. The youths, two 18-year-olds and a 14-year-old, were due to appear today in provincial court. Their names were not released. Harrower, at a news conference, declined to say what charges would be filed. The youths commandeered the bus as it was taking students home from school and ordered the driver to drive to a car dealership, Sgt. Elles Peleskey said. Two of the 13 students aboard the bus were released shortly after the bus arrived at the Sunland Motors lot, he said. Police sharpshooters were sent to the scene and the downtown area closed off. No shots were fired by either side. About 2{ hours into the standoff, police supplied the trio with a getaway car and allowed them to take one of the male students with them. The youths drove north out of Prince George, turned off the main highway onto a side road to elude police, but crashed into a snowbank and were captured, Harrower said.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Claim Killing More Than 2,000 Ethiopian Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: Two Ethiopian rebel groups, fighting on separate fronts, claim to have killed nearly 2,500 government soldiers during weekend battles in two northern provinces. It was not possible to independently verify the rebel claims, made in broadcasts from their clandestine radio stations. The Eritrea People's Liberation Front today said its fighters killed 600 government soldiers in fighting Sunday near Karan, in Ethiopia's northermost province, Eritrea. Tuesday night, the Tigre People's Liberation Front said it put 5,344 soldiers out of action in fighting Saturday and Sunday around Wichale and Mersa in Wollo province on the main road north from the capital, Addis Ababa. ``In the attack, 1,813 soldiers were killed, 2,520 were wounded and 1,011 soldiers were captured,'' the Tigrean rebels said. Wichale and Mersa are about 200 miles from Addis Ababa. The Eritreans, who launched their first major offensive in a year last week, said they had ``put a total of 1,500 out of action in the offensive.'' The offensive followed two attempts at negotiations to end the 28-year-old insurgency. The Tigreans have controlled their home province since early last year. In August, they claimed a series of battlefield victories as they moved west to Gonder province and south to Wollo and Showa provinces. Early this year, the government launched a counteroffensive and claimed to have retaken some of territory. But on Saturday, the ``Voice of The Broad Masses of Eritrea'' radio announced the offensive along a front 125 miles long and the capture of Massawa, one of Ethiopia's only two ports on the Red Sea coast. The fighting around Karan 55 miles west of Massawa began Sunday. The rebels said they destroyed eight government brigades, about 12,000 men, sank nine naval vessels and captured 46 tanks in three days of fighting. Ethiopian officials accused the Eritreans of launching the offensive Thursday to relieve pressure on the Tigreans by government troops. The Tigrean and Eritrean rebels have different goals but they have coordinated their attacks in the past. The Eritreans have been fighting since 1962 for the independence of Eritrea, a former Italian colony. The Tigreans took up arms in 1975 and seek President Mengistu Haile Mariam's ouster and the establishment of a government patterned after that of Albania, the last hard-line Marxist state in Eastern Europe. Relief officials say the fighting around Massawa has halted efforts to feed drought victims in northern Ethiopia, leaving 50,000 tons of food stored at the port. The food is part of 700,000 tons of emergency food the United Nations hoped to deliver over the next months to 4 million people threatened with famine, most of them in Eritrea and Tigrea. In Khartoum, the capital of Ethiopia's western neighbor, Sudan, officials said 24,000 Ethiopians had crossed the border this month to escape renewed fighting in Eritea.

DOC.HEAD: Precede ANDERSEN AIR FORCE BASE
Defense Secretary Pledges No ``Drastic'' Cut in Korea Troop Strength
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 8 grafs with arrival statement; picks up at pvs 6th graf, On Sunday
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney today pledged no ``drastic reduction'' of U.S. troop strength in South Korea and said America's commitment to its Asian ally remains strong. However, he was expected to press for a sharp increase in the South Korea's financial support for the 43,000 U.S. troops who are stationed here under a 1954 mutual defense treaty signed after the Korean war. ``U.S. troops will remain in Korea as long as they are needed to guarantee the peace, and the Korean and American peoples and governments want them to remain,'' Cheney said after arriving from Hawaii on the first stop of a two-week tour of Asian nations hosting U.S. forces. ``The U.S. commitment to Korea remains firm and unequivocal ... speculation regarding a U.S. withdrawal from the peninsula or drastic reduction of our troop presence here apparently disregards the obvious: the threat to peace on the peninsula remains real and has not diminished,'' he added. Greeting Cheney, South Korean Defense Minister Lee Sang Hoon said the two nations were meeting at a time when military tension between South Korea and hardline communist North Korea ``remains undiminished,'' but he said the two allied nations would work closely together to provide for a stable and peaceful Asia. Cheney, before leaving Hawaii on Tuesday, said the threat from North Korea remains ``very high.'' ``If there's one place in the world where as secretary of defense I get up in the morning worried about the possibility you could have a short-warning or a no-notice attack against U.S. forces, it's in Korea,'' Cheney told the Pacific and Asian Affairs Council in Honolulu. The defense secretary planned to spend three days in South Korea, including a trip to the demilitarized zone 35 miles north of Seoul. On Sunday, he goes to the Philippines for a round of meetings Monday with Philippines officials _ but apparently not with President Corazon Aquino who has said she will not meet with him. Although Cheney has said he will have plenty to keep him busy, the Aquino snub drew a rare public rebuff from President Bush, according to a published report. ``She can learn a great deal from Dick Cheney about the way we view the very important United States presence in the Pacific,'' the president said Tuesday in an interview with New York Newsday. ``Maybe you could learn from the man _ or he could learn from you, Madame President,'' Bush said in the interview in remarks aimed at the Philippine leader, who turned aside a coup attempt Dec. 1 with the help of U.S. Phantom jets. In announcing the would not meet Cheney, Aquino said the United States has failed to follow through on pledges of economic aid and also took offense at U.S. blaming the December coup attempt in part on corruption and inefficiency in her government. Bush denied in the interview that he was angry. ``There's no problem,'' he said. ``She's given her opinion. I'm right to give mine.'' Meanwhile, a senior Pentagon official traveling with Cheney told reporters the secretary and his delegation intend to ask South Korea to increase its $300 million annual contribution to the U.S. defense to around $700 million by 1993. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said he expected the discussion to be ``a very difficult one'' for both sides and that no specific resolution was anticipated during the secretary's visit. The money issue also is troublesome because the South Koreans argue they contribute more than $2 billion to the U.S. forces annually through such things as the use of prime real estate in downtown Seoul for the U.S. military headquarters and an 18-hole golf course. The official said the delegation intends to suggest some numbers to the South Koreans but he didn't expect a resolution until October. The official said the Asian nations hosting U.S. forces ``are very sensitive to being pushed around about money.'' ``The important thing is the trend. Are they moving in the right direction,'' the official said, describing the negotiations as ``sort of a Kabuki,'' referring to the stylized Japanese dance. The official said another issue on the agenda will be working out details for the co-production arrangement for the sale of FA-18 Hornet fighter jets made by McDonnell Douglas Corp. The $4.2 billion sale has sparked some controversy on Capitol Hill over concern that some of the sensitive technology in the fighter would allow the South Koreans to develop their own aviation industry to compete with U.S. firms. The sale requires congressional approval. Under the plan the South Koreans would buy a dozen planes, assemble three dozen more from U.S.-supplied kits and co-produce 72 in Korean factories with the help of the U.S. contractor. Cheney has backed the arrangement as a means of helping the Republic of Korea upgrade its air defenses. The United States spends about $2.6 billion a year on troops in South Korea and Cheney has come under severe pressure to reduce the numbers and increase the support from nations with booming economies that benefit by the U.S. protection. Some lawmakers, unhappy with the U.S.-Korean trade imbalance, have called for pulling at least 5,000 troops from the peninsula while others want to slash the force to 10,000 soldiers. Even though Cheney said at the outset of his two-week tour of South Korea, Japan, Hong Kong and the Philippines that he sees no need to ``drastically reduce'' U.S. forces in the Pacific, he has said ``adjustments'' would be made. Talk of a reduced U.S. presence has become more common amid the revolutionary changes sweeping the Soviet Union, but Cheney warned while in Hawaii that the United States must be ready for any change in Soviet policy, and the threats from other sources such as communist North Korea.

DOC.HEAD: Bar Association's Policy-Making Body Adopts Pro-Choice Resolution
DOC.TEXT: The American Bar Association approved by a 2-1 margin a resolution opposing government intervention in a woman's decision to end a pregnancy. The ABA's House of Delegates passed the resolution 238-106 Tuesday after about 2{ hours of debate and attempts by opponents to defer the resolution, said Estell Rogers, a chairwoman of the ABA's Rights of Women Committee. It was the first time the ABA has taken a stand on abortion itself, although the bar association has issued policy statements calling for uniformity in state laws and on the right of funding for abortion, Rogers said. The resolution could lead the bar association to join pro-choice advocates in arguments over future abortion cases before the U.S. Supreme Court, Rogers said. ``It means that the resolution is now the official policy of the association,'' said Debbie Weixl, an ABA spokeswoman. Resolution proponents were reacting in part to a 1989 Supreme Court decision, which affirmed efforts in Missouri to curtail abortion rights, Rogers said. The so-called Webster decision ``has just invited a tremendous amount of activity in state legislation that will have to be litigated,'' said Faye Wattleton, president of the Planned Parenhood Federation of America, who backed the resolution. The ABA policy statement ``recognizes the fundamental rights of privacy and equality guaranteed by the United States Constitution and opposes legislation or other governmental action that interferes with the confidential relationship between a pregnant woman and a physician or with the decision to terminate the pregnancy.'' Among those opposing the resolution was ABA President L. Stanley Chauvin Jr. of Louisville, Ky., who said the resolution was beyond the ABA's mission. Others argued the resolution should be tabled because the issue was so divisive it would discourage membership. The House of Delegates is the ABA's only legislative body authorized to make policy.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Officials Say Drug Use Figures Still Too High
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds one graf with detail on survey method
DOC.TEXT: A new survey shows fewer high school students and young adults are using illicit drugs, but federal health and drug officials say the numbers are still too high. ``One out of two (high school) students still uses an illegal drug before he graduates; one out of 10 uses cocaine,'' said national drug policy director William Bennett. ``Those numbers are unacceptably high.'' The survey released Monday is an annual effort by the University of Michigan and funded by the National Institute on Drug Abuse to track the use of drugs by high school seniors, college students and other young adults. It shows a decrease in overall illegal drug use over the past decade and in 1989 by all three groups. High school seniors and college students today are half as likely to try an illegal drug as they were in 1980, according to the survey. Despite the good news, said Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan, ``We must not allow our efforts to slacken.'' The decline in alcohol use has been more modest and cigarette smoking is about as widespread today among seniors as it was a decade ago. Nearly 19 percent of seniors are daily smokers and 60 percent have used alcohol within the past 30 days. Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., chairman of the House Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control, said the survey ``understates the drug problem because it omits dropouts who are an enormous core of the drug crisis.'' He said the survey is of ``extremely limited value.'' Survey officials acknowledge the limitation, but said the data suggest drug use among dropouts may also be declining. They said the survey shows the drop in drug use among high school seniors who are truant and have bad grades is as great as the drop among seniors who are not truant and have good grades. Among specific drugs: _Marijuana: Casual use _ within the last 30 days _ among seniors is down from a peak of 37 percent in 1979 to 17 percent in 1989, and for college students, it has dropped from 34 percent in 1980 to 16 percent last year. _Cocaine: 2.8 percent of seniors are casual cocaine users, down from a peak of 6.7 percent in 1985, and among college students the drop is larger. But for the smokable form of the drug known as crack, casual and daily use has stayed about the same for seniors since 1987 when it was first included in the survey. _Ice: Also known as crystal methamphetamine, ``ice'' was included for the first time in the survey because of increasing concerns about the drug. About 1.2 percent of the seniors surveyed said they had used it at least once in the past year. Use was highest in the West, where 3 percent of the seniors had used it. _Ecstasy: The drug MDNA, known as ``ecstasy,'' also was included for the first time, and was tried by 3.8 percent of the college students surveyed and 3.3 percent of the high school graduates not in college. _Steroids: About 3 percent of high school senior said they had used anabolic steroids, which are a controlled substance used to build muscles. The survey of high school seniors, which began in 1975, polled about 17,000 students in 135 public and private high schools nationwide. The other survey is a follow-up study of previously participating graduating classes. In this survey, about 1,200 college students and about 6,600 high school graduates who are one to 10 years past high school were resurveyed by mail.

DOC.HEAD: No Longer Cheek to Cheek, Not Quite Cheeky
DOC.TEXT: Are Donald and Ivana Trump turning nasty, brutish and short with each other? Or are they having a kinder and gentler celebrity divorce for the '90s? Judge for yourself.

The stakes: Ivana, as reported today by Liz Smith in the Daily News: ``All I have now asked for is a fair and equitable share of the fortune Donald and I built together, for ourselves and our children.'' Donald, in the News: ``Ivana doesn't want the money. She wants Donald.''

Track record: Donald: ``You know I've always been good to her. I always will be good to her,'' he told Cindy Adams of the New York Post in today's editions. ``I have a great affection for Ivana. I always have from the day I met her. I always will have that great feeling for her.'' Ivana: Mum's the word since the split.

The exit: Donald: (When The News asked him what it was like walking out the door.) ``The hardest day of my life.'' Why? ``Because I still like her,'' Donald emoted. Like her? ``Love her. Make that I still love her.''

The road ahead: Ivana, in the News: ``I am afraid. I know the children and I will be Donald's next project. I know how he is. He will simply zero in on us.'' Donald, also in the News: ``It's not an easy situation. It's not like your typical business transaction.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs Peterson item to CORRECT retirement year in 3rd graf.
DOC.TEXT: Barney Peterson, a San Francisco newspaper photographer for more than 40 years and a former international chairman of The Newspaper Guild, died Monday. He was 77. The cause of his death was not given. Peterson's first newspaper job was with the San Francisco Examiner. He went to the Chronicle in 1936 and, except for the World War II years he spent in the Marine Corps, stayed with the paper until retiring in 1978. Peterson was one of the founders of the San Francisco local of the Guild and in 1973 was elected international chairman. After retiring, he went to Europe and bought a 32-foot sailboat which he sailed on the Mediterranean and then, when he was 75, across the Atlantic to the West Indies. He is survived by three sons: John, of Washington, D.C.; Charles and Alan of San Francisco, and a brother, William P. Peterson of San Francisco.

DOC.HEAD: Ottawa Agreement on Unification Talks Praised by Germans
With PM-Germany-Four Power, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Government officials in East and West Germany today praised the Allies for agreeing to help settle security issues raised by the prospect of reunfication. East German Premier Hans Modrow welcomed the agreement to hold talks among the two Germanys, Britain, France, the Soviet Union and the United States on security and political issues, said spokesman Rolf Bachmann. Modrow considered the six-power approach to German unity to be the best way to ensure that the interests of the World War II victors are protected, as well as those of the German states, Bachmann said. ``We see this as an exceptionally important development and a great success for the West German foreign minister, an important step toward German unity,'' said Hanns Schumacher, a West German Foreign Ministry spokesman. Under the agreement reached in Ottawa on Tuesday , officials of East Germany and West Germany will meet after the March 18 East German elections to discuss the legal, political and economic issues of reunification. Outside powers may not interfere with decisions of the two Germanys in those talks. Afterward, foreign ministers of the two Germanys and the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union will meet to discuss other issues involved in reunfication, especially regarding security and armed forces. Modrow today wrapped up a two-day summit with West German leaders in Bonn. Also Tuesday, the two Germanys agreed to start talks on making the West German mark the official currency of East Germany, a move that could lay the economic foundation for unification. The announcement late Tuesday from Ottawa that the foreign ministers of the six countries would soon begin talks on reunifying Germany came too late for most West German newspapers. But the agreement was swiftly reported by some broadcast media. West Germany's ARD television went live to its correspondent in Ottawa late Tuesday, with the reporter saying most issues seemed clear but that the problem of the NATO membership of West Germany had been temporarily delayed. The brief statement from Ottawa did not mention a united Germany's military allegiance. The United States wants the state to remain in NATO, while the Soviets have pressed for a neutral united Germany. ``Astoundingly fruitful,'' East Germany's official news agency ADN said in describing the two-day ``Open Skies'' conference in Ottawa. ``The dramatic progress of events in the heart of Europe pushes toward negotiations.'' ADN stressed the discussions about unification ``will also include the questions of security of neighboring states.''

DOC.HEAD: Rival Christian Forces Exchange Fire; 2 Killed
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Michel Aoun's gunners and Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces today fought with howitzers and mortars in east Beirut and in Kesrouan province north of the capital. Police said two people were killed. The latest deaths raised the toll from the 16-day, intra-Christian showdown to 515. By police count, 1,724 people have been wounded since the confrontation for mastery of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave broke out Jan. 30. A reliable source today said Aoun has threatened to overrun the Christian enclave north of Beirut to crush the rival militia if it refuses to disband. The source, who demanded anonymity, said Aoun on Tuesday gave mediators ``a clear message to Geagea that he would overrun Kesrouan and break the Lebanese Forces'' if the militia chieftain continued to refuse to disband peacefully. The source, who is close to the mediators, said despite Aoun's threat ``Geagea refrained from giving the mediators a clear answer.'' The three-man mediation committee has been holding separate meetings with Aoun and Geagea in an effort to work out a settlement to their confrontation, the worst conflict among the Christians in the nearly 15-year-old civil war. Also today, the government of President Elias Hrawi, along with three foreign humanitarian organizations, dispatched 100 tons of food in nine trucks to 10,000 families in east Beirut across the city's dividing Green Line. Archbishop Khalil Abi Nader, the Maronite Catholic spiritual leader for Beirut, sponsored unloading the relief aid at a church in the district of Ashrafiyeh. ``This is aid from man to fellow man. We thank those who helped us,'' Abi Nader told reporters. Aoun told reporters Tuesday that Geagea's 6,000-strong militia is ``an unacceptable tumor in our body'' and stressed that no armed organization besides his 19,000 army would be allowed to dominate the Christian enclave. ``They are welcome if they want a political responsibility,'' Aoun said. The source said Aoun held the news conference after his threat was relayed to Geagea and after the 54-year-old general called up reservists in apparent preparation for an offensive in Kesrouan. The Lebanese Forces command, in a communique, reported ``suspicious troop movements'' in the Aoun-held territory along the eastern and southern flanks of Kesrouan, which is the militia's main power base. The independent newspaper An-Nahar quoted unidentified sources close to Aoun as saying the ``countdown for the decisive battle has started.'' A police spokesman said ``hundreds of exhausted civilians'' reached the Lebanese Forces-controlled central and western sectors of Kesrouan on Tuesday and today after walking across snow-blanketed valleys and rough terrain. The spokesman said civilians in east Beirut continued to stock supplies of food, drinking water and medicines in underground shelters, where they have been living since the confrontation broke out. Hrawi has appealed to the superpowers, France and the Vatican to support possible intervention by his Syrian-backed troops to halt the fighting. Aoun does not recognize Hrawi's Christian-Moslem government, which is backed by Syria. He also has vowed to drive the Syrians, who support the Moslem militias of west Beirut, from Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Indicates Compromise Possible
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3 grafs for grafs 13-15, `Police, meanwhile...' to UPDATE with four more killed. Pickup 16th pvs, `Mandela has...'
DOC.TEXT: The African National Congress is willing to compromise with the government on details of a post-apartheid political system as long as the principle of black rights is ensured, Nelson Mandela said today. The 71-year-old black leader, giving his first interviews since his release Sunday after 27 years in prison, was asked if the ANC was willing to ease its demand for a one-person, one-vote system that would lead to black majority rule. ``Compromises must be made in respect to every issue, as long as that compromise is in the interest not only of one population group but the country as whole,'' Mandela told reporters outside his home. ``That is the nature of compromises.'' The ANC repeatedly has rejected any system falling short of one-person, one-vote. Mandela has stressed since his release that his movement would like to address white fears of black domination, although he opposes the government's concept of ``group rights'' which would give special legal protection to whites and other minorities. ``We are aware of the fears of the whites in the country, of being dominated by blacks and we are addressing that very seriously and very earnestly,'' he said. ``I am convinced that in discussions between the ANC and the government, we will be able to find a solution which will be accepted by everybody.'' Mandela, who plans to consult soon with exiled ANC leaders in Zambia, did not elaborate on what compromises might be reached. ``I think it be most presumptuous of me to speak for the ANC,'' he said. ``It is the ANC who would decide what compromises it should make... We are ready for honorable compromises without surrendering our principles.'' In Lusaka, Zambia today, the ANC began a two-day meeting of its top policy-making body that was expected to focus on Mandela's future role. No precise agenda for the talks was released, and ANC officials gave no indication whether they expected Mandela to travel from South Africa to attend. In the months preceding his release, Mandela met frequently with senior government officials, including President F.W. de Klerk, to discuss prospects for negotiations between them and the ANC. In these discussions, Mandela said today, ``My optimism has been strengthened.'' De Klerk, who has transformed South African politics by freeing Mandela and lifting a 30-ban on the ANC, seeks to negotiate a new constitution that would extend political rights to the black majority but preserve some sort of political guarantees for whites. Police, meanwhile, reported that a new outbreak of fighting between rival black factions left at least 13 people dead. Police squads using tear gas, rubber bullets and shotguns were trying to quell the unrest at Kwanobuhle near Uitenhage, where nine people were killed. Four more killings were reported in Natal Province, where black supporters and opponents of the ANC have been feuding for three years. The government said army troops would be deployed to halt black sectional fighting. Mandela has condemned black-against-black violence, saying it weakens the fight against apartheid, the system of institionalized racism that denies the country's blacks a say in national affairs and forces them to live in segregated districts. Mandela and his family stayed overnight at the modest four-room house in Soweto that the black leader has rented for decades. The area was quiet after the wild scenes of jubilation when he returned to Soweto following his release from prison on Sunday. He briefly left today to visit Elias Motsoaledi, an old comrade who was put on trial with Mandela in 1964 on sabotage charges and is now quite ill. As Mandela left his friend's house, he talked to some young children, urging them to go school to gain education and help fight apartheid. More than 120,000 people crammed shoulder-to-shoulder into the country's largest stadium Tuesday to greet the man revered by most South African blacks as their leader. Many in the crowd were getting their first glimpse of him. He said the ANC would ``continue the armed struggle as long as the violence of apartheid continues.'' In Cape Town, the government issued its first formal response to Mandela's statements since his release. Constitutional Development Minister Gerrit Viljoen said the government agreed with Mandela that apartheid must be eliminated and voting rights extended to blacks. But he criticized Mandela's support for continued guerrilla violence and economic sanctions. ``The government is not prepared to accede to the handing over of power,'' Viljoen said. ``If that is the goal of the armed struggle, then there is no meaningful way ahead.''

DOC.HEAD: Second Day of Violence Rocks Camp Holding Boat People
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with higher injury toll. Pickup 6th pvs, ``The night...''
DOC.TEXT: Police fired tear gas today to quell clashes among Vietnamese refugees at a detention center where two days of fighting have left nearly 70 people injured, officials reported. At least 38 refugees and 30 corrections staff members have been hurt in the feuding, said government spokeswoman Fanny Kong said. Some have required hospitalization. The violence broke out today when about 1,000 refugees were moved to another section of the Whitehead Detention Center, but refugees living in that area protested, threw stones at the newcomers and tried to start fires, Ms. Kong said. She said rival groups of Vietnamese from Haiphong and Quong Ninh were involved in the fighting. The night before, about 300 Vietnamese rioted in the camp, and 150 police were called to the camp to restore order Police had searched the camp throughout the night and uncovered 296 homemade weapons, some made from bars of window and bed frames, said Ish Bhagat, a government official responsible for running the detention centers. ``This is an ongoing problem,'' he told government-funded radio. ``As soon as we seize some (weapons), they make others.'' Factional violence has frequently broken out in the crowded and squalid Vietnamese camps in this British colony. Five people died last year in riots. The Vietnamese migrants are considered illegal immigrants unless they can prove they fled persecution. Those who are denied refugee status and have their appeals rejected can volunteer to go home or face forced repatriation. In December, 51 Vietnamese were returned to Vietnam against their will.

DOC.HEAD: Exiled ANC Leaders Meet To Discuss Mandela Role
With PM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: The African National Congress today began a two-day meeting of its top policy-making body that was expected to focus on the future role in the organization of Nelson Mandela. No precise agenda for the closed talks was released, and ANC officials gave no indication whether they expect Mandela to travel from South Africa to attend. The ANC international affairs spokesman, Thabo Mbeki, said the 35-member National Executive Committee will discuss a broad range of issues stemming from the reforms announced by President F.W de Klerk on Feb. 2. De Klerk lifted a 30-ban on the ANC and legalized or lifted restrictions on dozens of other opposition groups. He seeks to negotiate a new constitution that would extend political rights to the black majority but preserve some sort of political guarantees for whites. Mbeki told reporters that the 35-member executive was empowered to make firm decisions without the presence of Mandela, an ANC leader who was released Sunday after 27 years in prison. The ANC has maintained its external headquarters in Zambia for more than two decades. Mbeki said there were no differences within the ANC over whether the group should continue its guerrilla campaign in light of the reforms in South Africa's political life. Senior committee member Joe Slovo said Mandela's leading role in the ANC was undisputed but did not indicate what his future position might be. ``He is one of the prime leaders of the organization. This was his position inside prison and is even more so outside,'' Slovo added. The meeting in Lusaka is expected to endorse the ANC stand on possible negotiations with the Pretoria government. The group says de Klerk has not created a climate for talks because he has not shown a commitment to dismantle apartheid. The ANC has demanded the lifting of all provisions of the state of emergency and the release of all political prisoners as conditions for direct talks.

DOC.HEAD: Princeton Eating Club Votes to Admit Women, 2nd Vote in 1991
DOC.TEXT: One of the two remaining all-male eating clubs at Princeton University has voted to admit women, but two more rounds of voting must be conducted next year before female students can join. The Ivy Club, formed in 1879, voted 51-23 Tuesday to allow women, said Robert Garrett, the club's undergraduate president. Club policy states that two consecutive votes must be held to alter rules. Garrett said the second vote will be next year, followed by a vote by the graduate board, made up of Princeton alumni. The Ivy Club and the Tiger Inn are the only two of the school's 13 private eating establishments that do not admit women. Most juniors and seniors take their meals at the clubs, which are housed in private homes near the campus. Their exclusion of women was challenged in state Supreme Court last week by Princeton graduate Sally Frank, now a faculty member at New York Law School. Ms. Frank, backed by the state attorney general's office and Princeton University, argued that the clubs have a ``symbiotic relationship'' with the university that removes them from protection under the laws governing private organizations. She said they are subject to the state's anti-discrimination laws. Attorneys for the two clubs argued that they are similar to fraternities and sororities and have the right to choose their own members. Ms. Frank said her case and recent picketing by students and faculty put pressure on the Ivy Club. Garrett said members voted as they did ``for different reasons'' and that the club as a whole believes strongly it has a constitutionally protected right of association that lets it determine its own membership.

DOC.HEAD: Catholic Cleric Groups Denounce U.S. Intervention in Panama
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leadership Conference of Women Religious is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Two Catholic leadership organizations jointly denounced U.S. policies in Central America and defended the right of clerics to speak out on moral issues. ``We ... feel compelled by recent months' bloodshed and violence in Central America to speak out against U.S. interventionist policies there,'' said Brother Sean Sammon, president of the Conference of Major Superiors of Men. The joint announcement Tuesday by the men's conference and the Leadership Conference of Women Religious reiterated many of the complaints the Catholic groups have aired in the past over what they called American ``interventionist'' policies in Central America. ``We always have a right and a responsibility to speak out on critical religious and moral issues,'' said Sammon, who made his remarks in a room hung with grisly photographs of slain men, women and children. ``We join with Latin American governments in condemning the U.S. invasion of Panama as a demonstration of naked interventionism ... we lament the deep wound inflicted ... on a free and sovereign nation,'' said Sammon. The two groups represent 123,000 brothers and sisters of Catholic religious orders. ``Our country has funded the debilitating war in El Salvador for more than 10 years, and during that decade 70,000 Salvadorans have lost their lives,'' Sammon said. Sister Helen Marie Burns, president of the women leaders, said, ``We see those lives as simply representatives of the thousands of lives that are being lost and mutilated in the Central American countries.'' ``The murders which frame the decade for us, of the four churchwomen in 1980 and the six Jesuits and two women in 1989, point clearly to the persecution of the church there and the reality of violence and repressions'' against clergy, Sammon said. He said plans were being made to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the March 1980 assassination of Salvadoran Archbishop Oscar Romero.

DOC.HEAD: Drexel Parent Files for Bankruptcy Court Protection
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after the 4th and INSERTS 1 graf after the 9th graf pvs, ``In its...'' to UPDATE with details from bankruptcy court filing, debtors. A longer version moved on financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: The bankruptcy filing by the parent of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. could take years to sort out, but already there is little left of the firm whose junk-bond machine fueled the fast-buck, megamerger 1980s. With most securities firms refusing to trade with Drexel and banks unwilling to lend money to stem its cash crisis, the one-time powerhouse began liquidating its huge bond portfolio even before its board authorized the bankruptcy filing.
