Employees, meanwhile, scrambled to look for jobs in an industry that has been shrinking steadily since the October 1987 stock market crash. Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., parent of the securities company, filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors late Tuesday. Only four years earlier, riding the crest of a takeover boom, Drexel had posted record pretax profits of nearly $1 billion. ``DBL Group currently faces a liquidity crisis and does not have the financial resources to weather this storm without court protection,'' Drexel chief executive Frederick H. Joseph said in bankruptcy court papers obtained today. Joseph blamed the firm's demise largely on ``a downturn in the financial markets.'' He said a slump in the market for commercial paper _ short-term IOUs issued to raise cash _ contracted in 1989 and Drexel was forced to repay $575 million without selling new paper to replenish the supply. ``The burden of meeting these obligations effectively wiped out DBL Group's liquidity, rendering it incapable of meeting other obligations as they matured,'' Joseph said in the papers. The filing showed how quickly confidence can sour on Wall Street, analysts said, and marked the beginning of the end for a firm humbled by criminal entanglements and a plunge in demand for high-yield but risky bonds, a market Drexel created. Guards inspected boxes of personal belongings as employees left the downtown headquarters Tuesday night. Resumes and phone calls from Drexel workers flooded other Wall Street firms. While no formal layoffs were announced, employees considered their departure a foregone conclusion. Drexel brokers roamed the floor of the New York Stock Exchange openly soliciting jobs. Employees were told they would get paid Thursday but there were no guarantees after that. ``People were told the firm at some point is going to wind down,'' a Drexel executive said on condition of anonymity. ``You don't need to draw a picture.'' In its petition for bankruptcy court reorganization, the firm listed liabilities exceeding $3 billion and assets exceeding $3.6 billion. The largest creditor listed is Taiyo Mutual Life of Tokyo, owed $69.7 million. It is followed by Home Capital Services Inc., New York, $42.7 million; Banque Indosuez Paris, $30.5 million; Sumitomo Life Insurance Company, Tokyo, and the state of California's retirement system, $25 million. Fourteen of the top 20 creditors are foreign-owned companies. The filing affects only the parent company, not the securities subsidiary. Broker-dealers are ineligible for Chapter 11 reorganization under federal bankruptcy law. Nevertheless, with confidence shattered, analysts expect Drexel will liquidate its remaining broker-dealer holdings. Drexel immediately began dismantling its securities operations Tuesday, starting to liquidate billions of dollars worth of goverment bonds and mortgage-backed securities, tens of millions in junk bonds and other financial instruments. Drexel also negotiated the transfer of customer brokerage accounts to Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co.; withdrew as a market maker in 228 over-the-counter stocks; and put entire business units up for sale. The parent company said it defaulted Tuesday on about $100 million in loans and a lack of cash threatened other defaults. Drexel was turned down for bank financing that it sought to avert the filing. The downfall of Drexel, which was founded in 1838 in Philadelphia by a portrait painter named Francis Drexel, has been as startling as its recent recent rise, mirroring the career of junk-bond genius Michael Milken. Milken is credited with single-handedly creating and controlling the market for low-rated debt securities and using them to finance billions of dollars in hostile takeovers. The high-flying firm made gargantuan profits in its heyday _ almost $1 billion before taxes in 1986 _ and paid its employees accordingly. Milken personally made more than $1 billion from 1983-87. Drexel's attitude was embodied by brash letters telling clients it was ``highly confident'' it could raise hundreds of millions of dollars during corporate takeover battles, and by its lavish annual junk-bond conference known as the ``Predators' Ball.'' But the luster began fading in 1986 when Drexel investment banker Dennis Levine was arrested on insider-trading charges. The investigation later snared arbitrager Ivan F. Boesky, Drexel, other employees and an investment firm it did business with, Princeton-Newport Partners. Drexel in late 1988 agreed to plead guilty to six felonies and pay $650 million in fines and penalties. Milken was indicted last year on 98 counts of fraud and racketeering and has since left the firm. Some Wall Street professionals _ not all Drexel backers _ maintain the firm wrote its own epitaph when it settled with the government to forestall a possible racketeering indictment and agreed to let go of Milken, which left the $200 billion junk-bond market without a leader. The junk market collapsed last fall as several big companies staggered under their debt burden. The value of Drexel's huge debt portfolio fell with the market. In the end, some observers see Drexel's junk bonds as the emperor's new clothes of big business in the 1980s. ``Milken found a void and he filled it,'' said Muriel Siebert, a former banking regulator who runs a small New York brokerage. ``Unfortunately, it got out of hand. They were making too much money. We're seeing the unraveling of the extreme excesses of money.''

DOC.HEAD: Controversial Activist Sharpton Jailed, Then Sprung
DOC.TEXT: Activist Al Sharpton spent a few hours in jail for his role in a 1987 protest that stalled city subways but was released early today pending an appeal of his conviction. Brooklyn Criminal Judge Albert Koch on Tuesday found Sharpton and two other black activists guilty of obstruction of governmental administration, criminal trespass and disorderly conduct. He ordered them jailed immediately for 45 days. The three had faced up to six months in jail. ``Crack dealers will walk out of this courthouse today; muggers and robbers will walk out of this building today, and we will go to jail,'' Sharpton told the judge after the sentencing. ``Just give me a glass of water each day.'' Later Tuesday Sharpton's lawyer, Alton Maddox, obtained a stay of his client's sentence from the Appellate Division pending appeal, said Patrick Clark, spokesman for the Brooklyn district attorney's office. Sharpton, the Rev. Timothy Mitchell and Charles Barron were held in protective custody in the hospital at the Rikers Island jail until their release early today, said Ruby Ryles, a spokeswoman for the city Correction Department. The charges stem from the Dec. 21, 1987, ``Day of Outrage'' protest against racism in the city. Sharpton and more than 70 others were arrested when they disrupted subway service in Brooklyn during the evening rush hour by jumping on tracks, pulling emergency cords and holding subway doors open. Charges were dropped against most participants. Sharpton faces similar charges for a 1988 protest when demonstrators blocked traffic on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway.

DOC.HEAD: Inmate Stable After Being Force-Fed
Retransmitting to fix cycle designator.
DOC.TEXT: The condition of a prisoner on an 11-month hunger strike has stabilized as doctors for the second straight day force-fed him a liquid protein diet, one of inmate's attorneys said. Doctors at Duane Waters Hospital next to State Prison of Southern Michigan in Jackson had feared inmate Rene Acuna's heart might suddenly fail unless he received nourishment other than his diet of water and coffee laced with sugar. Paul Denenfeld, legal director for the Michigan chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union, said Acuna, 37, of Detroit, put up no resistance Tuesday to the second day of feeding through a nasal tube. ``The doctor called me late yesterday afternoon and indicated it would still be a couple of weeks before we could anticipate an upswing in his health,'' said Denefeld, who expressed optimism for Acuna's recovery. The Cuban immigrant went on the strike because he said God wants him to prove he is innocent of his conviction on drug charges. The Michigan Court of Appeals overturned for lack of evidence Acuna's convictions on conspiring to traffic more than two pounds of cocaine in August 1988. The convictions carried sentences of mandatory life in prison without parole. Prosecutors said he was a lookout for drug dealers, but Acuna has insisted the all-white jury convicted him solely because he happened to be in a white neighborhood when other Hispanics sold drugs to undercover agents. Acuna, a self-employed handyman and mechanic, is unable to post the $100,000 appeal bond while the prosecution asks the Michigan Supreme Court to overturn the dismissal of the convictions. A campaign has raised $150 toward the $10,000 cash needed to obtain the bond, said Carolyn Peyser, a Birmingham nurse collecting the funds. Acuna has said he won't eat until he is able to return to Anna Sossa, his longtime companion, and his two daughters. His condition worsened last week when he began refusing liquids to protest the setting of the appeal bond. His weight has dropped from 180 pounds to just over 100 pounds, Denenfeld said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Chief of American Brands Dead At 71
DOC.TEXT: Robert Karl Heimann, chief executive of Greenwich-based American Brands Inc. for four years, has died at age 71. Heimann, who lived in Riverside, died Sunday of what was described only as natural causes at Greenwich Hospital. He served as chairman and chief executive of American Brands from 1977 until his retirement in 1980. He had been chairman since 1973. As head of American Brands, Heimann led the company in acquiring Gallagher Ltd., now the largest tobacco company in Britain. The company also diversified into such fields as foods, alcoholic beverages and fruit juices. Earlier in his career, Heimann worked in securities and publishing, serving as managing editor and executive editor of Forbes magazine from 1949 to 1953. He also was an editor at Nation's Heritage. Heimann joined American Brands in 1954 when it was the American Tobacco Co. He was assistant to the president from 1961 to 1964 and produced studies that tried to show a correlation between the stress of urban living and lung cancer. He was named vice president for marketing and public relations in 1964, when American Tobacco stopped sponsoring sports events on radio and television ``to avoid any appearance of appealing to young people,'' he said at the time. Heimann is survived by a daughter, a son and a sister. A private funeral was held Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Education Committee Kills Governor's Drug-Education Bill
DOC.TEXT: The Nebraska Legislature's Education Committee has killed a bill that would have punished state college and university students for drug convictions. The bill called for students convicted of first-offense drug violations to take a rehabilitation course. A subsequent offense would have brought suspension from school and a cut-off of financial aid. The committee voted 5-1 to kill the bill Tuesday on a motion from state Sen. David Bernard-Stevens. ``I agree that we need to address the problem,'' Bernard-Stevens. ``We need to do more and more to stop abuse in its beginning. One of the keys is an education.'' The suspension for second offense wouldn't mean they can't attend another school, but they would have to use their own money, said the sponsor, state Sen. Elroy Hefner. Bernard-Stevens took issue with that, noting that the bill would hit the poor hardest.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules State Can Tax Airline for Drinks Served in Wisconsin Airspace
DOC.TEXT: The state may collect its 5 percent sales tax from an airline for drinks sold while its jets flew over Wisconsin, a judge has ruled. Dane County Circuit Judge James Boll ordered Tuesday that Republic Airlines Inc. pay Wisconsin $90,622 in overdue sales tax for drinks consumed on its flights over the state between 1981-84. Boll rejected Republic's argument that a law authorizing a sales tax on drinks consumed ``in this state'' did not mean ``over this state.'' The judge ruled the state had the right to fairly impose its sale tax on flights overhead for any airline that had some definite link to the state _ such as offices based in Wisconsin or incorporation within the state. Republic, with its numerous facilities in Wisconsin, received substantial benefits from the state, said State Revenue Secretary Mark Bugher. He declined to say whether other airlines might be similarly taxed. ``Generally, we would not be looking to reach out and touch every airline that touches the state's atmosphere,'' Bugher said. ``If Japan Airlines, for instance, happens to fly over the northern reaches of Wisconsin, it wouldn't be our policy to tax.'' Republic Airlines, which was purchased in the mid-1980s by Northwest Airlines Inc., contended that applying the state sales tax to flights violated the due process clause of the U.S. Constitution. Republic was engaged in interstate transportation, with offices in Minneapolis, Minn., when the state sought to collect the $90,622. The airline appealed an order of the Wisconsin Tax Appeals Commission that it owed the tax, leading to the court case. Before it was bought out, Republic maintained offices in Wisconsin, had equipment and personnel located at airports in the state and flew regularly scheduled flights into and out of Wisconsin cities. Republic said it did not keep records of the location of its aircraft when it sold drinks, particularly whether the aircraft was in Wisconsin's airspace or above another state. Republic attorney Frederic Brouner said he did not know whether Northwest Airlines would appeal. Brouner said Wisconsin's attempt to collect on the tax after the sale was ``particularly onerous'' because it was impossible for the vendor to tax the consumer at the point of sale.

DOC.HEAD: New Hampshire Legislature Rejects Life at Conception Bill
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers in the state House rejected two anti-abortion measures before passing a bill allowing abortions until the 25th week of pregnancy, a defeat for anti-abortion advocates. The 212-148 vote Tuesday on the measure allowing second-trimester abortions fell short of the two-thirds that would be needed to override Gov. Judd Gregg's promised veto. The measure must pass the Senate before it reaches Gregg, something it is not likely to do before the Legislature begins a two-week break Friday. By a much wider margin, the House rejected a bill that would declare that life begins at conception and a bill that would bar the use of public money, employees or facilities to assist or perform abortions. During Tuesday's passionate debate on the abortion-regulating bill, anti-abortion House members pleaded with their colleagues to think of the unborn. ``We are considering a law that would permit the execution of the unborn at any time ... for any reason,'' said Rep. Kathleen Hoelzel. Rep. Matthew Sochalski said the measure's restrictions could be abused. He said the measure's specification that the mother's life or health could be considered when allowing abortions after the 25th week could let women claim their mental health is endangered by an otherwise routine pregnancy. But supporters of the measure, which follows guidelines for legalizing abortion set down in the Supreme Court's 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision, said their peers should remember that abortion is a step not taken lightly. ``Part of living in a free society is allowing people to make decisions in their private lives that we as individuals do not agree with,'' said Rep. Thomas Gage, whose Judiciary Committee recommended the bill be passed.

DOC.HEAD: Economists See Bush Proposal Worsening Deficit
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's proposed capital-gains tax cut would worsen the federal budget deficit by $11.4 billion over the next five years and continue to lose revenues far into the future, congressional economists said today. The estimate by the staff of the Joint Committee on Taxation disagrees markedly with one by the Treasury Department, which says the tax cut would actually boost revenues by $12.5 billion over five years. The two estimates agree that the capital-gains reduction would raise tax collections this year and next. The congressional estimate puts the 1990-91 gain at $3.9 billion; the administration forecast is for a $5.4 billion increase. Capital gains are profits from the sale of stock and other investments. The realization, or cashing in, of such profits grows with the overall economy, a report by the congressional tax staff said. ``Consequently, if the economy continues to grow in years beyond 1995, we would predict the revenue losses in those years would exceed the revenue loss for 1995, and would grow in magnitude each year thereafter,'' the report said. The disagreement over effects of a capital-gains tax cut is a long-running one. In essence, the Treasury traditionally has contended that a reduction would so spur investment that economic growth would increase tax collections _ even if the rate of tax were lowered. Congressional experts rejected those arguments. The staff report estimated that 66.1 percent of the benefits of a capital-gains reduction would go to those with total incomes of $200,000 and more. Those making $100,000 and more would reap 83.1 percent of the tax reduction, it said. People with incomes under $20,000 would receive 0.4 percent of the benefit. The estimated 638,000 people at that income level who would receive any of the benefit would get tax cuts averaging $88, the report said. The tax cut would benefit 681,000 people making more than $200,000 a year; their tax cut would average $15,454. Under current law, capital gains are fully taxed at the same rates as wages and other income. When fully in effect, Bush's proposal would tax at those rates only 70 percent of the profits from the sale of assets owned three years or more. Property owned for more than a year but less than three would qualify for a lesser benefit.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Challenge U.S. During Visit To Strategic Air Command
DOC.TEXT: Members of the Supreme Soviet visiting the Strategic Air Command said they would never be the first to use nuclear weapons and challenged the United States to make a similar pledge. During the visit Tuesday, which SAC officials believed was the first by members of the Soviet legislative body, the Soviets also questioned conclusions of an SAC report showing Soviet military superiority. SAC Commander Gen. John T. Chain Jr. said he was pleased by the ``healthy dialogue,'' but criticized the first-strike pledge. ``A pledge is an intriguing thing,'' Chain said. ``But it is meaningless. It is nice rhetoric, but meaningless.'' ``Mr. Gorbachev may be the nicest guy in the world, and tomorrow Stalin the Second might take power in the Soviet Union,'' Chain said. ``It is my job to assess capabilities, and to prevent an attack.'' All the 10 Supreme Soviet members saw of SAC were the outside of the headquarters building and an auditorium where they were given a briefing on relative U.S.-Soviet strategic force capability. The briefing by Maj. Dave Moore concluded that Soviet military spending and modernization required the United States to make efforts to improve its strategic forces. ``We were taken aback by the statement made by the major,'' said Vitaliy M. Shabonov, a member of the Supreme Soviet and deputy minister of defense. ``It is not a good thing to try to educate us on this matter.'' After the Soviets left, Chain defended the information presented by Moore. ``We didn't give them any information that can't be backed up with pictures,'' Chain said. The Soviets were accompanied by U.S. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, and U.S. Rep. Peter Hoagland, D-Neb. The visiting Soviets are members of the Defense and State Security Committee of the Supreme Soviet. They came to the base near Omaha at the invitation of Aspin's committee. Shabonov said U.S.-Soviet military discussions should focus on intentions rather than capabilities alone. ``I have learned that our views of world stability are similar,'' Shabonov said. ``And the world is looking to us to cooperate.'' ``It is only natural that a strategy of fear and intimidation concerns us very much,'' Shabonov said. He concluded that while the number of Soviet strategic nuclear weapons would go down, they would continue to be modernized. ``You were the first to invent atomic weapons,'' said Vladimir L. Lapygin, chairman of the Supreme Soviet Committee on Defense and State Security. ``We simply had to catch up. You started to develop the Minuteman and ICBMs. I would like to underline that what we are doing all the time is trying to catch up to you.'' ``We would like to take a mutual pledge that neither side will be the first to use nuclear weapons,'' Lapygin said. The visit was part of a 12-day tour of U.S. military installations and scientific facilities that began Feb. 7, SAC officials said. The tour also includes stops at Los Alamos National Laboratories, Kennedy Space Center, North American Air Defense Command and Minuteman missile and B-1B facilities at Ellsworth, S.D., Army Armored Forces, the F-16 fighter plant at Fort Worth, Texas, and Navy, Marine and Air Force bases on both coasts.

DOC.HEAD: Texaco Announces $1 Million Program to Plant Trees
DOC.TEXT: Texaco Inc., one of the nation's oil giants, announced today a $1 million program to plant trees in three cities this spring to kick off private sector involvement in President Bush's ``America the Beautiful'' program. James W. Kinnear, Texaco president, said the tree money will be shared in Denver, Houston and New Orleans, where the company has extensive operations. Kinnear told a news conference at the Agriculture Department that the plantings will be done by Texaco volunteers and that he expected around 50,000 trees would be set out in the three cities. The trees, he said, will be ``big enough to make a difference this decade.'' Both Kinnear and Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter expressed hope that Texaco's example would lead others in the three cities and elsewhere to chip in with their own efforts. Yeutter said existing programs in USDA can accomplish a lot in rural areas but that a special effort is needed in the cities. Rep. Lindy Boggs, D-La., said thousands of trees in New Orleans have been ravaged by pests and that Texaco's program is desperately needed. The ``America the Beautiful'' project was included in Bush's budget proposals for fiscal 1991 to help protect, conserve and enhance the nation's natural resources. It included the planting of one billion trees per year. One argument in favor of more trees is their ability in the growth process to remove carbon dioxide and certain impurities from the atmosphere, and release oxygen as a byproduct.

DOC.HEAD: `Driving Miss Daisy' Leads Academy Award Nominations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from Cruise, Kovic and Pearson, picking up 8th graf pvs, ``Isabelle Adjani...'' SUBS 20th graf, ``Screenplay adaptation...'' to DELETE now redundant first reference to Kovic.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto Staffing
DOC.TEXT: ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' the bittersweet story of a contrary Southern lady and her wise old chauffeur, led Academy Award nominations today with nine, followed by the Vietnam film ``Born on the Fourth of July'' with eight. ``Glory,'' the epic of black soldiers in the Civil War, and ``My Left Foot,'' the story of an Irish cerebral palsy victim, followed with five nominations apiece. ``Driving Miss Daisy'' earned nominations for best picture, and for acting by Morgan Freeman, Jessica Tandy and Dan Aykroyd, but suprisingly not for its director, Bruce Beresford. ``Born on the Fourth of July'' scored for best picture, Tom Cruise's starring performance, and the direction by Oliver Stone, who also shared a screenwriting nomination with Ron Kovic, the disabled veteran-activist whose story the film portrays. ``Everyone worked very hard on this film, not only making it but trying to get it made,'' Cruise said in a statement from the Daytona, Fla., location of his latest movie. Kovic, about to board a plane in New York, called his nomination ``Truly one of the happiest and most triumphant moments of my life.'' The Academy voters demonstrated selectivity by nominating for best actor Kenneth Branagh of ``Henry V'' and Robin Williams of ``Dead Poets Society.'' Both have been little mentioned in pre-nomination predictions. Along with Freeman and Cruise, Daniel Day-Lewis of ``My Left Foot'' also was nominated for best actor. ``My Left Foot'' producer Daniel Pearson said Day-Lewis ran out in the street when he heard the news at his agent Julian Belfrage's office: ``He's so thrilled, he's just run out of the building. At the moment, it's madness in here.'' Isabelle Adjani of ``Camille Claudel'' was a surprise nominee for best actress. Other nominees: Pauline Collins, ``Shirley Valentine''; Jessica Lange, ``Music Box''; Michelle Pfeiffer, ``The Fabulous Baker Boys''; and Miss Tandy. Belying the legend that films released late in the year are favored in the Oscars, the voters nominated ``Field of Dreams,'' released April 21, and ``Dead Poets Society,'' released June 2, for best picture of 1989. Other nominees for best picture: ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' ``Driving Miss Daisy'' and ``My Left Foot.'' Among the curiosities in today's nominations: No major honors for the year's top box-office money maker, ``Batman,'' which earned $251.2 million in 1989. There were no nominations at all for the critically acclaimed ``Drugstore Cowboy.'' ``My Left Foot'' director Jim Sheridan and ``Henry V'' director were nominated for their directorial debuts, a feat that has led to only four Oscars. Branagh, Freeman and Miss Collins were nominated for roles they created on the stage; 19 Oscars have been won by actors repeating theater roles. Landau and Miss Pfeiffer are the only repeat nominees from last year. Marlon Brando, who won an Oscar for ``On the Waterfront'' and rejected one for ``The Godfather,'' was nominated for supporting actor for his brief role as a liberal South African lawyer in ``A Dry White Season.'' Others named for supporting actor: Danny Aiello, ``Do the Right Thing''; Aykroyd, ``Driving Miss Daisy''; Martin Landau, ``Crimes and Misdemeanors''; Denzel Washington, ``Glory.'' For supporting actress: Brenda Fricker, ``My Left Foot''; Anjelica Huston, ``Enemies, A Love Story''; Lena Olin, ``Enemies, A Love Story''; Julia Roberts, `` Steel Magnolias''; Diane Wiest, ``Parenthood.'' For best direction: Along with Branagh, Sheridan and Stone; Woody Allen, ``Crimes and Misdemeanors''; Peter Weir, ``Dead Poets Society''; and Jim Sheridan, ``My Left Foot.'' Best foreign language film: ``Camille Claudel,'' France; ``Cinema Paradiso,'' Italy; ``Jesus of Montreal,'' Canada; ``Santiago, the Story of His New Life,'' Puerto Rico; ``Waltzing Regitze,'' Denmark. Original screenplay: Allen, ``Crimes and Misdemeanors''; Tom Schulman, ``Dead Poets Society''; Spike Lee, ``Do the Right Thing''; Steven Soderbergh, ``sex, lies and videotape''; Nora Ephron, ``When Harry Met Sally...'' Screenplay adaptation (from another medium): Stone and Kovic, ``Born on the Fourth of July''; Alfred Uhry, ``Driving Miss Daisy''; Roger L. Simon and Paul Mazursky, ``Enemies, A Love Story''; Phil Alden Robinson, ``Field of Dreams''; Jim Sheridan and Shane Connaughton, ``My Left Foot.'' Filmmaker Michael Moore had as much trouble meeting Oscar as he did catching General Motors president Roger Smith in his documentary ``Roger and Me.'' The film failed to win a nomination in the documentary feature category. Recent weeks have brought criticism of Moore's film for its faulty juxtaposition of time elements and its entertainment values at the expense of accuracy. The nominees for original song: ``After All'' from ``Chances Are''; ``The Girl Who Used to be Me'' from ``Shirley Valentine''; ``I Love to See You Smile'' from ``Parenthood''; ``Kiss the Girl'' from ``The Little Mermaid''; ``Under the Sea'' from ``The Little Mermaid.''

In awards already handed out, the New York Film Critics voted ``My Left Foot'' as the best film of 1989. ``Enemies, A Love Story'' won for best director, and ``Drugstore Cowboy'' was awarded the best screenplay prize by the New York reviewers. Film critics in Los Angeles awarded their best film and best director trophies to ``Do the Right Thing,'' with best screenplay to ``Drugstore Cowboy.'' ``Roger & Me'' was named best documentary by the Los Angeles and New York critics' organizations. The National Society of Film Critics chose ``Drugstore Cowboy'' as the best film of the past year and the best directed. The Oscar nominations represent judgment by filmmakers' peers. Each of the Academy's branches votes for its own achievements _ actors nominate actors, directors nominate directors, etc. _ and all members vote for best picture. Categories such a foreign-language film, documentaries and shorts are nominated by committees. Screenings of all nominees start Friday at the Academy's Samuel Goldwyn Theater, and the polls close March 10. The awards ceremony will be held March 26 and broadcast nationally on ABC-TV. After two traffic-plagued years at the Shrine Auditorium, the awards are returning to the Los Angeles Music Center, which presents a big problem for the Academy. The Shrine accommodated 5,800 while the Music Center holds only 2,850. ``Tickets are at a great premium,'' said Academy spokesman Bob Werden. ``A lot of feelings are going to be hurt.'' The 62nd-annual show's producer, Gilbert Cates, has promised to avoid last year's plodding pace and tasteless production numbers, one of which included Rob Lowe and a ``Snow White'' lookalike. The telecast will return to the one-man emcee format, with quick-witted Billy Crystal doing the honors.

DOC.HEAD: Passenger Jet Crashes In South, 91 Reported Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5th graf, `One airline...' to UPDATE with 17 foreigners, including two Americans, reportedly aboard the flight. Pickup 6th, `A spokesman...'
DOC.TEXT: An Indian Airlines jet with 146 people aboard crashed and burst into flames while attempting to land at a southern Indian airport today and 91 people were killed, authorities said. The Airbus 320 crashed at 1 p.m. while on final approach to the runway at Bangalore airport, airline and airport officials said. ``The crash occurred before the plane touched the runway, and it caught fire as soon as it crashed,'' said P.S. Shetty, airport manager in Bombay, where the hourlong flight had originated. Airline officials said the plane, which was an hour behind schedule, carried 139 passengers and a crew of seven. One airline official said 17 foreigners were believed to be on the flight to Bangalore, one of India's richest cities and the center of the country's high-tech and research centers. They foreigners included a Frenchman, two Canadians, two Americans, three Japanese and a Hong Kong resident, all who survived, said the spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity. A spokesman for the airline in New Delhi reported earlier that at least 135 people were killed. But airport officials in Bombay and doctors at hospitals where the victims were taken said 55 people survived the crash and were being treated for broken bones and burns. ``They're alive. That's all I can say,'' said one doctor who declined to give his name. News reports said the plane apparently undershot the runway by about 50 yards. The Press Trust of India said the plane struck a fence or an embankment as it was descending to the runway. Local villagers rushed out of their huts and across the field littered with baggage and debris toward the flaming wreckage. Local police were called to try to keep them away. Airline officials did not know what caused the crash, but they said weather was not a factor. The jet was acquired by the nation's government-run domestic carrier about three months ago for $38 million. After Indian Airlines announced it was adding 31 Airbus 320s to its aging fleet of Boeing, Fokker and Avro planes, news reports criticized the airline for failing to adequately train pilots to fly the sophisticated aircraft. The carrier was also criticized for failing to provide adequate hangar space to house and maintain the planes. The last Indian Airlines crash occurred Oct. 19, 1988, when a Boeing 737 crashed on final approach to an airport in the western city of Ahmedabad, killing 133 of the 135 people on board. An investigation later blamed pilot error for the accident, the worst in the airline's 26-year history. On the same day, a Fokker propeller-driven plane operated by the other domestic carrier, Vayudoot, slammed into the side of a mountain during a fierce rainstorm. All 34 people on board died. Indian Airlines, the major domestic carrier, flies to 73 cities nationwide and to nine nearby countries. It has come under criticism for allegedly failing to maintain pre-flight safety procedures on its fleet and to adequately supervise its pilots. Delays in flight schedules also are endemic. Air India, also owned by the government, is the country's international carrier. The A320, built by the European consortium Airbus Industrie, is the first civilian airliner equipped with a fully computerized flight control system, which the manufacturer says permits safer, electronically controlled flight. Developed at a cost of nearly $2 billion, the A320 was certified for flight on Feb. 26, 1988, and went into service in April 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Pilot Who Died Ejected Because Jet Was On Fire
DOC.TEXT: A Marine pilot killed during a training exercise bailed out of his jet because it was on fire, an official said. A second aviator ejected safely from another plane during the three-plane exercise Monday when he mistakenly thought his craft was ablaze, said Capt. Kevin Murphy. The exercise over the Air-Ground Combat Center, 125 miles east of Los Angeles, involved Marines from the 2nd Marine Aircraft Wing in Cherry Point, N.C., Murphy said. The pilot who died, Capt. Thomas Kolb, 28, of San Diego ejected from his single-seat AV-8B Harrier attack jet after another pilot radioed him that his plane was on fire, said Murphy. The Harrier crashed in a remote area and Kolb was taken to Naval Hospital, where he died nearly two hours later, he said. The aerial observer in a Marine OV-10 Bronco reconnaissance plane ejected when he mistakenly thought the radio warning to Kolb was for him, Murphy said. The observer, Capt. Jeffrey P. Schade of Southhold, N.Y., was treated and released, Murphy said. Murphy said Marine investigators were trying to determine the cause of the fire in Kolb's jet and why he died in the ejection.

DOC.HEAD: Satellites Launched to Test Plan for Destroying Missiles With Space Mirrors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with rocket launched, other details; no pickup.
DOC.HEAD: Laserphoto covering
DOC.TEXT: Two ``Star Wars'' satellites rocketed into space Wednesday to test a plan to destroy enemy missiles by bouncing deadly laser beams off orbiting mirrors. A mirror on one of the satellites was designed to reflect lasers fired from a mountaintop in Hawaii back to a ground target to assess the accuracy of a system for intercepting ballistic missiles. Sensors on the second payload were to measure laser strikes in a test aimed at correcting laser distortions caused by dust, moisture and gases as the beam shoots through the atmosphere. ``These are key technologies for developing a ground-based laser system; if we get rid of the distortion in the atmosphere and get good accuracy with the laser coming off a mirror, it is a major step in our program to develop directed-energy weapons,'' said Air Force Col. William Browning, one of the project managers. The satellites were carried aloft by a 12-story Delta rocket that roared off its launch pad right on time at 11:15 a.m. ``The tracking chart shows the vehicle right down the middle of the track; it's right on target,'' launch commentator Ray Adams reported minutes after liftoff. Success of the mission could help preserve much of the $4.5 billion that President Bush has requested for research in budget year 1991 for the program formally known as the Strategic Defense Initiative. Some members of Congress want to cut deeply into that amount. The beam-bouncing satellite, called Relay Mirror Experiment, carried a 24-inch diameter mirror designed to point a laser beam with an error of less than 57 millionths of a degree. The experiment will use two ground stations on Maui, Hawaii. One is at the Air Force Maui Optical Station, located on the summit of Mount Haleakala. The second is about 12 miles away, at the base of the mountain. Both ground stations will aim low-powered laser beams simultaneously at the 2,300-pound satellite, orbiting 270 miles up. RME will use those two beams as signals to orient its mirror. When the mountaintop station aims another beam at the satellite, the beam should reflect off the mirror and strike a sensor target at the second station. The tests, scheduled to start in about two weeks, were scheduled to last about eight months, with RME passing within range of the Hawaii stations at least once a day. The companion satellite is a 3,175-pound payload called LACE, for Low-power Atmospheric Compensation Experiment. Its principal instrument is a package of 210 laser-sensitive sensors packed into a square measuring 13 feet on each side. The Mount Haleakala laser to be used on LACE is equipped with a special flexible mirror designed to pre-distort the laser beam on Earth in such a way that the expected atmospheric disturbances will erase the distortion. The result should be a sharp and powerful beam by the time it reaches LACE orbiting 340 miles high. Previous laser tests using targets on satellites and on space shuttles have established a pattern for the type of distortion the atmosphere causes. LACE also carries an experiment to acquire and track the exhaust plumes of rockets in a test to determine which wavelengths are most useful in detecting these plumes. Another experiment will measure neutron levels in space in a test designed to help develop a means of distinquishing between enemy warheads and decoys. The LACE experiments are expected to start in about 60 days and continue for 30 months.

DOC.HEAD: White House Denounces Kidnappings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, editing throughout
DOC.TEXT: The White House today denounced the kidnapping of two Americans in Colombia to protest President Bush's planned visit, saying it ``cannot allow threats of terrorism to influence its policies or its activities.'' Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush ``shares the concern of all Americans about the kidnapping of these U.S. citizens'' and would cooperate with Colombian officials to help ``in any way deemed appropriate to help resolve this situation.'' Fitzwater also sought to minimize reports that Bush might use the occasion of the drug summit to propose a ``radar net'' off Colombia using U.S. warships to help track cocaine-carrying aircraft. ``I don't expect him'' to bring it up at the drug conference unless Colombia or other Latin American countries bring the subject up first, Fitzwater said. The spokesman's comments came on the eve of Bush's day-long attendance at a four-nation drug summit in Cartagena, a resort city on the northern coast of Colombia. Colombian authorities on Tuesday reported that leftist guerrillas had kidnapped two Americans in the drug capital of Medellin, Colombia, to protest Bush's visit. They were identified as David Kent, a teacher from Indianapolis, and James Donnelly, employed by a company that manufactures hydraulic equipment. Although there had been reports that Donnelly had been released, Fitzwater said today, ``We believe those reports are inacurrate.'' He said the U.S. embassy had been in touch with members of Donnelly's family. Fitzwater said Donnelly was kidnapped Monday night, but his wife was ordered not to report the kidnapping until Tuesday. ``The U.S. government cannot allow threats of terrorism to influence its policies or its activities,'' Fitzwater said. Fitzwater said little was known about the group, calling itself ``the National Liberation Army,'' which claims responsibility for the kidnappings, other than reports that it somehow has links with Cuba. ``We trust Colombian authorities will pursue this matter and secure the release of Mr. Kent and Mr. Donnelly as soon as possible,'' Fitzwater said. Meanwhile, the spokesman seemed to be backtracking from comments of the day before by National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft that he expected Bush would discuss a proposed ``radar net'' at the Cartagena summit. Acknowledging extreme sensitivies in Latin American toward any hint of a U.S. military role in the region, Fitzwater said some senior administration officials were concerned that news accounts of Scowcroft's remarks might not be well received by Colombian officials. Colombia objected strenuously to earlier reports that the United States was considering a naval ``blockade.'' Fitzwater said today that any plans for using U.S. forces, including the ``radar net'' proposal, should be deemed ``on the shelf'' unless Colombia or other drug-producing nations ask for specific U.S. help. ``We want to be able to persuade these countries we can be helpful _ at their request,'' Fitzwater said. The spokesman also held out the prospect that the administration would support some package of trade aid or concessions to help promote alternate crops in Colombia, including flowers and coffee. Colombian officials have protested that U.S. trade policies have undercut these exports at the very time American officials are seeking to curb cocaine production and persuade farmers in Andean nations to switch to other crops. Fitzwater said it was unlikely much progress would be made on this dispute at Thursday's meeting, but ``this is an area for discussion'' down the road. Colombian authorities say some 5,000 security agents will be in Cartagena to protect the four presidents. And two Amerrican warships have been deployed in the Caribbean, along with a Colombian escort ship. The U.S. vessels are the USS Nassau, an 820-foot amphibious assault ship which carries helicopters and a Marine landing team, and the USS Sampson, a 437-foot destroyer armed with missiles and two five-inch guns. Scowcroft acknowledged risks are involved in the trip. ``Of course, it's an unusual situation because there are in Colombia these guerrilla bands, terrorist bands with access to funds to purchase on the open market any kinds of arms, and so naturally there are unusual circumstances,'' Scowcroft said Tuesday at a White House briefing. ``But we think they're adequately taken care of,'' he added. The main purpose of Bush's attendance at the summit is a show of U.S. support for drug-fighting efforts in the three Andean drug-producing nations, plus the expected issuance of a joint communique vowing an increased effort to fight the problem.

DOC.HEAD: Sources Say U.S., Exxon Talking Plea Bargain in Alaska Spill
DOC.TEXT: Exxon Corp. and the Justice Department are conducting plea negotiations over possible criminal charges stemming from last year's massive Exxon Valdez oil tanker spill, government sources said today. Negotiations between government and Exxon lawyers are focusing on a possible plea bargain to settle environmental criminal charges that could be brought, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Justice Department spokeswoman Deborah Burstion-Wade confirmed discussions between department lawyers and Exxon, but she declined to say if they involved negotiations over possible criminal charges. Sources said prosecutors from the environmental crimes section of the department's Land and Natural Resources Division were participating in the negotiations. A plea bargain involving criminal charges could be an outcome of those discussions, said the sources. A settlement could come in the next month, one source said. The negotiations were first reported in today's editions of The Wall Street Journal. Company spokesman Bill Smith said Exxon had no immediate comment on the report. The nation's worst oil spill occurred last March when the 987-foot tanker Exxon Valdez ran aground on a reef along Alaska's southern coast, spilling more than 10 million gallons of North Slope crude. The tanker's captain, Joseph Hazelwood, is on trial in state court in Anchorage on charges of criminal mischief, reckless endangerment and operating a vessel while intoxicated. He faces a maximum sentence of seven years and three months in prison and possible fines totaling $61,000 if convicted on all counts. The Journal also reported that separate negotiations are under way over creation of a $500 million fund to be bankrolled by Exxon to complete the cleanup of the oil spill and restore the Alaska coastline.

DOC.HEAD: Schools Reopen as Protests Continue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with schools quiet today; picking up 8th graf pvs, `Roussell was....'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MY1, MY2
DOC.TEXT: Authorities reported no problems today as students filed into Selma's public schools amid heavy security for a second day after classes were shut down for a week by a racial protest. ``Everybody got in peaceably,'' said National Guard Sgt. Norman Arnold. Gov. Guy Hunt ordered 200 National Guardsmen into Selma on Tuesday to help local police and state troopers protect students at the nine public schools that had been closed since last Wednesday. Two others closed a day earlier. ``This is the first time troopers have been used to ensure that whites could go to school,'' said Jamie Wallace, executive director of the Selma chamber of commerce. The level of protest sparked by the dismissal of superintendent Norward Roussell seemed to recede from past days when demonstrators thronged City Hall, rekindling memories of civil rights marches in Selma in 1965. There were no immediate figures on today's attendance. No student protesters showed up at Selma High School when classes began. On Tuesday, about 150 black student protesters boycotted the high school and marched around the flagpole before the opening bell, chanting ``Shut 'em down! No school!'' At City Hall, about two dozen protesters continued a sit-in for a seventh day. Outside, some protesters carried placards saying ``Equality! Education!'' ``Both black and white parents seriously want their children back in schools,'' said Roussell, in announcing Tuesday's absenteeism rate was below the 30 percent that had been expected. About 77 percent of the school system's 5,971 students returned to classes Tuesday, he said. Roussell was restored last week but protesters want his contract to be extended another three years. He had earlier been dismissed by the majority white school board. Selma's population is 52 percent black. Roussell said he doubted the conflict will end ``until there is some movement on my contract,'' which expires in June. His supporters say he was dismissed because of race and his efforts to place blacks in higher learning levels. Detractors said the decision was made because Roussell lacked the adequate managerial skills. He has held the $80,000 post for 2{ years. ``It saddens me that children have to be pulled into a political and racial conflict that should have been solved years ago, after the Edmund Pettus Bridge,'' Roussell said, referring to the Selma bridge where civil rights marchers were clubbed by state troopers in 1965. Police Chief Melvin Summerlin said a 16-year-old white student reported he was beaten by three blacks with a brick and sticks as he walked alone from the high school's agriculture center to the main building about three hours after classes resumed. Summerlin said the teen-ager, who was not seriously injured, indicated his assailants were older than students. He said the teen-ager told officers the men said they were beating him because he was white. The school system is about 70 percent black, and some white parents have moved their children to private schools or other systems during the past week. Roussell said 54 students were withdrawn from schools Tuesday, but he believes most will return ``once they see we're open and things are going smoothly.''

DOC.HEAD: World War II Victors Give Shape to German Unification Process
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 8-9, `The announcements ...single currency.'' with four grafs to UPDATE with White House comment, detail of spy flight accord; picks up 10th pvs: West Germany's ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto OTT6
DOC.TEXT: The four World War II Allies, vanquishers of Nazi Germany and occupiers of Berlin, have begun a process aimed at ensuring a unified Germany will not pose a threat to world security. Foreign ministers from France, Britain, the Soviet Union and United States announced Tuesday that they would meet with their counterparts from East and West Germany to discuss the alignment and military strength of a unified Germany. No date for such a meeting was given, but before it takes place the two Germanys will be left alone to tackle the considerable domestic hurdles that must be overcome before unity is possible. With Tuesday's announcement, the powers that divided Germany in 1945 clearly acknowledged that reunification is inevitable now that Communist rule has collapsed in East Germany. The brief, one-paragraph statement did not address U.S. concerns that a unified Germany belongs to the NATO alliance. The Soviet Union seeks a neutral state. The announcement said preliminary talks by lower-level officials on a unified Germany's place in the new European order would begin ``shortly.'' It was released about an hour before the Soviet Union and United States announced agreement on troops cuts in Europe in which the Soviets essentially accept a proposal by President Bush and agree to a ceiling of 195,000 troops for each side in Central Europe. The agreement allows the United States to keep an additional 30,000 troops elsewhere in Europe, which Mikhail S. Gorbachev had rejected just last week in seeking parity. The announcements came during a conference of 23 NATO and Warsaw Pact countries on opening up the world's skies to surveillance by unarmed military planes. On that issue, they tentatively agreed to allow the first legal spy flights over each other's territory. The accord is to be finalized May 12. Officials have shied away from saying when a unified Germany could become a reality, but the two German states are moving swiftly toward that end. On Tuesday, they set up a joint commission to set up a single currency. At the White House, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said: ``The president finds that a very reasonable approach to the unification question and we are quite supportive.'' He called it ``a good beginning that ensures a certain degree of stability and sureness of course as we proceed through this.'' West Germany's foreign minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, said in Ottawa on Tuesday that he hoped a 35-nation summit would address the issue of reunification in November. The statemen on a single German state said six-country talks would focus on ``external aspects of the establishment of German unity, including the issues of security of the neighboring states.'' The foreign ministers made no comment after release of statement, apparently reflecting their desire not to create undue expectations or prejudice the work facing the two Germanys. The four-power plan, adapted from a U.S. initiative, calls for the powers to address external security concerns only after East Germans elect new leaders in free elections set for March 18, U.S. officials said. The plan was first set forward by Secretary of State James A. Baker III and dubbed ``Two Plus Four'' for the two Germanys and the Allies. The statement came after the foreign ministers met for several hours on the issue, overshadowing the ``Open Skies'' conference. The subject of German reunion has preoccupied NATO and the Warsaw Pact since East Germany's hard-line Communist leader Erich Honecker was ousted in November in a peaceful popular revolt. The country's discredited Communists struggled to hold on to power but agreed last month to share power with opposition groups until the elections. But there is no confidence in East Germany's economy and the Westward exodus has not abated. Genscher sought to reassure the world that a unified Germany will not pose a threat to peace. ``We tell all our neighbors what we want to unite: The Federal Republic of Germany, the German Democratic Republic and the whole of Berlin _ no less, and no more. We do not have territorial claims against any of our neighbors.'' ``We seek a European Germany, not a German Europe,'' he said. Concern about Germany's alignment stems from the strategic importance of the region, and the possibility that a unified Germany could again become an aggressor. West Germany's 500,000-troop military is the biggest in Western Europe, having been stoked by NATO as a frontline defense against a Warsaw Pact invasion. Along with unification, West German officials reportedly have promised to cut their forces by about 100,000 troops, and East Germany would disband its army, said David Shorr, an analyst at the British American Security Information Council in Washington. The four powers were under pressure to keep the West German military in check and so they devised the ``Two Plus Four'' plan, said Shorr, who attended the conference. NATO has insisted that a unified Germany be part of the 16-member North Atlantic Treaty Organization. But the Soviet Union, which maintains about 380,000 troops in East Germany, wants a unified Germany demilitarized so ``it can be of no threat to others,'' Foreign Ministry adviser Vitaly Churkin said Monday. Britain's foreign secretary, Douglas Hurd, said Tuesday that few countries at the conference other than the Soviet Union have suggested a unified Germany would be neutral. Genscher did not mention the neutrality issue specifically in his Tuesday speech, saying only that unification should occur in the context of integration of the European community and that nothing will be negotiated without participation of the four World War II Allies. As part of the plan, a unified Germany also likely would renounce the use or stationing on its soil of nuclear weapons, U.S. officials said. Germany's neighbors in Europe would have a voice in the talks during the second phase, a Polish Embassy official said on condition he not be identified.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Lashes Out at Rioters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads thruout to UPDATE with Gorbachev quotes, details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today lashed out at rioters in the republic of Tadzhikistan and called for harsh action against them, saying the ``country's destiny and the safety of our citizens is at stake.'' The Tass news agency said more soldiers were sent to Dushanbe, the capital of Tadzhikistan, but officials denied news reports that 37 people were killed in rioting. Two separate reports put the death toll at 11 or 12. Shouting with anger during a parliamentary session, Gorbachev criticized the Interior Ministry for releasing three suspects. The violence in Dushanbe is the latest in ethnic disturbances that have killed hundreds of people in Central Asia and the Caucasus in the past year. ``This is a kind of chain reaction accompanied by an orgy of violence,'' Gorbachev said. ``We should throw the book at those who, under slogans of ethnic revival, draw people into a fight for their ambitions and selfish goals.'' He said new legislation was being prepared to deal with the issue. ``The country's destiny and the safety of our citizens is at stake, comrades. We must do everything to put out the fire.'' Mikhail Shtatnov, a spokesman for the republic's Interior Ministry, said young men from surrounding villages entered Dushanbe this morning and prowled the city's suburbs, damaging buildings. He said the center of the city was under the control of soldiers and armor. He denied a TV and Moscow Radio report late Tuesday that 37 people had been killed. He said 11 had died and 143 were injured in the rioting that broke out Monday. Tass put the death toll at 12, and said that among the injured were 50 militia and soldiers. Shtatnov said none of the dead had been killed by Interior Ministry soldiers. But Malik Khadyrov of the state radio and TV in Dushanbe said his correspondents reported seeing some people shot and killed by soldiers. The government issued a radio appeal for citizens in the capital, Dushanbe, to fight the bands of rioters, said a resident, Zina Ushanova. The city's streets were patrolled by soldiers in tanks and armored personnel carriers. Violence broke out Monday in the city of 400,000 after rumors spread that thousands of Armenian refugees from ethnic violence in the Caucasus were being given preference for new housing at the expense of natives. Soviet journalist Anatoly Larenok said the republic's Communist leader offered his resignation today in a bid to quell the violence. Protesters angered over the dismal state of the economy are demanding the resignation of the predominantly Moslem republic's entire Communist leadership. After two days of attacks on Communist headquarters, crowds gathered again today in the main square of Duhanbe, said Larenok, a correspondent for the national newspaper Vozdushny Transport. The crowd demanded that those killed be buried in the square, Larenok said. He said officials refused. All stores were closed and no bread was available, Mrs. Ushanova said by telephone. Public transportation was stopped, she said. Radio Moscow said bands of young men were ignoring the 10 p.m.-6 a.m. curfew and state of emergency imposed Monday. It said dozens were detained. The government called on residents of the city to don white headbands to distinguish themselves from rioters, who it described as mostly young men. Tensions also were reported high Monday in Frunze, capital of the neighboring republic of Kirgizia on the border with China, following rumors that Armenian refugees were to receive apartments in the city, Komsomolskaya Pravda newspaper said. No violence was reported there. Interfax, a publication of Radio Moscow, said the crowd Tuesday demanded the deportation of all Armenians from Tadzhikistan, the closure of an ecologically dangerous aluminum plant, the return to the republic of all proceeds from cotton production, and the resignations of the Communist Party and government leadership. Tadzhikistan Communist Party leader Kakhar Makhkamov offered his resignation to an emergency meeting of the party Central Committee, but the leadership rejected it while the unrest was continuing, Larenok said. The party meeting was attended by alternate national Politburo member Boris Pugo, the journalist said. Komsomolskaya Pravda reported that Makhkamov also had told a crowd Monday that he intended to resign. Larenok said at least 300 Armenians have fled the city aboard special flights to Yerevan, the Armenian capital. Some of the mainly Christian Armenians had fled from the violence in the predominantly Moslem Azerbaijan. Armenians have been involved for the last two years in bloody dispute with predominantly Azerbaijanis over control of the Nagorno-Karabakh region of Azerbaijan. More than 200 people have been killed in the southern Caucasus republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan since Jan. 13. Gorbachev sent thousands of soldiers into the area to end a nationalist revolt in the Azerbaijani capital of Baku and end attacks on Armenians.

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers throughout the country. Feb. 10 The Providence (R.I.) Journal-Bulletin on Reagan-Poindexter: The Iran-contra affair began as a series of policy blunders by the Reagan administration, quickly developed into a witch hunt conducted by the Democratic-controlled Congress _ and then became an inordinately expensive and seemingly interminable legal farce scripted by Special Prosecutor Lawrence Walsh. Now U.S. District Judge Harold Greene threatens to turn it into a constitutional morass as well. Having broken seven butterflies on his prosecutorial wheel, ... Walsh is now preparing to go after his eighth and presumable final quarry, ... (former national security adviser John) Poindexter. But before that can happen, the country may be subjected to a protracted constitutional controversy. For ... Poindexter's lawyers want to go through President Reagan's volumimous private diaries to see if they can find something _ anything _ that might suggest their client was acting under presidential directions. ... (Green) has taken the unprecedented action of ordering ... Reagan to submit to videotaped interrogation by defense lawyers. ... This long-running travesty has already inflicted personal damage on several honorable, if overzealous, public servants. It should not be allowed to undermine the institutional authority of the presidency as well.

Feb. 8 Concord (N.H.) Monitor on Reagan-Poindexter: To date, all the Contra-gate conspirators have received less punishment for their crimes against democracy than most car thieves. ... Did Ronald Reagan actually authorize that gross abuse of the Constitution to get around a reluctant Congress? Did he, in essence, conduct a private war? And did President Bush, as we believe, sit in on the planning? ... Reagan, like (Richard) Nixon before him, is aruing that he must claim executive privilege to protect the privacy rights of future presidents. We are respectful of those rights, but they do not include the right to cover up crimes and abuses of power. The law says Reagan will have to testify or produce his diaries only if it is absolutely crucial to (former national security adviser John) Poindexter's defense. Lt. Col. Oliver North, you'll remember, received a light sentence largely because most jurors believed he was following orders from Poindexter and other superiors. Poindexter has pointed the finger higher. It is crucial to his defense, and to the truth, that Reagan finally come clean.

Feb. 12 Los Angeles Times on South Africa: Freedom took a new meaning Sunday (Feb. 11) as the world watched Nelson Mandela walk out of 27 years of captivity. The exultant celebration of his countrymen measured their own expectations. The violence that accompanied the celebration underscored the complexity of what lies ahead. The climax of the day was written in Mandela's address to the nation, as the man imprisoned for terrorism set the agenda for all South Africans. With eloquence and vision, he looked beyond the bondage of apartheid to ``the establishment of democracy'' on ``a non-racial basis.'' He used his first hours of freedom to facilitate what now needs to happen. He was conciliatory, praising President Frederick W. de Klerk as ``a man of integrity'' and recognizing his constructive leadership. But he was also realistic, insisting on two preconditions for negotiations: the end of the national emergency and the release of the remaining political prisoners. ... Mandela also issued useful warnings: ``To lift sanctions now would run the risk of aborting the process toward the complete eradication of apartheid.'' That reality has been accepted by the American government. The struggle, he cautioned, is not yet over. ... Mandela walked free from prison but not from a system of racism that still strangles the lives of the blacks. ... Unpredictable forces have been freed with him. They provide now unprecedented risk, but also opportunity.

Feb. 13 Portland (Maine) Press Herald on South Africa: Now that (Nelson Mandela) has been released, it remains to be seen whether he can translate his special status as a political symbol into practical administrative leadership. In other words, can a man cut off from the world for more than a quarter of a century effectively deal with that world when suddenly thrust back into it? There is no shortage of hope _ not only among South Africans themselves but within the world community _ that he can do so. And the words he spoke with such vigor, dignity and resoluteness on Sunday (Feb. 11) can only bolster that hope. While acknowledging South African President Frederik W. de Klerk's role in opening opportunities for change, he vowed never to retreat from his own struggle for ``a democratic and free society in which all persons live together in harmony and with equal opportunities.'' It was precisely that vow that landed Mandela in prison 27 years ago. That it had to be repeated shows how little political progress in South Africa has made in the intervening years. That is was spoken freely this time shows how much progress has been made in just the past few days. A lot now hangs on the ability of a heroic symbol to give practical shape to that long-deferred struggle.

DOC.HEAD: Chianti Chairman Dies at Age 60
DOC.TEXT: Francesco Folonari, the innovative general manager of one of Italy's most prestigious Chianti wineries, has died at the age of 60, Italian media reported Wednesday. Folonari died Monday of complications following heart surgery, according to the reports. Born in 1929, Folonari entered the family winery Chianti Ruffino SpA following the death of his father in 1951. He had served as general manager of the winery since 1966. In 1954, Folonari introduced screwtop wine bottles with a deposit added to the price to reuse the bottles. Both were firsts for the Italian wine market. Asked about his company's policy of innovation, Folonari was reported to have said, ``One must continually keep one's mentality up to date, even for daily table wine.''

DOC.HEAD: Lions Fall Out of Trailer into Traffic
DOC.NOTE: Eds: `Sampson' is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Lions may be king of the jungle, but two of them cowered in fear when they found themselves in the middle of a busy highway. The pair fell out of a trailer during rush hour Tuesday on Interstate 40. A witness said the trailer door opened and the lions ``just rolled out.'' ``We don't know how it came open,'' said owner Jerry Garrett, a pet shop proprietor in Purcell who was pulling the trailer. ``After they landed, they just sat there and cowered. They were scared.'' Neither of the lions, Sampson and Casey, was injured. Animal control officers used a tranquilizer gun to sedate them before using nooses to load them back into the trailer. ``They were pretty docile. We just took precautions,'' said Lt. Stewart Meyer, Highway Patrol spokesman. Garrett said the animals were used for shows, promotions and education. His store was fined $1,000 in June after Sampson, then a 7-month-old cub, knocked its cage open and bit a 6-year-old girl. The U.S. Department of Agriculture alleged the store was negligent in handling and housing the lions there. Garrett said he was moving the lions from the store to a 68-acre ranch he owns in Purcell, where they are to be put on display behind 12-foot fences.

DOC.HEAD: East German Economy, Once Pride of the East Bloc, Sliding Toward Disaster
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's heavily industrialized economy was long touted as one of the strongest in the East bloc, but an exodus of workers devastated productivity and has hastened moves toward unification with West Germany. When East German leaders opened the country's borders Nov. 9, they were hoping to stop the flight by convincing citizens that serious reforms were under way. But the exodus spiraled, bringing the economy closer to collapse. More than 85,000 East Germans have come West this year, joining 340,000 who arrived last year. Peter Pietsch, an economist for the West German bank Commerzbank, said the effect on East Germany has been devastating. ``In many offices, every fourth of fifth employee is missing,'' Pietsch told The Associated Press. ``The country could face a collapse if this outflow continues.'' Statistics released Tuesday in East Germany show how bad the situation is: industrial production fell 5.6 percent in January 1990 compared to the previous year, mostly because of the exodus, the government said. The lost productivity has led to a severe drop in exports, it said. Serious worker shortages have been reported across East Germany. Mail is no longer delivered in some areas because there's no one to deliver it. Soldiers are being used to operate trolleys. Strikes and slowdowns by workers who fear they could lose their jobs as East Germany undergoes democratic change are another factor. East Germany's economy always lagged behind that of Western industrialized nations. But for years it was considered the strongest in the Soviet bloc, churning out industrial goods, chemicals and other products for itself and other East bloc countries. Its average per capita income last year was the highest in the East bloc. But a growing number of East Germans are attracted to wealthy West Germany because of the prospects of living the kinds of lives they were denied under 40 years of rigid Communist rule. West Germany's own social services, in addition to its job and housing markets, are seriously burdened by the newcomers, and the dire situation has led to a number of moves toward unification. In Ottawa, Canada, on Tuesday, it was announced the two German states and the four World War II victors _ the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union _ would soon begin talks on German unification. On Wednesday, the West German Cabinet approved a supplementary 1990 budget that provides $3.45 billion in funding for ``immediate measures'' to help East Germany. The two German states _ at West Germany's initiation _ are also about to undertake talks on establishing a common currency, with West Germany's powerful Deutsch mark the currency for both countries. This would be a giant leap toward unification. When the idea first arose, there was considerable opposition from West German financial experts who feared it could result in higher taxes and drag down the value of the Deutsch mark. Economists are still advising that such a step be taken cautiously. But support for the idea has grown with acknowledgment of East Germany's desperate condition. Economists say it will take huge amounts of money to rebuild East Germany's economy, but they believe it can be done in 10 years. Pietsch said West Germany's construction industry especially sees good possibilities for investment in East Germany, once free-market economic conditions are established there. His Commerzbank plans to open branch offices in East Germany at some point. ``The machinery and equipment is generally better in East Germany than in other East bloc countries,'' he said. ``The prerequisites are there for a strong economic upswing once investments from the West get going,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Up To Five Years Sought For Radicals Who Attacked U.S. Residence
DOC.TEXT: The prosecution demanded Wednesday that three radical students charged with assaulting the U.S. ambassador's residence be sentenced to five years in prison. Prosecutors demanded four-year terms for three other students who briefly occupied the residence of U.S. Ambassador Donald Gregg in Seoul in October. The students scaled the walls of Gregg's residence at daybreak and occupied it for nearly an hour, hurling homemade bombs and swinging iron bars, before officers drove them out. Gregg and his wife escaped unhurt through a side door. The students said they wanted to protest U.S. trade pressure on South Korea, which they claimed was hurting poor farmers. Washington pressured South Korea to reduce its trade surplus by increasing its market for U.S. products. Radicals are a small but vocal minority in South Korea. Their public support has decreased sharply in recent years because of their violent tactics and extremist views.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrations Banned Outside President's Office
DOC.TEXT: Police announced a five-day ban on demonstrations and rallies outside the president's office beginning at midnight Wednesday, apparently to thwart a protest planned by the opposition. The opposition Awami League denounced the restriction as ``undemocratic'' and said it would go ahead with the planned march Thursday to demand the resignation of President Hussain Mohammed Ershad. ``The ban ... shows how nervous the government is about the democratic movement,'' said party general secretary Sajeda Chowdhury. The Awami League and another opposition group, the Bangladesh Nationalist Party, are campaigning for the resignation of Ershad, which they say will pave the way for free and fair elections. Opposition parties, charging the government with corruption and autocracy, have sponsored several strikes and demonstrations in recent months to press their demand. A former army general, Ershad, 59, took power in 1982 in a bloodless military coup. Since then he has held one presidential election and two parliamentary votes. All the elections have been marked by allegations of fraud. Ershad has said he is ready to hold new elections, but the opposition has refused to participate unless he resigns first. They say elections under Ershad would be rigged in favor of his Jatiya Party.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Presents Lebanese Police With Patrol Cars
DOC.TEXT: Israel presented Lebanese police with a small fleet of Mercedeses on Wednesday so they can better patrol the Israeli-controlled zone of south Lebanon, security sources said. One source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Israelis asked the police to inscribe the six cars ``Lebanese Police.'' The source said there are some 150 Lebanese policemen inside the zone. The Beirut government only sends them paychecks and uniforms. It avoids giving them orders that contradict Israel's interests in the zone. Unlike other police stations, the force in the Israeli zone does not maintain radio contact with headquarters in Beirut. Israel carved out the six-to-10-mile strip in 1985 when it withdrew the bulk of its invasion army from Lebanon after a three-year occupation. It is to serve as a buffer against cross-border raids into Israel. In addition to Lebanese police, the zone is patrolled by about 1,500 Israeli troops and 3,500 militiamen of the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army.

DOC.HEAD: Record Amount of Cocaine Seized From Yokohama Warehouse
DOC.TEXT: Police seized a record 52.14 pounds of cocaine from a warehouse in Yokohama in a smuggling case involving three Colombians and one Peruvian, officials said Wednesday. The cocaine, valued at $11.8 million, was the largest seizure of the drug ever in Japan, a Tokyo Metropolitan Police Department official said. The previous record was 26.4 pounds confiscated in July. Police said they found the drugs Tuesday after statements from two Colombians arrested last month. The two led police to the other suspects. The maximum penalty for cocaine trafficking in Japan is 15 years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Family of American Hostage Sends Valentine's Message
DOC.TEXT: A Beirut newspaper published a Valentine's Day message Wednesday to American hostage Thomas Sutherland from his family. The message, carried by the As-Safir daily in English and Arabic, was accompanied by a picture showing Sutherland's wife, Jean, and family. It read: ``We send ourselves with special Valentine love and a prayer that it finds you in heart and health. ``May the warmth and mutuality of our caring prevail, ``As ever and for aye, ``Joan, Ann, Simone, Jean and Kit.'' Sutherland, 58, of Fort Collins, Colo., was acting dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut when he was kidnapped June 9, 1985, on the Beirut airport highway. Besides Sutherland, 17 other Westerners are missing in Lebanon. The hostage held longest is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Membership a Major Obstacle to German Unity
With AM-Germany,Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet objections to NATO membership for a united Germany remain a major obstacle to reunification despite optimism in both East and West Germany that they soon will be one again. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union has said Germany cannot be part of the ``structure of NATO'' and unification should lead to neutrality or even demilitarization. Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany wants to keep a united Germany in the alliance, and the United States is intent on it. As a compromise, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany has proposed keeping NATO and Warsaw Pact troops out of what is now East Germany. The United States now has 255,000 soldiers in West Germany and the Soviet Union has more than 380,000 in East Germany. On Tuesday, they agreed to reduce their troops in Central Europe to 195,000 each. NATO membership is an important issue for West Germans, whose nation is among the world's richest after four decades of protection by the Western alliance. A look across the crumbling Berlin Wall at the grime-covered, ill-kept buildings of East Berlin is enough to convince most people NATO membership has its advantages. ``For the Federal Republic of Germany, I see little change in the NATO position,'' says Josef Janning, an East-West specialist at the University of Mainz. He said West Germany's leaders would insist on retaining NATO membership, but the issue is complicated and Janning told The Associated Press he feels demilitarizing East Germany is the most practical solution. Janning said demilitarized status could end when Europe worked out its security arrangements. ``If there are no crises in Eastern Europe and there is no coup in the Soviet Union, that could happen as early as this decade,'' he said. That would lead to a radical realignment of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, turning its attention to Atlantic rather than land defenses, Janning said. He added that the United States would be a smaller military presence and the rest of its missiles would be removed, but he predicted nuclear weapons would remain in Europe because its security arrangements would include them. The Soviet Union, which lost more than 20 million people in World War II, wants a single Germany demilitarized so ``it can be of no threat to others,'' Soviet Foreign Ministry adviser Vitaly Churkin said Monday at an East-West conference in Ottawa. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd of Britain said Tuesday few countries in Ottawa except the Soviets suggested a neutral Germany. Soviet officials also have spoken of abolishing NATO and the Warsaw Pact altogther, but the comments were greeted skeptically in Washington and Western Europe. East Germany's caretaker government also insists on neutrality, and the new administration to be chosen in free elections next month is expected to oppose full NATO membership. In a poll conducted last week, 92 percent of the 1,429 East Germans surveyed favored neutrality. It was conducted by the Wickert Institute of West Germany for Quick magazine, based in Munich. West Germany's opposition Social Democrats have said cutting the size of West Germany's armed forces might resolve the issue. Defense spokesman Andreas von Buelow said: ``The Soviets will prove cooperative if they can be sure the German side cannot mount an offensive war and if no threats to borders come from there.'' The Social Democrats have a large following in East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Blacks More Likely to Get Tuberculosis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: The relatively high rate of tuberculosis among blacks, long blamed on poverty, appears to result in part from a genetic susceptibility to the disease, a study concludes.
