The rejection could lead to a lawsuit or a Justice Department investigation, said Georgetown University law professor John Banzhaf II. Banzhaf has been helping two South Carolina women with Justice Department complaints contesting the school's policy. He would not say whether he was assisting the rejected applicant. ``Once you are a graduate, you are often thought of as belonging to an advantageous club. Women deserve the same advantage,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Major Low-Income Landlord Blasts Suspension; Says Transfers Likely
DOC.TEXT: A major subsidized housing landlord suspended by HUD Secretary Jack Kemp said Wednesday he planned to give up control of most of his properties, accusing Kemp of a ``scandalous vendetta'' that was crippling service to low-income tenants. A. Bruce Rozet, president of California-based Associated Financial Corp., said he was negotiating with several housing investment and management firms and hoped to transfer roughly 300 of the 350 properties owned, managed or otherwise controlled by his company and affiliates. Nonetheless, Rozet said the company would challenge the suspension, saying the accusations were without merit and that the company had provided documents to prove that to HUD but has been ignored. Rozet also said Kemp's fear of scandal had virtually halted government housing programs. ``We have now become caught up in a political campaign to divert attention from a continuing national housing policy of benign neglect in the name of HUD reform,'' Rozet said. ``The tenants are being made the victims while HUD carries out it scandalous vendetta against our company.'' Kemp, in a statement, said poor conditions at the properties cited in the suspension letter ``speak for themselves.'' He said his ``outrage is not directed at any one owner or manager'' but at a number of owners and investors he says have reaped lucrative tax benefits but invested little of their own money in the projects. The department also released a memo from one of its attorneys that said HUD's inspector general was working with the FBI to investigate whether Associated Financial Corp.'s management affiliate, Housing Resources Management, billed HUD for subsidies for vacant units at an Oklahoma development. That memo said local HUD officials in several states had raised questions about Housing Resources actions. Rozet said the company on two occasions billed HUD for subsidies for units that became vacant after the requests were filed. But Housing Resources quickly reported the vacancies and overpayment to HUD, Rozet said, saying such developments were routine because of high tenant turnover. When HUD issued the suspension late last month, Rozet said his role as a fund-raiser for Sen. Alan Cranston of California, two-time presidential contender Jesse Jackson and other Democrats gave Republicans looking for a Democrat to draw into reports of HUD scandals an easy target. Kemp has said politics had no role in his actions against Associated Financial and its affiliates. At a Washington news conference he called to answer HUD's charges, Rozet said he shared many of Kemp's goals. He contended Kemp has been misled about Associated Financial's performance by ``minions'' who went after the company. ``In HUD's desperate rush to damage our companies, HUD has, in fact, hurt the people it claims to be protecting,'' said Rozet, who is scheduled to testify before Congress in the near future about his companies' properties, which include 45,000 subsidized apartments. Although the suspension only prohibits Associated Financial and its affiliates from seeking new HUD business, Rozet said Kemp recently ordered field offices to send all Associated Financial-related work to agency headquarters. HUD inspectors this week also began visiting the properties with cameras, demanding to see ``your worst unit,'' Rozet said. Those developments, he said, had convinced him Associated Financial had to give up the properties it controlled until it resolved its battle with HUD. Rozet said his companies would receive no money through the planned transfer of control and that HUD would have to approve the deal. ``It's not a question of money. It's a question of housing,'' Rozet said. ``If HUD won't do business with me, I have to find somebody else that they will deal with or the tenants will just sit there and suffer.''

DOC.HEAD: Agricultural Pest Arrived With U.S. Soldier From Panama
DOC.TEXT: Screwworm larvae were discovered in the wound of a U.S. soldier injured in Panama, prompting warnings that the pest could infect animals in Texas. Screwworms are the larvae, or maggots, of a blowfly that feed on the flesh of warm-blooded animals. They can kill livestock if the animals go untreated. A 30-year program had eradicated the screwworm, first in the United States and later in Mexico. The soldier was among the first to arrive in San Antonio on Dec. 20 for treatment at Brooke Army Medical Center, hospital spokesman Ray Dery said Tuesday. ``There's just a remote possibility that anything escaped from the hospital,'' said Paul Jensen, assistant area veterinarian with the U.S. Department of Agriculture. ``The weather was in our favor.'' A hard freeze that hit San Antonio in late December probably killed the larvae, which thrive in warm climates, officials said. Some of the larvae from the soldier's wound were saved for analysis, and the rest were disposed of in medical trash and ended up at a local landfill, Dery said. Weeks later, entomologists with the National Museum of Natural History in Washington identified the samples that were saved as screwworm. ``We're asking any local veterinarian within a 20-mile radius if they find any larvae infestation in any animal wound to send it to our identification lab in Mission,'' Jensen said.

DOC.HEAD: Civil Servant Strays to Slay
LaserPhoto LON8
DOC.TEXT: Humphrey is one employee of Her Majesty's Government who gets results _ a score of mice, voles and rats since he took up his post in September. The long-haired black and white tom, named after Sir Humphrey Appleby in the ``Yes Prime Minister'' TV series, customarily dumps his victims at the entrance of the Cabinet Office, according to a press spokesman. Taxpayers provide a daily tin of food and milk. ``But it is a good investment,'' said the spokesman, who disclosed details of the cat's activities with the usual proviso of not being identified. ``What is more, he is affectionate and even Sir Robin Butler, the cabinet secretary, likes him,'' the spokesman added. ``At night, Humphrey pops out of No. 70 Whitehall, trots along Downing Street, past No. 10 (the prime minister's residence), and spends the night hunting in the park. ``He returns in the morning, rather tired.''

DOC.HEAD: Theater Announces New Artistic Director
DOC.TEXT: Adrian Noble, the 39-year-old director whose credits range from Shakespeare to Cole Porter, was named Wednesday the next artistic director of the Royal Shakespeare Company. Noble will assume his post April 1 as artistic director-elect. He takes over fully in July 1991 when current artistic director Terry Hands steps down after 25 years with the company. Noble will have a team of three _ executive producer Michael Attenborough, associate producer Genista McIntosh, and general manager David Brierley _ to form what a press statement called ``a powerful artistic planning and operational nucleus for the company.'' The announcement came just a week after the company announced it was closing its two London theaters for four months beginning in November in order to stem a mounting deficit that threatened to reach $6.8 million. ``Some people have said I've been offered a poisoned chalice,'' Noble told a news conference at the company's London base, the Barbican. ``I've simply been offered to guide and run the greatest theater company in the world ... Fund us properly to fulfill that brief,'' he said. The revamped structure answers criticism that management of the company had become too large a job for one person. It echoes somewhat the delegation of authority at the Royal National Theater, London's other large state-subsidized playhouse, which divides responsibilities between artistic director Richard Eyre and executive director David Aukin. Noble, a graduate of Bristol University, has been an associate director of the company for 11 years, staging such admired productions as ``Henry V,'' which marked the professional Shakespearean debut of this year's Oscar nominee Kenneth Branagh; Henrik Ibsen's ``The Master Builder,'' with Broadway veteran John Wood; and a trilogy, ``The Plantagenets,'' drawn from four Shakespeare history plays. His 1987 revival of Cole Porter's ``Kiss Me, Kate'' drew mixed reviews but transferred to the commercial West End for a lengthy run. A mooted Broadway engagement never materialized. Noble made his American directing debut last December in New York, earning excellent reviews for ``The Art of Success'' off-Broadway at the Manhattan Theater Club. Next, he stages Chekhov's ``Three Sisters'' for the Gate Theater in Dublin, opening March 27. The production, a dynastic occasion, will star leading Irish actor Cyril Cusack and three of his four actress daughters: Sorcha, Sinead, and Niamh.

DOC.HEAD: DNC Panel Agrees to Allow California to Change Primary Date
DOC.TEXT: The Democratic Party moved Wednesday to allow California to shift its presidential primary from June to early March, a change that would place the largest state among the first to vote in 1992. The Democratic National Committee's rules and bylaws committee, acting with the support of DNC Chairman Ron Brown, agreed to change party rules to permit California to hold its presidential primary on the first Tuesday in March. The change, expected to be approved easily by the full DNC next month, means a proposal in the California Legislature to hold its Democratic and Republican presidential primaries March 3, 1992, would be permissible under national Democratic Party rules. ``California felt very strongly they wanted to be a player in the process,'' said Alice Travis, a member of the DNC executive committee from California. ``Coming last made it somewhat irrelevant.'' The proposed rules would allow the party to apply a new sanction against states that violate national party rules by holding primaries or caucuses too early or too late, or violate other delegate-selection rules. The change would provide an automatic 25 percent reduction in the state's total delegates. The California Assembly last summer approved shifting the state's presidential primary from June to March and the state Senate is expected to vote on the change Thursday. Republican Gov. George Deukmejian has dropped his opposition to the change, removing a major obstacle. The new Democratic rules allow Iowa's caucuses to be the first presidential delegate-selection event, followed a week later by New Hampshire's first-in-the-nation primary. California, under the proposed schedule, would become the first big state to vote. One consequence could be to lessen the importance of the two earliest states by allowing well-financed, better-known candidates to concentrate on the state with the richest block of delegates. ``It is important that a large state crucial to electing a Democratic president weigh in early in the process,'' Brown said. California's June primary date has placed it at the end of the delegate-selection process, when the nominee was already a foregone conclusion. The 1988 California primary victory by Michael Dukakis over Jesse Jackson gave Dukakis the delegates he needed to clinch the nomination, but his nomination had been assured for practical purposes months earlier. The party action technically moved up by one week the opening of the so-called ``window'' for states to hold primaries or caucuses. With the change, that period would run from the first Tuesday in March to the second Tuesday in June. Special exceptions allow New Hampshire's primary one week earlier, however, and Iowa's caucuses eight days before New Hampshire. A special provision also allows Maine to begin its caucus process early. The change presents a calender with Iowa, New Hampshire and California on successive weeks, followed one week later by the so-called Super Tuesday round of numerous state primaries. Illinois would hold its primary a week after that. Party activists expect the California change to trigger other states to move up their dates, and perhaps some will join California on March 3.

DOC.HEAD: US Refuses To Allow Nicaraguan Official To Make Speaking Tour
DOC.TEXT: The State Department has refused to grant a visa to a top Nicaraguan diplomat to make public appearances this week in Washington and New York, a U.S. official said Wednesday. The official, asking not to be identified, said the decision was made because Nicaraguan officials could not guarantee that visas would be issued to all members of Congress wishing to go to Nicaragua next week to observe the presidential election there. According to the official, some members of Congress who have requested visas have not received them. A Nicaraguan spokeswoman said delays have been common in processing visas because of a large number of requests. Nicaraguan Vice Foreign Minister Victor Hugo Tinoco had been scheduled to make an appearance here Thursday at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. He also was planning to appear later in the week before the Americas Society in New York. The U.S. official said Tinoco withdrew his request for a visa after the State Department imposed its condition concerning congressional observers. The State Department had been willing to grant Tinoco a visa if he had agreed to limit his activities to the United Nations and the Organization of American States. Nicaraguan Embassy spokeswoman Cecilia Lopez had no comment on the State Department action. But she said that about 3,000 foreign observers are expected to be on hand for the Feb. 25 balloting, which features a matchup between President Daniel Ortega and an opposition coalition led by Violeta Chamorro. Last week, a 20-member congressional delegation appointed by President Bush was disbanded because the Sandinista government denied some members permission to enter the country. The Nicaraguan position is that it is inappropriate for the Sandinistas to accept an official U.S. delegation because of American support for the Nicaraguan Contras and the U.S. economic embargo imposed against that country. The Nicaraguans invited the delegates to apply for visas to observe the election in an unofficial capacity. Twelve members of Congress will join an unofficial observer delegation headed by former President Carter. Eight other lawmakers will form part of two other delegations organized under the auspices of the U.N. and the OAS.

DOC.HEAD: `Miss Daisy,' `Fourth of July' Lead Oscar Nominations
LaserPhotos LA4,5,6, NY40, LaserColor NY87
DOC.TEXT: The bittersweet ``Driving Miss Daisy'' carried off a leading nine Academy Award nominations Wednesday as Oscar voters passed over box-office blockbusters and maverick movies with equal abandon. ``Daisy,'' which traces the relationship over the decades between a testy Jewish widow and her tolerant black chauffeur in the South, drew nominations for best picture and actors Morgan Freeman, Jessica Tandy and Dan Aykroyd. ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' director Oliver Stone's account of Ron Kovic's painful passage from blind patriotism to unselfish protest by way of a Vietnam injury that left him a paraplegic, got eight nominations, including best picture. Also nominated in the top picture category by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences were ``Dead Poets Society,'' ``Field of Dreams'' and ``My Left Foot.'' ``This is truly one of the happiest and most triumphant moments of my life,'' said Kovic. Among other multiple nominees, ``Glory,'' a look at an all-black regiment in the Civil War, and ``My Left Foot,'' the story of an indomitable Irish artist with cerebral palsy, each earned five nominations. ``The Abyss,'' ``The Adventures of Baron Munchausen,'' ``Dead Poets Society'' and ``The Fabulous Baker Boys'' grabbed four nominations each. Oscar voters largely ignored many of the year's highest-grossing titles, as ``Batman,'' ``Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade,'' ``Lethal Weapon 2,'' ``Honey, I Shrunk the Kids'' and ``Look Who's Talking'' captured only five nominations combined. A number of modestly budgeted, independently minded efforts also were given short shrift, including the critically embraced ``Drugstore Cowboy,'' which was shut out. ``Do the Right Thing,'' while landing on numerous critics' Top 10 lists, snared just two nominations, and ``sex, lies and videotape,'' one of the best-received independent films of the decade, generated just one. For the second time in two years, Academy voters did not nominate the year's most acclaimed documentary. ``Roger & Me,'' filmmaker Michael Moore's satirical perspective on General Motors and the people of Flint, Mich., was overlooked. In 1989, the Academy did not nominate Errol Morris' ``The Thin Blue Line,'' the movie which set convicted murderer Randall Dale Adams free. The awards will be presented on March 26. The show will be seen on ABC. ``Born on the Fourth of July'' was nominated for Tom Cruise's lead performance as Kovic, for adapted screenplay, for Stone's direction, cinematography, editing, original score and sound. Joining Freeman and Cruise in the race for best actor were Kenneth Branagh, the star, director and adaptor of Shakespeare's ``Henry V,'' Daniel Day-Lewis, who played artist Christy Brown in ``My Left Foot,'' and comedian Robin Williams, as an unconventional teacher in a very conventional school in ``Dead Poets Society.'' Isabelle Adjani, featured in France's ``Camille Claudel'' as an impassioned sculptress, was perhaps the most surprising nominee for best actress. Miss Adjani will compete against Miss Tandy, who played the widow Miss Daisy; Pauline Collins, who starred as a frustrated British housewife who finds happiness on a Greek isle in ``Shirley Valentine''; Jessica Lange, who defends an alleged Nazi war criminal who also is her father in ``Music Box,'' and Michelle Pfeiffer, the chanteuse of ``The Fabulous Baker Boys.'' British stage star Branagh joins a select list of Oscar nominees by being recognized for both starring in and directing ``Henry V.'' Woody Allen (``Annie Hall''), Warren Beatty (``Heaven Can Wait,'' ``Reds'') and Orson Welles (``Citizen Kane'') are among the few who have shared the dual acting-directing recognition for the same film. In addition to Branagh, the nominees for best director were Stone for ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' Allen for ``Crimes and Misdemeanors,'' Peter Weir for ``Dead Poets Society'' and Jim Sheridan for ``My Left Foot.'' Belying a tradition that films released late in the year are favored in the Oscars, ``Field of Dreams'' was released April 21 and ``Dead Poets Society'' June 2. ``Field of Dreams,'' writer and director Phil Alden Robinson's magical tale of a man who rediscovers the past on a Iowa baseball field, also was nominated for best adapted screenplay. ``We got letters from people saying the film had changed their lives, that it had brought families back together. We couldn't have asked for more than that,'' Robinson said.

DOC.HEAD: Pesky, Pushy Sea Lions Invade San Francisco Pier
LaserPhoto FX2
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of pushy, barking sea lions, some weighing more than 800 pounds, are occupying at least 20 slips at the pricy Pier 39 yacht basin, delighting tourists but making life miserable for the marina and boat owners. ``They're cute as buttons, but they're very aggressive,'' complained management spokeswoman Lucy Hobgood-Brown. ``They're not hurting business, but they're damaging the docks, and they have bad breath.'' The problem is that the herring-gobbling sea lions are under the federal Marine Mammals Protective Act and may not be harassed, hunted, captured or killed. ``I don't think you can even glare at them,'' said marina manager Sheila Chandor. National Marine Fisheries Service biologist Brad Hanson said experts are mystified as to why the mammals have descended on such a public spot. He said they usually prefer relatively isolated areas. For more than a month, the members of the herd _ with up to 300 animals _ have been fishing, frolicking and fighting at the boat berths, which can sell for up to $50,000. Pier 39 is a shopping, restaurant and amusement complex just east of Fisherman's Wharf. The management is worried that the bulky animals, adding unexpected tons of weight to floating docks, will do serious damage to them and the attached water pipes and electric conduits. When the whole gang is out of the water, the docks are awash. Many electric meters at dock boxes have already been slapped loose when the sea lions haul out of the water. The frisky creatures also scrape loose metal flashing and bash in relatively fragile dock boxes. ``Our `guests' won't leave,'' Chandor mourned. ``But the tourists love it.'' The pier's main walkway runs directly in front of the sea lions' adopted neighborhood. During afternoons, the place is a cacophony of barking blubber, chattering tourists and clicking cameras. The sea lions are all bulls, most of them 3- to 5-year-old juveniles, Hanson said. Some, however, are full-grown and highly aggressive characters that have charged people venturing onto the docks. No one has been hurt. Hanson thought the sea lions invaded the marina because the berths happened to be empty at the time. Boats are to be returned to the occupied docks next week, and all hands are hoping for the best. ``The mating season starts in May and we're hoping the males here will go and join the ladies at the breeding grounds in the Channel Islands,'' said Hobgood-Brown. The islands are north of Los Angeles, near Santa Barbara.

DOC.HEAD: Allied Agreement Allays Some Fears, But Poland Demands A Voice
With AM-Germany Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An agreement giving the four Allies of World War II an advisory role in German reunification allayed fears in many countries about a military resurgence, but some anxieties remained Wednesday. Poland, worried about its borders, demanded a role in talks on the security aspects of unification. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, who had not hidden her unease about a united Germany, felt ``much happier'' after the argreement Tuesday in Ottawa, Canada, to hold the six-power talks, her aides said. ``We were worried there wasn't a framework in which we and the Russians and other interested parties could actually discuss the external side of this,'' Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said. ``Now we have that framework ... we are much happier.'' Under the agreement, the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France _ the Allies that conquered Nazi Germany and still occupy Berlin _ will confer with both Germanys on the security ramifications of a single Germany. Officials of East Germany and West Germany will negotiate after East German elections March 18, then join the Allies to focus on the ``external aspects ... including the issues of security of the neighboring states,'' the Ottawa announcement said. A six-power agreement would be presented to a 35-nation summit before the end of the year. The Soviet Union, whose casualties in World War II were heaviest, said Wednesday its sensitivities should be taken into account. ``We have a psychological trauma. We lost 26 million'' people in the war, Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov told a news briefing. He added, however, that he believed Europe was changing for the better. Premier Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland said at the end of a three-day visit to Britain: ``We want to be present whenever the question of the security of Germany's neighbors is discussed. Our stand is that our security matters cannot be settled by proxy for us. We must be present.'' Mazowiecki said Poland wants a treaty guaranteeing its borders, which embrace territory populated by ethnic Germans and annexed from Germany at the end of World War II. No peace treaty was signed, so Poland has no formal guarantees. West Germany has said a unified Germany would respect the border and make no territorial claims. Israeli officials referred to a statement Monday by Foreign Minister Moshe Arens that the Jewish state puts its faith in democracy. ``No one, but certainly us Jews, can think about reunification without somehow remembering what happened 50 years ago,'' Arens said, referring to the 6 million Jews killed by the Nazis. But he added: ``If a united Germany is a democratic Germany ... then I don't think that there is a danger to be concerned about.'' Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany said after an hourlong meeting Wednesday with Mrs. Thatcher that final arrangements for reunification should be ready before the end of the year. ``The prime minister has expressed firm support for German unity,'' Genscher told reporters outside Mrs. Thatcher's residence at 10 Downing Street. ``It is an enormous encouragement ... for Germans in East and West.'' In November, Mrs. Thatcher said German unification was ``not on the agenda.'' Her aides say that was before East Germany slid into economic chaos, largely due to the mass flight of skilled workers to West Germany. ``The pace of events has surprised everyone,'' Hurd said Wednesday. Mrs. Thatcher has been accused at home of wasting British influence by belatedly and grudgingly accepting German unification. Hurd said the most important issue for the six-power talks was whether a single Germany would remain in NATO, as the United States wants, or becomes neutral, as the Soviet Union prefers. President Francois Mitterrand of France urged the 12-nation European Community, which includes West Germany, to hasten its own moves toward closer union. ``For me, what is essential is that Europe again take its true place in the world after the self-destruction of two world wars,'' he said in an interview with eight regional French newspapers. ``The acceleration of the inter-German process should be accompanied by the acceleration of the European process.'' Ireland, current president of the European Community, said it would summon the 12 nations soon to discuss German reunification.

DOC.HEAD: Three Top Tadzhik Leaders Resign; Violence Reportedly Peaks
LaserPhoto LON1
DOC.TEXT: Villagers threw firebombs and acid at troops protecting the Communist Party headquarters in the Tadzhik capital on Wednesday, but the violence eased after three leaders in the republic resigned, Soviet media said. The three agreed to resign during a meeting of party leaders and activists who are protesting housing shortages and the arrival of Armenian refugees, said Orif Aminov of the Tadzhik branch of the state television and radio agency. Earlier in the day, about 5,000 young men went on a rampage in the republic's capital, looting, setting fires and attacking passers-by ``irrespective of nationality,'' the Soviet news agency Tass said. But officials denied Soviet television reports that 37 people had been killed in the violence in Tadzhikistan, which borders Afghanistan and China. Tass said 12 people had died. Tadzhik Interior Ministry spokesman Mikhail Shtatnov reported 11 dead and 143 injured. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev criticized the rioters and called for harsh action against them, saying the ``country's destiny and the safety of our citizens is at stake.'' Ethnic disturbances have killed hundreds of people in Central Asia and the Caucasus areas of the Soviet Union in the past year. The violence in Tadzhikistan broke out Monday after rumors spread that ethnic Armenians reportedly persecuted by natives of the Azerbaijani republic were being moved into the Taszhik republic, where housing is scarce. More troops landed in Dushanbe, the capital, on Wednesday to guard strategic points and restore order, Tass said. The evening television news show Vremya showed hundreds of people facing a wall of troops carrying riot shields with a barren stretch of street between the two tense groups. However, Shtatnov and Dushanbe-based journalist Anatoly Larenok said in telephone interviews that the troops were in full control. Larenok said they had blocked approaches to the city to prevent rioters from neighboring villages from entering. Larenok said the crowd outside the Central Committee headquarters was demanding that victims of the three days of violence be buried in that central square. Tass described a pitched battle between protesters and troops. It said the crowds demanded that the leaders resign and that all Armenians in the republic be expelled. ``Militants have been making attempts to reach the Tadzhik Communist Party headquarters since this morning,'' Tass said Wednesday. ``Crowds throw gasoline bombs, bottles with sulphuric acid and stones at troops blocking the building's entrances.'' Aminov said the city quieted after the Communist Party Central Committee, meeting with protest leaders calling themselves the Popular Committee of 16, announced the resignation of Tadzhik party chief Kakhar Makhkamov, Premier Izatullo Khayeyev and President Gaibnazar Pallayev. Aminov said the crowd outside the Central Committee headquarters also demanded the ouster of the interior minister and military commandant, Kamil Pulatov, but he remains in his post. The national newspaper Trud said the rioters were young men from villages in the nearby Gissar region, many of whom still are living in tents after their homes were destroyed in an earthquake in January. Though the rioting reportedly was set off by rumors that Armenian refugees would be given priority for new housing, the young men who had come into Dushanbe with concealed sticks, metal rods and canisters of gasoline, had attacked Russian-speaking people in five suburbs, the newspaper said. Gorbachev told the opening session of the Supreme Soviet legislature in Moscow that new legislation is being prepared to deal with such violence. ``We should throw the book at those who, under slogans of ethnic revival, draw people into a fight for their ambitions and selfish goals,'' Gorbachev said Wednesday. ``This is a kind of chain reaction accompanied by an orgy of violence,'' Gorbachev said. ``The country's destiny and the safety of our citizens is at stake, comrades. We must do everything to put out the fire.'' Gorbachev's greater tolerance of dissent has given rise to fierce demonstrations of ethnic pride that range from peaceful independence movements in the Baltics to brutal ethnic clashes in the Caucasus. Shtatnov said none of the dead was killed by Interior Ministry soldiers sent in to quell the fighting. But Malik Khadyrov of the state radio and television offices in Dushanbe said his correspondents reported seeing some people fatally shot by soldiers. Radio Moscow quoted commanders of regular army forces in Dushanbe as saying they would not step in to restore order because they did not want to repeat the mistakes made in April in the republic of Georgia, when soldiers attacked peaceful demonstrators and led to 20 deaths. The government issued a radio appeal for citizens to fight bands of rioters, said a Dushanbe resident, Zina Ushanova, in a telephone interview. It called on residents of the city to don white head bands to distinguish themselves from rioters.

DOC.HEAD: Noted Legal Scholar Says Soviets Must Revamp Judicial System
DOC.TEXT: A prominent Soviet legal scholar said Wednesday the Soviet judicial system is riddled with incompetent judges and must be revamped if political reforms are to succeed, Yuri Rozenbaum, who has drafted proposed new Soviet laws on freedom of conscience and the press, also said the Soviet bureaucracy has ``many no-goods, incompetents, who have to be thrown out.'' Rozenbaum, an attorney who works on the Commission on Freedom of Conscience of the Supreme Soviet, or parliament, spoke at the East-West Forum, a private organization that sponsors contacts between Soviet and U.S. scholars and government officials. Before the reforms of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, judges were picked by the Communist Party and held onto office if they were sufficiently ``subservient,'' Rozenbaum said. ``We've discovered we don't have competent judges,'' he said. Reformers would like to see the next batch of judges picked without party interference, and to have their pay increased to assure their indepedence, Rozenbaum told the group. Independent selection of judges can only occur if local elections in the Soviet Union are conducted in democratic fashion, he added. Communist Party candidates are expected to face tough challenges in republic and local elections being held this month and next in the 15 republics that make up the Soviet Union. Secessionist candidates are expected to do well in the Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, as well as the southern republics of Georgia, Armenia and Azerbaijan. In the four Central Asian republics, no significant changes are expected in local elections because the largely Moslem population there votes according to tribal and family customs, he said. ``The most fundamental problem is in the executive branch,'' said Rozenbaum. Some incompetent bureaucrats have already been discarded under the political and economic restructuring initiated by Gorbachev, he said. But ``the government apparatus is the primary problem for perestroika'' or restructuring, because entrenched bureaucrats have been dragging their heels implementing the reforms, Rozenbaum said. Bureaucrats are ``uncomfortable'' with the growing contact between elected lawmakers and non-government lawyers, he said. ``This makes the bureaucrats afraid because the deputies are becoming too independent and not paying attention to lawyers within the apparatus,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Rebel Groups Claim Killing Hundreds Of Government Troops
DOC.TEXT: Two Ethiopian rebel groups on Wednesday claimed they killed hundreds of army troops and wounded hundreds more in fighting since last week. A communique by the Eritrean People's Liberation Front also said the government cut off electricity to Massawa, a Red Sea port they claim to have captured. Massawa gets its electricity from Eritrea's capital, Asmara, whose 40-mile road westward from the port is also claimed to be in rebel control. The rebel communique, issued from their office in Khartoum, Sudan, said they killed more than 600 troops, wounded 900 and captured 27 in fighting in recent days around Keren, 55 miles west of Massawa. They provided no rebel casualty figures. The rebel offensive, the largest in more than a year, coincided with fighting in Wollo province where another rebel group, the Tigre People's Liberation Front, has claimed it killed more than 1,800 government troops, wounding 2,500 and capturing more than 1,000. The fighting was Saturday and Sunday 180 miles northeast of the Ethiopian capital, Addis Ababa, the group said in a clandestine broadcast. President Mengistu Haile Mariam's Marxist government has not directly denied the rebel claim they control Massawa and the only land route to Asmara. In Addis Ababa, the government had made no statement since saying Monday there was heavy fighting along the 40-mile-long Asmara-Massawa road and at the port itself. Meanwhile, shipping sources in Copenhagen, Denmark, said Wednesday the Eritrean rebels seized the ship Svea Atlantic 27 nautical miles north of Massawa. The sources said the ship, owned by Svendborg West of Denmark, left Dublin, Ireland, Jan. 17 with relief aid for Ethiopia. The status of the eight-man crew remained unknown. The rebel communique made no mention of the ship. United Nations officials say the fighting around Massawa has halted efforts to feed drought victims in northern Ethiopia, leaving 50,000 tons of food stored at the port. The food is part of 700,000 tons of emergency food the United Nations hoped to deliver over the next months to 4 million people threatened with famine, most of them in Eritrea and Tigre. The Eritrean rebels have been fighting since 1962 for the independence of Ethiopia's northermost province. The Tigre group, fighting since 1975, controls the province Tigre and seeks Mengistu's ouster and the establishment of a government patterned after that of Albania, the last of the hard-line Marxist states in Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Prime Minister To Meet With Bush
DOC.TEXT: Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti has accepted an invitation from President Bush and will make an official visit to Washington March 5-8, it was announced Wednesday. Bush will meet with Andreotti on March 6 and host a dinner in his honor that night. After the official portion of his trip, Andreotti will make a private visit to New York.

DOC.HEAD: Traffickers Intensify Publicity Campaign Before Bush Visit
DOC.TEXT: The Medellin cartel, which officials have feared might attack President Bush during his visit here, apparently decided to aim for positive publicity beginning with the surrender of three cocaine laboratories. The three jungle labs, worth an estimated $20 million and capable of producing 20 tons of cocaine each month, were turned over late Tuesday by cartel representatives. But the national police chief, Gen. Miguel Gomez, told reporters Wednesday the laboratories had not been used for some time and that there was no cocaine or chemicals for processing at them. Furthermore, police raided another laboratory Tuesday and seized 1,540 pounds of coke and 60,000 gallons of chemicals, proving the traffickers are going ahead with their production of cocaine, Gomez said at a news conference in Caratagena. He also said the traffickers' promise to free hostages to end the drug war was meaningless because five people released in the last six weeks had to pay ransoms. Gomez did not say how much the ransoms were. Leftist guerrillas Wednesday continued to hold two U.S. citizens kidnapped to protest the Bush visit this week, a police spokesman said. He denied earlier reports that one of the victims had been released. The Americans were identified as David Kent, a teacher from Indianapolis, and James Donnelly, employed by a company that manufactures hydraulic equipment. The White House denounced the kidnappings and said it ``cannot allow threats of terrorism to influence its policies or its activities.'' Bush is to meet in this port city with presidents Virgilio Barco of Colombia, Alan Garcia of Peru and Jaime Paz of Bolivia to try to build a four-country strategy to halt the flow of cocaine into the United States. The Colombian national radio network RCN, citing Barco administration sources, said Barco would ask Bush to help the country seek $1 billion in credits from international banking organizations over the next three years. Barco will ask the U.S. Treasury Department to guarantee Colombian bonds to be sold on European markets, RCN said. RCN, which said it received an advance copy of the agreement to be signed Thursday by the four presidents, said the document calls for a world anti-drug conference next year without specifying a date or the place. The four presidents pledge in the statement to meet again within six months to review their progress in the war against cocaine, according to RCN. Also expected to be on the summit agenda are U.S. plans to control exports of chemicals used to process cocaine as well as to fight trafficking in arms used by drug barons. The Bush administration has said it will give $2.2 billion in aid to Bolivia, Colombia and Peru over the next five years to help in their anti-drug efforts. The three jungle laboratories, in Choco state on the border with Panama, were opened to journalists Tuesday night. The journalists also received a communique repeating a peace offer from the Extraditables, as the Medellin drug bosses call themselves. On Jan. 17, traffickers offered to lay down their arms, abandon the cocaine business and help fight crime in Colombia if the government would promise them ``constitutional and legal guarantees.'' Most officials took that to mean guarantees against what the traffickers fear most _ extradition to the United States. Since Barco intensified a campaign against traffickers last August, the government has extradited 14 drug suspects. In the last month, the traffickers have released six of 21 hostages authorities say they are holding and have turned over a bus with 1,000 pounds of dynamite. The goodwill gestures have done little to ease security fears, and 5,000 security personnel from the four countries at the summit have been sent to Cartagena to protect the leaders. In addition, guests at local hotels are being finger-printed, and dynamite-sniffing dogs will be on patrol. The United States has also stationed two ships, the Nassau and the Sampson, off the coast of Colombia to protect Bush.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Appeals for Strong Presidency, Lawmakers Balk at Setting Timetable
LaserPhotos MOSB2, MOSB3
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev appealed Wednesday for legislative backing for a stronger presidency and said it was vital to his reforms, but wary lawmakers refused to be stampeded into setting a timetable. Once again, the 542-member Supreme Soviet proved itself a force to be reckoned with in the new Soviet political game, which under Gorbachev has shifted more from closed-door sessions of the Kremlin leadership to elected government bodies. After a two-month break, the fledgling Soviet legislature reconvened for the third time in its less than one-year history. Lawmakers approved a 22-item agenda to debate bills designed to put flesh on the skeleton of Gorbachev's economic and social reforms, including legalization of private property. However, the Kremlin leadership's proposal to call an emergency session of the Supreme Soviet's parent body, the Congress of People's Deputies, to replace the office now held by Gorbachev with a stronger Western-style presidency met with raucous debate. ``Unless democracy is strengthened and ensured by corresponding mechanisms, democracy will perish and we'll lose,'' Gorbachev angrily told his critics. Otherwise, he said, the victors will be forces who want to ``tighten the screws even tighter than they were earlier.'' More power for the presidency would strengthen Gorbachev's government powers while further weakening the Communist Party apparatus that he is trying to reform. Gorbachev would have two powerful instruments to implement his program of ``perestroika'' _ the party apparatus and the reinforced machinery of government. Vice President Anatoly I. Lukyanov, who flanked Gorbachev beneath a gilded globe emblazoned with the hammer and sickle, recommended that lawmakers call the Congress into session Feb. 27 to fortify the presidency and make other constitutional changes _ including the planned abandonment of the Communist Party's legally guaranteed right to govern. A close Gorbachev adviser, Georgy Shaknazarov, told reporters during a break in the proceedings that top Kremlin officials want the Congress to elect the new president within a month. But the Supreme Soviet voted 304-95, with 34 abstentions, to debate the presidential issue first. If the Supreme Soviet approves Gorbachev's plan to fortify the presidency, it must then be confirmed by the Congress of People's Deputies. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader since March 1985, is likely to be a candidate for the new presidency, but for the second time in a week he spoke guardedly about whether he will run. ``If we proceed to take a decision on the presidency, we will decide that there will be alternative candidates,'' he said. ``I don't know if I will be among the alternatives.'' Still, a half-dozen speakers Wednesday criticized the rush to create a more powerful presidency, and Gorbachev acknowledged that some Soviets equate him with late Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. He did not clarify whether the comparison was being made by reformers or by hard-liners who supported Ceausescu's brand of iron-fisted leadership. Ceausescu was ousted by a popular revolution and executed Dec. 25. Gorbachev told the legislature that he was once opposed to presidential power, but ``life has demanded changes.'' In the Soviet political system, the head of state has traditionally been merely a figurehead. A prominent liberal lawmaker from Leningrad, Anatoly Sobchak, said that increasing the powers of the presidency would decrease those of the legislature, and he opposed such a shift. Ilmar Bisher of Latvia said he supported the stronger presidency but only if the powers of the office are carefully tailored. He said that couldn't be done in time to hold a session of the 2,250-member Congress this month. Another speaker said the people would consider it strange for the Congress to elect a president now, since it elected Gorbachev to a five-year term as Supreme Soviet chairman _ sometimes termed ``president'' for short _ only last spring and increased his powers. In the corridors outside the Kremlin hall, a legislative opposition, the Inter-regional Deputies Group, circulated a petition demanding that the president be directly elected by the people. It said voters should cast ballots in secret and have a choice of candidates from several parties. The petition, read on the floor of the Supreme Soviet by group member Sergei Stankevich, also called for the question of a bolstered presidency to be postponed until new legislatures to be elected in the 15 Soviet republics this spring can consider the idea. In a platform approved last week, the Communist Party's policy-making Central Committee called for removal of the party's constitutional guarantee on power and set aside the strict Marxist prohibition against large-scale private ownership. The Supreme Soviet will consider both issues. It scheduled a report Thursday morning on a bill that will allow Soviet citizens and foreigners alike to own property, including buildings and entire factories.

DOC.HEAD: Peruvian President Puts Off Flight To Drug Summit
DOC.TEXT: President Alan Garcia postponed his departure for the drug summit in Colombia, reportedly because he saw no point in arriving a day early only to wait for President Bush's arrival on Thursday. Garcia had been scheduled to leave Wednesday afternoon, for Cartagena, Colombia, for the meeting with Bush and presidents Virgilio Barco of Colombia and Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia. His departure was delayed until 5 a.m. Thursday, and he told reporters at Government Palace that a full schedule was responsible. But according to local press reports, Garcia disapproved of the original schedule, which had the three Latin American presidents arriving a day early and waiting for Bush, whose one-day visit is to be made under heavy security. On Wednesday, Garcia presided over the ceremonial lowering of the Panamanian flag from above Government Palace, where he ordered it raised as a symbol of protest after U.S. troops invaded Panama Dec. 20 to oust Manuel Antonio Noriega. Garcia ordered the flag to remain until U.S. troops were gone. The White House announced Tuesday that all invasion forced had returned home. Garcia has been one of the region's most vocal critics of the invasion. He announced in December he would not attend the Cartagena summit, saying ``I cannot meet with the leader of an invading nation.'' He also recalled Peru's ambassador to Washington in protest and briefly halted Peruvian-U.S. anti-drug operations in the Huallaga Valley. Then on Feb. 2 Garcia reversed his decision after Bush said the troops would be out by the end of February. A Palace official, who asked that his name not be used, said Garcia's plane would arrive in Cartagena about half an hour before Bush's on Thursday morning. Among those accompanying Garcia will be Foreign Minister Guillermo Larco Cox and Peru's ambassador to Colombia, Javier Pulgar. Completing the entourage will be two officials from a coca-growers cooperative and a U.N. official who works with the cooperative in Peru's Upper Huallaga Valley, where most of the country's coca leaf is grown. Garcia invited the three along as observers.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Approves Drug to Ease Symptoms of Reproductive Disorder
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday approved a new drug that relieves the symptoms of endometriosis, a disorder of the reproductive tract that affects more than 4 million U.S. women. The drug, Synarel, is the first drug of its class to be approved for this condition. It will be marketed by Syntex Corp. Synarel is administered as a nasal spray twice daily for six months and works by stimulating and then suppressing production of estrogen, which controls the growth of the endometrial tissue that lines the uterus. Endometriosis occurs when this tissue, which usually is shed monthly with menstruation, migrates outside the uterus, most often into the abdominal and pelvic region, where it swells and bleeds during menstruation. This tissue implants on the ovaries, the intestines and the fallopian tubes, where it can cause blockage and infertility. Symptoms of endometriosis include severe menstrual cramps, pain during sexual intercourse, painful urination and painful bowel movements. Side effects of Synarel, which is nafarelin acetate, are the same as problems associated with menopause, including hot flashes, vaginal dryness and, less commonly, decreased sex drive, Syntex said. A small loss of bone density also can occur, but most is recovered after treatment is completed. Currently, the most widely prescribed drug for treatment of the symptoms of endometriosis is danazol, a derivative of a male sex hormone. Its side effects include weight gain, decrease in breast size, deepening of the voice, acne, oily skin and unwanted hair growth.

DOC.HEAD: FCC Rule Change Would Allow Dial-A-Porn Under Limited Conditions
DOC.TEXT: A proposed change in Federal Communications Commission rules would allow dial-a-porn services to transmit indecent material to adults if they required credit card payments, issued access codes, scrambled their messages and asked phone companies to list 900 calls to their services on customers' bills. The FCC is seeking public comment by March 2 on the rules, which the commission first adopted in 1987. But Congress, concerned that the rules were not tough enough to prevent enterprising youths from gaining access to the sex messages, banned dial-a-porn services outright in April 1988. But the Supreme Court overturned the law, saying the statute could apply only to commercial material that was judged obscene _ ``patently offensive'' and without redeeming value _ not merely indecent. The court said the technological safeguards proposed by the FCC were enough to ensure that minors would not reach the dial-a-porn services and, therefore, the government was left with no compelling reason to ban such calls for adults. The court retained the outright ban on for-pay obscene telephone material. In its notice Tuesday, the FCC asked for comment on the ``effectiveness, feasibility and need for the billing notification requirement ... in light of intervening statutory, regulatory or market changes.'' It also asked commenters to suggest alternatives, including technological advances and new telephone company service offerings, including a discussion of the related costs and benefits of each alternative.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Troop-Cut Agreement Removes Obstacle to Arms Treaty
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 10th graf: ``Preparing for,'' with Baker-Shevardnadze meeting
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, hailing ``historic change'' in superpower relations, said Wednesday that Soviet acceptance of his troop cut proposal removed a major obstacle to a conventional arms treaty for Europe. Bush said he was caught by surprise at how quickly the troop agreement and a separate pact to speed German unification had fallen into place. ``We're dealing with historic change,'' Bush told reporters. He added with a laugh, ``I mean to be very elated about this.'' Bush was criticized last year for his low-key public reaction to news that East Germany was opening the Berlin Wall. The latest developments came Tuesday in Ottawa in talks between Secretary of State James A. Baker III, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and other European foreign ministers. With Baker at his side, Bush said he was ``delighted'' with the agreement on troop cuts. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who last week called for parity with U.S. forces, agreed to a pullout that will leave both sides with 195,000 troops in Central Europe, but an additional 30,000 U.S. troops in Britain, Italy, Spain, Greece and Turkey. ``This is an important breakthrough which removes a major obstacle to the early conclusion of a CFE (Conventional Forces in Europe) treaty, and it also established the principle that U.S. forces in Europe are not to be treated as equivalent to Soviet forces in Eastern Europe,'' said Bush. ``Now, let's close the deal. That's what I want to do,'' he declared. ``There's still some technical problems in it.'' Preparing for other possible deals, notably on long-range nuclear weapons, Baker will meet Shevardnadze again in April in Washington to prepare for the June summit of Bush and Gorbachev, officials said. Despite the agreement on manpower ceilings, the United States and the Soviet Union still must settle differences over combat aircraft and anti-cheating procedures to wrap up a 23-nation treaty to reduce forces and weapons in Europe. The treaty is now under negotiation in Vienna between the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact. For treaty purposes, Central Europe is defined as West Germany, Denmark, Belgium, Luxembourg and the Netherlands for the U.S. side and East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary for Soviet troops. On the Germany question, the four powers that defeated Adolf Hitler's Nazi Germany in World War II _ the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France _ have agreed to meet with leaders of the two Germanys to lay the groundwork for unification. Bush, who had said Monday it was too early for a four powers' meeting on the future of Germany, said he was surprised at the pace of events. ``This brings us a step closer to realizing the longstanding goal of German unity,'' said Bush, who has insisted that a united Germany must belong to NATO. He also said the developments bring closer ``a Europe that is whole and free.'' Meanwhile, Yuri Dubinin, Soviet ambassador to the United States, said the manpower levels agreed upon at Ottawa ``are the ceiling and not the floor in our view.'' ``We should continue with these talks to secure the withdrawal of all foreign troops from Europe by 1995-1996 and the elimination of all military bases on foreign territories by the year 2000,'' Dubinin told a news conference. Bush, asked why he thought Gorbachev had acceded to his position on the troop cuts, said, ``Events are moving awfully fast there, and I think they see this as good for them. I hope they see it as a stabilizing agreement for Europe.'' Asked if the Warsaw Pact as well as NATO could have a role in a new Germany, Bush said: ``The allies want the stability of U.S. forces in Europe ... and a strong NATO. The Eastern European countries that make up the Warsaw Pact want the Soviets to leave. They have a different equation. ``We are talking about Germany remaining in NATO; flexibility on where the troops in Germany are, but a strong NATO,'' said Bush. Asked if he were ready to propose initiatives for talks on long-range nuclear missiles, Bush said he had not yet had a chance to talk to Baker since his return from Moscow and Ottawa. ``But now, guess what we're going to do? We're going to go in and talk about this,'' Bush said. Bush fielded questions from reporters after signing a $42 million aid package to help Panama recover from the effects of Manuel Antonio Noriega's dictatorship and the U.S. invasion that overthrew him. Some of the money was shifted from African aid accounts. Congress is still working on a $1 billion Panama aid package.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Leader Seeks to Discuss Reunification with Germans
With AM-The German Question, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Simon Wisenthal Center has asked to meet with the leaders of West and East Germany to discuss ``the great fear that German reunification brings to the community of victims of Nazism.'' ``I must tell you I am not among those in the cheering section applauding the rush towards German reunification,'' Rabbi Marvin Hier wrote Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany and Prime Minister Hans Modrow of East Germany. ``However, if that is the inevitable course, let us at least place on record our concerns,'' he said. Hier is the founder of the center, headquartered in Los Angeles, which seeks to keep alive the memory of the Nazi persecution of Jews in Germany and Nazi-conquered lands. In nearly identical letters, he asked to meet with Kohl during his forthcoming trip to Washington and with Modrow in Germany next month. The letters were made available Wednsday to The Associated Press. ``You are undoubtedly aware,'' he wrote both leaders, ``of the great fear that German reunification brings to the community of victims of Nazism.'' ``It is not an irrational fear of the kind that one explains away as the nightmares of victims who remain locked into their past and lose all perspective of present reality. ``The fears are real because those who bear the scars of the last `unified Germany' do not see their concerns being addressed in the current reunification discussions betwen world leaders.'' Hier listed 10 points he wanted to raise. Among them were a program to teach German schoolchildren about the annhilation of the Jews; the creation of an agency to monitor and prosecute hate groups; the continuation of the ``special relationship'' now existing between West Germany and Israel; the convening of a 1992 conference of world leaders on the 50th anniversary of the conference at which ``the final solution'' was developed; the establisment of a German commission to protect Holocaust sites; the banning of terrorist organizations that ``have enjoyed respectablity in East Germany;'' a cultural exchange program between German and Jewish organizations; German television and radio programs on the reconciliation; restitution payments to the families and victims of Nazism, and a German commitment to revitalize former synagogues in East German territory.

DOC.HEAD: Bright and Brief
DOC.TEXT: Valentine's Day may be a time to celebrate the quality of love _ but there's nothing wrong with a little quantity too. Just ask 167 couples who tied the knot or reaffirmed their vows together on a dance floor Wednesday. ``His mother passed away ... and said she'd always wanted us to have a large wedding,'' Kim Moore said before her marriage to Jeff Hamilton. ``What other place are you going to have 1,000 people at your wedding?'' The nuptials organized by radio station KATT featured a healthy helping of rock 'n' roll and a his-and-hers sing-along of the theme song from the 1960s TV show, ``Green Acres.'' In addition to the 94 couples getting married for the first time and the 74 reaffirming their vows, 668 guests packed the room at the Sheraton Century Center for the mass wedding. The couples lined up in rows along the dance floor included the very young and the middle-aged. Some men were decked out in tuxedoes, but others showed up in jeans and sneakers; many of the women wore elegant gowns. Everyone seemed to have a good time, and the mood was festive. ``It's fun. It's more relaxed,'' said Paul Arnold, who married his wife of 7{ years, Debby, for the second time. They said that after passing the seven-year mark, they felt it was time. The ceremony conducted by the Rev. Jack D. Denny was fairly standard until the end. ``Kiss the bride!'' Denny ordered, and the music began. The crowd joined in as the band performed the ``Green Acres'' theme, with couples singing the men's and women's parts.

It's tubular! Like, a dude at the Hawaii House of Representatives wants the Postal Service to put out a stamp honoring the daddy of surfing. According to Rep. Fred Hemmings, 1990 is, y'know, the 100th birthday of Duke Paoa Kahinu Makoe Hulikohola Kahanamoku. Hemmings said Tuesday that surfing's father should get the same respect as such sporting greats as Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig. The Legislature in 1985 passed a resolution asking the Postal Service to issue a Kahanamoku commemorative, but the request wiped out. Hemmings said Tuesday it's time to try again. ``We implore the United States Postal Service to recognize the achievements of great Hawaiian athletes who may have participated in sports not readily acknowledged by the Mainland states,'' he said. Totally happening.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Activist Hatcher Pleads Guilty, Gets 18 Years
DOC.TEXT: An Indian activist pleaded guilty Wednesday to 14 kidnap charges stemming from the armed seizure of a newsroom in 1988 and was sentenced to 18 years in prison. Eddie Hatcher, 32, and fellow Tuscarora tribesman Timothy Jacobs had claimed they were trying to draw attention to local law enforcement's alleged involvement in drug dealing when they held up to 20 people hostage at The Robesonian newspaper on Feb. 1, 1988. The pair, armed with shotguns, surrendered to the FBI after 10 hours. After Hatcher and Jacobs were tried and acquitted on federal kidnapping charges, a Robeson County grand jury indicted them on state charges. Jacobs pleaded guilty to kidnapping charges last year and received a six-year sentence. Hatcher made no statement during Wednesday's court appearance. He answered only ``yes'' or ``no'' as Superior Court Judge Coy Brewer Jr. asked him about the plea bargain. The hearing contrasted with Hatcher's last appearance, when he threw pens at a judge and called him a ``racist.'' Defense attorney Barry Nakell said Hatcher, who faced a maximum sentence of 420 years on the charges, had decided on his own to seek the plea bargain. Nakell said the newspaper seizure had led to some ``small measures of progress, but not the through investigation the situation deserves.'' District Attorney Richard Townsend said Hatcher and his attorneys had created a ``media circus'' with their charges, but none of them had been valid. ``There have been attempts to influence what happens in this courtroom by making accusations, and the wilder the better,'' Townsend said. ``But the only accusations that have been found to have any merit are the 14 charges of kidnapping in this case.'' Townsend said Hatcher's flight from Robeson County to seek asylum at two Indian reservations and the Soviet consulate in San Francisco, combined with his charges of official corruption, ``sounds like a plotline from `Dallas' with `Meet the Press' thrown in, and a dash of `Miami Vice.''' Townsend said the newspaper hostages had agreed to the plea bargain. ``It certainly was acceptable to me,'' said Lee Hamilton, one of The Robesonian reporters held. ``I definitely thought he (Hatcher) would drag it out as long as he could and get all the attention he could.''

DOC.HEAD: West Germany Offers New Aid; Both States Praise Unity Accord
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 21st and final graf, `Modrow and ...' to give Schaefer's full name.
DOC.TEXT: West Germany approved $3.6 billion in aid for East Germany on Wednesday to keep its economy afloat and prevent its citizens from fleeing in frustration until the two nations become one. An additional $1 billion was approved to resettle East Germans who come to the West. Though the money is earmarked for specific East German programs, none of it will go directly to the government of Communist Premier Hans Modrow, who likely will be ousted when the country holds its first free elections on March 18. Modrow, whose two-day summit here concluded Wednesday, had requested $9 billion in immediate direct aid Tuesday but was turned down by the government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Both leaders, however, hailed the landmark agreement by the Soviet Union, the United States, France and Britain that sets up a procedure for formal talks on reunification. The agreement by the four World War II Allies that defeated and divided Germany 45 years ago is a diplomatic breakthrough and a first step to a timetable for reunification. ``We see this as an exceptionally important development and a great success for the West German foreign minister, an important step toward German unity,'' Hanns Schumacher, a West German Foreign Ministry spokesman, said Wednesday. Modrow told reporters in Bonn that he welcomed the announcement, made during a meeting of Warsaw Pact and NATO nations Tuesday in Ottawa, and considered it the best means of protecting both German interests and those of the wartime allies. The accord follows Kohl's weekend visit to Moscow to meet with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who tacitly approved Germany reunification. The talks will take place in two parts. The two Germanys first will discuss merging their economies and other domestic issues. The second phase is to include the four wartime powers and will deal with the strategic and global implications of a united Germany, particularly its military allegiance. East German is a key component of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact and West Germany serves much the same role in NATO. The United States wants to keep a united Germany in NATO, while the Soviets are pressing for German neutrality. During the talks between the Germanys, West Germany has a commanding position because of its vibrant economy, which will be needed to bail out the financially ailing eastern state, where thousands are fleeing to the West. Modrow, who spoke with West Germany industrial leaders on the last day of his visit, told reporters before returning to East Berlin that he was disappointed by Kohl's rejection of East Germany's appeal for immediate aid. Government and opposition political forces had asked for up to $9 billion to help the East German government until the election. West German Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann said Bonn turned down the request because it ``makes no sense'' to grant loans or credits to East Germany when so little is known of its economic situation. However, Finance Minister Theo Waigel on Wednesday announced Cabinet approval of $2.4 billion to modernize East Germany's aging factories, repair roads, install a new phone system and other ``immediate measures'' to improve production and living standards. The 1990 budget supplement also provides $1 billion to cope with the costs of tens of thousands of East Germans resettling in West Germany, and an additional $1.2 billion for a contingency fund for unforeseen expenses related to East German reforms. Haussmann told reporters that the bulk of the money would be available immediately. But the funds are earmarked for specific projects and will not be at Modrow's disposal to cover daily expenses and the East German government's mounting debts. Modrow and Kohl did agree on Tuesday to establish a joint commission to work out a formula for merging the two economic systems after the March 18 elections. Bonn government spokesman Norbert Schaefer said the group would hold its first talks on Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Fighting Between Rival Groups Injures 68; 78 Refugees Voluntarily Return
DOC.TEXT: Police fired tear gas Wednesday to stop a second day of factional fights at a detention center among Vietnamese boat people armed with stones and iron bars, officials reported. Government spokeswoman Fanny Kong said at least 68 people had been injured in the battles _ 38 boat people and 30 staff members of the Correctional Services Department, which runs the camp. Violence has broken out before in the British colony's squalid refugee camps, where about 44,000 people who fled their Communist homeland have landed since mid-June 1988 in hopes of starting new lives. Five people were killed in riots last year. In December, 51 Vietnamese were repatriated against their will, leading to increased tension in the camps. About 70 Vietnamese rioted for nearly two hours Wednesday morning in the Whitehead Detention Center. Some set fire to dormitories before 300 police and correctional services reinforcements reached the scene, Ms. Kong said. About 300 Vietnamese had taken part in a two-hour brawl the previous night that also was stopped by police firing tear gas. Refugee coordinator Mike Hanson said most of the fighting was between rival groups of Vietnamese from Haiphong and Quong Ninh, and ``the spark for the latest disturbance seems to have been thefts and revenge attacks.'' Police found more than 500 homemade weapons, including iron bars and knives, swords and spears made of scrap metal, window railings and bed frames, a government statement said. The Vietnamese are considered illegal immigrants unless they can prove they fled persecution. Those who are denied refugee status and lose appeals can volunteer to go home or face forced repatriation. Seventy-eight Vietnamese who fled to Hong Kong illegally returned home voluntarily, the official Vietnam News Agency reported. The group, the 12th to be repatriated from Hong Kong, arrived in Hanoi on Tuesday, the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Sharon Says He Will Form New Likud Faction
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with Sharon saying he will resubmit resignation, form new party faction. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Industry Minister Ariel Sharon, who resigned this week, said Wednesday he will form a new faction to pressure his right-wing Likud bloc into taking a tougher stand on peace and the Palestinian uprising. Attorney General Yosef Harish ruled earlier Wednesday that the resignation was invalid because Sharon did not tell the government of his plans before submitting a letter to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. That gives the former defense minister until the weekly Cabinet meeting Sunday to reconsider, but Sharon said Wednesday he would resubmit his resignation at the meeting. It would take affect 48 hours later. On Israel television, Sharon said: ``I must, according to regulations, submit my resignation again. This I will do.'' ``On the same day, I intend ... to announce that I will go out and fight for a new policy and for achieving security. I got up from my chair to begin marching so that in the future someone will not say, `How come you didn't warn us of the coming disaster?''' On Monday, Sharon told the Cabinet his main reason for resigning was to protest Shamir's plan for holding elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip as a prelude to peace talks. He claimed Shamir had left an opening for possible PLO involvement in negotiations by not ruling out Palestinians deported by Israel during the 26-month-old uprising in the occupied lands. He also has urged the military to use harsher measures in the territories. At least 656 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers during the uprising and 182 have been slain by other Palestinians, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel. Forty-three Israelis have died. Sharon said he will visit local Likud branches to seek support and will travel abroad to meet with leaders of Jewish communities. He accused Shamir of leading ``a silent government that is incapable of adopting any decisions.'' Two Israeli sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Foreign Minister Moshe Arens might stop in Washington later this week on the way to Mexico. That could be a step toward a meeting Secretary of State James A. Baker III has sought with Arens and Esmat Abdel-Meguid, the Egyptian foreign minister, as a way of beginning talks between Israel and Palestinians. Sharon, 62, directed Israel's 1982 invasion of Lebanon as defense minister. He was forced to resign in 1983 when an Israeli commission found he bore some responsiblity for the massacre of hundreds of Palestinians in Beirut refugee camps by Lebanese militias allied with Israel. Shamir's spokesman, Avi Pazner, indicated Wednesday the prime minister did not want Sharon in the Cabinet and was seeking to remove him as chairman of Likud's Central Committee. Associates of Shamir said he would have more room to maneuver in the peace effort with Sharon out of the way. In another development Wednesday, the army reported that Israeli soldiers killed a Palestinian guerrilla who infiltrated Israel's border ``security zone'' in southern Lebanon, and allied militiamen captured three of his comrades. It said the infiltrators were spotted at midday on the bridge to Beaufort Castle, a Crusader fort three miles north of the border, and ``their intention was to attack Israeli forces in the security zone.'' Three infiltrators were killed in the same area Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Whale Sightings Up, But Farther South Than Usual
DOC.TEXT: The government raised its count of gray whales along the Baja California coast Wednesday but said there were still fewer whales than normal. It also said the main concentrations had gathered nearly 300 miles farther south than usual. ``In the southern part of the distribution zone more than 500 whales were observed,'' Luis Fleischer, head of the National Marine Mammal Program, said in a statement by the Fisheries Department. The Ecology Department reported no more than 120 grays on Monday in the Pacific waters of Baja California, where the marine mammals migrate annually to reproduce. But department experts also said that bad weather had limited a weekend survey. The grays ``continue to be behind schedule and we know that they are arriving at points further south than usual, but we can't say why,'' Fisheries Department spokesman Elias Kuri said Wednesday in a telephone interview. The whales have traditionally given birth in three lagoons within the Vizcaina Biosphere Reserve, 330 miles south of San Diego, where a population of 900 to 1,150 can usually be observed this time of year, reserve biologist Jorge Hernandez said. Some grays would travel to a lagoon about 260 miles farther south called Magdalena Bay. However, Fleischer said the terfront corruption. ``They throw his name around just to throw it around,'' Cutler said. ``It's a continuing vendetta.'' Gotti, who was acquitted last week for the third time in criminal cases, and the other individuals face no criminal charges in this case. The suit instead seeks to remove from office any ILA officer convicted of violating federal racketeering laws, and to allow appointment of trustees to oversee union elections and discipline ILA officials. The defendants also could be forced to pay back illegal profits. ``We're trying to take the ILA away from the mob and give it back to the ILA rank and file,'' said Fox, the FBI agent. The ILA locals named in the suit were Local 1804-1 of North Bergen, N.J.; Local 1588 of Bayonne, N.J.; Local 814 in Brooklyn; and Locals 1809, 824 and 1909, all in Manhattan on the West Side. According to the suit, the Genovese family controlled the New Jersey locals; the Gambino family, the Brooklyn local; and the Westies, through influence of the Gambino family, the Manhattan locals. Thirty-two present and former ILA officials, including current ILA president John Bowers, also were sued. In addition to his position with the association, Bowers is president of the three Manhattan locals named in the suit. Most of the allegations in the suit are based on previous criminal cases. The guilty pleas two weeks ago in Brooklyn's federal court of two ILA officials and the racketeering conviction in 1988 of Donald Carson, the second highest ranking ILA official, also were cited. Another case listed was the Westies racketeering prosecution of 1988 in which McElroy and other Westies members were convicted of controlling the West Side piers through violence. Coonan is serving a 75-year sentence. Leonard Newman, the executive director of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor, said that despite the numerous convictions of ILA officials, corruption continued. ``Out of office is not out of power,'' he said. Thornburgh said the individual prosecutions were not successful in removing the ``pervasive influence of organized crime'' from the waterfront. He said the civil suit was needed to attack corruption as ``a systemic problem.'' The case is similar to one the federal government settled with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters last year, in which the government tried to wrest control from allegedly corrupt union leaders through court-appointed administrators. Another suit against the union at Manhattan's landmark Fulton Fish Market was unsuccessful. In January 1989 a judge rejected the government's attempt to take over the union. The ILA suit was assigned to U.S. District Judge Leonard B. Sand, who will hold a hearing on the case Feb. 26.

DOC.HEAD: Valentine's Day Weather Wet, Windy
DOC.TEXT: America got a cold, wet kiss on Valentine's Day, with most of the country dampened by snow, freezing rain or rain. Even normally sunny Southern California faced snow flurries, hail, showers, fog and winds up to 52 mph that made travel treacherous. Temperatures varied widely across the nation Wednesday. Low-temperature records up to 62 years old were broken in eight Western cities. In the Northeast, high-temperature marks were snapped in four cities and tied in two others. Snow fell in sections of Illinois, Wisconsin, Iowa, Kansas, Nebraska, Oklahoma, Arizona, Colorado, Wyoming, Idaho, Utah, Montana, Washington state and Oregon. Snow mixed with freezing rain, a mixture of freezing rain and rain, and rain stretched from the Texas Panhandle to Oklahoma, Kansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana, Ohio and Pennsyvlania. The weather caused scores of traffic accidents in the Midwest, and canceled or delayed a number of flights at Chicago's O'Hare International and Midway airports, officials said. In Southern California, strong onshore winds, high waves and choppy seas halted overnight cleanup work along beaches contaminated by last week's 400,000-gallon oil spill and most offshore oil skimming, officials said. High winds or snow grounded helicopters, stranded at least 30 tractor-trailers on Interstate 5 in a mountain pass linking Southern California with the north called the Grapevine, and prompted urgent road warnings. Winds hit 52 mph in Daggett about 90 miles northeast of downtown Los Angeles. In Los Angeles, rare hail and snow fell, but melted soon after landing. At Malibu's Paradise Cove, a few minutes of snow drew double takes from people at the Sand Castle restaurant near the homes of Dick Clark and Johnny Carson, according to waitress Debbie Alme. ``Everybody in the restaurant went, `Whoa! What's that?''' she said. ``One lady thought they were filming a movie.'' The weather forecast held unseasonably low temperatures for the region Wednesday night, with wind chills as low as 30 below zero. A warning for freezing temperatures was posted for the valleys. In addition to Southern California, wind warnings were posted for Arizona. Gale warnings were in effect for much of the northern Pacific Coast. Warnings of strong winds today were posted over the mountains of southern California and central Arizona. Warning of gale force winds tonight were also posted over much of the northern Pacific Coast. Snowfall in the six hours ending at 1 p.m. EST included 3 inches at Grand Junction, Colo., and an inch in Moline, Ill. Low-temperature records included 17 degrees in Olympia, Wash., where the old mark for the date had stood since 1928. Other records included 20 degrees in Portland, Ore., 22 degrees in Seattle and 39 degrees in Oakland, Calif. Across the continent, high-temperature records up to 41 years old were smashed.
