Cities where high marks were set included Washington, D.C., (71 degrees, 70 in 1951); and Atlantic City, N.J., (72, 67 in 1949). Philadelphia tied its 1946 record of 67 degrees. The low temperature for the Lower 48 states was 29 degrees below zero in Ely and International Falls, Minn. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 0 degrees at Warroad, Minn., to 84 degrees in Sarasota, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Five Killed in Crash of Gubernatorial Candidate's Plane
DOC.TEXT: A small plane carrying five business associates of Republican gubernatorial candidate Clayton Williams crashed and burned in a rural area Wednesday, killing everyone aboard, officials said. Williams put his campaign on hold and gathered the victims' families at his home after learning of the morning crash five miles south of Putnam, about 150 miles west of Dallas. ``All were business associates and dear, dear friends of Clayton's. They were all based in Midland and flying from Midland to Dallas on a business trip,'' said Mona Palmer, a campaign spokesman for Williams. Williams is considered the Republican front-runner in a March 13 primary for the seat that will be vacated by Republican Gov. Bill Clements. The victims were not members of Williams' campaign staff ``but they were key advisors and key people to his campaign,'' Ms. Palmer said. The wreckage was burning when it was spotted by a pipeline patrol airplane, National Transportation Safety Board Regional Director Tommy McFall said. He said it wasn't known if the fire started before or after the crash. The pilot of the Mitsubishi MU-2 twin-engine turboprop had requested a lower altitude from 15,000 feet, said Ray Wall, an investigator with the NTSB in Fort Worth. The plane went off radar after it reached 14,800, Wall said. NTSB investigator Warren Wandel, who was at the scene, said it appeared the plane was out of control and crashed at high speed, nose first. Ms. Palmer said the plane apparently hit a utility pole. Reporters at the crash scene said the craft also hit power lines. The plane is owned by one of Williams' companies, Williams Aviation. The victims were identified as: Jamie Winkel, 45, chief executive officer of Clayton W. Williams Jr. Companies; Randy M. Kidwell, 37, vice president for business development of Advanced Telecommunications Corp. and a former Williams' employee; Robert Smith, 62, president of R.R. Smith Consulting; Aaron Giebel, 63, president of Aaron Giebel Petroleum Ltd.; and pilot Kenneth Mardis, 51. Smith and Giebel were board members for Williams' ClayDesta National Bank.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Reserves Right to Lift Sanctions on Pretoria
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Britain will confer with its European Community partners about ending sanctions against South Africa, but it reserves the right to act on its own, Foreign Office Minister William Waldegrave said Wednesday. ``Of course we are obliged, and willingly would accept, the obligation to consult with our partners in the EC, which is what we will do,'' Waldegrave said in a House of Commons debate on South Africa policy. ``If we fail to reach agreement the government must reserve its rights to act on its own if necessary _ and that is the legal position.'' Earlier, Waldegrave's chief, Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd, sidestepped persistent inquiries from Gerald Kaufman, foreign policy spokesman for the opposition Labor Party, who wanted him to say if the government would act unilaterally. Since Nelson Mandela, leader of the African National Congress, was freed from prison on Sunday, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has said she intends to try to get the 12-nation European Community to drop a ban on new investment and on promoting tourism to South Africa, both voluntary measures. She hinted she will go ahead alone if necessary. EC foreign ministers will discuss the issue Tuesday in Dublin, Ireland. Kaufman called Mrs. Thatcher the ``world's best friend of apartheid.'' Hurd said the government firmly rejected South Africa's racial segregation policy. ``It is wrong, it doesn't work, and the sooner it is ended the better,'' Hurd said. Opposition lawmakers jeered Mrs. Thatcher on Tuesday when she defended her position on sanctions. She did not participate in the more subdued debate Wednesday. Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock said if sanctions were lifted, the only force for change left in South Africa would be ``mass action with all its risks.'' Hurd said the government was not proposing to lift all sanctions. ``What we are proposing is a step-by-step approach _ a measured approach.''

DOC.HEAD: Country's Only Nuclear Medicine Isotope Manufacturer Shut Down
DOC.TEXT: The nation's principal maker of radioactive isotopes for nuclear medicine was shut down indefinitely because of a leak in its reactor cooling system, the third in three months, officials said. The U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission and the state Department of Environmental Conservation ordered the CintiChem reactor shut down Tuesday until the company proves it can operate without radioactive leaks, according to a joint statement. Tests showed none of the leaks were a threat to public health, said Dr. Ronald Massey, head of the NRC's on-site inspection team. The company, located about 50 miles northwest of New York City, manufactures radioactive isotopes _ unstable forms of ordinary elements _ from uranium. The isotopes are made into medical tracers for diagnosing cancer and other diseases. ``One out of every three or four people in the United States are affected by what nuclear medicine does,'' said David Gallaher, company operations director. An expert on nuclear medicine said Wednesday that hospitals and other medical facilities would be searching for an alternate source of technetium 99, the principal radioisotope used in nuclear medicine. Technetium, which does not exist in nature, also is produced in Canada and Europe, and may also be available from the U.S. Department of Energy, said Dr. Stanley Goldsmith, a member of the state Low-Level Radioactive Waste Siting Commission and a member of the Physics-Nuclear Medicine Department at Mount Sinai Medical Center. Goldsmith said CintiChem was ``the major producer of radionuclides (isotopes) for medicine and biology for the northern hemisphere, maybe north and south.'' ``I think there is going to be a shuffling and hopefully there will be provisions made,'' said Goldsmith. ``They probably have supplies for a week of the short-lived material.'' In a letter to company officials, the NRC acknowledged the effects the suspension could have on nuclear medicine, said NRC spokesman Steve Horwitz. ``Therefore, please keep the regional administrator informed of the impact of this order on the ability of the medical community to obtain radioisotopes,'' the letter said. All of the leaks were contained, and none allowed radioactive material to reach the nearby Indian Kill Reservoir, which serves more than 100 households, company officials said. The latest leak was found in a water tank that is part of the reactor cooling system. It was confined to a pump room, said plant manager James J. McGovern. The shutdown order requires CintiChem to determine causes of the leaks and check for equipment breakdowns; show how repairs will be done and prove that they will hold; and put together a monitoring program to assure prompt detection of future leaks. In addition, the state DEC intends to delay approval of CintiChem's air emissions and drainage runoff discharge permits until the company does a detailed environmental audit for possible on-site contamination. McGovern said much of the required repair work is underway. CintiChem also was cited for six violations of NRC regulations in October. The company faces both federal and state fines, but has challenged the citations.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Mistrial After Witness Says He Lied Under Pressure From China
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge declared a mistrial in a Chinese heroin-smuggling case Wednesday after a key prosecution witness said he had lied under pressure and death threats from Chinese officials. U.S. District Judge William Orrick halted proceedings in the case against three men, accused in connection with $700,000 worth of heroin found inside dead goldfish, after the witness recanted his testimony and said he had been tortured in a Shanghai prison. He is seeking asylum in the United States. The case, which dates from March 1988, was the first international drug prosecution involving cooperation between Chinese and U.S. officials. Orrick said the breakdown of the trial was ``proof positive you can't meld the legal system in the People's Republic of China with the legal system in the United States.'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Eric Swenson told reporters Orrick's conclusion was valid for this case, but ``I'm still confident that this type of problem does not have to affect future cases. ... The legal system in China is almost identical to many of the western European systems.'' No decision has been made on a retrial, Swenson said. Federal drug agents said in 1988 that seven pounds of Southeast Asian heroin had been put inside condoms that were sewed into the bodies of goldfish and mixed into shipments of live goldfish from China to the United States. Three men arrested in San Francisco, Leung Tak-Lun, Chico Wong and Andrew Wong, were charged with possessing heroin with intent to distribute. The witness, Wang Zong-Xiao, was arrested in Shanghai in March 1988 and held there for most of the time until last December, when he was brought to San Francisco. He testified Feb. 1 that he took part in the heroin shipment along with Leung. But Wang filed for asylum four days later, saying he had been threatened with death by officials from Shanghai who accompanied him to the United States. He said in court papers that he had been coerced into confessing and warned by the Chinese officials not to reveal the coercion or the later beatings and electric shocks he was given; not to contradict testimony of Shanghai security officers, and not to disclose that students and workers were held and tortured in the Shanghai prison. Wang returned to the witness stand Tuesday, outside the presence of the jury, described his torture in China, and said he had lied in his testimony that implicated Leung. Orrick said Wednesday he was declaring a mistrial because of the allegations of perjured testimony, and because the Chinese government had not provided defense lawyers before the trial with Wang's earlier statements, as the judge's order required. After those actions, any conviction in the case would surely be reversed on appeal, he told the jury. He also noted that the two Shanghai officers who accompanied Wang to San Francisco had returned suddenly to China on Sunday. ``I don't think you'll be seeing them again,'' Orrick said. The judge issued an order last week prohibiting U.S. officials from returning Wang to China while his asylum application is pending. Cedric Chao, a lawyer appointed to represent Wang, said the case for asylum is strong, and described Wang as ``at peace with himself'' after his latest testimony. ``It would be unconscionable to send him back to China to face certain death,'' Chao told reporters.

DOC.HEAD: Selma Schools Returning to Normal; Roussell to File Suit
DOC.TEXT: Selma school officials said attendance figures approached normal levels Wednesday and no major problems occurred as students returned to classes a second day after a weeklong shutdown. ``There were no fights and no arrests,'' James Carter, an aide to the school superintendent, said of the 11 public schools closed by racial protests. But the man whose contract termination prompted the protests, Superintendent Norward Roussell, said Wednesday he will file a federal lawsuit against the school board. ``I plan to protect my right under Title 7 of the 1964 Civil Rights Act and to charge that the board's termination or failure to extend my contract was racially motivated, among other things,'' said Roussell, the first black to hold the post in the historic civil rights city. The protests began when white school board members refused to extend Roussell's contract beyond June. Carter said 92 percent of the enrolled students attended classes Wednesday. At Selma High School, where student protesters held a five-day sit-in, 86 percent of the enrolled students were back in class. The absenteeism rate of 14 percent was down significantly from Tuesday's figures. Absenteeism in the city school system is normally around five percent, according to Roussell. It was 23 percent Tuesday, when schools reopened amid heavy security, and down to eight percent Wednesday. Roussell said he hopes that all parents will soon return their children to school and that the schools, guarded by police, National Guardsmen and state troopers, will soon ``no longer look like armed camps.'' Most of the absentees have been blacks, including about 150 who marched around the flagpole in front of Selma High School on Tuesday and chanted slogans.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Murdered in Sri Lanka, Amnesty International Reports
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people disappeared or were murdered by government forces, death squads and insurgents in Sri Lanka last year, Amnesty International said in a report released early Thursday. Reports of killings increased sharply after emergency regulations introduced in June 1989 permitted the immediate disposal of bodies, the London-based human rights group said. ``Members of the security forces who commit murder are aided and abetted by these regulations,'' the group's report said. Amensty International acknowledged the government faces extensive violent opposition. ``Nevertheless, armed opposition violence can never justify torture or deliberate killings of prisoners and civilians by government forces,'' the report said. It said the tactics of Sri Lankan security forces and allied death squads ``increasingly mirrored the criminal violence of the armed opposition Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna (People's Liberation Front).'' The front is a Sinhalese nationalist group opposed to the Sinhalese-dominated government's 1987 peace plan with the Tamils in the northeast. The Sinhalese group, according to the report, is believed to be responsible for thousands of murders since it began its insurgency in the south in 1987. ``Thousands of prisoners were detained in the south without charge or trial under emergency regulations and there were widespread allegations of torture and deaths in custody,'' Amnesty International said. In the northeast, Indian troops who were sent to enforce the peace plan were reported to have committed summary executions and ``there were numerous allegations of torture of prisoners by members of the (Indian force),'' the report said. The last of the Indian troops are to be withdrawn by the end of March. Amnesty International also said the guerrilla group the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam ``were generally believed responsible for hundreds of murders, including the killing of prisoners and civilians.'' The Liberation Tigers oppose the Indian troop presence and are fighting for autonomy. Tamils comprise about 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million population. Most Tamils are Hindus and they say they are discriminated against by the Buddhist Sinhalese majority. Nationwide ``it is impossible to estimate the true number of victims, and although some bodies were identified by relatives, the identities of many remain unknown,'' Amnesty International said. ``Hundreds of victims have been mutilated beyond recognition, burnt in heaps on tires or in pits, or have been thrown into rivers,'' it said. Amnesty International said the victims included lawyers who had taken up human rights cases and witnesses to alleged cases of human rights violations.

DOC.HEAD: Actress Thrust Center Stage in Trump Divorce War
LaserPhotos NY55,86
DOC.TEXT: Friends say she's no homewrecker. Her agent says she's got nothing to do with it. And the media are ready to tell you everything you ever wanted _ or didn't want _ to know about actress Marla Maples, who's been thrust center stage in the battle of the Trumps. For instance: Did you know her most unsung attribute from the knees down is her feet? This timely nugget comes in a New York Post story on Wednesday headlined: ``Tale of the tape in the battle of the belles,'' which gives scintillating facts like Ivana Trump's dress size (6) and Ms. Maples' weight (125). Mrs. Trump's most unsung attribute, by the way, is her toenails. Are we getting silly yet? Billionaire developer Donald Trump officially left the couple's penthouse Sunday. On Monday, we learned of the prenuptial agreement that would give Ivana $25 million, custody of the Trumps' three children, and their Connecticut mansion. Tuesday's headlines said Ivana wanted more: the jet, the Plaza Hotel and $150 million. Mrs. Trump pooh-poohed the latter, calling it a ``figment of someone's imagination,'' and told Daily News columnist Liz Smith all she wanted was a fair, equitable share of Trump's estimated $1.7 billion fortune. On Wednesday, Trump tried to explain the breakup, saying, ``I have always loved Ivana. Unfortunately, we have grown apart.'' Mrs. Trump said nothing, even when confronted by a horde of reporters and cameras at her 41st birthday party at an expensive French restaurant. Blanketed by Trump security men, she looked upset and scared. Some in the crowd applauded as the fur-clad Mrs. Trump alighted from her jet-black Mercedes, and several women shouted their advice: ``Get the money, Ivana.'' ``She was tickled,'' columnist Smith, who attended the lunch, said afterward. ``I mean, I don't think she expected it.'' About 15 socialite friends and relatives, including Trump's mother, Mary, and sister-in-law, Blaine, showed up but had little or nothing to say. ``Nobody spoke ill of Donald,'' said TV personality Barbara Walters, another lunch guest. ``There was a lot of laughing and a lot of good will.'' To say New Yorkers are interested in the Trump split's seamy details is putting it mildly. The city's three tabloids on Wednesday devoted a total of 13 inside and two front pages to the breakup of the couple's nearly 13-year marriage. The media have also descended on Ms. Maples' hometown of Dalton, Ga., the self-proclaimed carpet capital of the world, and inundated her parents with queries about their only daughter's life. Anyone who ever knew the 26-year-old actress is being asked for an opinion on the Trump split and Ms. Maples' alleged role. ``Heavens to Betsy, she's no homewrecker,'' said Margaret Culberson of Dalton, who coached Ms. Maples in a regional Miss Georgia Teen pageant. ``She's one of the sweetest persons you've ever seen.'' The actress, a former bikini-clad pinup for Delta Air Lines' ``Fly Florida'' campaign, found herself at the center of the Trump storm after published reports had her arguing with Mrs. Trump during an Aspen, Colo., vacation. Even the venerable Fifth Avenue church where the Trumps were married became part of the story. Ms. Maples met Trump at Marble Collegiate Church, and the two sat together fairly regularly, a source who spoke on condition of anonymity told The Associated Press. About 14 months ago, Trump sought counseling from Arthur Caliandro, the church's minister, about his relationship with Ms. Maples, according to the source who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``He (Trump) was quite broken up'' over the emotional conflicts between the relationship and his marriage, the source said. Trump had decided at the time it would be best for all concerned if he stopped seeing Ms. Maples. There were also reports that Trump paid for Ms. Maples' room at the St. Moritz hotel (which he once owned) and that the actress, who has had only small walk-on parts on TV and one forgettable movie, is ready to marry him. All of this, said her agent, Chuck Jones, is garbage. Jones said he paid for her room at the St. Moritz, where she filmed a soda commercial. ``It was a job,'' he said. ``She has nothing to do with this,'' Jones said. ``She doesn't need the publicity and doesn't want it.'' If she was a certain type of person, Jones said, Ms. Maples could capitalize on the brouhaha. ``She was just offered $250,000 by the National Enquirer to tell her story but since there's no story to tell, she turned them down,'' he said. ``She's not interested and she's gotten plenty of offers for work,'' said Jones. He said all the media attention is ``a disservice to Ivana and Donald Trump because they're good people. They don't deserve it. ... and Marla Maples doesn't deserve it, either. She's got too much class.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Kill 19 Guerrillas in Jungle Battle
DOC.TEXT: A police patrol killed 19 Shining Path rebels in a jungle battle, the interior ministry said Wednesday. According to a statement issued by the ministry, a police patrol encountered the rebel column Tuesday morning near Andamarca, 165 miles east of Lima. An ensuing firefight left 19 guerrillas dead, the report said. No casualties were reported among the police. Police later found an arms cache that included automatic weapons and 250 sticks of dynamite, the interior ministry said. Also Wednesday, police in Ayacucho, 235 miles southeast of Lima, said six Shining Path rebels broke into the home of an education ministry employee Tuesday night and shot her in the head. Police identified the woman as Dolores Chavez, 50, a teacher and deputy director of the education ministry in Ayacucho state. The government says more than 17,500 people have died since the Shining Path launched its armed insurgency in 1980, including police, soldiers, rebels, government officials and civilians.

DOC.HEAD: CBS to Build New Studios
DOC.TEXT: CBS said Wednesday it plans to build two new studios worth more than $15 million at its Television City center in Los Angeles, the largest expansion of its production facilities in 20 years. The studios mainly will be used for the production of situation comedies, but also for daytime shows on weekends, CBS said. Construction is expected to take about 18 months. The network's Television City currently has five studios. CBS also co-owns a television production center with MTM Productions at the old Republic Studios in Studio City, Calif., and has its own Broadcast Center in New York, where the network produces news programs and daytime shows.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Traveling to Colombia With Lean Staff For Security Reasons
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 14th graf, bgng: ``There will xxx to UPDATE with report on U.S. plans for electronic monitoring of flights from Colombia and White House comment.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will refuse to meet with Peruvian coca growers at the Colombian drug summit and will travel to Cartagena with a sharply reduced staff because of concerns for his safety, White House officials said Wednesday. On the eve of the one-day meeting of four hemispheric nations, the White House also retreated from previous suggestions that Bush would revive a proposal to send U.S. Navy warships into South American waters to track cocaine-trafficking planes. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater denounced the kidnapping of two American citizens in Colombia on Tuesday by leftist guerrillas who said they were protesting Bush's impending visit. While saying that Bush shared concerns over the two Americans' safety, Fitzwater asserted that ``the United States government cannot allw threats of terrorism to influence its policies or its activities.'' Bush will fly to Colombia early Thursday, joining Presidents Virgilio Barco of Colombia, Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia and Alan Garcia of Peru for six hours of anti-drug talks at a heavily guarded navy base at Cartagena. The four leaders plan to issue a joint statement pledging to cooperate in the fight against drug trafficking. Bush's summit partners were expected to press him for more economic aid to ease their farmers' shift from lucrative coca plants _ used to produce cocaine _ to growing legal crops. The United States has pledged a $206 million increase in spending on military, law enforcement and economic assistance for Peru, Colombia and Bolivia next year, as part of a five-year, $2.2 billion Andean aid package. Garcia, who had once threatened to boycott the summit because of the U.S. invasion of Panama, has invited a group of Peruvian coca growers to accompany him to the Cartagena summit to underscore the economic impact of eradicating cocaine production, Fitzwater said. ``We have no opinion of that,'' Fitzwater said. ``He can take anybody he wants. That's fine.'' But Fitzwater said Bush would not meet with the coca growers and indicated that the United States does not want the growers to attend the summit sessions. `This is a summit meeting between the heads of state,'' Fitzwater said. ``There will not be other ancilliary kinds of activities involved.'' On the issue of U.S. naval warships in South American waters, Fitzwater would not rule out the possibility of a summit discussion of using U.S. vessels. But he said Bush did not intend to raise the subject because it is such a sensitive issue in Latin America, particularly since the Panama invasion. Brent Scowcroft, the White House national security adviser, had broached the idea Tuesday during a meeting with reporters. Fitzwater said resulting press accounts had caused ``some consternation'' among U.S. officials who were worried about how Scowcroft's remarks might be interpreted in Latin America. ``There will be no military assistance for drug fighting to any country that is not requested by them, coordinated through them and executed in support of their counternarcotic objectives,'' Fitzwater said. NBC reported Wednesday that the United States is setting up an ``electronic picket fence'' in the air and on the ground to monitor suspected drug flights from Colombia. The report said the U.S. forces are supposed to spot the planes and the Colombian forces will chase them. NBC, citing American military sources, said American cargo planes and as many as 160 U.S. soldiers already are on the ground in Colombia. White House spokeswoman Alixe Glen said she knew nothing about the NBC report. Despite stringent security precautions being taken in Colombia, there were deep concerns about protecting Bush in a country where drug lords are blamed for widescale bombings, assassinations and other violence. Fitzwater said the United States has ``every assurances of safety and maximum security'' from Colombian officials. ``I think, however, that it is clear from the past history that one cannot rule out various kinds of activities at some location,'' he said. Fitzwater said Bush's official entourage has been reduced to ``a minimal staff'' and that the usual backup plane for other traveling aides has been eliminated. Fitzwater said the purpose was ``to eliminate any excess personnel and for security reasons, to simply not have any more people there than is absolutely necessary.'' Bush will be accompanied by Secretary of State James A. Baker III, White House chief of staff John Sununu, Scowcroft, drug policy director William Bennett, Fitzwater and a handful of other aides.

DOC.HEAD: Innocent Plea Entered For Man Accused Of Rebecca Schaeffer Slaying
DOC.TEXT: A judge entered an innocent plea Wednesday for a man accused of stalking and killing actress Rebecca Schaeffer, despite protests that the defendant was extradited illegally. Deputy Public Defender Stephen Galindo refused to enter a plea on his client's behalf, stating that John Bardo's extradition from Arizona to California was a mistake and the court therefore had no jurisdiction. ``His transportation was in fact illegal and in violation of both Arizona and California codes and federal procedures,'' said Galindo, who has asked that the case be dismissed. Superior Court Judge Gary Klausner entered the plea and a denial of a special circumstance allegation of lying in wait. If convicted of murder and the allegation, Bardo could be sentenced to death in the gas chamber. Klausner set a pretrial hearing March 1 before Superior Court Judge Jacqueline Connor, said Sandi Gibbons, a district attorney's office spokeswoman. ``The court is taking the position that it wants to hurry this thing along,'' Galindo said. Miss Schaeffer, 21, a co-star in the TV series ``My Sister Sam,'' was gunned down at the front door of her apartment on July 18, 1989. Bardo was arrested the next day in Tucson, Ariz., as the 19-year-old man ran in and out of traffic on an interstate highway in what may have been a suicide attempt. District Attorney Ira Reiner announced Aug. 10, 1989, that his office had seized on an inadvertent mistake in the paperwork by Bardo's Tucson lawyer to move in and spirit the defendant out of Arizona overnight. Deputy District Attorney Marcia Clark, who has said the unorthodox transfer would not have any impact on prosecution, said Wednesday that since Bardo is here now, Galindo's arguments regarding extradition are moot. Bardo, clothed in jeans and T-shirt, stayed silent through Wednesday's proceedings. Galindo said Bardo, of Tucson, has been medicated from time to time while in custody. He did not know what kind of medicine his client was taking.

DOC.HEAD: ABC Axes ``Mission Impossible''
DOC.TEXT: ABC, which in 1988 revived the ``Mission Impossible'' series that CBS aired from 1966 to 1973, said Wednesday it is taking that low-rated show off the air and replacing it with a series called ``H.E.L.P.'' ``Mission Impossible,'' a Saturday series, is being put on ``hiatus,'' ABC said, and will have its last broadcast on Feb. 14. The show had low ratings this season. ``H.E.L.P,'' about a New York emergency unit made up of police officers, firefighters and paramedics, will premiere on March 3. Its initials stand for Harlem Eastside Lifesaving Program. NBC this season began a similar series, ``True Blue,'' which airs on Fridays and is about a police emergency unit.

DOC.HEAD: Najib Pleads Anew for Afghan Peace Negotiations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 3 grafs at end of story to UPDATE with Kabul complaints lodged iwth United Nations. ^With AM-Afghan-Year After, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Najib pleaded anew to Afghan opposition forces to enter into peace talks in an address to the nation on the eve of the first anniversary of the Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan. Soviet Foreign Ministry Eduard Shevardnadze meanwhile offered in Moscow to discuss removal of the stockpiles of weapons his country has sent to Afghanistan. The United States has long refused to consider halting its arms shipments to the Moslem guerrillas because it says the Soviets built up enormous arsenals for the Najib regime. Shevardnadze also suggested a conference on Afghanistan to include representatives of the various Afghan groups, the United States, the Soviet Union, Iran and Pakistan, with U.N. representatives participating. Najib offered the guerrillas a six-month cease-fire and said his troops would stop firing long-range Scud missiles if the guerrillas stopped firing rockets at Kabul and other cities. So far the guerrillas have rejected all truces offered by Kabul and have refused all negotiations with Najib and his People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan. There was little in Najib's invitation that seemed likely to entice them to give up their nearly 12-year-old attempt to oust the ruling party, which took power by coup in 1978. The guerrillas, whose headquarters are across the borders in Pakistan and Iran, call themselves mujahedeen, or Islamic holy warriors. Najib took office in 1986. He is one of four successive Soviet-backed leaders to run Afghanistan through a series of internal party coups and power struggles. Soviet troops entered Afghanistan in December 1979 to prop up its faltering protege party and started withdrawing in May 1988 under a U.N.-sponsored accord. The last Red Army combat troops crossed the border back to the Soviet Union on Feb. 15, 1989. The Aghan president, former head of the dreaded Khad secret police, again proposed creating a national council that would form a broad-based coalition government. He called for new parliamentary elections. They would be held ``without resort to force for influencing them'' and the results would be respected by the Kabul government, he said. Najib also said his government ``places enormous value to the role of the United Nations ... and is ready for cooperation with whatever outline the U.N. may table.'' He did not address the question of whether he himself would step aside during any peace talks. But about four hours before his speech was broadcast by state-run television, Najmuddin Kawyani, a member of his party's powerful Politburo, dismissed this idea. Kawyani told foreign reporters there could be no preconditions to any talks. News reports before and after U.S. Secretary of State James Baker III's visit to Moscow last week said the Americans would drop their demand that Najib resign before any peace negotiations began _ provided he was gone before the talks ended. ``During the talks, the results of the talks should be clear,'' Kawyani said. ``It should be decided who should go. If the Americans determine the results before the talks, that ... (Najib) should go, then the talks will be for what?'' Najib proposed sending a Kabul delegation to talk to mujahedeen leaders in Peshawar and Quetta in Pakistan. He said the delegation should also visit Tehran, Iran, where a second mujahedeen alliance is based, and to Europe, where Afghan exiles opposed to both the Najib government and the mujahedeen live. He said if the opposition refused to accept representatives of his government or party, the delegation could consist of clergymen, scholars and intellectuals with no affiliations. The mujahedeen rejected similar offers in the past, considering any delegates who might be sent from Kabul as nothing more than Najib's henchmen. He also invited the guerrillas to come to Kabul and said ``they are not required, at the first stage, to meet state and party authorities in Afghanistan.'' He offered restructuring of the economy with a movement away from state control of investment and enterprise. Najib said the United States, Pakistan and Saudi Arabia continued to arm the mujahedeen and denounced them for it. An English translation of Najib's spech, delivered in Kabul's Persian Dari language, was provided by the Foreign Ministry's press center. Kabul complained Wednesday in a letter to the U.N. Security Council that Pakistan and the United States were intensifying aggression against Afghanistan in violation of accords aimed at ending the war. It said Pakistan was helping in the shipment of military supplies and training for the rebels, and that the United States was delivering advanced weapons. A spokesman at the Pakistan U.N. Mission denied the allegations and called them part of a propaganda campaign to divert attention from Kabul's problems. A State Department official said Afghanistan has made similar statements in the past and that Washington saw no merit in the allegations.

DOC.BYLINE: Police Chief Accuses Israeli of Airline Bombing ^By STAN YARBRO
DOC.TEXT: Retired Israeli Col. Yair Klein, accused of training drug traffickers' paramilitary squads, trained the men who placed a bomb aboard a airliner that killed all 107 aboard last fall, the head of Colombia's intelligence police said Wednesday night. ``This is the person who has done the most damage to Colombia,'' and according to Colombian law is responsible for the deaths, said the police chief, Gen. Miguel Maza Marquez, in a news conference in the city of Cartagena. Cartagena is the site for Thursday's drug summit to be attended by President Bush of the United States and Presidents Virgilio Barco of Colombia, Jaime Paz of Bolivia and Alan Garcia of Peru. Last year Colombian authorities issued an arrest warrant for Klein, whom they accused of leading a team of Israeli, British and Australian mercenaries in Colombia. Colombian police seized films of the group training paramilitary squads and said that drug traffickers paid the mercenaries to give the courses. Maza said that some of the men receiving training later blew up the Avianca 727 shortly after taking off from Bogota on a domestic flight Nov. 27. The attack was one of over 262 terrorist actions contracted by drug traffickers since the government intensified a campaign against them last August. More than 200 people died in the attacks. ``Klein was the man who trained the actual perpetrators of the Avianca airline attack,'' Maza said. ``He was the one who taught them how to make the bomb and therefore is responsible under Colombian criminal law for this atrocious crime.'' Klein is living in Israel and is being investigated by that country's authorities. There is no extradition agreement between Israel and Colombia. Maza said that two of the suspects in the airliner bombing were killed in a chain of Bogota massacres following the death of Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, a leader of the Medellin drug cartel, in a Dec. 15 gunfight with police. A joint operation carried out by Colombian police and Interpol, the international police agency, uncovered evidence that two Basque separatists belonging to ETA, the Basque terrorist organization, also had carried out terrorist activities in Colombia, Maza said. He accused the two men of carrying out a Dec. 6 bombing of the intelligence police headquarters in Bogota in which 63 persons died. He would not identify the suspects because he said the investigation of their activities was continuing. But he said they had been hired by the Medellin cartel to kill him. Police have said that Maza, in the headquarters at the time, was the target of the bombing. Maza also announced that Colombia and Spain would sign an agreement next week to share information about traffickers. He has predicted that Spain could become the European Colombia because traffickers had chosen it as a distribution point for cocaine shipments from Latin America.

DOC.HEAD: About 30 Prisoners Escape
DOC.TEXT: About 30 inmates escaped Thursday from the Modelo Prison in the capital, but some were recaptured within a few hours, the warden said. Capt. Alberto Soto told reporters the inmates fled in small groups during visiting hours and while a group of human rights observers were touring the jail. Soto refused to give further details other than to say some prisoners had been recaptured, and other government authorities refused to answer reporters' questions. Soto also refused to say to which group the human rights observers belonged. A few hours later, reporters saw five people who appeared to be escapees being driven back to the jail in military vehicles. It was not known if any of the escapees were members of dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega's Defense Forces, which were disbanded after he was overthrown by the U.S. invasion in December. Modelo Prison, in the capital's Chorrillo neighborhood, holds about 900 inmates but was built with a capacity for only 250.

DOC.HEAD: Precede LANSING, Mich.
Michigan, South Carolina Senates Pass Abortion Restrictions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with South Carolina Senate approving parental consent bill, details, ADDS Michigan party affiliations, New Hampshire House approving abortion bill. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Michigan's Senate on Wednesday overwhelmingly passed a bill requiring minors to get permission from a parent or judge before having an abortion, and South Carolina senators unanimously approved similar legislation with a twist. Under South Carolina's bill, parents who deny a daughter's request for an abortion would have to share legal and financial responsibility for her child until the young mother turns 18. The Michigan legislation, adopted 29-8, now goes to the House, which is expected to pass the restriction. However, Democratic Gov. James Blanchard is expected to veto the bill, setting up an override battle or an attempt by anti-abortion forces to enact such a law through a petition drive. The measure adopted Wednesday would allow a girl under 18 to seek a probate court order allowing an abortion if she couldn't get the permission of a parent or adult guardian. It is the first anti-abortion legislation to advance in Michigan since the U.S. Supreme Court in July gave states more power to restrict abortions. Pennsylvania last fall adopted the nation's toughest abortion law, but many of its provisions have been put on hold because of a challenge from abortion-rights groups. ``I'm very positive the House will accept what we've done,'' said Republican Sen. Fred Dillingham, manager of the bill in the Senate. ``Michigan wants and needs protection for parents and for minors with problem pregnancies,'' Barbara Listing, president of Right to Life of Michigan, said in a statement. The Senate rejected amendments offered by minority Democrats who called the bill too harsh. The most substantive would permit consent by another family member and require counseling. Another would allow an abortion in cases of rape or incest. The bill generated some heated debate, although the outcome was assured. ``Today will be a day of infamy for this body,'' said Sen. John Kelly, a Democrat. ``We're going to have to live with the despair, the suicides, the back-alley abortions. These young people have committed no crime.'' South Carolina's bill, passed unanimously on a voice vote, is also the first since the U.S. Supreme Court's decision. The state already has a law requiring girls under 16 to obtain a parent's consent for an abortion, but similar laws without a judicial consent option have been declared unconstitutional in other states and South Carolina's ordinance has not been enforced. Under the bill passed Wednesday, girls under the age of 17 could obtain permission for an abortion from a grandparent or guardian in addition to a parent or judge. ``It's not everything that we wanted, but it's much of what we wanted,'' said Sen. David Thomas, a Democrat and an abortion opponent. ``This is the best I could have hoped for.'' Abortion foes had opposed any Senate amendments to a bill passed by the House last year allowing only parents or a judge to give consent, but were forced to accept compromises on who could approve an abortion and on the issue of responsibility. ``Overall, we were realistic. We knew the state was not going to break with precedent,'' said Inez Tenenbaum, a lobbyist for South Carolina Coalition For Choice. ``If anything, we're very encouraged that we got some positive changes in the current law.'' The bill now returns to the House, which can either accept the Senate amendments or work with Senators on a compromise bill to submit to both chambers. Republican Gov. Carroll Campbell has promised to approve abortion restrictions. On Tuesday, New Hampshire's House approved 212-148 a bill to allow abortions until the 25th week of pregnancy and in health-related situations afterward. The bill goes to the Senate, which is not expected to take up the bill until at least March. Republican Gov. Judd Gregg has promised to veto the bill.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Legislators Pay First Visit to NATO
DOC.TEXT: A delegation of Soviet legislators Wednesday became the first lawmakers from their country to visit the NATO military alliance, and it urged more talks in the future. Valentin Falin, a member of the Supreme Soviet's international affairs committee, said the group had ``very substantive discussions'' with NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner. ``The discussion was a rather open one. I think we need such kind of discussions,'' he told reporters after the hourlong meeting at the headquarters of the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization. ``Moreover, both sides came to the conclusion that there is a need for a series of such discussions so that we understand each other better,'' Falin said, speaking through a translator. He also said talks were needed ``so that we have a clearer vision of things to come. On this particular subject both sides have much in common in their appraisal and also have to seek ways to achieve these objectives.'' Falin said the officials only discussed the sensitive topic of the reunification of West and East Germanys in an ``indirect manner. It was not a precise subject of discussion.'' Also in the delegation was Marshal Sergei Akhromeyev, a key adviser to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and former chief of staff of the Soviet armed forces. Late last year, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze made a historic visit to NATO, becoming the first Soviet foreign minister ever to do so.

DOC.HEAD: Third Mate Says Hazelwood Seemed Calm and Cool After Accident
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with second mate testifying that Hazelwood had warned others about helmsman's abilities, move up testimony on Hazelwood's remarks to helmsman, deletes last 10 grafs to tighten and eliminate redundant material; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Exxon Spill
DOC.TEXT: The skipper of the Exxon Valdez thought the seaman who was at the tanker's helm when it ran aground had problems steering and warned others to watch over him, the ship's second mate testified Wednesday. Both Capt. Joseph Hazelwood and third mate Gregory Cousins talked about problems with Robert Kagan's steering of the ship, second mate Lloyd LeCain Jr. testified at Hazelwood's trial. ``How would you rate Mr. Kagan's abilities?'' the prosecutor asked LeCain. ``I'd say slightly below normal,'' LeCain said. ``I talked to Capt. Hazelwood about it. He knew he had a problem. He told me to keep an eye on him when he was steering.'' LeCain claimed that Cousins, whom Hazelwood had left in charge of the ship, had been on previous voyages with Kagan and knew he had to be watched. Cousins, however, testified he had never sailed with Kagan before the fateful trip. The March 24 accident, the worst oil spill in U.S. history, caused more than 10 million gallons of Alaska North Slope crude oil to spill into the clear waters of Prince William Sound. Outside the jury's presence, Hazelwood's lawyer, Dick Madson, said that that Exxon had placed LeCain on leave because of mental and emotional problems, and that LeCain was known for making up wild stories and claims. ``He has a problem with fantasy,'' Madson told Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone. He said LeCain once told Hazelwood he kept two cyanide pills with him in case he had to commit suicide and that he was ``Ninja-trained.'' LeCain also had claimed involvement in the Iran-Contra affair, Madson said. Johnstone said he would not permit Madson to tell this to the jury because it was ``character evidence'' prohibited by Alaska law. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., is charged with one felony count of second-degree criminal mischief and misdemeanor charges of reckless endangerment, negligent discharge of oil and operating a vessel while intoxicated. The maximum penalty for conviction on all counts is 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. Kagan, who was blamed by Cousins for not steering the ship properly, had told jurors the captain commended him for his handling of the wheel in the wake of the accident. But Cousins testified earlier Wednesday that the comment attributed to Hazelwood actually was typical of the captain's sarcasm. ``Did you hear the captain say anything to Kagan?'' asked Madson. ``Yes,'' said Cousins. ``I remember the comment, something to the effect of, `Damn fine job, Bob.''' ``And did you take that as serious or sarcasm?'' asked the lawyer. ``Kind of dark humor,'' said the witness. Cousins also contradicted two widely circulated reports that followed the accident. He said the ship was not on autopilot in the minutes before it ran aground. And he said Hazelwood never tried to reverse in an effort to pull the tanker off the reef. Cousins said he realized Hazelwood ``was in shock,'' as was the rest of the tanker crew, after the vessel ran aground and caused what became the nation's worst oil spill. Hazelwood's first order to him ``was to get a fix'' on the ship's location, Cousins said. ``Did that seem a prudent command?'' asked Madson. ``Yes, we needed to know where we were on the reef,'' said Cousins. Madson then asked whether Hazelwood seemed able to give ``clear, concise commands,'' and Cousins said he did. Madson asked whether any of the engine commands required reversing position. Cousins said, ``No,'' indicating that Hazelwood ordered the ship to move forward. Madson asked whether an order to reverse would have been proper if Hazelwood was trying to get off the reef. ``That would make sense,'' said Cousins. ``But my experience in being on a reef is very limited. This was the first.'' His comment drew laughter in the courtroom. He added, ``It makes sense that if you plow into a pile of rocks, the way to get off is back off.'' Other witnesses, however, have said that had Hazelwood succeeded in reversing the ship and backing off, it probably would have capsized, causing a worse oil spill and possibly a loss of life. His lawyers contend he left clear instructions for an ice diversion maneuver and that if his instructions had been followed, the ship would have moved smoothly past Bligh Reef. Hazelwood was fired by Exxon after the spill. Cousins, 39, a veteran seaman, said he was on the phone with Hazelwood at the moment the Exxon Valdez went aground. Cousins said that although Hazelwood had left the bridge 10 minutes before the accident, his office was a mere 15 seconds away.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Labor Is Unhappy with Bush's Visit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `Rigid police ...' to UPDATE with U.S. flag burned; pickup 9th graf pvs, `About 100 ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos CART7,CART19, LaserColor CART15
With AM-Bush-Drug Summit, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Colombia's four main labor federations denounced President Bush's visit and prompted marches in at least three cities Wednesday to protest his trip and this country's economic policies. Police clashed with students in one demonstration, held after the unions issued a joint statement on the eve of Thursday's anti-drug summit in Cartagena to be attended by presidents Bush, Virgilio Barco of Colombia, Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia and Alan Garcia of Peru. Paz flew into Cartagena late Wednesday and praised Bush for making cocaine trafficking a top priority of his administration. ``He best understands the dimensions of the drug problem,'' Paz told reporters at the airport. Cartagena was under intense security to guard against possible attack by drug traffickers or leftist guerrillas. Colombian newspapers have said about 5,000 members of Colombian security forces were assigned to the Cartagena area. All vehicles entering Cartagena were searched Wednesday, and Colombian marines stopped cars at roadblocks to look for weapons. Witnesses estimated a few thousand people took part in a peaceful march called by labor officials in Bogota, the capital. Other marches took place in Medellin, home of the infamous Medellin drug cartel, and in the northern city of Cucuta. Workers marching in Bogota with ``Bush go home'' banners burned an American flag, but rigid police control had been ordered to prevent violence and none was reported. About 100 demonstrators clashed with police near the National Univerisity of Colombia in Bogota, but no injuries were reported. Police shot tear gas at students throwing stones, witnesses said. The union statement, issued in Bogota, condemned the U.S. invasion of Panama in December and declared: ``For this and 1,000 more reasons ... we are not happy with the visit to the country of the U.S. president. ... Colombians will not applaud the (U.S.) Marines in any Latin American country, much less in our own territory.'' The unions ordered the marches to protest Bush's visit and the government's free-market-oriented economic policies. About 3 million workers out of a total labor force of 10 million belong to the four unions, which represent a wide range of political forces. Jorge Carrera Rojas, president of the Colombian Central Workers Union, told Bogota marchers, ``When President John F. Kennedy visited Colombia more than 25 years ago he brought something for us: Houses were built all over Colombia. I'd like to ask what is Mr. Bush bringing in to our people.'' He was referring to Kennedy's Alliance for Progress program for Latin America that assigned priority to housing for the poor throughout the continent. Colombian marines with assault rifles and grenades, meanwhile, surrounded the news center in Cartagena. But the greatest danger to the estimated 1,200 reporters, photographers and camera crews appeared to be tripping over themselves in the crush. There also was the physical toll of scooting out of the air-conditioned luxury of the Cartagena convention center _ into 95-degree heat for interviews. Photographers and camera crews busied themselves filming and photographing warships in the bay, soldiers using mirrors to search under cars for bombs and anti-riot police standing by. The U.S. Secret Service heightened anxieties by leaking that the drug traffickers had ground-to-air, shoulder-fired SAM-7 missiles and might use them during the summit. Presidential aides plan to confine the White House press corps accompanying Bush to a hangar in Baranquilla, where Bush will land Thursday morning. The reporters will be kept there six hours while Bush is taken to Cartagena 85 miles away for the drug meeting, which will be held in a 17th century Spanish fort on the Cartagena bay. Despite signals from the White House and the Secret Service that violence would not come as a surprise, no bombs, bullets or threats materialized on Wednesday. The only apparent casualties were reporters with sunburns. Two U.S. warships prowled the Colombian coast. Helicopter gunships buzzed around the bay and all tourist boats and other non-military sea traffic was ordered to clear out. A Colombian frigate and high-speed navy patrol boats armed with twin .50-caliber machine guns were anchored in the bay, not far from the Spanish fortress. Frogmen were seen entering the bay at several points, apparently checking for explosives. One was seen coming up with a lobster.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Groups, Bishop, Denounce Avril
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Eleven political parties issued a statement Wednesday denouncing the personal power of Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril and said no elections are possible under his rule. ``The prerequisites of free and honest elections at all levels cannot be met by the present government,'' said the statement, signed by Haiti's major parties, including the Communists and a conservative coalition. Avril has promised to allow presidential elections scheduled for October. During a crackdown in January police arrested more than 50 opposition activists, who said they were beaten in custody. All were released except for the nation's seven most prominent activists, who were exiled. The crackdown followed the killing of an army colonel. After strong criticism from France, the European Community and the United States, Avril lifted a state of siege and said the exiled leaders could return. Most refused, however, saying elections were not possible under Avril. Also Wednesday, the Rev. Willie Romelus, the radical bishop of the western city of Jeremie, urged Haitians to boycott carnival celebrations later this month to show they oppose the military regime. ``We can't celebrate carnival while the country is topsy-turvy,'' Romelus said on the Roman Catholic Church's Radio Soleil. The government has said public participation would mean support for Avril. The three-day festivity comes before Lent and is Haiti's most popular annual event. All businesses close and thousands of people dance, sing and drink in the streets to the music of dozens of bands. But no carnival has been widely attended since 1985, the year before dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier fled into exile in France after a popular uprising. Romelus said elections were not possible under ``a regime which has violated the constitution.'' ``They (voters) know they have two alternatives: Nov. 29 and Jan. 17,'' Romelus said, referring to the November 1987 Election Day massacre in which thugs protected by soldiers killed dozens of voters, and to army-rigged elections the following January.

DOC.HEAD: Vassar Students Occupy Building To Protest Moynihan's Alleged Remark
DOC.TEXT: Vassar College students angered by an offensive remark allegedly made by U.S. Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan continued occupying a campus building Wednesday, prompting him to resign an honorary professorship. Moynihan sent a letter to Vassar's president Wednesday night saying he would return the professorship and the $1,000 stipend that went with it. The students had demanded that the college sever its ties to the senator. ``This doesn't change anything,'' said Jubi Headley, a member of the student coalition that took over the bulding. ``What it does do is it facilitates negotiations. We still have a list of demands that must be met. ``We are not planning on leaving the building tonight,'' he said. At least 51 students barricaded themselves inside Vassar's main administration building Tuesday morning at the 2,400-student college 70 miles north of New York City. By 6 p.m. Tuesday evening, about 40 students continued to block entrances and occupy the building's switchboard room, said Cleon Edwards, president of the Vassar Black Students Union. Edwards, a senior from New York City, said the students would remain in the building at least until 9 a.m. Thursday, when a meeting is scheduled between student leaders and Vassar President Frances Fergusson. ``We are doing everything we can to meet with the students,'' Fergusson said. Moynihan spokesman Paul Browne, speaking from the senator's Washington office, said Moynihan did not recall ever making the alleged remark to a black Jamaican woman. The woman, Folami Gray, said she challenged Moynihan on a speech he made at Vassar on Jan. 29 and was told afterward by the New York Democrat that if she doesn't like it in the United States, she should pack her bags and go back to where she came from. Moynihan allegedly made the comment at a reception after he gave the Eleanor Roosevelt Lecture. Gray, who is not a student and heads the Dutchess County youth bureau, said she had questioned Moynihan on his contention that the U.S. was a model of ethnic cooperation. In his letter to Fergusson, Moynihan wrote, ``Heavens, what hath on lecture wrought!'' Edwards said student demands include removing Moynihan from the Roosevelt Chair, establishment of an ``intercultural center'' for minority meetings, a rabbi to minister to Jewish students and handicapped access to all buildings.

DOC.HEAD: Second Escapee Caught in Joliet Breakout
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with charges, suspensions of guard in prison breakout, picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Terry W...'
DOC.TEXT: Criminal charges will be sought against a guard believed to have brought a hacksaw blade into prison that was used by six inmates to escape, authorities said Wednesday. Two of the prisoners from the maximum-security Joliet Correctional Center were captured by Wednesday but four others, including three convicted murderers, remained at large. Two guards at the state prison will be suspended for Sunday's escapes, said Department of Corrections spokesman Nic Howell. The department also will ask the Will County state's attorney's office to bring charges against one of the suspended guards, Howell said. Prosecutors will determine the charges, he said. County State's Attorney Edward A. Burmila said he would review a report from prison officials before making a decision. Howell declined to identify any of the five guards who had been under investigation for negligence or wrongdoing in the escape from the prison's discipline-segregation unit. Inmates whose cells were near the escapees' told authorities they observed the men cutting their cell bars with hacksaws for two nights before fleeing. ``We recovered a blade in the cell of one of the guys who took off,'' Howell said. The first inmate was captured in Chicago several hours after the escape. The second escapee was captured Wednesday after thumbing a ride on a cold, rain-soaked Chicago freeway and being recognized by the owner of a towing service. Terry W. Colburn, 21, was arrested Wednesday in this Chicago suburb about 40 miles from Joliet after a motorist picked him up on the expressway late Tuesday, said State Police Capt. Dan McDevitt. The motorist had driven the burglary convict to a friend's tow truck operation to spend the night. Airline Towing owner Lonnie Bramlett Jr. said he initially suspected nothing when the wet, cold stranger showed up, but became suspicious after seeing TV accounts and reading about the escape in a newspaper. Bramlett said he called Airline Towing to warn the dispatcher about his suspicions, then called police. Colburn was arrested without incident. He was not armed. ``He was more scared than anything else,'' McDevitt said. ``You have several guys come into the room with guns on you and it tends to have a sobering effect.''

DOC.HEAD: Workers Find Oily Sludge Heaved Ashore By Winter Storm
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 10-11, `Volunteers and ...,' with 7 grafs to UPDATE with oil percolating into beach, environmentalist comment, Coast Guard reporting no oil at sea, comment by Department of Fish and Game chief, CORRECT mayor's name to `Mays,' sted `Hays;' picks up 12th graf, `Deukmejian deferred ...' SUBS grafs 14-16, `Huntington Beach ...,' to CORRECT resident's name to `Livsey,' sted `Livesay,' assistant secretary of labor's first name to `Gerard,' sted `Gerald.'
DOC.TEXT: Bitter northwest wind and heavy seas heaved gooey crude oil on shore Wednesday, forcing skimming boats to suspend operations while workers tackled the bulk of a coastal oil spill on the beach. Wind trailing a Pacific winter storm gusted from 25 to 30 mph under a sunny sky while a mixture of tar balls, brown foam and thick oil coated miles of the coast, especially beaches exposed head-on to the pounding surf. In Balboa about 10 miles south of here, resident Ralph Gray said thick muck hit the beach for the first time Wednesday. ``I thought it was no big deal before since they said it was just a little amount of oil out there,'' said Gray, 27. ``But we need bulldozers now.'' About 400,000 gallons spilled from the tanker American Trader on Feb. 7 after its hull was punctured, apparently by its own anchor, while the ship maneuvered into a mooring station about 2 miles offshore. Wind blasting to gale force forced 16 oil-skimming boats to suspend operations Tuesday night and the gusts apparently drove much of the remaining crude onto the beach. Aerial observers reported Wednesday that a light oily sheen still hugged the coast from Lower Bolsa Chica State Beach to Newport Beach, but Coast Guard officials reported that very little of the spilled crude remained in the water. ``We expect the balance of the oil to wash ashore today, enabling cleanup crews on the beach to get what's left,'' said Peter Bartelme, a spokesman for British Petroleum America Inc., which owned the spilled crude. Disaster crews, which were tripled to more than 1,200 members as officials struggled to deal with the spill, resumed work after dawn Wednesday. Oil washed ashore had percolated as deep as 3 feet into the sand in some areas, according to cleanup officials. Environmentalists were concerned. ``There is a whole world of organisms that live in the intertidal zone that are going to be affected as oil washes up on the beach,'' said Dorothy Green of Heal the Bay, a local environmental group. ``Just think of where the shore birds usually are, following the waves in and out and poking at the beach. Those birds are feeding on those organisms.'' Volunteers and others so far have found about 135 birds killed by the oil, and wildlife rescue workers are striving to save an additional 329 oiled birds, said Tom Paulek of the California Department of Fish and Game. Two unidentified mammals were killed, he added. By Wednesday evening, Coast Guard planes reported no oil visible at sea, said Newport Beach police Sgt. Andy Gonis. In Sacramento, Department of Fish and Game Director Peter Bontadelli criticized aspects of the cleanup. He said some protective booms initally were installed incorrectly and that skimming failed to collect enough oil. ``Many of these problems should have been anticipated and were not,'' Bontadelli said. Huntington Beach Mayor Tom Mays told reporters he was disappointed that Gov. George Deukmejian spurned his request to declare his community a local disaster area. ``We feel there is a major disaster here,'' Mays said. Deukmejian deferred action on the request Tuesday, said Eileen Baumgardner, assistant director of the state Office of Emergency Services. ``As far as we can tell, there are no needs that are not being met,'' she said. British Petroleum, which chartered the ship, is coordinating most of the cleanup but is not expected to pay for final costs, which likely will come out of the insurance of the ship's owner, American Trading Transportation Co., said James H. Ross, president and chief executive of British Petroleum. Huntington Beach residents complained that fumes from the beached crude were causing headaches and nausea, according to Don Livsey, a Huntington Beach resident and founder of a local group called Save Our Surf. ``You can get the smell going out our front door,'' said Livsey, who lives two blocks from the beach and who said he is among those stricken with headaches since the spill. ``My wife is experiencing the same thing, and there's concern because she's pregnant.'' Assistant Secretary of Labor Gerard Scannell, who administers the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, told reporters he was unaware of complaints about hydrocarbon vapors. ``Our environmental team, in cooperation with OSHA and the Coast Guard, have extensively sampled the area and have not found levels of exposure that could cause illness,'' Bartelme said. A class-action lawsuit involving the spill was filed Tuesday by Newport Beach resident Chet Holifield in federal court in Los Angeles. The suit seeks compensation for damage and economic losses caused by the spill and the alleged failure to properly clean up the oil. Among the defendants named are British Petroleum and American Trading.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinistas Threaten Expropriation of Opposition Properties
DOC.TEXT: President Daniel Ortega said Wednesday that if his leftist Sandinista party wins this month's elections it will seize property owned by opposition leaders, including the only opposition newspaper. ``If we win, I say we will hand them a complete bill, so they will be left without a newspaper _ La Prensa _ and the homes of the candidate and the vice presidential candidate will be converted into children's homes on the day after the elections,'' Ortega told a campaign rally. Ortega and Vice President Sergio Ramirez are seeking re-election Feb. 25, running against La Prensa publisher Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and Virgilio Godoy on the ticket of the 14-party United National Opposition, or UNO. The Sandinista leader was responding to a recent speech by Godoy, who said if UNO wins the election, ``we are going to make the Sandinistas pay the bills one by one'' for alleged violations of human, civil and political rights. Ortega, in a speech before 80,000 cheering Sandinista supporters in Matagalpa 75 miles north of the capital, challenged the U.S.-backed UNO leaders to repeat Godoy's words before international observers monitoring the elections. Ortega repeated accusations he made Tuesday that the U.S.-supported Contra rebels and UNO leaders were planning to disrupt the campaign. After meeting with Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo, the Roman Catholic archbishop of Managua, Ortega told reporters late Tuesday that about 2,000 rebels had infiltrated northern Nicaragua from bases in neighborhing Honduras to disrupt the voting. Ortega also accused UNO leaders of planning to call the elections fraudulent. ``Since they know they have already lost the elections, they have this plan of saying there was fraud and the elections would be invalid,'' Ortega said Wednesday. He also said the army was taking action to neutralize any Contra infiltrators.

DOC.HEAD: Blood Drive Canceled Over Rejection of Haitian Donors
DOC.TEXT: Officials at a Roman Catholic high school in Miami's Little Haiti area canceled a blood drive after learning Haitian donors were not welcome. ``I have no problem with their blood being rejected after being tested but to single out a group, that takes me aback,'' said Brother Genaro Sulo, principal of Archbishop Curley-Notre Dame High School. ``It seems to be saying that all Haitians have AIDS.'' The exclusion is required under a federal Food and Drug Administration policy that bars people born in or emigrating from Haiti and certain parts of Africa as blood donors, said FDA spokesman Brad Stone. A previous FDA policy banned donations from Haitians who arrived in the United States after 1977 when the deadly virus first was detected in the U.S. The Miami chapter of the American Red Cross changed its guidelines to comply with the revised FDA rule Tuesday. The national Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta stopped listing Haitians as a high-risk group for the transmission of AIDS in 1985 after the extent of the disease in the world population became known, but CDC still discourages Haitians from donating blood. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome is caused by a virus carried in blood. Heterosexual activity is believed to be the prime means of transmission in Haiti. School officials learned of the guidelines last week when senior Lisa Henry, the blood drive leader, was recruiting students. A teacher told her that some Haitians had been rejected last year. It was learned that 25 of the 138 volunteers wouldn't be allowed to participate under the FDA's mandatory rules. When Sulo heard that the students would be turned away, he called off Tuesday's blood drive. ``Our hands are tied,'' said Christopher Chidley, spokesman for the Red Cross in Miami. ``It is not something we look forward to doing. It's going to be harder for us to collect blood.''

DOC.HEAD: Cosmonauts Link Up with Mir Space Station
DOC.TEXT: A Soyuz TM-9 capsule arrived at the Mir space station Tuesday and the two cosmonauts aboard relieved two others finishing up six months of work in space, the official Tass news agency said. It was the latest step in a mission designed to turn a profit of more than $40 million, a first in the 32-year history of the Soviet space program. Tass reported no problems as flight commander Anatoly Solovyov and engineer Alexander Balandin docked their Soyuz TM-9 with the space station. The other cosmonauts, Alexander Viktorenko and Alexander Serebrov, have been aboard the orbiter for two months and were to return to Earth on Monday, Tass said. The Soyuz blasted off Sunday and the new cosmonauts also are to spend six months in space. Under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, pressures have increased on the once sacrosanct Soviet space program to prove its usefulness to the severely strained economy. Some Soviet lawmakers have even called for funding reductions, saying the country can ill afford costly space missions when it cannot provide a reliable supply of meat and potatoes. The Soyuz TM-9 mission, however, is designed to put to use the Kristall module, described by the government newspaper Izvestia as the first orbital factory for the full-scale manufacture of technological and biotechnological materials in the near-weightless conditions on Mir.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Offers Valentine's Day Discount Rates
DOC.TEXT: AT&T is offering to kiss and make up to customers cut off by the computer-generated phone crash last month, discounting its Valentine's Day long-distance rates by a third. The company cut an average of 33 percent off regular rates for calls within the United States between 8 a.m. and 5 p.m on Wednesday, and 37 percent off international rates, said Lynn Newman, a spokeswoman at the company's operations headquarters here. ``This is our way of saying we're sorry the outage happened and our way of trying to compensate our customers,'' Newman said. A programming error in AT&T's call switching network partially knocked out long-distance service nationwide for about nine hours Jan. 15 and kept millions of calls from being completed. The phone company placed ads publicizing the discount in newspapers in 12 major metropolitan areas, Newman said, but the ads make no mention of the outage. ``I don't know why we didn't mention it,'' Newman said. ``If anything, we were trying to point up the fact that it's Valentine's Day'' and that people can call their loved ones for less money, she said. The company recorded 108 million telephone calls on its circuits last Valentine's Day.

DOC.HEAD: Cohen, Domenici Announce for Re-election
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Sens. William Cohen of Maine and Pete Domenici of New Mexico announced they would seek re-election Tuesday, and the son of former Vice President Walter Mondale launched his political career with a bid for state senate. In Indiana, U.S. Sen. Dan Coats opened an unchallenged bid to become GOP candidate for Vice President Dan Quayle's former seat, to which he was appointed in early 1989 by then-Gov. Robert D. Orr. Cohen, a 49-year-old Republican, told hometown supporters in Bangor he has ``much more to give'' as he launched his drive for a third term. Addressing nearly 100 luncheon guests, Cohen reached out for support from beyond the Republican Party and sought to link himself with Maine's other U.S. senator, Democrat George J. Mitchell, who won re-election overwhelmingly in 1988 and became Senate majority leader. The two Mainers have a ``close friendship'' and ``remain a very effective team,'' said Cohen, who has been a prominent voice in foreign affairs and co-wrote a book with Mitchell on their experiences as part of the Iran-Contra investigating panel. Democratic state Rep. Neil Rolde of York has announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for the Senate. Domenici, also a Republican, announced in Las Cruces, N.M., that he would seek re-election to a fourth term. He said he would work to create new and better jobs in New Mexico, fight drugs and protect the state's environment. ``We must improve our productivity, our economic efficiency, so that the standard of living we enjoy continues to improve,'' said Domenici, 57, who was first elected to the Senate in 1972. The only other announced candidate is Democrat Tom Benavides, a state senator from Albuquerque. In St. Louis Park, Minn., Ted Mondale, son of former U.S. Sen. and Vice President Walter Mondale, declared himself ``proud to be a Mondale running for office'' in seeking the state senate seat of Republican incumbent Phyllis McQuaid. ``My father has given me a good name, but he gave me much more: a respect for public service and a willingness to stand up for people who are not rich and powerful,'' Mondale, 32, told supporters at his home in this Minneapolis suburb. The gathering included his family. ``These values are timeless, and, Dad, I promise to apply them to the challenges of the 1990s and beyond.'' Mondale is a 1988 graduate of the William Mitchell College of Law in St. Paul and is employed by the Minneapolis law firm of Larkin, Hoffman, Daly and Lindgren. He worked on his father's vice presidential and presidential campaigns in 1976, 1980 and 1984. In Indiana, the 1990 Senate campaign is a special election to fill the remaining two years of the term won by Quayle in 1986. The winner of this year's race will face re-election in 1992. Coats, a 46-year-old Republican, will likely face four-term state Democratic Rep. Baron P. Hill of Seymour, who entered the race after better known Democrats, including U.S. Rep. Lee H. Hamilton, decided not to run. ``Our first challenge is to sustain and expand the remarkable economic growth of the last six years,'' Coats told supporters in South Bend.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Brigade Accuses Police of Bungling Earthquake Rescue
DOC.TEXT: A confidential report on December's deadly earthquake in Newcastle says police ``bungled'' rescue efforts and prevented more lives from being saved. The report prompted officials to order an investigation Wednesday. The report by the New South Wales state fire brigade, leaked to a Sydney radio station, said police were late to the scene and not persistent enough in searching for survivors in the Dec. 28 quake that left 12 people dead. ``At the Newcastle Workers Club it was an horrific situation _ response from the fire brigade approximately two to three minutes, ambulance half an hour, police rescue in excess of one hour,'' the report said. ``As the rescue effort continued it was apparent that confusion and bungling began to spread,'' it said. The report said it may have been possible to save trapped people if rescue operations had been continued earlier and added that one fire officer felt police had prematurely collapsed portions of the building. Nine people died there. Ted Pickering, the state's police and emergency services minister, ordered a full investigation into the allegations. The fire brigade report was prepared after a meeting of fire officers two days after the earthquake in Newcastle, a predominately industrial city of 500,000 75 miles north of Sydney. Fire brigade officials on Wednesday acknowledged existence of the report, with one senior officer said fallout from its release would create ``a lot of problems between us and the police.'' The head of the New South Wales Police Rescue Squad defended police involved in the quake, saying they acted professionally at all times. ``In a situation like that, when everyone is under pressure, I don't feel anyone should be critical,'' Inspector Ken Holmes said. The quake measured 5.5 on the Richter scale and was Australia's most destructive temblor. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Every increase of one number means that the ground motion is 10 times greater. A quake of magnitude 5 can cause considerable damage in populated areas, while one measuring 6 can cause severe damage in populated areas.

DOC.HEAD: Ontario City Declares Itself English-Only
DOC.TEXT: City council has declared this northern Ontario center English-only despite last-minute pleas from local francophones not to take such a drastic stand. In a 9-4 vote after a lengthy meeting Monday night, the council adopted English as the official language in this city of 125,000 _ making it the largest of at least 44 Ontario communities to go that route. Francophones comprise 2.3 percent of the city's population. More people speak Italian, Finnish and Ukrainian than speak French, according to city statistics. The English-only declarations throughout Ontario are largely a protest against the province's French Language Services Act. Under the act, which became law in November, the province offers services in French and English in areas designated to have a large francophone population.

DOC.HEAD: Lake Placid Kicks Off Weeklong Remembrance of 1980 Winter Olympics
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with details of opening ceremony, edits to tighten. No pickup.
