DOC.TEXT: A week-long celebration opened Tuesday to commemorate the 1980 Winter Olympic Games, a spectacle that began with bureaucratic blundering and finished with one of the United States' grandest moments in sports. ``Ten years ago today on this site, the focus of the world was on this community as the Olympics returned to Lake Placid,'' Master of Ceremonies Dennis Ryan said at the opening night ceremony. ``We tell the world tonight that we remain ready again to host the Winter Olympic Games.'' People in the tiny Adirondack Mountain village looked forward to the Olympics 10 years ago, but at the start nearly everything that could go wrong did go wrong. A mismanaged bus system left thousands of spectators stranded in the bitter cold and ultimately the state declared a partial transportation emergency. Massive traffic jams in and around Lake Placid further prevented transportation to and from the various sports venues. The ticket-selling and telephone systems were overloaded. The International Olympic Committee even issued a public reprimand to the Lake Placid organizing committee for its bungling of the first medal ceremony on frozen Mirror Lake. But the bus system improved dramatically after a few days and speedskater Eric Heiden and the U.S. Olympic hockey team made the nation briefly forget its troubles. Every motel room in Lake Placid has been booked for the weekend, and organizers expect 20,000 people to visit the village of 2,500 by the time the celebration ends Sunday, said Lake Placid Commerce and Visitors Bureau spokesman Peter Wilson. ``There seems to be an incredible amount of interest,'' said Don Krone, a spokesman for the organization that assumed control of most Olympic facilities following the 1980 games, the Olympic Regional Development Authority. ``A lot of people are calling, people who have fond memories of 1980, even the athletes. ``They didn't get to see what Lake Placid was like 10 years ago. The figure skaters who are coming back _ Lisa Marie Allen, Michael Botticelli, David Santee _ have spent a lot of time talking to each other on the phone in the past couple of weeks, and they're all over the country.'' Eight members of the U.S. Olympic hockey team, including goaltenders Jim Craig and Steve Janaszak, captain Mike Eruzione and defenseman Bill Baker, will return Saturday. They will be honored in a ceremony in the same arena where they shocked the sports world by defeating the Soviets and winning the gold medal. Former Olympians will also hold a figure-skating exhibition. The opening ceremonies Tuesday night were much more modest than those of a decade ago, when 23,000 people watched the traditional parade of athletes spread a sea of color across the Olympic stadium. Instead of 1 million flowers, 2,000 birds, 40 hot-air balloons and 25,000 helium-filled balloons, a small torchlit Parade of Nations was watched by a crowd of about 3,000 standing in a muddy field. There was some international representation in the procession but it was composed mostly of local high school athletes dressed in their favorite sports outfits and carrying flags from the 37 nations that participated in the 1980 games. The 75-foot tall Olympic flame was ignited amidst a backdrop of fireworks and music. When the 1980 Games ended, Lake Placid was saddled with a $6 million debt, and some disgruntled citizens wanted to sell the Olympic torch to raise money. That never happened, but the torch fell into disrepair and only recently was re-assembled. Part of the opening ceremony was dedicated to the memory of the Rev. J. Bernard Fell, who was president of the Lake Placid Olympic Organizing Committee. Fell died in 1985 after a long illness. The Olympic torch will become a permanent memorial to him, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Charges Doctor Tried to Help Her Commit Suicide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 16-17, bgn `Jenks was...,' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with comments from doctor's attorney. Elisabeth is cq in 4th graf.
DOC.TEXT: A woman is suing her psychiatrist for $14 million, claiming the doctor tried to help her commit suicide on four occasions _ once spoon-feeding her yogurt lethally laced with Seconal, her lawyer said Tuesday. Fern Isaacson, 31, of Manhattan, who suffers from an incurable and degenerative illness, survived the incident in 1987 when she decided she did not want to die and the psychiatrist induced vomiting, said the attorney, Bruce Clark. The psychiatrist's lawyer denies that the doctor was trying to help Isaacson commit suicide, but rather was trying to get her to reaffirm that she wanted to live. Isaacson also has asked the Manhattan district attorney's office to look into attempted murder charges against D. Elisabeth Jenks, Clark said. The lawsuit is for medical malpractice. ``We have opened a preliminary review of Ms. Isaacson's complaints. We have not begun a formal investigation yet,'' said Gerald McKelvey, spokesman for District Attorney Robert Morgenthau. He would not elaborate. ``Within a few months after she started seeing Dr. Jenks, the doctor first suggested she commit suicide,'' Clark said. ``She said Fern shouldn't have to go through this pain and horrible life she's living and she should end it.'' Isaacson was diagnosed in 1980 as having Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, an incurable disease that attacks the body's connective tissue. By the time she began seeing Jenks in 1986, Isaacson had undergone 70 operations, was severely depressed and suffered problems stemming from her childhood, Clark said. He said Isaacson's mother, a pediatrician, tried to commit suicide when Isaacson was 2{ by slitting her wrists. She locked her daughter in the bathroom with her during the attempt, Clark said. When Isaacson was 8, her mother killed herself _ in her daughter's bed, said Clark. ``So suicide was always on Fern's mind because of what her mother did.'' Clark said the doctor, who works out of Gouverneur Hospital in Manhattan, ``first suggested Fern take a large amount of her cardiac drugs.'' He said the conversations were recorded, at the doctor's request, and that he has ``quite a few'' tapes. Clark said Jenks suggested suicide four times, and was present twice when his client made the attempts. Each one involved using medications prescribed to Isaacson by her other doctors, Clark said. He said the ``most significant one'' occurred in 1987 when Jenks emptied the contents of 29 Seconal capsules, went back to Isaacson's apartment with her, mixed the drug into some yogurt and ``spooned it into Fern until there was only one spoonful left and Fern said she didn't want to die.'' Clark said the doctor then induced vomiting and helped Isaacson to a hospital. Jenks was not at Gouverneur Hospital on Tuesday and did not immediately return a call left on her answering machine. Jenks' attorney, Anthony Sola, said Jenks participated in ``pretend suicides'' meant to bolster her patient's will to live. ``Dr. Jenks' goal, which was successful, was to convince the patient that she did not want to die,'' Sola said. He also said that Isaacson has a long history of psychiatric disorders and has previously threatened lawsuits against other psychiatrists. The federal Drug Enforcement Agency is also looking into the case. ``We're still in the preliminary stages of our investigation,'' said DEA spokesman Mark Hannan. He added that the DEA was ``looking at it from the compliance perspective, monitoring prescriptions by doctors.''

The four World War II Allies, vanquishers of Nazi Germany and occupiers of Berlin, have begun a process aimed at ensuring a unified Germany will not pose a threat to world security. Foreign ministers from France, Britain, the Soviet Union and United States announced Tuesday that they would meet with their counterparts from East and West Germany to discuss the alignment and military strength of a unified Germany. No date for such a meeting was given, but before it takes place the two Germanys will be left alone to tackle the considerable domestic hurdles that must be overcome before unity is possible. With Tuesday's announcement, the powers that divided Germany in 1945 clearly acknowledged that reunification is inevitable now that Communist rule has collapsed in East Germany.

The bankruptcy filing by the parent of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. could take years to sort out, but already there is little left of the firm whose junk-bond machine fueled the fast-buck, megamerger 1980s. With most securities firms refusing to trade with Drexel and banks unwilling to lend money to stem its cash crisis, the one-time powerhouse began liquidating its huge bond portfolio even before its board authorized the bankruptcy filing. Employees, meanwhile, scrambled to look for jobs in an industry that has been shrinking steadily since the October 1987 stock market crash. Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., parent of the securities company, filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors late Tuesday. Only four years earlier, riding the crest of a takeover boom, Drexel had posted record pretax profits of nearly $1 billion.

Voters rejected by a 2-1 margin an attempt to make this Alpine resort the nation's first furrier-free town despite a campaign that attracted animal rights activists from as far away as Sweden. Residents also voted Tuesday for growth, defeating by 1,561 to 1,051 a measure to reduce the size of a luxury hotel by 25 percent, and approving measures to widen the highway leading into town and a bond measure to build employee housing. The winners hailed the results as a victory for free enterprise. The losers conceded that the mood in the town, home to ``gonzo'' journalist Hunter S. Thompson and other eccentrics, had taken a lurch beyond the bourgeois.

An original goal of Radio Free Europe, born in the Cold War to penetrate the Iron Curtain, was to close when Eastern Europe opened up and the news flowed freely. But the Western network is staying on the air with a new mission _ to spread word on how democracy works. ``Yes, we are going to stay in business,'' said William W. Marsh, executive vice president of Radio Free Europe and its sister station Radio Liberty, which broadcasts into the Soviet Union. ``Our job is not done.'' Radio Free Europe, founded in 1949 and Radio Liberty, established two years later, are based in Munich but controlled by the Washington-based Bureau of International Broadcasting and funded by the U.S. Congress. It is popularly known as RFE-RL. RFE-RL was distinct from the Voice of America, the British Broadcasting Corp. and other Western radios, because it was ``a surrogate for free media that did not exist'' in Eastern Europe, said Robert E. Gillette, the deputy director.

West Germany approved $3.6 billion in aid for East Germany on Wednesday to keep its economy afloat and prevent its citizens from fleeing in frustration until the two nations become one. Another $1 billion was approved to resettle East Germans who come to the West. Though the money is earmarked for specific East German programs, none of it will go directly to the government of Communist Premier Hans Modrow, who likely will be ousted when the country holds its first free elections March 18. Modrow, whose two-day summit here concluded Wednesday, had requested $9 billion in immediate direct aid Tuesday but was turned down by the government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl.

President Mikhail S. Gorbachev appealed Wednesday for legislative backing for a stronger presidency and said it was vital to his reforms, but wary lawmakers refused to be stampeded into setting a timetable. Once again, the 542-member Supreme Soviet proved itself a force to be reckoned with in the new Soviet political game, which under Gorbachev has shifted more from closed-door sessions of the Kremlin leadership to elected government bodies. After a two-month break, the fledgling Soviet legislature reconvened for the third time in its less than one-year history. Lawmakers approved a 22-item agenda to debate bills designed to put flesh on the skeleton of Gorbachev's economic and social reforms, including legalization of private property.

The African National Congress insists on full black voting rights, but it is open to compromise on other constitutional issues and to considering guarantees for whites, Nelson Mandela said Wednesday. Mandela, who plans to consult soon with ANC leaders in Zambia, did not elaborate on what compromises might be reached. ``I think it be most presumptuous of me to speak for the ANC,'' he said. ``It is the ANC who would decide what compromises it should make. ... We are ready for honorable compromises without surrendering our principles.'' During a conversation with a small group of reporters, Mandela was asked whether the ANC was willing to negotiate about its demand for a one-person, one-vote system, which would lead to black majority rule.

President Bush will refuse to meet with Peruvian coca growers at the Colombian drug summit and will travel to Cartagena with a sharply reduced staff because of concerns for his safety, White House officials said Wednesday. On the eve of the one-day meeting of four hemispheric nations, the White House also retreated from previous suggestions that Bush would revive a proposal to send U.S. Navy warships into South American waters to track cocaine-trafficking planes. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater denounced the kidnapping of two American citizens in Colombia on Tuesday by leftist guerrillas who said they were protesting Bush's impending visit.

The bittersweet ``Driving Miss Daisy'' carried off a leading nine Academy Award nominations Wednesday as Oscar voters passed over box-office blockbusters and maverick movies with equal abandon. ``Daisy,'' which traces the relationship over the decades between a testy Jewish widow and her tolerant black chauffeur in the South, drew nominations for best picture and actors Morgan Freeman, Jessica Tandy and Dan Aykroyd. ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' director Oliver Stone's account of Ron Kovic's painful passage from blind patriotism to unselfish protest by way of a Vietnam injury that left him a paraplegic, got eight nominations, including best picture. Also nominated in the top picture category by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences were ``Dead Poets Society,'' ``Field of Dreams'' and ``My Left Foot.''

An Indian Airlines Airbus jet that had been in use only three months crashed onto a golf course and burned Wednesday short of a runway in southern India, and 91 of the 146 people on board died, officials said. The Airbus-320 grazed a clump of trees on its final approach to Bangalore airport and caught fire when it hit the ground, about 50 yards from the runway, officials said. The flight originated in Bombay, 530 miles northwest of Bangalore. The officials said 139 passengers and a crew of seven were on the hour-long flight and at least 55 people survived the crash, including two Americans, the airline said.

DOC.HEAD: Network Offers Police Training Via Television
DOC.TEXT: Television, for years the mythic battleground for cops and robbers, is becoming as much a part of law enforcement equipment as handcuffs and badges. Officers can now learn more about everything from making traffic stops to subduing unruly suspects by tuning in to the Law Enforcement Television Network. The network went on line full time in July 1989, and since then has acquired about 1,200 law enforcement agency subscribers throughout the continental United States _ ranging from small departments to the FBI, said network President Billy Prince. ``The comments we're getting back say it's the best thing since the two-way radio. We've been hearing stories of officers staying after a shift to watch it,'' Prince said. LETN's satellite programming, available to subscribers 24 hours a day Monday through Friday, runs the spectrum from the latest law enforcement techniques to police news. The network showcased its programming last month at the American Society of Law Enforcement Trainers' conference in San Diego. Each of the five regular training segments is designed with a level of law enforcement in mind, from ``Street Beat,'' geared toward the officer on the beat, to ``Command Update,'' which provides training for supervisors and administrators. The programs are supplemented by ``Roll Call,'' a quarter-hour of police news and training segments. ``Our purpose is to train existing officers in the up-to-date things going on in their profession,'' Prince said in a telephone interview from his Dallas office. ``(We) let them know what's going on and let them know what works and what doesn't work so they don't wind up reinventing the wheel.'' The network took its cue from a similar project begun in 1986 to train auto mechanics and car salesmen, Prince said. In mid-1988, Wescott Communications began funding what would eventually become LETN. The service was initially limited to one day a week. Now it operates on a $10 million annual budget, said Prince, a former Dallas police chief. LETN's staff is mostly ex-law enforcement professionals, including three former police chiefs. Technical adviser Missy O'Linn, who is licensed to practice law in Ohio and has a background in unarmed self-defense instruction, reviews all programs and scripts for content including faithfulness to police procedure. ``Because adults learn from what they see and hear, it's important that all of the details are right,'' O'Linn said. ``That's important. We don't want to endanger an officer because of the program.'' Although the network employs no full-time instructors, trainers are chosen from among the best in the nation, O'Linn said. Dale Stockton, training and personnel manager for police in Carlsbad, a coastal town north of San Diego, said the department has been pleased with LETN since it became a subscriber in October. ``My recommendation would be to continue it,'' Stockton said. ``It costs this department $488 per month. I ask myself: For $488 what else can I do that would effectively deliver such comprehensive training as this? So far, I haven't found anything.'' One of the network's most notable subscribers, the FBI, has been with LETN since its inception, although spokesman Mike Kortan said the bureau's public affairs office in Washington, D.C., does not employ LETN for actual training. ``I would not characterize them as a training vehicle for the FBI. For us it's sort of a news outlet for the FBI,'' Kortan said. ``Their format allows for a little more in-depth stories, which is a break from the usual short soundbites that we're used to.''

Elsewhere in television... QUANTUM QUALITY: NBC's ``Quantum Leap'' will be honored by the Museum of Broadcasting as an outstanding example of imaginative, innovative television programming. The award will be presented March 17 as part of the Los Angeles Television Festival. The series stars Scott Bakula as a scientist Sam Beckett, whose time-travel experiment goes awry and keeps him bouncing between the 1950s and 1970s, assuming various identities. Also starring Dean Stockwell, the Belisarius Production is made in association with Universal Television.

DOC.TEXT: A proposal goes before the Southern Baptist executive committee next week to cut the denomination's support of an inter-Baptist religious liberty lobby in Washington from $391,769 a year to $50,000. Dominant fundamentalists in the 14.8 million-member denomination have long sought to curtail participation in the Baptist Joint Committee on Public Affairs, which also serves eight other Baptist denominations. The subcommittee's proposal, if it gained approval by the Southern Baptist Convention in June, would shift most of the funding to a separate denominational agency. In Washington, the Rev. James M. Dunn, executive director of the BJCPA, called the move irresponsibile, saying such efforts have been rejected by five recent annual conventions. ``It is highly questionable whether Southern Baptists will suddenly and precipitously reverse themselves on what has been a united Baptist witness in Washington over the past 53 years.''

The Christian Century, an ecumenical weekly regarded as reflecting mainline church concerns, is considered theologically ``liberal'' by 55 percent of its readers, while 42 percent consider it ``moderate.'' A survey also found that about two-thirds consider the magazine politically liberal.

A survey of more than 100,000 Episcopalians finds that 89 pecent of them oppose ordination of avowed practicing homosexuals and 88 percent oppose blessing homosexual ``unions,'' reports an unofficial group critical of the church's leadership. Neither of those policies is condoned by the denomination, but a practicing homosexual with a male mate was ordained recently in Newark, N.J., and has since been suspended from the ministry. Episcopalians United for Revelation, Renewal and Reformation also said 88 percent of respondents oppose ``inclusive'' language in worship services. Services using sexually inclusive language have been issued for trial use. The Rev. Ted Nelson, Episcopalians United board chairman, said the denomination is ``dying'' because of ``policies and practices of our current leadership.''

The Evangelical Lutheran Church in America reports it distributed $967,000 in domestic hunger grants in 1989, including an 8 percent funding increase to food pantries and emergency shelters. The Rev. Robert S. Hoyt, the program's director, said government funds for such aid has been further cut while the number needing it has increased. He said people generally are becoming less responsive to such need and added: ``They are either becoming callous or are becoming so aware of the need that it is shocking their system _ desensitizing them.''

The National Catholic Reporter, an independent weekly, reports that between 10 percent and 20 percent of U.S. Roman Catholic dioceses and archidoceses are showing financial deficits. The budgetary difficulties were attributed partly to reduced contributions and to the necessity of hiring lay personel to replace scarce and cheaper nuns and religious-order priests.

A survey finds that 78 percent of American Jewish leaders say the Palestine Liberation Organization is determined to destroy Israel, but 73 percent would support Israeli talks with the PLO if it ``recognizes Israel and renounces terrorism.'' ``What might appear as a contradiction is a practical expression of Jewish leaders' `Americanism','' says Arye Carmon, president of the Israel-Disaspora Institute, an Israel-based public policy group that funded the survey of 780 U.S. Jewish leaders. ``Americans often join the table with their adversaries, but do not necessarily always eat what's served.''

DOC.HEAD: Spending the `Peace Dividend'
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: There's only one certainty about the peace dividend: everybody wants a piece of it. And that includes some politicians who aren't enthusiastic about declaring much of a dividend yet. The government hasn't yet figured out how much it will be, and how or when it will be produced. There will be defense spending cuts, targets and timing yet to be determined. The peace dividend is a slogan-size name for an urgent new installment in the long debate over defense spending and national priorities, now transformed by the ending Cold War, the transformation of the communist bloc and the apparent easing of the Soviet threat. With Congress in recess this week, that's one of the issues campaigning members are taking up with their constituents. The peace dividend debate already is unfolding in congressional committees, where the chairman of one House panel showed defense chieftains an ax and said it was symbolic of the mood at the Capitol. While President Bush is trying to avoid runaway expectations of a sharp, swift cut in defense expenditures because of the revolutionary changes in eastern Europe and Moscow, the administration has its own plans for the potential dividend, seeing the potential savings as a guarantee that he can stand permanently on his promise of no new taxes. A conservative think tank, skeptical about the whole business, says that if there really is a peace dividend, it should be used to cut taxes. Otherwise, according to the Heritage Foundation, the savings are likely to be used in ``a congressional spending spree... ``Dividends normally are paid to investors, not kept by the corporation,'' the foundation said. The Bush defense budget is under attack in Congress, where some Democrats argue that it looks like a Cold War leftover. The budget seeks a $5.3 billion increase in Pentagon spending; adjusted for inflation that means a reduction of about 2 percent in real growth. Administration critics say the threat is receding a lot faster than that. Bush said this week that his budget makes good sense. ``I think the American people want a cautious approach to this,'' he said. ``I don't think any of us think we can see with clairvoyance as to what's going to happen the day after tomorrow... ``Some of the Democrats are jumping all over us,'' he told a news conference. ``But that's all right, that just goes with the system.'' But there also is skepticism among some members of Congress, in both parties, who tend toward the cautious approach Bush advocates. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Armed Services Committee, says he's looking for an administration defense blueprint that takes into account the changing world balance and the prospects for arms control. He said he doubts Congress will go ahead with costly weapons systems like the stealth bomber program, the Star Wars space defense system and the mobile MX missile unless the administration presents a blueprint that fits its proposals into arms control prospects in the post Cold War world. While those are the big ticket weapons, the administration maintains that sharp, immediate cost cuts could come only in conventional force spending, an argument Pentagon critics dispute. Nor does the current budget anticipate significant savings this year through the withdrawal of U.S. forces from Europe. Bush proposes the withdrawal of 80,000 troops from Europe under an East-West agreement now in negotiation. The president said those savings, too, will come gradually, over the years. He said he doesn't want soldiers who seek reenlistment to be dumped by the arms services. ``I would hope that attrition can take care of the cuts that inevitably will be coming,'' Bush said. He also said there is no reason to change the NATO weapons plan that includes short-range nuclear missiles, battlefield weapons that would be targeted on East Germany and other Warsaw Pact states. The West Germans resisted modernizing those U.S. missiles even before the undoing of the old communist regimes. Bush said that at this point, he sees nothing to change the NATO compromise that left the modernization question open until 1992. For all of that, and despite the fact that economists say any peace dividend will be far smaller than those after Vietnam and Korea, the search for a dividend is on. Budget Director Richard G. Darman called it the ``spend the peace dividend game'' in which the politician-players conjure up vast sums in supposed savings to be appropriated for their pet projects. ``Thus Washington entertains the notion of spending fifty times a dividend that has not yet definitively materialized _ a true Wonderland phenomenon,'' Darman said in his introduction to the budget. Then again, anyone who had forecast the remodeling of eastern Europe a year ago would have been accused of wonderland dreaming, too.

DOC.HEAD: Investing in a Post-Drexel World
DOC.TEXT: Savers and investors watched with remarkable calm this week as a pillar of the financial scene for the past decade, Wall Street's Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., collapsed. Some specialists in matters of personal finance said the steady behavior of the stock and bond markets proided impressive evidence of long-term confidence in the economic and investment outlook. Others suggested that decision-markers, in individual households and offices of professional money-management firms alike, had simply been numbed by a long succession of crises and did not know what to do next. In many ways Drexel personified the golden era on Wall Street with its daring and innovation, bringing what once was considered high-risk debt into the mainstream of the investment world. So the instant message of its demise seemed to be ``the '80s are over.'' But if a turning point has been reached, how should anyone with money to manage respond? Is it time to cash in the mutual fund investments, abandon plans to buy a house, and run for the hills? Or will patience and confidence be rewarded for those who sit tight and ride out the storm? Few of the experts profess to have any pat, all-purpose answers to those questions. But there is ample evidence, they say, that individual investors began months or even years ago to protect themselves from jolts like the recent slide in the junk-bond market or the 1987 crash in stock prices. Last year, for instance, assets of money-market mutual funds surged by nearly $100 billion to record highs. In the nearly two decades since they first appeared, money funds have become a popular choice for investors seeking to minimize their risks in uncertain times. Financial adviser William E. Donoghue attributes the resurgence of money funds now to such factors as ``excessive real estate loan losses'' and ``writeoffs of bad loans in general.'' As many investors in stock mutual funds know, the stock market has also been showing the effects of debt worries for some time. ``Although the Dow Jones industrial average posted record highs last October and in early January, most of the market has been in a deteriorating phase since last August,'' observes the Merrill Lynch Market Letter in its current issue. In the wake of the debt boom, furthermore, a new financial job description is already in vogue on Wall Street _ the ``workout'' specialist, looking to find bargains and salvage whatever assets remain in the wreckage of deals gone bad. For the speculatively inclined, ``the supply of bankruptcy bonds has increased sharply in recent years,'' said George Putnam III, editor of the Boston-based Turnaround Letter. In 1989, Putnam calculates, 37 companies with $7.1 billion in bonds outstanding filed bankruptcy actions. ``We expect these trends to continue for at least the next year or so,'' he added. ``There will certainly be no shortage of bankruptcy securities for turnaround investors to consider.'' If the situation creates opportunities, it also embodies risks and perils that have not yet been fully grasped, argues James Grant, whose Grant's Interest Rate Observer has long warned of severe fallout from debt excesses. ``If the woes of junk are unique to junk, there would be nothing to fear in the stock market, much less in business activity,'' he said. ``If, however, the junk bond market's break is the sign of broad distress, investors must take appropriate precautions.'' In Grant's view, a potentially traumatic move from adventures in debt back to traditional financial values is under way. ``The thunderheads rolling across the sky are the portents of a return to conservative lending,'' he says. ``That is bullish for many things in the long pull. For the short run, however, it is not bullish for stock prices _ or for business activity.''

DOC.HEAD: Annual Recruiting Drive Under Way for Appalachian Trail Volunteers
DOC.TEXT: The annual drive has begun to recruit hundreds of volunteers to make the Appalachian Trail more walkable along its 2,100-mile route from Maine to northern Georgia. Promoters put it this way: Break rocks. Get muddy and sweaty. Dig in the dirt. Sleep with rhododendron, laurel and bears. Split logs. Bridge bogs with the logs you split. If that isn't incentive enough, the Appalachian Trail Conference promises that volunteers will ``get a strange T-shirt your old friends won't understand and your mother won't want you to wear.'' Volunteers conceived and built the hiking trail in the 1920s and 1930s and have managed and maintained the path ever since. Gradually, the trail gained support from national forest and park authorities and from the states involved. In 1968, the route was officially designated by Congress as a national scenic trail. The 65-year-old private, non-profit Appalachian Trail Conference was appointed the footpath's day-to-day caretaker in 1984. The Forest Service in the Agriculture Department and the National Park Service in the Interior Department are major sponsors. The trail connects eight national forests, six national park units and more than 60 state park, game and forest lands. ``It winds its way along the crests of the mountains, across farm valleys, and through rugged and secluded high country,'' says the conference. ``Almost all the trail is located on lands owned either by the National Park Service, the U.S. Forest Service, states or other public bodies.'' Spokesman Brian King said in a telephone interview from conference headquarters in Harpers Ferry, W.Va., that he had no tabulation of 1989 work for the entire trail but that the southern crew, for example, had 80 volunteers who worked 8,500 hours and built 7.7 miles of footpath, along with bridges, one shelter and three outhouses. The seasonal crews of volunteers began in 1983 in southwestern Virginia, and a mid-Atlantic crew started in Pennsylvania in 1984. The conference also works with New England clubs to finance and recruit season workers in that area. The conference is comprised of 31 clubs and 24,000 individual and family members. The southern crew, which works in Virginia, North Carolina and Tennessee in the late spring and summer, is based in the Mount Rogers National Recreation Area in southwestern Virginia. Mid-Atlantic operations are scheduled in September and October in Virginia, West Virginia, Maryland, Pennsylvania, New York and New Jersey. King said volunteers have come from all across the United States and there are usually two or three from overseas, often from Britain. The conference's recruiting literature says the volunteer teams ``concentrate on trail construction and resource-management projects that might not otherwise be tackled by local maintaining clubs or public agencies with limited budgets.'' Work includes trail design and construction, shelter and bridge construction, rough carpentry, rehabilitation of eroded trails, clearing and open-area management. ``The work is often physically demanding, requiring perseverance and patience while living with limited comforts in the outdoors,'' the report said. ``Trail crews of four to six volunteers are led by a skilled leader on projects from Thursday through Monday and return to a base camp for Tuesday-Wednesday weekends, when members may explore area attractions.'' Volunteer crew members can opt to work for a week or the whole season. Anyone age 18 or older, male and female, can apply. There is no age limit. ``Enthusiasm, good health and adaptabilaity are important prerequisites,'' the report said. ``Willingness to following instruction and safety rules and to share equally in camp chores is essential. Previous experience is helpful but not necessary.'' Once a volunteer reachs a base camp, most expenses are covered, including lodging, food, transportation to and from work sites, tools, safety equipment, group camping gear (as available), and ``a small weekly stipend'' for laundry and incidentals. For further information, prospective volunteers should write ATC Southwest and Central Virginia Regional Office, P.O. Box 10, Newport, Va. 24128, or call 703-544-7388. The Appalachian Trail Conference headquarters also may be called at 304-535-6331.

DOC.HEAD: THE GRAMMYS 1990
Grammy History: Rock's Been Grammy's Stepchild
DOC.TEXT: Roll over Chuck Berry and tell Bob Dylan the news. At the first Grammys banquet in 1959, rock 'n' roll was out in the streets. In the beginning were Perry Como, Henry Mancini and Louis Prima. Rock 'n' roll was well established by the late 1950s, but the first winner for record of the year was Domenico Modugno for ``Volare'' while album of the year honors went to Mancini for the ``Music From Peter Gunn.'' Twenty-eight trophys were handed out that first Grammy ceremony in Los Angeles, which was not televised. This year, 77 Grammys will be given out during the awards broadcast from the Shrine Auditorium on Wednesday. At the first show, Como won for best vocal performance by a male. Prima and Keely Smith were cited for best performance by a vocal group or chorus. So what happened to Elvis Presley, Little Richard and Buddy Holly? ``It baffles me as to exactly how so many important artists were not part of the process,'' said Michael Greene, president of the National Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences, which conceived the Grammys shortly after forming in 1957. ``You look at the people who began the academy. It was started by the Nat `King' Coles, the big band people, the jazz people. It has a way of kind of perpetuating itself.'' Though started because many artists and technicians in the recording business were seeing their efforts go largely unrecognized, for years the Grammy Awards seemed like one long bloopers record for rock 'n' roll fans. Though Presley never won a Grammy for rock, he received the Bing Crosby Award for ``members of the recording industry who, during their lifetimes, have made creative contributions of outstanding artistic or scientific significance'' in 1971. Presley did win three times for gospel albums, and twice _ in 1967 and 1974 _ for the same record, ``How Great Thou Art.'' Winners for record of the year include Percy Faith, Tony Bennett and Herb Alpert. Robert Goulet, the Starland Vocal Band and the Swingle Singers have all been cited as best new artist. The album of the year in 1960 was Bob Newhart's ``Button Down Mind.'' Two of rock's greatest singles, the Rolling Stones' ``(I Can't Get No) Satisfaction'' and Bob Dylan's ``Like a Rolling Stone'' came out in 1965, but the best contemporary single Grammy went to Roger Miller's ``King of the Road.'' From 1966 to 1978, there was no category for best rock 'n' roll record. In 1975, writer Pete Hamill earned a Grammy for best album notes for Dylan's ``Blood on the Tracks,'' though what he wrote was deleted after the first pressing. The same year, Bruce Springsteen released ``Born to Run,'' but the winner for record of the year was the Captain & Tenille's ``Love Will Keep Us Together.'' Greene is a former musician and Grammy basher who decided the only way to beat the system was to join it. He worked his way through the academy in the early 1980s and after being elected president in 1985, gently nudged the Grammys away from Tin Pan Alley. Categories for hard rock-metal, contemporary blues, new age and rap have been added. The Rolling Stones, Fats Domino and Paul McCartney received Lifetime Achievement Awards. But what about all those Perry Como fans? Were they ready to step aside for Public Enemy and Living Colour? ``When I became chairman we had around 5,000 members,'' Greene said. ``We now are up to 8,000. Those additional 3,000 are as a result of membership outreach programs to communities we had not addressed before: rap, metal, new age, Hispanic. ``I refer it to as the graying of the academy membership. We had to come up with a formula which wouldn't disenfranchise the older membership. I think you can ask anyone; it's not a problem anymore. Those people who really had a problem, they had a choice to get with the program or step aside.''

DOC.HEAD: THE GRAMMYS 1990
Garry Shandling Host for Star-Studded Salute to Recording Artists
DOC.TEXT: The rambling, slow speech is the nemesis of any television awards show. So how did comedian Garry Shandling get picked to be host of the three-hour CBS telecast of the 32nd annual Grammy Awards? ``Well, you know, I hosted the ACE awards a few years ago, and, and, and uh, uh, it went well and it really wasn't a problem with uh, my, my delivery,'' the droll Shandling explains. ``It's not, it's really not that slow. You know I'm laid back but _ I put it more as laid back _ I've never had anyone actually come up to me and say, `Speak faster,' other than my girlfriend in the heat of an argument.'' The National Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences will present its coveted Grammys for the best music of 1989 at the cavernous Shrine Auditorium on Wednesday. Don Henley and his thoughtful ``The End of the Innocence'' album was nominated for four top awards, leading a host of pop and rock veterans up for more awards or receiving long-overdue consideration for Grammys. Henley, who has one solo Grammy to his credit and four from his old days with the Eagles, had his LP nominated for album of the year and best male rock performance. The title tune is up for record and song of the year. Other nominees include Bette Midler, Linda Ronstadt, Tom Petty, Billy Joel and Bonnie Raitt, who's looking for the first Grammy in a distinguished career. Perennial favorite Aretha Franklin could win her 16th Grammy. Prince also was a major nominee, earning four of seven bids drawn by the ``Batman'' movie soundtrack. Neneh Cherry, Indigo Girls, Milli Vanilli, Soul II Soul and Tone Loc were nominated as best new artists of 1989. Presentations will be framed by performances of nominees Harolyn Blackwell, Larry Carlton, Rodney Crowell, Miles Davis, Fine Young Cannibals, Herbie Hancock, Henley, Billy Joel, k.d. lang, Branford Marsalis, Aaron Neville, Raitt, Ronstadt and Sting. The glitter, glamour and variety will be provided by presenters including spunky dance queen Paula Abdul, rockers Motley Crue and Bob Seger, breezy singer Olivia Newton-John and actress Meryl Streep. So what does Shandling figure to do? ``I'll do a little opening monologue _ and then I understand there's going to be some music. From what I understand there's a lot of music on this particular awards program,'' he said. The connection between Shandling, star of ``It's Garry Shandling's Show,'' and the recording industry seems a bit tenuous. ``I made a 45 once,'' he says, conceding: ``I have a little catching up to do. I still have an eight-track tape system.'' Shandling will review the award show format and write his own material. Beyond his haircut and getting plenty of sleep the night before, he claims no worries about the show. ``I guess Guns N' Roses isn't going to be making an acceptance speech, so that takes some of the risk out,'' he says. ``It'll be exciting to meet a lot of the musical stars who will be there because I've spent quite a lot of money on them. This will be an opportunity for them to give me some of my cash back. ... I'm certainly going to hit Paul McCartney up for $200,000.'' McCartney and jazz trumpeter Miles Davis will receive lifetime achievement awards. Dick Clark will be presented the Trustees Award, and posthumous tributes will be paid to pianist-crooner Nat ``King'' Cole and pianist Vladimir Horowitz. In all, there were 388 nominees in 77 categories.

DOC.HEAD: In Two Years, Kennedy Solidified Conservative Supreme Court Majority
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court's nine members are among the most private of public officials. They wield enormous political power, but rarely hold news conferences or give interviews. A recent poll indicated only one in three Americans can name any of the nine. This, the third in an intermittent series, offers an up-to-date look at one member of the nation's highest court.

Anthony M. Kennedy, who has solidified a conservative Supreme Court majority since becoming a justice two years ago Sunday, says he feels no special pressure when thrust to center stage. ``People ask me, `How do you feel being the ninth vote?' I say, `Well, I'm one of nine.' Everybody's vote makes a difference,'' Kennedy said in a rare interview. As the junior member, he is the last to give his views and to cast his vote on each case during the court's secret conferences. ``If it's 5-4, my say is very important,'' Kennedy said. ``I'm guaranteed an audience.'' Legal scholars say Kennedy, an unassuming Californian, may underestimate his role and impact. They say his appointment may have marked a turning point in the court's history _ giving Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist the conservative equivalent of the working liberal majority Arthur Goldberg's appointment in 1962 gave Chief Justice Earl Warren. ``Over the range of cases, the Goldberg-Kennedy analogy is quite apt. He has provided a consistent conservative vote,'' said Mike Seidman, a law professor at Georgetown University. In his first full term, which ended last July, Kennedy joined 5-4 rulings that gave states greater power to regulate abortions and allowed capital punishment for mentally retarded murderers and killers who committed their crimes when as young as 16. Kennedy also provided the crucial fifth vote in a series of rulings that outraged civil rights activists by limiting the scope of affirmative action and federal anti-bias laws. He wrote for the court when it upheld drug testing for some U.S. Customs employees and for railroad workers involved in serious accidents. Kennedy's most surprising vote last year helped form a 5-4 majority to strike down a Texas law banning desecration of the U.S. flag. In a recently published book, New York University law professor Bernard Schwartz theorizes that the flag-burning law probably would have been upheld had Kennedy not joined the court. He cites a 1974 court memorandum quoting Justice Lewis F. Powell as saying, ``The physical integrity of the flag may be protected.'' Kennedy replaced Powell, who retired. The close votes left some scars, with justices on both sides authoring some acrimonious opinions. ``Last year, the rhetoric, I thought, was unfortunate. I plead guilty,'' Kennedy said. ``It was, in part, because of the tremendous number of issues we were trying to deal with. (It) reflects the competitive nature of the judges.'' He hinted that several justices at one point realized things might be getting too competitive. ``Some of us took steps ...,'' Kennedy said before pausing and laughing. ``It could have been much worse.'' Kennedy said it is important to distinguish the justices' professional relations from their personal relations. ``Of course, we disagree, but personal relations here are good,'' he said. Kennedy, 53, was Ronald Reagan's third choice for the post left vacant by Powell's retirement in June 1987. Reagan's nomination of conservative Judge Robert H. Bork was rejected by the Senate after a bitter political struggle in which Bork was portrayed as a rigid extremist. Reagan's second choice, Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg, withdrew after news reports that he smoked marijuana while a law professor. ``On the whole, the difference between Kennedy and Bork probably has not been dramatic,'' said Rod Smolla, a law professor at the College of William and Mary. ``Kennedy voted the way you would expect Bork to vote.'' But Daniel Farber, a University of Minnesota law professor, said Kennedy may prove to be more flexible. He has ``a reputation for thoughtfulness and open-mindedness,'' Farber said. ``I hope he will stake out his own positions in future years.'' Despite the mountain of work, more than 400 appeals, handed to Kennedy when he arrived, he had little trouble getting accustomed to the change from his life as a judge on the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in his native Sacramento, Calif. He worked as a federal appellate judge for 12 years after a career in law and as a lobbyist in the Legislature. ``I worked hard in the 9th Circuit, but I would say there's three times more work here,'' Kennedy said. ``Obviously, there's not three times more hours in a day so the intensity level is different.'' Kennedy often works six days a week at the court's impressive building, arriving by 5:30 or 6 most mornings. His office offers a striking view of the U.S. Capitol across the street. He also works each evening in a basement office at his suburban Virginia home, he said, ``but I switch to non-work related reading after eight.'' His evenings are spent quietly, reading and talking to his wife, Mary, a former elementary school teacher whom he married 25 years ago. ``We aren't much for television,'' he said. The couple's three grown children live in California. For years a part-time professor of constitutional law at the University of the Pacific's McGeorge School of Law in Sacramento, Kennedy now enjoys traveling to law schools for lectures and speeches. ``That's one thing about the job change,'' he said. ``When I get invited someplace now, Mary gets invited. We enjoy traveling together.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Star Watch: `Gigi' Maintains Active Career at Age 58
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: That famous gamin quality still shines in Leslie Caron's face, but an air of worldliness has been added to the star who entranced the film world as Lili and Gigi. That's only natural, since the French actress-dancer at 58 has weathered 40 years in films. She maintains an active career, both as actress, writer and, she hopes, as director. But don't ask her to dance. ``Dancing _ oh, no!'' she declares. ``It gets too hard. ``The last time I was lured on the stage, my swan song was the utmost. I can't do anything to come close to that: I dance seven minutes with Baryshnikov and Nureyev. I am the only dancer ever to do that with both of them on a stage. It was for a charity event at the Met, if you please. ``After that, I bowed out.'' Caron returned to Hollywood for the launching of a new film, ``Courage Mountain.'' It's an update of the ``Heidi'' saga, with Juliette Caton as the adolescent Swiss heroine and Charlie Sheen as her army sweetheart. Caron plays the stern, iron-willed headmistress of Heidi's boarding school in Italy. The school is caught in the turmoil of the start of World War I, and the schoolgirls escape over the Alps to safety, pursued by a villainous Italian. ``I've been associated with children's stories quite a lot in my career _ all those little girl parts,'' observed the star. ``I should think that was why they asked me to play in this film. ``But lately I haven't been playing such nice characters. Immediately after `Courage Mountain,' I played a madam in a bordello and in the same year I played Coco Chanel, a woman of tremendous authority. ``This role was nice; I felt like I was playing a schoolmarm who was a little bit crazy, so intense about her teaching and the education of those children and the forming of their minds. She was rather a dear lady. I enjoyed playing that. ``I saw her as a kind of pioneer. I based her character a little bit on the Bloomsbury set _ Virginia Woolf and all those women with high ideals. I went much farther than the part demanded, but this is what I had in mind.'' Leslie Caron became an immediate star in 1951 when Gene Kelly picked her out of Roland Petit's Paris ballet to dance with him in ``An American in Paris.'' She was barely 16, the daughter of a French chemist and an American dancer. She followed with such films as ``Lili,'' ``The Glass Slipper,'' ``Daddy Long Legs'' (with Fred Astaire), the Oscar-winning ``Gigi,'' ``Fanny,'' ``Father Goose'' (with Cary Grant) and ``Promise Her Anything.'' What does she remember fondly of her Hollywood years? ``Gene Kelly's house on Saturday night. It was open house; there were no keys on the locks in those days. From eight o'clock on, anyone who felt the need for a good drink and good company would wander in. Guests would sit down at the piano or start singing or start dancing, or just talk. ``There were so many entertainers there on Saturday night that it was really quite thrilling. And always (producer-director) Stanley Donen would be sleeping through it all.'' What does she remember not so fondly? ``The iron rule of the studio (MGM) was uncomfortable,'' she recalled. ``One was a property of the studio. It was a little regimented; you had to do what they told you. I'm very self-willed, as you may have noticed. I didn't always want to do the films that the studio wanted me to do. So I would stand up to them sometimes. That was frightening; it took some courage. ``Why did I leave? I just liked liberty. I didn't want to be under contract. I tried to leave from the moment I was locked in there. It took me eight years to get my liberty back _ which was probably a foolish thing on my part, because I think the studio system was good, especially for actresses. You had constant work. Had I been a little more intelligent and been able to work with the system, I could have found some parts. I could have worked, instead of being rebellious as I was.'' With ``The L-Shaped Room'' in 1962, she proved she was a dramatic actress as well as a dancer. Her three marriages _ to meat-packing heir George Hormel, British director Peter Hall and American director Michael Laughlin _ ended in divorce. With her two children by Hall on their own, she has engaged in a wide range of activities, from serving on film festival juries to writing short stories and, next, directing. ``I've been writing a script and I want to direct it,'' she said. ``It's my third script, and I want to direct this one. I'd love to start on that profession. Don't tell me it's a bit late, I don't believe it. ``It's an experience actors want to have gone through. I think every actor always has wanted to do that. Usually they stop after one experience. Charlie Laughton directed one film, so did Albert Finney.'' Also: Frank Sinatra, Kirk Douglas, Jack Lemmon, Marlon Brando. For the past 13 years, Caron has maintained her home in Paris. ``Sometimes I think it's too nice there,'' she said. ``Sometimes you can just be lulled away by the wonderful, wonderful things that happen in Paris: premieres, theater, films, dinners, friends. You could just waste your life away doing pleasant things, not working. I'm a hard-working person; I love to work.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
The Artists: A Splash of Color, A Dab of Tint
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Long before cable broadcaster Ted Turner began coloring black-and-white prints, Margaret Spargo was adding a blush to the cheeks or a splash of color to the dresses of the subjects in her monochrome portraits. Almost daily she sits at a little red table in the window of her storefront studio, with its old bellows camera in back and its shelves piled high with papers, photographs and tools of her trade, carefully coloring photographs by hand. Propped around her are examples of her handiwork, a technique that is regaining popularity in art schools. That makes little impression on her. Spargo, who won't reveal her age, is a woman of few words, especially describing how she learned her technique nearly 60 years ago. ``I just did it on my own. Don't ask me how I learned. I just did it,'' she says. Working from detailed notes about her subjects, she deftly dabs nearly transparent oil paint with a piece of cotton onto the faces of a mother, father and son. She had spent several painstaking hours working with a colored pencil and brush to match the woman's blue print dress. ``That was a Lulu. It's not quite right, but it's close,'' she said, admiring her work and wistfully recalling the days when clothes were plainer. She works quickly, with widening circular strokes. If she strays, the paint can be wiped away until it fully dries in about a day. The artistry comes in blending the colors and highlighting the features, so the boy's blue eyes have a lifelike, almost impish sparkle. In Spargo's typical unconcerned attitude, she can't tell you how long it takes her to finish a typical photograph. ``That sounds silly, but I've never timed myself. People are much too scientific about things,'' she said. A typical 8- by 10-inch tinted portrait of one person costs $50, but if the customer wants Spargo to color with heavier opaque oils that must be brushed on, it will cost $200. Hand coloring emerged in the 1840s, shortly after daguerreotypes, the first commercially viable photos taken on glass plates, said David Gibney, negative archivist of the International Museum of Photography in Rochester, N.Y. At first, a little blush was added to the cheeks and a splash of color to jewelry. Fully tinted photos became popular after the turn of the century until color photo materials improved and became affordable in the 1940s. ``I think a lot of sins that the camera's lens brings out can be hidden with hand coloring, and you can enhance the good things,'' Gibney said. It made its resurgence in college fine art programs during the past 10 years as an art form, said E. Ken White, chairman of fine art photography at the Rochester Institute of Technology and himself a hand colorer. Workers at John G. Marshall Manufacturing Co. in Chicago, the major distributor of the special oils, only know they've shipped many more paint kits lately. ``We get calls every day from practically all over the world,'' said Margaret Heft, who helps assemble the kits. ``I've worked for the company for nine years and every year it's increased.'' She estimated the company ships about 50,000 tubes of paint and kits a year directly to customers, compared with about 20,000 a decade ago, and about 10 times that number are shipped through an affiliated wholesaler. Even the best color print will begin to age in five years, but hand-colored photos can last 50 years without much deterioration, White said. Hand-colored prints of still-lifes or scenery became a major industry around the turn of the century, with photographers such as Wallace Natting of Boston maintaining stables of retouchers, he said. ``It's hard to visit an antiques store in New England and not find a Wallace Natting hanging on the wall somewhere,'' White said. Spargo doesn't recall all the specifics of when she got into the business. She only remembers that it was sometime in the 1930s and she was 19 when she went to work for photographer Fred Stiles at his downtown studio. She was dissuaded from becoming a nurse by her older sister who worked at the local hospital for a summer, so she went to Stiles, who had shot her parents' wedding photos. ``I just thought I wanted to do something that I would learn something, not just a job,'' she said, but after the first day of retouching the photo of a boy to remove his freckles, she almost went looking elsewhere. Stiles ``told me it looked like a hen scratched it, which it probably did,'' she said. But Spargo persevered under a succession of owners and four years later bought the studio. It was at a national photography workshop at Winona Lake, Ind., where she went to learn more about commercial photography, that she took up hand coloring. Spargo had planned to do color photography, but the great hurricane of 1938 wiped out much of Westerly, and made supplies hard to get. After that, other things came up and she just never got around to it. ``I don't know why,'' she said. She also does a good business in copying and retouching old photographs, but discourages people from getting them hand colored because they probably don't know what the true colors were. In her own way, she hews to tradition, even while adding color to black and white, and that's why she doesn't like the new trend toward colorizing movies. ``I like them better (in black and white). They were made that way. Why change them,'' she said. ``It's just a notion I have.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Music Makers: Keeping the Blues Dirty
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Something strange has been happening lately to bluesman Bobby Radcliff. The bikers and flying beer bottles have disappeared from his concerts. No guns, no knives, no cops. Suddenly, his audiences are no longer confined to drunks, aging beatniks and hippies. Yuppies like him, jazz collectors, too. How, Radcliff worries, can he keep the blues dirty in front of people so well-behaved? ``I've been in these rough and tumble clubs most of my life,'' said the 39-year-old singer-guitarist, whose first national release is called ``Dresses too Short.'' ``Just in the last year we played at CBGB's, and that went over really well and freaked me out a little bit. All of a sudden you're playing in these big places and it's a little unnerving,'' he said of the New York club. ``We played at the Ritz last week. You're playing in front of 10 times an audience. I've been in these small clubs where people are right in your face. You know what they're thinking, what they're feeling. And you know how to gauge their response level. You'll play a note and they'll go, `Yeah.''' Not that Radcliff is complaining. He has no wish to return to the lean times of the mid-1970s, when a dying blues scene forced him to earn a living lifting boxes. But the blues is a most personal kind of music, demanding active interchange with an audience. Radcliff remembered seeing B.B. King in small clubs, talking up women while squeezing sounds from his beloved guitar, ``Lucille.'' ``The intimacy of a small place is pretty cool,'' Radcliff said. ``That's when you see an audience and a performer come together. At a nightclub, you can start up and mellow out, go along and start up again; you're working in a framework of three or four hours. ``In these big rock gigs you got to go right on up, and when I'm off I don't feel like I'm warmed up yet.'' Radcliff grew up in affluent Chevy Chase, Md., and by age 12 was already checking out live shows around Howard University nearby Washington, D.C. ``Our teacher let us out of school early _ he was one of these hip teachers,'' he recalled. ``For $2.50 you'd see three acts: Jimmy Reed, Booker T. and the MG's, Sam and Dave. Across this street was this huge record store, and we'd go buy the records that we had heard played.'' Radcliff loved Elvis Presley, Johnny Cash and the other early rock 'n' roll stars, but longed for something more. In the early 1960s, he found it: the blues, first, Slim Harpo, then Muddy Waters, Howlin' Wolf and dozens of others. When he was 16, Radcliff ran away from home in search of bluesman Magic Sam, who showed his young fan around the clubs of Chicago's West Side. Back home, he modeled his singing on Elvis and Magic Sam and started playing guitar in local bands, giving concerts at churches, picnics and barbeques. By the early '70s, he was performing in blues clubs, notably Cousin Nick's, a tiny bar in northwest Washington. ``Sometimes we'd go back and hang out in the alley at the rear of the club, and the bass player almost got his bass stolen from a small gang of kids,'' he recalled. ``There were lots of little mini-holdups and stuff. Some of our fans would get robbed coming in and out of the clubs. That was kind of a rough area.'' But Cousin Nick's closed in the mid-'70s and Radcliff bounced around California, Albuquerque, N.M., and Washington again before settling in New York. It was 1977, the discos days, the time of ``Saturday Night Fever'' and Donna Summer. The blues seemed outdated and Radcliff watched his peers drop out. ``They got really depressed, wound up drinking themselves under the table,'' he said. ``I guess I had some kind of deep belief that somehow maybe it would work out, even though nothing was. There was that deep part of me that thought there was some slim chance.'' Now, the blues are back and Radcliff has an album on Black Top Records. Major labels were interested, but at a price, with one record company executive even imagining him as a cross between Elvis and David Bowie. ``Dresses too Short'' is pure Radcliff. Several of the songs _ ``Kool and the Gang,'' ``Going Home Tomorrow,'' ``Hard Road to Travel'' _ have been in his live show for years, lasting as long as the trusty white Fender guitar he's owned since the late '60s. ``Most people will tell me that there's so much garbage on the radio,'' Radcliff said. ``Big companies are not really interested in hiring a lot of alternative type bands, like blues. They want bands they can filter through the system. ``A lot of the stuff that's out now is not feeling or intellectual. I like pop myself, but I couldn't live on it.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Books and Authors: Invisible Pilgrim of Latin American `Boom'
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-five years before Gabriel Garcia Marquez created his imaginary Macondo in ``One Hundred Years of Solitude,'' the Cuban writer Alejo Carpentier laid the literary foundations of ``magical realism'' in a visit to Haiti. Viewing the fantastic ruins left behind by the Emperor Henri-Christophe, Carpentier was struck by the ``marvelous reality'' of Latin America, where collective faith in the supernatural wrought incredible alterations on the real world. Garcia Marquez once remarked that if Franz Kafka had lived in Latin America, he would have been considered a realist. But it was Carpentier's matter-of-fact treatment of the magical in ``The Kingdom of This World'' _ where the protagonist turns into a fly _ that marked a turning point in the Latin American novel. In recent months Farrar, Straus Giroux has released ``The Kingdom'' and three other works by Carpentier in paperback editions. Given the steady popularity of Latin American fiction among American readers in the past decade, the attention paid to this silent forerunner of the ``boom'' is welcome. Carpentier, who was born in 1904 and died in 1980, had the misfortune to be ahead of his time. When ``The Kingdom of This World'' and ``The Lost Steps'' were first translated in the 1950s both flopped. His fascination with the African sources of Caribbean culture may have left American readers cold 30 years ago, but it is timely today given the renewed interest in the music, food and culture of the region. The other new editions are ``Explosion in a Cathedral,'' also quickly remaindered after its 1962 publication, and ``The Chase,'' published in Spanish in 1956 and never before translated. Carpentier's writing is intensely sophisticated and less light-spirited than that of Carlos Fuentes, Mario Vargas Llosa and Garcia Marquez, all of whom acknowledge a debt to him. As one of the first Latin American writers to appeal to a worldwide audience, he had to lay down firm roots in European traditions that later ``boom'' writers were able to transcend. Like so many other Latin American writers, Carpentier went to Paris as a political refugee. In the '30s he was associated, through his interest in avant-garde music, with some of the founders of modernism _ Picasso, the dadaist Tristan Tzara, the surrealists Louis Aragon and Andre Breton. It was French surrealism, in Carpentier's words, ``that taught me to see textures, aspects of Latin American life that I had not noticed.'' Carpentier abandoned the naturalistic novel, what he called ``those poor slices of life that fill bookshop windows with their pages that smell of cheap boarding houses and civil servants' dandruff,'' to investigate the unique, baroque quality of Latin American reality. A 1943 visit to Haiti, and further explorations in the depths of the South American continent, led him to the realization that Latin American consciousness, so different from that of North America and Europe, required a new literary vision. His novels are remarkable for their coverage of a variety of themes in modern Latin American fiction _ ``not only the major waves but even the lesser ripples,'' as Terry J. Peavler, a Latin American literature profsesor at Penn State University, has written. In ``Explosion in a Cathedral,'' he describes the ravages of the French Revolution on the Caribbean, bringing to light a forgotten chapter of history while probing the contradictions inherent in revolutionary movements. Some of the same territory is covered in ``The Chase,'' the story of the intermingled lives of a ticket-taker at a concert hall and a misguided student activist, in the Cuba of the '30s. ``The Lost Steps,'' a clear precursor to Mario Vargas Llosa's latest book, ``The Storyteller,'' and a cousin to Thomas Mann's ``Death in Venice,'' explores the protean lure of indigenous spiritualism for the inhabitants of modern civilization. While Carpentier was a man of the left, his books are far from sanguine in their assessment of revolutionary politics. In the closing pages of ``Explosion in a Cathedral,'' the two main characters offer soliloquies that might be taken as expressions of Carpentier's dualistic view of revolution. Victor, a charismatic cynic, speaks of playing ``so many parts that I no longer know which one I should be playing. I've put on so many costumes I no longer know which is the right one.'' His lover, Sofia, responds: ``Perhaps that is the most splendid thing the Revolution has done, to have altered more than one person's ideas.'' Carpentier's greatest works were produced in the '40s and '50s when he lived in Venezuela. In 1959, he returned enthusiastically to Havana after Fidel Castro's triumph. The Cuban poet, Heberto Padilla, recounts an espisode in the early '60s, when Carpentier had been called to Paris to receive a literary prize. When he failed to appear for the ceremony, Cuban Embassy officials panicked, afraid he had defected, Padilla said. They were relieved to learn he had simply skipped off for a vacation with a girlfriend. ``The Cuban government never trusted him,'' said Donald Shaw, a University of Virginia professor who has written a book on Carpentier. ``His attitude toward them was always ambiguous, and their reception of him was equally ambiguous.'' Carpentier directed the state publishing house until 1968, when he was dismissed and sent to Paris as a cultural attache. When he died, his body was returned to Havana for a state funeral procession headed by Castro himself.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Nashville Sound: Whitey Shafer Writes About Marriage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Lyndia cq 7th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Three failed marriages helped country music songwriter Sanger D. ``Whitey'' Shafer to compose the memorable ``All My Ex's Live in Texas.'' In fact, he wrote the amusing ditty _ recorded by George Strait _ with his fourth wife's assistance. The 1987 song is probably Shafer's best known work in a 25-year composing career that's yielded 200 recorded tunes. ``I think I've written something about everything that's ever been written about,'' the 55-year-old Shafer said recently. His wry look at former spouses, embellished by the catchy title, became one of the most popular country songs of the past decade. Local country music bands everywhere have the song in their repertoire. The tune also helped Strait win the prestigious ``Entertainer of the Year'' award from the Country Music Association last year. And attention all those ex's: the royalties helped Shafer, too. He and current wife, Lyndia, who have been married eight years, wrote the song about his three ex-wives. It's not malicious, and listeners tend to feel sorry for the fellow in the song who can't even return to the river where he learned how to swim. ``That's why I hang my hat in Tennessee,'' the song says. ``He'd like to go to Texas, but things are kinda hot down there,'' explained Shafer, born and raised in the Waco, Texas, area. ``It was a fun song to write. I did change the names to protect the guilty.'' The rhyming title, which has become one of the most famous in country music, is a followup to a punchy line he wrote in the 1970s for another song: ``I was following the rodeos in Texas and being chased by the fathers of my ex's.'' ``Some titles don't tell the whole story, but this one did,'' said Shafer, who got the nickname ``Whitey'' in high school because of his light-colored hair. He gives Strait, a fellow Texan, credit for taking a chance on the song others considered inappropriate. ``I think if he had not have cut that, it would never have been recorded,'' Shafer said. ``People are funny about cutting cute songs, but that one just had something about it. It was too cute to pass up. ``I wish I had a bushel basket full like that one.'' The inevitable question is whether his three ex-wives really do live in Texas and how they reacted to the song. ``They do live there, but one sort of drifts back and forth between California and Texas,'' Shafer said. He's not sure how two of them feel, but ex-wife Darlene took it fine. ``We're still friends,'' he said. Last year, Shafer wrote the hit song ``I Wonder Do You Think of Me,'' which was the first tune released by country singer Keith Whitley after Whitley died in May of an accidental overdose of alcohol. It was a No. 1 record. ``I liked him a whole lot and he'd been to my house a lot when he first came to town,'' Shafer said. ``He was a heck of a talent, a great singer and was only getting better as he went on. He also had a great personality.'' Some of Shafer's other top songs include ``Does Fort Worth Ever Cross Your Mind,'' recorded by Strait; ``That's the Way Love Goes,'' a No. 1 country music record by both Merle Haggard and Johnny Rodriguez; and ``I Never Go Around Mirrors,'' also recorded by Whitley. Shafer moved to Nashville from Texas in the mid-1960s with the idea of becoming a singer. He did some performing, but found the competition stiff. ``There were too many singers,'' he recalled. So he turned to songwriting. ``For some reason, I've always been able to retain a string of notes I've heard,'' he said. ``It just seems like I know what kind of idea will go with a certain melody.'' Shafer, who recently was inducted into the Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame, describes himself as a writer of traditional country music with little interest in pop oriented styles. Give him a few beers and his favorite instrument and he'll come up with a country song. ``It just seemed like a guitar and six pack went together,'' he said. ``Right now I like to write love songs because I'm in love. When I was rough and rowdy, I wrote rough and rowdy songs.'' But he says country music's honky-tonk songs glorifying alcohol, such as Hank Williams' ``There's a Tear in My Beer,'' aren't as popular as they used to be. ``Drinking and getting drunk is not hip any more. People don't like to see it. It's almost indignant to be tipsy. People just don't want to mess with people who can't control their lives.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Entertainment Briefs
DOC.TEXT: The Nickelodeon television network's new facility at Universal Studios in Florida will begin production of its programming for children in June. The 90,000-square-foot center, which features two sound stages and a three-story building, is the first studio constructed exclusively for children. The control rooms and production areas have been designed so that visitors touring the center can see what shows are in progress. Young guests will have an opportunity to audition for programs or be a part of a studio audience. Nickelodeon, an advertiser-supported cable service owned by MTV Networks, airs daily programming for children ages 2 to 15. Shows include animation, adventure, live action, comedy and music. The network becomes Nick at Nite after 8 p.m. with shows aimed at a general audience.

Estelle Parsons will return to Broadway in her highly acclaimed, Tony-nominated role of the tyrannical schoolteacher in Roberto Athayde's play ``Miss Margarida's Way.'' The production opens Feb. 15 at the Helen Hayes Theater. ``Miss Margarida's Way'' was first presented in New York at the Public Theater in 1977 and later transferred to the Ambassador Theater on Broadway, where Parsons received a Tony nomination for best actress. Parsons has performed the role all over the United States and abroad. In ``Miss Marigarida's Way,'' the domineering Miss Margarida terrorizes her eighth grade class _ the audience _ with her ``lessons'' of the day. Audience participation can be a key element of ``Miss Margarida's Way,'' with each performance capable of inciting a wide array of intense _ and vocal _ reactions. Parsons currently appears on TV's ``Roseanne.''

On Valentine's day, give a loved one a work of heart. For the fifth straight year, Pacific Northwest artists are donating their special Valentines for an auction with the theme ``Works of Heart'' to help raise money for a museum's permanent art collection. The works feature art with a Valentine theme in just about every conceivable medium, each donated to the Cheney Cowles Museum by artists who have exhibited there. The artists, who receive no money for their work, say the February festival gives them a chance to examine each other's work and meet in a common cause. The annual event has raised $30,000 over the past four years.

DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said its parent company was filing for federal bankruptcy court protection, signaling the demise of the Wall Street firm that became synonymous with riches and scandal during the go-go 1980s. Drexel's board of directors on Tuesday authorized the parent, Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., to seek protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy code. The step climaxes one of the most tumultuous periods in Wall Street history for the cocksure investment house, which pioneered the use of risky, high-interest ``junk bonds'' to finance billions of dollars worth of corporate takeovers under its now-indicted executive Michael Milken.

NEW YORK _ The impact of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s stunning decline reaches like an octopus past Wall Street and the risky IOUs known as junk bonds, potentially threatening the health of many businesses that depend on financial markets to raise money. A Drexel bankruptcy filing could inject more sellers into the already depressed junk bond market that the firm dominates, creating a confidence crisis that might spread into stocks, higher-grade corporate debt and other securities, investment experts and business executives said Tuesday. Such turmoil in turn would affect the broader economy, possibly by pushing interest rates and the dollar higher in opposition to government attempts to sustain economic growth.

NEW YORK _ Integrated Resources Inc., which built its fortune on tax shelters and tried to become a financial services giant by turning to junk bonds, sought federal bankruptcy protection after some of its creditors balked at restructuring more than $1.6 billion in debt. Tuesday's move came as the parent of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which underwrote a large portion of Integrated's debt, also prepared to file for bankruptcy protection. Drexel, Wall Street's junk bond leader, is Integrated's fifth-largest creditor.

WASHINGTON _ Retail sales rose a strong 1.6 percent in January, their sharpest gain in more than a year, the government reported. Analysts said the broad advance demonstrated enough consumer confidence to hold off any recession. ``Consumer spending is still alive,'' John Silvia, an economist with Kemper Financial Services in Chicago, said Tuesday. Most categories showed advances that ``suggest to me that the consumer is coming back in the first quarter, taking up his normal pace of spending.''

WASHINGTON _ U.S. and Soviet trade negotiators expressed satisfaction with the progress made in their first round of talks aimed at wiping away nearly a half-century of trade friction between the two superpowers. Deputy U.S. Trade Representative Julius Katz said Tuesday he was confident that a new trade agreement can be negotiated in time for President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev to sign the document at their next summit meeting in June.

BONN, West Germany _ The Germanys agreed to begin formal talks on making the West German mark the official currency of East Germany, a move that could lay the economic foundation for reunification.
