Meanwhile Tuesday, the rush to reunify the Germanys gained further impetus in Ottawa, where British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said the Western allies and the Soviet Union are close to agreeing on a way to unite the two nations.

WASHINGTON _ Over the objections of government attorneys, a federal judge allowed lawyers for Phoenix millionaire Charles H. Keating Jr. to portray him as a victim of a vendetta by federal savings and loan regulators. U.S. District Court Judge Stanley Sporkin repeatedly overruled objections to testimony alleging leaks of confidential information from the Federal Home Loan Bank Board about Keating's Lincoln and Savings and Loan Association. Attorneys for the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision, which last year replaced the bank board as the thrift industry's chief regulator, argued that the leaks were irrelevant to Keating's suit challenging the federal takeover of the $5.5 billion thrift last April. Sporkin, however, said he wanted to learn the ``broad backdrop'' to the case.

Chrysler Corp. reported a $664 million fourth-quarter loss and a two-thirds drop in annual earnings for 1989, mostly due to costs of closing plants and cutting jobs. The results mean no profit-sharing for hourly workers and no bonuses for salaried employees at the nation's third-largest automaker, Chrysler Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Lee A. Iacocca said Tuesday. Chrysler also said that to raise cash it had agreed to sell its Gulfstream Aerospace subsidiary for $825 million, to a partnership of Allen E. Paulson, chairman and founder of the corporate jet maker, and the New York investment firm of Forstmann, Little & Co.

NEW YORK _ IBM became the first company to announce pilot production of a 16-million-bit computer memory chip, which has four times the memory capacity of today's most advanced chips. A 16-million-bit memory chip can store the equivalent of about 1,600 pages of double-spaced, typewritten text. Other companies are known to be working on 16-million-bit chips, but none so far has announced pilot production, industry analysts said Tuesday.

Stock prices closed mixed Tuesday as the market mulled a likely Chapter 11 filing by the parent of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. The Dow Jones industrial average finished up 4.96 at 2,624.10. Crude oil futures declined, copper futures surged, grains and soybeans mostly were lower, and livestock and meat futures were mixed. The dollar mostly was higher and gold prices declined in the United States after a mixed performance overseas.

DOC.HEAD: Drexel Downfall Could Reverberate Through the Econony
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s demise could reach far beyond the junk-bond sensation it created, forcing interest rates higher, hurting the financing ability of many U.S. companies and possibly creating new takeover opportunities for foreign buyers. Investment strategists and business executives said Tuesday that these were the types of economic consequences to expect from Drexel's decision to seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, even though the investment bank is nowhere near the largest. ``When we had the explosion and problems at Three Mile Island, it impacted the entire utilities industry,'' said Paul E. Berg, president of Berg Fiduciary Consultants, a investment advisory firm in Port Chester, N.Y. ``You've got pretty much the same situation here.'' The Drexel bankruptcy filing could inject more sellers into the already depressed junk bond market that the firm dominates, creating a confidence crisis that might spread into other securities, some experts said. Such turmoil in turn could have a more profound effect by forcing interest rates higher, at a time when many economists say interest rates must come down if the economy is to avoid a recession. ``This means that the cost of capital to the United States will increase,'' said Chriss Street, a strategist at Seidler Amdec Securities Inc., a Los Angeles investment firm. ``The cost of capital overseas will be relatively lower. We should expect a lot of acquisitions by foreigners.'' To the surprise of some, the market for junk bonds survived a wave of paranoia Tuesday, and prices of many issues actually stabilized. Managers of several junk-bond mutual funds said they didn't receive any flood of calls from investors who wanted to get out. But others said the market's behavior reflected confusion about the ultimate impact of Drexel's problems, and they predicted that over the next several days at least the demand for junk bonds would stall. ``It's going to be very difficult to find buyers for that paper,'' said Jack Barbanel, managing director of First Global Asset Management, a Princeton, N.J., investment concern. ``You'll find many sellers but not many buyers.'' Many expressed surprise at the frightening speed with which Drexel hurtled toward collapse because of the junk bond market it largely was responsible for creating in the 1980s. ``It took a long time to string together this enterprise, and not much time at all for it to crack up,'' said James Grant, author of a prominent financial newsletter that frequently has warned against the perils of junk-bond debt. ``It's not unlike the collapse of Tyson in Tokyo.'' Others likened Drexel's demise to a disaster that will further erode the tarnished credibility of the depressed securities industry overall and convince investors to shun investments that have no relation to junk bonds. This could force companies that historically have relied on selling stocks and bonds for new capital to curtail spending plans, lay off workers or even seek bankruptcy protection themselves. Meanwhile, banks, insurers, pension funds, mutual funds and other investors who bought junk bonds because they promised such high rates of interest could wind up owning nearly worthless pieces of paper, some financial strategists said. ``Now the reality is beginning to sink in, it's coming home to roost, that when people originally called them `junk bonds,' that's exactly what they were,'' Barbanel said. Others emphasized, however, that the overall amount of junk bonds held by most investors remains only a tiny percentage of their portfolios. The total value of assets held just by pension funds, for example, is more than $2.5 trillion, while the entire junk bond market once amounted to about $200 billion. ``If everybody owned a piece of a junk bond it would be pretty small,'' said William Overgard, director of investment consulting at Buck Pension Fund Services in New York. Drexel vaulted to prominence in the 1980s by aggressively peddling high-interest securities with low credit ratings as a way to raise money for businesses seeking to expand. The securities became known as junk bonds because of their relatively higher risk of default compared with investment-grade corporate bonds. Even before Drexel's latest problems, a number of prominent deals that depended on junk-bond financing had begun unraveling or faced serious obstacles. Drexel played a role in many of them. On Tuesday, for example, Drexel client Integrated Resources Inc., a diversified financial services company that has been struggling for months, sought federal bankruptcy protection.

DOC.HEAD: Integrated Resources Filing Caps Rocky History
With PM-Drexel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Integrated Resources Inc., which tried to build a financial services empire with junk-bond financing provided by Drexel Burnham Lambert, sought federal bankruptcy court protection within hours of Drexel's own filing. Integrated sought Chapter 11 protection Tuesday after some of its creditors balked at restructuring more than $1.6 billion in debt. Unlike Drexel's filing, the move by Integrated wasn't a surprise. Integrated has been struggling since defaulting on nearly $1 billion in debt last June. The bankruptcy proceedings of the two companies are bound to be intertwined. Drexel, Wall Street's junk bond leader, is Integrated's fifth-largest creditor. Trading in Integrated was temporarily halted on the New York Stock Exchange after Tuesday's announcement. It later closed sharply lower at around 17 cents a share, down from 25 cents Monday. Integrated officials said they were forced to file for protection under Chapter 11 of federal bankrutpcy laws because a few creditors refused to negotiate the debt restructuring. The creditors had filed or planned to file legal complaints against Integrated. The company, which said it hoped to resume talks with creditors soon, said the creditors had the ability to seize Integrated's assets to satisfy their individual claims. ``Working out a consenual out-of-court reorganization depends on the good faith of substantially all the creditors,'' Chairman Stephen D. Weinroth said in an interview. ``We were spending too much time and too much money trying to stave off actions where the ultimate outcome was not in doubt. ``Sooner or later they were going to get a judgment,'' said Weinroth, a former senior executive with Drexel who left to manage Integrated. Integrated originally was a real estate company and expanded rapidly several years ago by selling tax-sheltered investments, eventually becoming the largest seller of those investments. That business was scuttled by 1986 tax-law revisions, and the company then moved aggressively into insurance and mutual funds, financed largely through junk bonds arranged by Drexel. For a while, Integrated was one of the many junk-bond financed rags-to-riches stories. But it was unable to sell enough real-estate partnerships, insurance policies and mutual funds to service its debt burden and its high overhead. ``They had a capital situation where they were living on the edge,'' said Leigh Walzer, a securities analyst with R.D Smith & Co. in New York. ``They were living in an age of high leverage that made them, then unmade them.'' Integrated's filing in U.S. Bankrutpcy Court in Manhattan protects the company from creditors while it continues to operate and attempts to reorganize its finances. The company said none of its subsidiaries and affiliates is included in the filing. Among the subsidiaries is corporate jet manufacturer LearJet Corp. of Wichita, Kan., which earlier this week agreed to be sold for $60 million to an investment group that includes the management of Savannah, Ga.-based Gulfstream Aerospace. Weinroth said he doesn't expect any major delays in winning the bankruptcy court's approval for the sale. The LearJet purchase by the management group is part of a two-part deal that also involves the group's acquisition of Gulfstream from Chrysler Corp. for $825 million. Weinroth said Integrated's liabilities totaled $1.961 billion as of June 30, the latest date for which results are available. That included $1.62 billion in long- and short-term debt, with junk bonds accounting for $800 million. Assets totaled $1.402 billion, giving Integrated a negative net worth of $559 million, according to Weinroth. According to the bankruptcy court papers, Integrated said its top 10 creditors included large banks and savings and loans, some of which bought much of the junk bonds issued by Drexel under its indicted former bond leader Michael Milken. Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. led all creditors with a total owed of $55.84 million, followed by Chemical Bank with $51.57 million. Drexel ranked fifth with $41.105 million in exposure. Centrust Savings and Loan, the Miami thrift seized less than two weeks ago by federal regulators, ranked seventh with $39 million in public debt. Integrated earlier this year sold its key financial services businesses to Broad Inc., a Los Angeles financial services concern, for $95 million, far less than the $450 million Integrated had hoped to receive. A few other units have been either liquidated or sold. Weinroth said $175 million in assets have been sold so far. Some analysts predicted Integrated would emerge from bankrutpcy a shell of its former self, focusing on real estate limited partnerships and interests in leveraged buyout operations.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Reports $664 Million Quarterly Loss
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. has taken sharp losses to cut jobs and close plants, but the leaner look and the sale of its Gulfstream subsidiary will help the company compete in a tough 1990 auto market, Chairman Lee A. Iacocca said. A $664-million fourth-quarter loss and a 66 percent drop in earnings for 1989 means no profit-sharing for hourly workers and no bonuses for salaried employees, Iacocca said Tuesday. But savings of $1.2 billion from the company's cost-cutting program should come through in time to help 1990 profits, although prospects for the first quarter remain doubtful, he said. ``We've got our capacity down. Our cash position just got a little better, and we're focused,'' Iacocca said. Analysts agreed. ``They are coming to grips with getting rid of some of this excess capacity and that's going to be felt in 1990,'' said Harvey Heinbach of Merrill Lynch and Co. in New York. ``The outlook should be promising for them on earnings,'' said Thomas O'Grady, president of Integrated Automotive Resources Inc. in Wayne, Pa. ``They have written all this off in 1989, so for 1990 they have a clean slate.'' Chrysler's first quarterly loss since 1982 came largely from a one-time restructuring charge of $577 million, which covered costs of closing plants, discontinuing some car models and paying pension and severance costs to trim the white-collar work force, the company said. The fourth-quarter loss, equivalent to $2.90 a share, compared with earnings of $433 million, or $1.85 a share, in October-December of 1988. Revenues for the quarter sagged to $7.9 billion from $9.3 billion a year earlier, the company said. For the year, Chrysler reported net income of $359 million, or $1.55 a share, down from $1.05 billion, or $4.66 a share, in 1988. Revenues were $34.92 billion vs. $34.15 billion in 1988. The fourth-quarter charge of $577 million was partly offset by a $309 million gain on the sale of part of the company's stake in Mitsubishi Motors Corp., the company said. Chrysler had an after-tax loss of $87 million before the one-time charges. But Iacocca said the results reflected what he termed a full-blown recession in auto sales, necessitating rebates of more than $1,200 a car just to keep sales limping along. ``I am not in the least disappointed,'' he said. United Auto Workers union President Owen Bieber and Vice President Stan Marshall, who directs the UAW's Chrysler Department, said they regretted that earnings didn't trigger profit-sharing for hourly workers. Under Chrysler's UAW contract, they said in a statement, ``At least there will be some equality of sacrifice and Chrysler executives will have to go without bonuses as well.'' Chrysler has shut down its Jefferson Avenue assembly plant in Detroit and announced plans to close its St. Louis car assembly plant in September. The company announced a cost-cutting program in October aimed at cutting $1 billion from its $26-billion annual budget by the end of this year, including elimination of 2,300 salaried jobs. It has since boosted the cost-cutting goal to $1.5 billion. The company said it agreed to sell Gulfstream for $825 million to a partnership of Allen E. Paulson, chairman and founder of the Savannah, Ga.-based company, and the New York investment firm of Forstmann, Little & Co. ``It's called restructuring to compete,'' Iacocca said. ``We looked at the market for the early 1990s ... and it looked a little grim. We probably could have muddled through, but we chose not to. We chose to get ready for the '90s. It's all part of our plan.'' ``I hear the words. I want to believe it. But the proof remains to be seen,'' said auto analyst Charles Brady of Oppenheimer and Co. in New York. ``The only true vote of whether you're doing your job or not is whether you are selling cars or not.'' Chrysler stock closed at $16.37{ on the New York Stock Exchange, down 25 cents. General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. are scheduled to report earnings Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: New Dealer Organization Chief Says He'll Keep Pressure on Automakers
DOC.TEXT: If automakers thought they would get a breather from pressure applied by the National Automobile Dealers Association, they may have to think again. Ray Green, the new president of the National Automobile Dealers Association, said there should be no cozy relationship between dealers and manufacturers. ``If this were a real marriage, we would have been in divorce court a long time ago,'' said Green, head of The Green Holding Co., which operates eight franchises in southern Illinois. ``Today, we are looking at some differences with the manufacturers that go to the very core of our relationship, differences that must be resolved if the auto dealerships in this country are to survive, much less thrive,'' Green said Tuesday at the close of NADA's four-day convention. NADA figures show that about half of the 25,000 dealerships in the United States aren't making money. And NADA leaders have put most of the blame on automakers. Green succeeds Ron Tonkin of Portland, Ore., who hammered dealers for their increasing reliance on incentives, mandatory membership in dealer advertising associations and other issues. ``If the manufacturers think we are just going to hide, they're wrong,'' Green said. He said he planned to keep up the fights Tonkin began, and he's planning to add a few of his own. He said dealers should be represented in nearly all levels of decision-making by the automakers _ product planning and marketing, for instance. He said that would be part of a new franchise agreement he's working on. He hopes to get half of the automakers to adopt the new agreement. In his opening address to the convention, Tonkin championed higher dealer involvement with manufacturers and dealer unification. Tonkin and Green said dealers and manufacturers should approach each other at arm's length. But Charles Folliott, owner of The Car Store in Norwalk, Vt., said his relationship with manufacturers is good. ``If anything, I feel that manufacturer representatives are more willing to listen,'' he said. Earlier this month, Chrysler Corp. showed they were more aware of NADA when executives invited Tonkin to speak to the board of directors. It was the first time that a dealer organization chief addressed the board of any of the Big Three automakers. And manufacturers felt the clout of their dealers when, at Tonkin's urging late last year, they began cutting their new-car orders to trim the growing inventories on their lots. At the same time, sales slumped and the combination of declining sales and dealer orders prompted the companies to cut production. In turn, that resulted in the layoff of thousands of auto workers.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Says U.S-Mexico Agricultural Trade Doubles, But Constraints Remain
DOC.TEXT: Restrictive government policies on both sides of the border and antiquated transportation and processing facilities threaten the growth in U.S.-Mexico agricultural trade, according to a study by congressional investigators. The General Accounting Office, Congress' investigative arm, said trade between the neighboring countries increased from $2.3 billion during the recession year of 1982 to $4 billion in 1988, the highest growth rate among major U.S. agricultural trading partners. While Mexico is one of the United States' best customers of agricultural products, GAO said several problems continue to impede trade, including stiff health regulations, import licensing requirements, and tariffs. Mexican growers complain their agricultural exports are subject to excessive U.S. plant and animal health regulations and that U.S. tariffs on certain crops are too high. U.S. sources complain that Mexico's continued reliance on import licensing requirements is inconsistent with international trading laws, GAO said. Mexico's transportation infrastructure also has been inadequate to handle the large increase in trade in recent years and, if not improved, will continue to limit trade volume between the two countries, said the study, requested by U.S. Rep. Kika de la Garza, D-Texas. GAO said Mexico's rail system is outdated and lacks the capacity to carry the increasing cargo from the United States. Storage facilities are also lacking and rail cars are used instead to store grain or other goods. Due to delays in returning rail cars to the United States and congestion at the border, GAO said, U.S. rail companies refused several times last year to accept any Mexican-bound shipments, imposing a de facto embargo. Roads in Mexico are in general disrepair, making transportation of goods by truck a slow process. U.S. truckers, meanwhile, complain that they cannot operate in Mexico while Mexican truckers can enter the United States with their cargo. Another problem, GAO said, is that congestion, bottlenecks and excessive delays characterize conditions at border crossing points. Saul Mercado, director for Latin American affairs at the Texas Department of Agriculture, said another problem for Texas exporters is that railroad rates are higher in-state than for out-of-state shippers, making it cheaper for someone from Kansas to get his grain to the border than a Texan. Mexican trucks can carry heavier loads than Texas law permits, requiring much costly loading and unloading at the border, Mercado said. Mexico is the No. 1 buyer of Texas' agricultural products, Mercado said. ``We export every day livestock and grain and all kinds of commodities to Mexico,'' Mercado said. The state, which has a positive balance of trade with Mexico, lists its top exports as cattle for breeding, sheep, goats and hogs for slaughter, and a few dairy cows and some horses. The state also ships corn, sorghum, rice and some wheat. Mexico provides the United States with tropical products and specialty crops such as coffee and tomatoes. Mexico's outstanding external debt, which totaled more than $100 billion in 1988, is also a major constraint to trade, GAO said. Despite those problems, Mexico bought more agricultural products from the United States than all but three other countries in 1988 _ Japan, South Korea and the Soviet Union _ with a total value of $2.23 billion. Mexico, in turn, ranked third among all agricultural suppliers to the United States, after Canada and Brazil, providing the U.S. with $1.82 billion in foodstuffs two years ago. The United States had a positive agricultural trade balance in 1988 with Mexico of about $414 million.

DOC.HEAD: Merv Griffin's Resorts Casino Hotel Leaders Tout Gaming Hall's Future
DOC.TEXT: Merv Griffin's Resorts Casino Hotel in Atlantic City will revive and have a stable financial future, leaders of the firm predict. Those assurances were made Tuesday to the Casino Control Commission despite recent troubles that forced the casino's parent firm into bankruptcy court. The casino, Atlantic City's oldest, plans to pump more than $45 million into much-needed capital improvements this year and next year so it can compete with rival gaming halls again, officials told the commission. State gaming enforcement officials, however, said they believe financial projections made by casino officials are too optmisitic and the cloud of bankruptcy leaves the operation open to problems. The commission is holding a series of hearings to determine if the casino's license should be renewed. Griffin, who purchased Resorts International in 1988 from billionaire developer Donald Trump, attended the hearing but did not testify before the commission. Resorts International is the casino's parent firm. During a break in the proceeding, Griffin said he is ``extremely confident'' his new management team can turn around the casino's fortunes. The entertainer and television game show mogul said Resorts' location next to Trump's huge, soon-to-open Taj Mahal Casino puts it in a prime spot to grab business from ``what will be the epicenter of activity on the boardwalk.'' ``I believe in Atlantic City and I believe in Resorts,'' said Griffin. ``I believe that our ideas and marketing plan will bring it right back to being one of the top three casinos on the boardwalk.'' Facing huge debts, Resorts International in December filed a reorganization plan in federal bankruptcy court that seeks to get rid of about two-thirds of its $912 million debt by allowing Griffin to swap 78 percent of his Resorts stock. The plan still requires approval from the firm's bondholders and the Casino Control Commission. Deputy Attorney General Mary Jo Flaherty, of the commission's gaming enforcement division, said the bankruptcy court proceedings are costly and give Resorts a stigma that will make it tougher to resolve its financial problems. ``If Resorts remains on a bankruptcy track, they will not be able to maintain a competitive position,'' Ms. Flaherty said. David C. Hanlon, president and chief operating officer of Resorts, said he expects the company to be out of bankruptcy by the early summer. Ms. Flaherty said casino officials have crafted a recovery plan that is too optimistic in its projections of how much business the casino can attract. She said the casino in 1989 accounted for nine percent of the space in Atlantic City, but had only eight percent of the market. Hanlon, however, said 1989 was an abberration and insisted that the casino's projections of revenue ``can't get any more conservative. I have a high level of confidence in these numbers.'' Hanlon said Resorts' business has lagged because the casino is in woeful physical shape compared to its competition, a condition the present ownership said it did not anticipate when it bought the property. He said a capital improvement plan to pump $35 million in 1990 and $10.5 million in 1991 will remedy this problem. ``Since 1983, there was little or no refurbishment at the facility at a time when every other major facility was making improvements,'' Hanlon said. ``From a physical, systems and technological point of view, we're well behind everyone else in town. People went elsewhere, and those who stayed did so as a matter of habit.'' Hanlon said he expects a great deal of the physical improvements at the casino to be completed by the time the Taj Mahal, touted as the world's biggest casino, opens in April. The hearing is expected to continue Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Gulfstream, Learjet Make Paulson Main Man in Corporate Aviation
LaserPhoto SAV1 of Feb. 13
DOC.TEXT: Allen Paulson's name and telephone number have been in the Rolodex of corporate jet shoppers for years. Now, prospective buyers of Learjets will be looking for him, too. Paulson and his investment partner, New York-based Forstmann Little & Co., bought Chrysler Corp.'s Gulfstream Aerospace Corp. subsidiary Tuesday for $825 million in cash, and in a separate deal agreed to purchase Learjet Corp. from Integrated Resources Inc. for $60 million. Paulson becomes the main man in corporate aviation with Gulfstream's small and medium-sized jets and the sleek and speedy Learjets. He founded Gulfstream in 1978 and said owning it again ``is like having your baby back.'' New York-based Integrated had been trying to sell Learjet since last August. Integrated filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization Tuesday. For Chrysler, the Gulfstream deal buoyed spirits on the day the company reported its first quarterly loss since 1982. ``If I had a company that really needed its own plane, the G-IV would be right at the top of my list. But if I go out to look at one of those and out of the corner of my eye, I see a fleet of Lears, maybe I buy one of those, too,'' said Charles Brady, an auto analyst with Oppenheimer & Co. in New York who has followed Gulfstream. Brady said Chrysler's sale of Gulfstream, which it bought from Paulson for $637 million in 1985, was a good move given Chrysler's current concentration on building cars and trucks. Chrysler still wants to sell Electrospace Systems and Airborne Systems, the other two pieces of Chrysler Technologies Corp. Gulfstream, the biggest piece of Chrysler Technologies, was carrying its weight, showing at least a year's backlog of orders for the planes it makes at three plants in Georgia, Oklahoma and California. Savannah, Ga.-based Gulfstream employs about 5,000 workers. ``I took the crown jewels out of Chrysler Technologies,'' Paulson said Tuesday during a news conference in Savannah. Paulson said he thinks Gulfstream can be more efficient on its own. Chrysler's board of directors voted down Paulson's suggestion last year to make an offer for Wichita-based Learjet. Ronald Glantz, an auto industry analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in San Francisco said the story going around when Chrysler bought Gulfstream was that Chairman Lee Iacocca, prohibited by the federal government from having a corporate jet during the years when Chrysler was recovering from its near bankruptcy, proved the company's recovery was complete by buying a jet-maker instead of a single jet. Government loan guarantees helped Chrysler survive in the early 1980s. Learjet is competing for a U.S. Air Force contract worth more than $1 billion to produce more than 200 Tanker Transport Trainer system aircraft to be used by New York-based Flight Safety International Inc. Flight Safety has a facility adjacent to the Savannah plant where Gulfstream customers' pilots and service representatives are trained. ``We in Savannah could do a lot for the Learjet product,'' Paulson said. Paulson said it was too early to discuss details of the union between Gulfstream and Learjet, but consolidation of the two company's engineering and sales departments is possible. Paulson also said Gulfstream would not be forced to sell off assets to satisfy the financing of the acquisition.

DOC.HEAD: Maryland Tobacco Growers May End 350-Year-Old Tobacco-Tying Tradition
DOC.TEXT: Maryland tobacco growers may soon end a centuries old tradition of hand-tying ``hands'' of tobacco leaves, opting instead for 70-pound bales that could cut labor costs by as much as 30 percent. ``It's the first major change in the form of marketing tobacco in more than 350 years,'' said Claude McKee, director of the University of Maryland's experimental tobacco farm near Upper Marlboro. The state Department of Agriculture has announced that at least two major buyers have agreed to purchase Maryland tobacco that is baled, and a third has given informal approval. McKee said he approached tobacco companies with the proposal and has received written agreements from Phillip Morris Cos. Inc. and Universal Leaf Tobacco Co. Traditionally, workers have spent the fall and winter months preparing for the spring auction by tying bundles of 25 to 30 leaves of similar quality into a fan-shaped hand using the stem of one leaf. Bales of tobacco measure three feet by two feet by one foot and weigh about 70 pounds. McKee said buyers have expressed a desire to have uniform bales throughout the industry. ``It would be a change from an antiquated way, and it could put more money in the farmer's pocket,'' said Maryland Agriculture Secretary Wayne Cawley. Whether the change occurs, however, depends on if buyers will pay as much for baled tobacco as they do for hand-tied tobacco, Cawley said. Cawley said an effort to change to bales three years ago failed because buyers at auctions declined to pay as much for baled tobacco. Baling was first used in the burley tobacco region, Kentucky, Tennessee, West Virginia, North Carolina and Missouri, about 10 years ago and almost all burley tobacco is now baled. ``My feeling is that the ground has been broken,'' McKee said. ``One or two will lead the way, and the rest will follow. It could be a big breakthrough, a real labor-saver.''

DOC.HEAD: Rhone-Poulenc to Restart MIC Production
DOC.TEXT: With new emergency notification rules in effect, a pesticide plant unit was set to resume production two weeks after leaking the same poisonous gas that killed 3,500 people in Bhopal, India. A Feb. 2 leak of methyl isocyanate at the Rhone-Poulenc plant went unreported for three days and prompted Kanawha County officials to demand strict notice requirements. ``I think we're going to have a lot of dialogue between communities and the plants about what is expected,'' plant manager Ron Bearer said Tuesday. ``That's one of the good things that are going to come out of this.'' The unit was shut down for routine maintenance Jan. 31. Two days later, it leaked ``a small puff'' of MIC that injured seven construction workers nearby, plant officials said. News of the leak was made public three days later. Bearer said production of MIC would resume today. The leak prompted changes in how and when Rhone-Poulenc will notify local emergency officials about poisonous gas leaks. The company now intends to announce all leaks of acutely toxic material, no matter how small, despite federal regulations that require notification only if a pound or more of material escapes. ``We're still working through the agencies about exactly what that does mean,'' Bearer said. ``One molecule is not what they want. We're literally treating it as any kind of release at all.'' Bearer also said he didn't believe the strict reporting requirements had to be adopted by other Rhone-Poulenc plants or other plants in West Virginia's ``Chemical Valley.'' ``I think this is related specifically to the fact that we handle MIC,'' Bearer said. ``We're just going to include other (toxic) materials.'' Rhone-Poulenc officials met again Monday with Kanawha County emergency workers to discuss the new plant procedures in notification and maintenance. ``I think they did a genuine review and they looked at problems they had and they addressed them,'' County Manager Ron Gregory said. The leak occurred when workers released a vacuum in the MIC unit to free a stuck pipe. When the pipe was opened, a small amount of MIC escaped. Under Rhone-Poulenc's new system, pressures and vacuums will be kept on the unit so the chemical can be forced out. Also, employees will work on only one piece of major equipment at a time. Estella Chandler, who has lived in Institute for 25 years and was a co-founder of People Concerned About MIC, questioned the honesty and intentions of Rhone-Poulenc and the two dozen other chemical plants nearby. ``It's business as usual, but we will continue to protest the presence of hazardous materials and do what we can to protect ourselves,'' Chandler said. In December 1984, methyl isocyanate gas leaked from a Union Carbide Corp. MIC unit at Bhopal and killed 3,500 people. The Institute plant was the only sister unit to the Bhopal operation. Union Carbide sold that part of the plant to Rhone-Poulenc in 1986, a year after a leak of another pesticide ingredient sickened 135 people in Institute.

DOC.HEAD: Drexel Defers Payments, Central Bank Watching, Markets Nervous
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Trading Ltd. said Wednesday it was deferring foreign currency and precious metals payments for one business day in the wake of the bankruptcy filing by its New York-based parent. A statement issued by Drexel's London office said the move was to ensure that its trading partners didn't call for payments which Drexel might not be in an immediate position to meet. ``It is anticipated that the settlement cycle will begin again with the payment of U.S. dollars for value Feb. 14 in New York, and the firm intends to settle transactions for value Feb. 14 and Feb. 15 by Feb. 15,'' Drexel said. The move was made with the approval of the Bank of England. The British central bank confirmed it was aware of the deferments and that it was watching developments in the Drexel case. It said it was, as in all cases, primarily concerned with monitoring capital adequacy. The foreign exchange, stock and metals markets were nervous Wednesday morning, but the markets' reaction to the Drexel filing under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Act was relatively subdued and there was no major sell-off. Foreign exchange dealers said the Drexel news didn't have any immediate impact on the dollar but the uncertainty surrounding the firm's future and the U.S. financial scene could limit the dollar's upside potential. The dollar was trading at $1.6928 against the British pound in London late Wednesday morning, compared with $1.6907 late Tuesday. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 17.3 points, or 0.8 percent at 2,310.5 at 11 a.m. in London. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $416 at midmorning Wednesday, down from $418.65 bid late Tuesday. ``It is obviously not good for confidence in U.S. investment as a whole,'' said Geoffrey Dennis, senior international economist at the London investment firm James Capel & Co. But he added: ``There is not much risk of systemic failure because of the Drexel bankruptcy.'' Bob Semple, a market strategist for County Natwest Securities, said: ``People shrugged off Drexel a bit too easily. You don't know where the ripples will stop.'' The head of foreign exchange at another British bank, who didn't want to be identified, said: ``It all depends on how it develops and whether the U.S. Fed has to help. Maybe, we haven't seen the full effect of Drexel yet.'' Some dealers described Drexel's trading in the currency markets as sizeable. But the firm's position was damaged as far back as the October 1987 stock market crash and the subsequent problems in the junk bond market, other said, so the impact of Drexel's Wednesday announcement was limited. But Drexel's decision to defer payments for one day likely will add to the firm's problems and the whole affair could raise questions about the credit worthiness of other U.S. investment banks, dealers said. ``The flight to quality will leave (Drexel) gasping for breath,'' said the head of foreign exchange at a British bank, who ask not to be identified, said. ``Would you want to give them credit after this?'' Drexel is one of the 13 market makers in the London gold bullion market and although it isn't certain whether the firm will pull out at this stage the announcement likely will damage its reputation, dealers said. However, other firms have pulled out as market markers in the past so this wouldn't in itself have any impact on the gold market.

DOC.HEAD: Airline Posts 39.4-Percent Profit Gain
DOC.TEXT: British Airways PLC on Wednesday reported after-tax profits jumped 39 percent in its third quarter partly because of buoyant traffic growth, lower in pension contributions and aircraft sales that more than offset rising fuel costs. British Airways said its after-tax profit in the three months ended Dec. 31 totaled $78 million, or the equivalent of 11 cents a share, compared with $56 million, or 88 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Pre-tax profit also rose 39 percent to $121 million from $87 million. This included an unspecified one-time gain from the sale of two aircraft, the airline said. Sales rose 13 percent $2.02 billion from $1.8 billion. For the first nine months of its fiscal year, after-tax profit rose 21 percent to $364 million, or 50 cents a share, from $301 million, or 42 cents a share in the year-ago period, British Airways said. Pre-tax profit jumped 21 percent $561 million from $464 million, while sales rose 14 percent to $6.3 billion from $5.6 billion. The airline said its costs rose 9 percent in the third quarter and 14 percent in the nine months because of a 48 percent jump in its third-quarter fuel bill. But passenger traffic rose 6.7 percent in the latest three months, it said. Scheduled traffic remains buoyant, and capacity in the summer season is expected to rise 20 percent, said British Airways Chairman Lord King. Prospects for the next financial year, however, depend on continued worldwide economic growth, he added.

DOC.HEAD: GBL Managers Recommend Write-Off of Drexel Stake
DOC.TEXT: Groupe Bruxelles Lambert SA managers today proposed that the Belgian holding company write off its stake in the U.S. securities firm Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Drexel's parent company filed for protection from creditors under U.S. bankruptcy law late Tuesday. In a statement, the company said its managing directors ``consider that it is prudent'' to propose to the board of directors ``a total write-off'' of the Drexel stake. GBL has an effective 26-percent stake in Drexel Burnham. The statement added that GBL had no commitment to Drexel other than the stock holding. The statement said that the write-off would reduce GBL's group profit in 1989 to about 4.1 billion francs, or $117 million, a fall of 29 percent from 5.8 billion francs, or $166 million, in 1988. GBL said that without the loss of the Drexel Burnham Lambert stake its net profit would have risen to about 7.5 billion francs, or $214 million. Trading in GBL stock, which had been suspended earlier today, resumed after the announcement was made. The stock fell to the equivalent of $112 from Tuesday's close of $116. GBL is Belgium's second largest holding company. Its other main portfolio holdings comprise large minority stakes in Petrofina SA, a Belgian oil company, Banque Bruxelles Lambert, Belgium's second largest commercial bank, and Royale Belge SA, Belgium's second largest insurance company.

DOC.HEAD: Toshiba Develops 4-Megabit SRAM
DOC.TEXT: Toshiba Corp. has developed a prototype of a 4-megabit static random access memory chip, company officials said Wednesday. Toshiba said the new 4-megabit SRAM is the first to use thin-film transistors as memory cells, a technology that reduces power consumption. SRAM chips are more complex than the more common dynamic random access memory chips, which are already available in 4-megabit capacity. SRAM chips generally use less power than DRAMs and do not need special ``refresh'' circuits to retain their information, making them well-suited to battery-powered equipment like lap-top computers. However, the larger number of transistors used by SRAMs make them harder to design and manufacture than DRAMs with the same memory capacity. Toshiba said the new chip has the same circuit density as 16-megabit DRAMs, which are expected to be the next generation of memory chips. On Tuesday, IBM said it has begun producing 16-megabit DRAMs on a trial basis, but said commercial production could be at least 18 months away. A Toshiba official said his company does not know when the 4-megabit SRAM will go into commercial production. Currently, the largest commercially available SRAM is 1 megabit. A 4-megabit memory chip can store about 4 million binary units of information, or the equivalent of about 16 newspaper pages.

DOC.HEAD: VMS Realty Halts Payments to Lenders, Funds
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Restores dropped letter in byline and SUBS 5th graf pvs, `The statement ...' to UPDATE with comment from VMS president; picks up 6th graf pvs, `Experts said ...'
DOC.TEXT: A decision by VMS Realty Partners, one of the nation's largest real estate companies, to suspend most payments to creditors and investors has been a long time coming, one industry expert says. ``To those of us who have followed this company closely, this is a little bit anticlimatic,'' said Barry Vinocur, editor in chief of Stanger Publications, a division of the investment research firm Robert A. Stanger & Co. ``Most people expected that the day of reckoning was going to come at VMS,'' Vinocur said. ``It was just a question of when it would arrive.'' Chicago-based VMS said Tuesday it had suspended ``non-essential'' payments to lenders and to its eight publicly owned mortgage-investment funds, citing ``severe cash flow problems.'' ``This presents the best option for preserving the value in the firm and all of its investors,'' said VMS President Jeffrey Park. He declined to comment further and the company statement did not elaborate. Experts said the development signals the seriousness of VMS' financial woes and reflects the decline of highly leveraged real-estate syndication, which provided tax-sheltered investment opportunities until the 1986 Tax Reform Act canceled the tax breaks. The partnership manages assets of more than $9 billion, including such high-profile properties as the Boca Raton Hotel and Club in Boca Raton, Fla., the Four Seasons Biltmore in Santa Barbara, Calif., the Grand Teton Lodge in Grand Teton National Park and the Westin Maui hotel in Hawaii. Tuesday's development follows a management shakeup in November that put Jeffrey J. Park, a former Xerox executive, in charge of VMS. A Xerox subsidiary, Xerox Credit Corp., owns 25 percent of VMS. At the time of the management change, VMS announced a $110 million writeoff that analysts said reflected the softening real-estate market, the declining popularity of real-estate investment trusts and the folly of VMS' heavy borrowing and interlocking business relationships among its funding operations, real-estate ventures and service companies. Critics say its business practices made the entire structure vulnerable to the financial difficulties of VMS. The Wall Street Journal reported Feb. 1 that from 1981 to 1989, VMS raised $2.6 billion in equity from 110,000 outside investors in 100 real-estate limited partners and the eight publicly traded real-estate investment trusts. The Journal reported that VMS had given back about $500 million through various distributions but that the fate of the remaining $2.1 billion was uncertain. Vinocur said VMS typically would use the money raised by the funds to obtain even bigger loans for real-estate acquisition or development. But the income from many VMS properties have failed to match expectations, making it difficult to meet loan payments, analysts said. Shareholders in some of VMS' trusts have filed lawsuits in U.S. District Court in Chicago accusing VMS and its owners of fraud and extensive conflicts of interest. VMS has said it will vigorously defend the charges. Vinocur said Tuesday's announcement may indicate that Xerox has taken charge of the situation after replacing former VMS Chairman Peter R. Morris with Park. Xerox Credit Corp. said its 25 percent equity in VMS has a book value of $106 million. Xerox Credit also said its interest in VMS includes three debt components: $136 million in subordinated notes and accrued interest, $125 million advanced to VMS through a line of credit, and $200 million in collateralized loans and other secured financing arrangements. B. Alex Henderson, an analyst who follows Xerox for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said VMS does not account for a meaningful amount of Xerox's operating profit.

DOC.HEAD: Hanson Posts 12.8 Percent Profit Gain
DOC.TEXT: British conglomerate Hanson PLC said Wednesday its fiscal first-quarter profit rose 12.8 percent from a year earlier despite a 5.7 percent decline in revenue. Hanson said net profit in the three months ended Dec. 31 came to the equivalent of $600 million compared with $532 million in the same quarter in the prior year. Revenue fell to $3.1 billion from $3.3 billion. Hanson said it had extraordinary income of $309 million from asset sales, compared with $281 million a year ago. Earnings per share came to 6.6 cents vs. 5.95 cents. Hanson said it plans to sell its 70 percent interest in Mount Goldsworthy Mining Associates in Western Australia. The disposal follows a series of sales by Hanson of assets from Consolidated Gold Fields PLC, which it acquired last year for $5.6 billion. Lord Hanson said in the brief statement that the results were ``a good start to the year, with our financial strength further increased.'' Sir Gordon White, chairman of Hanson Industries Inc. said the U.S. unit ``continues to perform well.'' The company didn't discuss the performances of its component parts.

DOC.HEAD: Bonn Offers New Aid to East Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to CLARIFY that the aid will be used for recovery projects, not East Germany's day-to-day expenses. Pickup 8th, `The real...' This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: East German Premier Hans Modrow, who is expected to be ousted in coming elections, ended his summit in Bonn today with promises of major West German investment but no immediate cash to bail out his economy. Modrow and Chancellor Helmut Kohl also agreed to begin talks on eventually making the West German mark the official currency of East Germany. But Modrow's brief summit was overshadowed by an agreement between the four World War II allies on eventual reunification of the Germanys. The Germanys, France, Britain, the United States and the Soviet Union agreed in Ottawa on Tuesday to hold talks leading to reunification. The hard details on merging the Germanys politically and economically, however, are not expected to be tackled until after East Germany holds its first free elections on March 18. Bonn on Tuesday rejected Modrow's request for $9 billion to bolster the failing East German economy until the elections, when Modrow's government is likely to be thrown out. But today, West German Finance Minister Theo Waigel announced that the government had agreed during a Cabinet meeting to add nearly $4.2 billion to this year's budget to finance recovery projects in East Germany. Those funds are earmarked for capital investments proposed earlier and will not be made available for tiding over the East Berlin government's day-to-day expenses, as Modrow had sought. The real news on Germany unity came in the Canadian capital, where Warsaw Pact and NATO nations were meeting to discuss allowing surveillance flights. Behind the scenes, the four World War II allies that divided Germany _ the Soviets, the United States, France and Britain _ were hammering out a method for negotiating reunification. The accord calls for two sets of talks, the first involving the Germanys, during which they are to work out economic and other domestic considerations for reunification. The announcement in Bonn of currency talks appears to have been timed to coincide with the Ottawa agreement. The second talks would involve the Germanys and the four allies that divided the country after defeating Nazi Germany, and which still technically occupy Berlin. Those talks are to deal with the critical issue of military alliances _ East Germany is a key strategic component of the Warsaw Pact and West Germany fills the same role for NATO. The Soviets want a neutral united Germany, while Washington insists on continued NATO membership. The agreement is partially the result of the perceived impending collapse of the economy in East Germany. Kohl claimed on Tuesday that more that 85,000 East Germans have fled to the West in the past six weeks. Modrow's provisional government, a conglomeration of pro-reform Communists and former opposition figures that came to power when mass protests toppled the hard-line government of Stalinist Erich Honecker last year, appears doomed in the March 18 elections. As a result, Kohl has avoided making substantial deals with the Modrow government until a new one is elected. Modrow met today with the head of the Association of German Industry, Tyll Necker, who said neither aid nor massive Western investment were advisable yet because East Germany's laws remain ``too restrictive.'' Several of the East German Cabinet members who accompanied Modrow to the talks said the delegation was disappointed with the Bonn meetings. Mathias Platzek of the East German Greens Party, a minister without portfolio in Modrow's interim coalition, told reporters that the West German hosts dealt with them ``somewhat schoolmasterly.''
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 426.91 up 1.16 from the previous day's close.

The stock market headed higher today, showing few ill effects from the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 11.71 to 2,635.81 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 5 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 718 up, 464 down and 524 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 50.02 million shares at midmorning. Stock prices turned in a mixed showing Tuesday as Drexel, which rose to prominence in the 1980s as the champion of ``junk bond'' finance, moved to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and liquidate. The firm's demise left many questions unanswered about the outlook for the high-yield bond market and the possible effect of pervasive debt problems on the economy as a whole. But analysts said the markets took the news as no great surprise, given the much-publicized weakening that has been going on for months in enthusiasm for junk bonds and other ``leverage'' investments. Some Wall Streeters believe the waning of ``junk'' debt might set the stage for a revival of traditional financial values that could put the stock and bond markets on a sounder long-term footing. Gainers among the blue chips included Chevron, up 1\ at 69|; Philip Morris, up { at 39\; American Telephone & Telegraph, up \ at 40\, and International Business Machines, up } at 104. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .84 to 183.69. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .41 at 358.86.

DOC.HEAD: Great Northern Seeks Other Buyers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE Georgia-Pacific going to court, SUBS prvs grafs 3 and 9.
DOC.TEXT: Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. isn't giving up the fight against a hostile takeover bid from Georgia-Pacific Corp., but it is ready to concede its independence. The Norwalk, Conn.-based paper-products company, which has been fighting Georgia-Pacific's $3.8 billion offer for more than three months, said Tuesday that several recent setbacks have led it to consider a merger, although it wants a higher price than Georgia-Pacific's $63-a-share bid. Georgia-Pacific went to court in Portland, Maine, this morning to mount a challenge to some of Great Northern's latest moves. The company faces a showdown at a March shareholders meeting at which Georgia-Pacific is seeking to have the company's directors replaced with its own candidates, who would allow the merger to go through. Stephen M. Hill, Great Northern's director of investor relations, said ``it certainly was a possibility'' shareholders would back Georgia-Pacific. Great Northern's directors on Tuesday postponed the shareholder meeting to March 20 from March 2 to give shareholders time to consider other possible offers. Great Northern also said it had directed its financial adviser, Goldman Sachs & Co., to contact qualified buyers and seek bids higher than $63 a share. Georgia-Pacific spokeswoman Gail Smith, reached in Atlanta this morning, said her company had gotten no information beyond Great Northern's announcement Tuesday evening. ``Based on the information in Great Northern Nekoosa Corp.'s press release, our view is that Great Northern's attempt to postpone the March 2 shareholder meeting and to amend its poison pill are unlawful and ignore the interests of shareholders,'' Georgia-Pacific said in a statement. ``We intend to seek appropriate relief.'' Georgia-Pacific attorneys filed papers in U.S. District Court in Portland this morning, asking Judge Gene Carter to stop Great Northern from delaying the March 2 meeting, Ms. Smith said. The court clerk's office said a filing had been made by Georgia-Pacific, but it had not yet been processed and made available to the public by late morning. Georgia-Pacific has said in the past that all terms of its tender offer were negotiable. Great Northern's announcement follows several setbacks in its efforts to remain independent. Earlier in the week, Georgia-Pacific announced it was selling off some of its paper operations to avoid antitrust questions that could impede the merger. Great Northern had raised the antitrust issues in a federal lawsuit in Connecticut that it considered its first line of defense in the takeover battle. In addition, a federal judge in Maine has struck down various provisions in Great Northern's bylaws that would have made the takeover more difficult. Great Northern said the accumulation of events led its board of directors to seek other potential buyers. ``The board believes that it is in the best position to conduct an orderly, active and effective exploration of all financial alternatives, designed to culminate in the highest possible per share value for shareowners,'' said Great Northern chairman William R. Laidig. ``We believe that a price of $63 per share is certainly achievable.'' Great Northern stock closed at $62, up 50 cents, in New York Stock Exchange trading Tuesday. The company's announcement was made after the market closed. Georgia-Pacific, an Atlanta-based forest products company, proposed buying Great Northern last year in a move that would create the largest company in the industry with $14 billion in annual sales. Great Northern has fought the bid vigorously, saying the price is too low and illegal on antitrust grounds. A federal judge in Bridgeport, Conn., is hearing testimony on whether the new company would have a stranglehold on linerboard, check paper and certain pulpwood markets, as Great Northern alleges in its antitrust suit. The company also has criticized Georgia-Pacific harshly for making the bid, saying it's trying to beef up its financial health and operating efficiency at the expense of Great Northern shareholders. ``We still felt that was the case,'' Hill said. ``But we're at a point in time where it's appropriate to (seek other buyers) to assure getting the best value for the shareholders.'' Hill would not comment on possible buyers. ``It's getting into fairly high finance, so there aren't that many players,'' he said. After Georgia-Pacific, the largest forest products companies are Weyerhauser Inc. and International Paper Co., according to testimony from Georgia-Pacific chairman T. Marshall Hahn Jr. in Bridgeport. When asked what price the company was seeking, Hill said, ``The best one possible with a qualified buyer, somebody with money to pay.''

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Down Slightly On Winter Storm, Slow Demand
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were slightly lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting slack demand and good prospects for significant precipitation in the Corn Belt. Wheat futures dropped more than a penny a bushel at the opening, continuing Tuesday's slide, as traders awaited news of significant new export sales. Japan and Egypt were reported to have bought some U.S. wheat overnight, but traders did not consider the amounts to be significant. In the soybean market, a combination of fundamental and technical factors kept pressure on prices. On the fundamental side, the European soybean market was weaker today and a winter storm was expected to spread beneficial moisture today and Thursday through much of the Midwest, where the majority of soybeans are grown. On the technical side, the March soybean contract dipped below Tuesday's low of $5.63{ early in the session, which analysts said could spur further selling. In early trading, wheat futures were 1\ cents to 1} cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $3.84 a bushel; corn futures were unchanged to { cent lower with March at $2.41\ a bushel; oats were \ cent to 1 cent lower with March at $1.39\ a bushel; soybeans were } cent lower to \ cent higher with March at $5.63} a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle futures were .05 cent lower to .05 cent higher with February at 79.52 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent lower to .07 cent higher with March at 82.05 cents a pound; live hogs were .02 cent lower to .20 cent higher with February at 49.97 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .20 cent lower to .48 cent higher with February at 49.70 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled mixed on Tuesday.

DOC.NOTE: $adv15
For Release PMs Thursday, Feb. 15
DOC.HEAD: Financial Debacles: They Happen All The Time
DOC.TEXT: The amazing thing about almost all financial debacles is that those involved know better but allow their negative feelings to be overcome by the lure of big profits. It happens regularly. When bankers clamped down on home mortgage loans in the 1970s because, they said, such loans could be risky, they lent hundreds of millions of dollars to less developed nations in order to obtain premium interest rates from then. It was well known at the time that the loans were hazardous and might not be repaid. Banker magazines warned of the practice and even the general media carried interviews with analysts who accurately forecast what would happen. Still, the chairman of one of the nation's largest banks repeatedly scorned the warnings, suggesting the writers were uninformed. These loans, he said, are backed by the full faith and credit of governments; they're secure, he said. It happened in Texas real estate, and later in New England. Everybody in the building and real estate knows from experience that their occupation is cyclical. Everyone in banking should know that the economy as a whole is cyclical, that it expands and contracts repeatedly. It didn't stop them. Builders built and lenders lent, and each one thought they would be the exception. As if the gods were watching over them, they gambled that they would close their deals before the downturn began. The serious problem with that thinking is that the line is never drawn, and each lender and builder tries just one more time. They might be forgiven for not anticipating a sudden disaster such as a collapse of oil prices, but they certainly had to know that in the natural cycle of events building booms come to an end, often abruptly. Moreover, a boom exaggerated by excessive lending is almost guaranteed to blow up. Nothing new in that; they've all seen it before. It happened with the savings and loan associations. While managers of some S&Ls seemed not to know what they were doing, since deregulation of financial institutions had opened up brand new lending (investing) opportunities for them, seasoned managers understood very well. They understood risk and they understood high investment returns. Knowing that their practices couldn't continue forever, they nevertheless felt they could cash in on a good thing just one more time. Soon they couldn't get out. Among the many problems that worsens greed is secrecy. No lender wanted another to know that they were going to take just one more risk, finance just one more building _ and then get out. So they all took one more risk. As a result, the nation suddenly had more office space, more industrial space, more housing than it needed, and all those beautiful projections that looked so good on paper were seen for what they were: Unsubstantiated hopes. Now we have junk bonds, or high-yield credit instruments designed to finance the very riskiest of enterprises, such as takeovers. Those who developed the idea knew the risks were great, but what is risk, they asked, but the other side of the coin? Doesn't everyone know that reward is in direct ratio to the risk assumed? Junk bonds were bought by the most highly educated and supposedly savvy portfolio managers, those who guided the affairs of foundations, mutual and pension funds, university endowments and the like. The lure overcame them. In none of these instances was the collapse general, although it was total in specific, individual instances. Some investors have indeed benefited _ the reward for assuming high risk _ and in the future others will. While the lure of big money is likely to produce future financial devices of the same sort, others probably will learn a lesson. Many banks, for example, are re-examining standards on home equity loans, known less euphemistically as second mortgages. Those loans have proliferated in recent years. An economic decline could put some of them in foreclosure. One tipoff is that some bank customers are working two jobs just to pay the interest. A warning sign.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Thursday, Feb. 15.

DOC.HEAD: Indicted Trader Told FBI Merc Corruption Was Widespread
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf: ``Bailin and ... March 8,'' to CORRECT trial date to May 21; picks up 8th graf: ``An exchange...
DOC.TEXT: An indicted yen trader told the FBI that corruption was widespread at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, and that the open outcry system was dominated by crooked brokers, according to recently filed court documents. Robert H. Bailin, one of 48 people indicted in the federal probe of the nation's largest commodities exchanges, also contended that many traders are forced to make cash kickbacks ``to the big guys upstairs.'' He was referring to commodity brokers who accept customer orders and phone them to floor brokers for execution. Bailin, 37, made the statements during interviews with two FBI agents in January 1989, six months before he and 20 other Japanese yen traders were indicted. But his attorney, Terence P. Gillespie, noted that Bailin has pleaded innocent and said he plans to contest the government's version of the interviews at trial, the Chicago Tribune reported in today's editions. Transcripts of the interviews were attached to a pretrial document recently filed by prosecutors. Bailin and 15 others who have pleaded innocent are scheduled to go to trial May 21, according to a clerk for the U.S. district judge in the case, William T. Hart. An exchange spokesman said the Merc would investigate Bailin's claims. The transcripts indicate Bailin told the FBI that he recalled a day in which $1 million in pork bellies futures contracts were bought and sold outside of the Merc's trading pit. ``The open outcry system does not work at the Merc,'' he told the agents, contending that the system was dominated by a small group of powerful brokers who refused to deal with honest traders. He said more than a dozen undicted yen brokers forced him to accept losses they had incurred through their own trading errors. During court hearings two weeks ago, Bailin and two other indicted yen traders told U.S. District Judge William Hart that they gave the interviews partly because agents and prosecutors had tricked them. Bailin denied any wrongdoing.

DOC.HEAD: Daniels Sells 49 Percent to 9 Executives
DOC.TEXT: Cable television mogul Bill Daniels plans to sell nearly half of his cable brokerage firm, Daniels and Associates, to nine of the company's executives. Daniels, 69, will sell 49 percent of the firm, leaving him a majority owner with 51 percent, said senior vice president of marketing Bob Russo on Tuesday. The move is part of Daniels' plan to give himself more time for other business and philanthropic interests, Russo said. ``He has been putting in place a management group ... that gives him the opportunity to focus in other areas and still remain confident his company is going in a direction that he wants to see,'' said Russo. Daniels is credited with being one of the founders of the cable television industry and has continued to take a high-profile role in its growth. Last year, Daniels and Associates brokered 100 cable and mobile communications transactions worth $5.7 billion, and Daniels wants to ensure it retains the preeminent financial services role, Russo said. ``Daniels has always espoused the idea that it's the boss who's beholden to the employees and not the other way around,'' said a representative of Paul Kagan Associates, a California cable TV analysis firm. ``It sounds like something that would be very much in line with his corporate management policies.'' Russo, one of the new minority partners, said the sale also indicates a ``distinct transition to more of a management committee direction as opposed to Bill's dynamic and very singular leadership.'' The deal should be completed by March, Russo said.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Fourth-Quarter Profits Rise 48 Percent
DOC.TEXT: CBS Inc.'s fourth-quarter profit climbed 48 percent, helped by television advertising gains despite a primetime ratings slump, the company reported Wednesday. For the final three months of 1989, CBS net income rose to $59.5 million or $2.31 a share, from $40.1 million or $1.56 a share in the year-earlier period. Revenue rose 12 percent to $865.8 million from $772.3 million. CBS attributed the gains largely to improved performance at the television network, stemming from higher unit prices for advertising. For the year, CBS earnings tumbled 74 percent to $296.3 million, or $11.51 a share, from $1.15 billion, or $44.75 a share, in 1988 when company earnings were inflated by $866.6 million from the sale of CBS Records to Sony Corp. Excluding the sales gains, CBS after-tax income from continuing operations rose 5 percent in 1989 to $297.1 million, or $11.54 a share, vs. $283.4 million, or $11.02 a share, in 1988. Revenue for the year totaled $2.96 billion, up 7 percent from $2.78 billion. CBS President and Chief Executive Officer Laurence A. Tisch said the gains reflected improved network television earnings ``and an almost steady level of interest income.'' Corporate interest income totaled $180.7 million in 1989, down 2 percent from 1988. ``For the year, the CBS Television Network reported higher profits due to renewed advertising demand and continued attention to costs, despite disappointing primetime ratings,'' Tisch said. CBS said it spent a substantial amount of money to buy television and radion stations, entertainment programs and sports rights and to retire long-term debt. ``At the end of 1989, the company's strong balance sheet included cash and marketable securities of $2.8 billion which far exceeded its total debt of $0.8 billion,'' CBS reported.

DOC.HEAD: Times Publishing Trustees Reviewing Bass Offer
DOC.TEXT: Trustees of the Poynter Institute for Media Studies have agreed to meet Friday to further consider an offer by a group of investors to buy the institute's Times Publishing Co. stock. The investor group, which includes Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass, owns a minority share in Times Publishing Co., publisher of the St. Petersburg Times. ``The board has never expressed any interest in selling the stock and is giving it (the offer) serious consideration as required by its responsibilities,'' Andrew Corty, marketing director of The St. Petersburg Times said today. In late January, the group offered $270 million for stock in the Times Holding Co., which is held by the Poynter Institute and controls a majority of the Times Publishing Co. stock. In a meeting Tuesday, the trustees were told by their legal counsel it is proper for them to consider Nelson Poynter's intentions and other factors when assessing the buyout offer. Nelson Poynter, former chairman of the St. Petersburg Times who died in 1978, founded the educational institute in an effort to keep ownership of the newspaper independent. The Bass partnership, in a lawsuit filed last week, charges that its rights as a minority stockholder are being violated by the dividend payment plan established by Poynter. Also Tuesday, the Bass group demanded the suit be heard by a jury. The case has been assigned to U.S. District Judge Elizabeth A. Kovachevich.

DOC.HEAD: Harrods Department Store to Close Fur Salon
DOC.TEXT: Citing a sharp decline in sales, Harrods is closing its fur salon which has sold minks to the rich and famous for nearly a century. The world renowned department store said Wednesday sales have dropped by 40 percent over the last four years, but it denied caving in to pressure from animal rights groups. The salon, whose concession is held by fur retailer Grosvenor Canada, will close on April 21, following a decision 13 months ago by Harrods' parent company, House of Fraser PLC, to end fur sales at its other 62 stores. That announcement followed firebomb attacks on House of Fraser stores, including against shops in Plymouth and Cardiff. According to government figures cited by Harrods, sales by Britain's biggest fur traders totaled the equivalent of about $19 million in the first half of 1989, compared with $136 million in all of 1984. Harrods said it would begin closing the salon with a sale beginning Friday at prices slashed by up to 75 percent. But it will not be the last time furs are sold at Harrods, according to spokesman Andrew Wiles. ``There's no doubt we will sell furs again, but not in the same way. It will be in a smaller, more specialized way. There's a chance we might consider selling designer furs,'' Wiles said. Harrods said it will retain its fur cold storage and continue to offer its fur alteration, cleaning and valuation services. Lynx, an anti-fur group, said: ``In less than five years the British public has become aware of the extreme and totally unnecessary cruelty involved in the production of fur coats.''

DOC.HEAD: Talks on Tropical Products Progress After Long Impasse
DOC.TEXT: World trade negotiators agreed on a plan of action Wednesday to liberalize trade in the $100 billion tropical products market, ending months of stalemate. The agreement clears the way for a new accord to reduce import barriers and duties on products such as nuts, coffee and spices to be signed when the current round of General Agreement on Tariff and Trade talks ends in December. Under the plan, each GATT member has to submit proposals for the elimination or reduction of its respective tariffs and non-tariff measures to the Geneva-based secretariat by March 15. Negotiators will then meet in April to discuss whether the various proposals go far enough to meet the GATT-sponsored Uruguay Round's objectives on the ``fullest liberalization'' of trade in tropical products. When the four-year round was launched in Punte del Este in 1986, governments agreed to pay due regard to eliminating duties on unprocessed tropical products, to abolishing or cutting duties on semi-processed and processed products, and eliminating or cutting non-tariff measures such as quotas. As a first step toward these goals, ministers meeting in Montreal in December 1988 agreed on a package of trading concessions to developing countries worth some 20 billion dollars. However, negotiations were subsequently held up by the impasse over an internationally-agreed approach to cutting overall tariffs. A compromise formula was agreed last month, freeing the way for progress in talks on tropical products. Trade officials were also expected to reach agreement Wednesday on a schedule for proposals aimed at cutting non-tariff measures in a wide range of products. A new accord to free trade in tropical products is regarded as vital by Third World countries, many of whom are dependent on export earnings from these commodities. Although tariffs on tropical products are generally low, they are also selective, according to a GATT official who spoke on condition of anonymity. The official cited the example of Colombia, which faces tariffs of about 20 percent on sales of cut flowers, one of its most important exports, to the European Community. Flowers from Israel entering the EC, by contrast, are not subject to duties, he said. GATT is the main international forum for sponsoring trade negotiations. Its 96 members account for about four-fifths of world trade.

DOC.NOTE: $adv14
For Release PMs Wednesday Feb. 14
DOC.HEAD: Do We Live Better Than Before?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To fix typo, SUBS 16th graf.
DOC.TEXT: A little-noted report suggests that more Americans are working at two jobs now than at any time in decades, perhaps since the 1940s, when there was a war-induced labor shortage. The report, from the Labor Department, shows dual jobs to be a growing trend. In 1980, 4.9 percent of employed people held two jobs. The percentage rose to 5.4 in 1985. And in 1989, it continued on to 6.2 percent. Simultaneously over the past decade, there has been a tendency of women to put in more hours at ``official'' rather than family jobs and for older workers to supplement pensions by working at retail outlets. Marriages are occurring later than before, and there is a similar tendency to postpone children until later in life. And to afford a home under present conditions often if not usually requires the bounty of two incomes. Still, in many areas of the country the financing and upkeep of the home takes a larger percentage of household income than it used to, up to 50 percent in certain instances, or double what used to be considered affordable. Question: Is this really the good life that was promised? Is this progress? In spite of so-called affluence, fom the Labor Department, shows dual jobs to be a growing trend. In 1980, 4.9 percent of employed people held two jobs. The percentage rose to 5.4 in 1985. And in 1989, it continued on to 6.2 percent. Simultaneously over the past decade, there has been a tendency of women to put in more hours at ``official'' rather than family jobs and for older workers to supplement pensions by working at retail outlets. Marriages are occurring later than before, and there is a similar tendency to postpone children until later in life. And to afford a home under present conditions often if not usually requires the bounty of two incomes. Still, in many areas of the country the financing and upkeep of the home takes a larger percentage of household income than it used to, up to 50 percent in certain instances, or double what used to be considered affordable. Question: Is this really the good life that was promised? Is this progress? In spite of so-called affluence, for example, debt is increasing. And that same Labor Department survey shows that 44 percent of those working an extra job are doing so to meet household expenses and to pay debts. Consider this: While more women than ever are working, well over 50 percent of them, they earn less than men and advance more slowly. And surveys show they still haven't shed most of their household chores. Questions about progress arise in other areas too. The national debt is greater than ever. Productivity increases have slowed. For the first time since the Great Depression of the 1930s, the percentage of homeowners is shrinking. Success in the fight against proverty has slowed. Herbert Hoover in 1928 said the country was ``nearer to the final triumph over poverty than ever before in the history of any land.'' Today, one in seven live in ``poverty.'' Progress? Consider these facts, taken from a study by the U.S. Census Bureau and the Conference Board, a private, not-for-profit educational and research group: Since 1900, life expectancy has risen from under 50 years to more than 75 years. Infant mortality has fallen from 99 per 1,000 births in 1915 to about 11 today. Average weekly hours in manufacturing declined to 40.5 hours in 1985 from 49.4 hours in 1915, while real hourly wages rose from $2.44 to $9.53. Comparable net worth figures weren't available for earlier years of the century, but in 1950 per capita net assets were $27,021, half those of 1985. And the relative costs of food, clothing and shelter have declined steadily. More houses have indoor plumbing and central heating systems. And each year those houses seem to have more baths, swimming pools, decks, family rooms, telephones, radios, TVs, electric toasters, computers and smoke alarms. Vacation time has risen. Leisure has become a big business, and activities that once were the exclusive preserve of the elite, such as golf, tennis, sailing and skiing, are growth industries. ``More money, more leisure and the pursuit of fun and travel have enormously enriched the way we live,'' says the report. What do you think?
DOC.NOTE: End Adv AMs Thursday Feb. 15

DOC.HEAD: Stocks End Slightly Higher
DOC.TEXT: Stocks finished slightly higher after a lackluster session on London's Stock Exchange Wednesday, as investors found little reason to buy. Dealers said the market appeared to be treading water, in anticipation of a barrage of British economic data and corporate earnings reports due to be released later in the week.
