Tuesday's news that Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. filed for protection under U.S. bankruptcy law still overshadowed the market, dealers said. ``Any rise in the market will be short-lived,'' said the head of equities at a London firm. ``There's far too much concern on (the prospect for higher) interest rates and the possibility that New York will fall out of bed, sooner or later, over this Drexel thing.'' Although Wall Street got off to a healthy start, London traders said there wasn't any discernible leadership coming from New York. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 5.1 points, or 0.2 percent, at 2,298.3. The Financial Times 30-share index was up 4.3 points at 1,822.4. The Financial Times 500-share index rose 2.67 points to close at 1,253.05. Volume amounted to a modest 465.2 million shares, compared with 436.4 million shares Tuesday.

For release Sunday Feb. 18
DOC.HEAD: Anheuser-Busch, Miller Jump Into `Near-Beer' Market
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: They used to call it near beer. It had a small market _ pimply kids looking for a way to emulate grownups. It's become big business. No-alcohol beer, it is called, thank you. The world's top two brewers, in an insatiable quest for customers, are leading the charge. Anheuser-Busch Inc. has rolled out O'Doul's Non-Alcoholic Brew and Miller Brewing Co. has launched Sharp's to stimulate a long-ignored segment of the market. The brews _ legally, the companies cannot refer to them as beer _ have less than a half-percent alcohol content. Will this stuff sell? One beer industry analyst, Bob Weinberg of R.S. Weinberg & Associates in St. Louis, said he was skeptical, partly because no-alcohol brew tastes, in his words, ``God-awful.'' Weinberg said the industry's Big Two were trying to position no-alcohol brew as a new adult soft drink, but they will have to displace Diet Coke and Diet Pepsi, already well-entrenched _ not to mention better-tasting and less-filling. ``This trend, it makes no sense to me,'' Weinberg said. ``I am baffled, in all honesty. I can't see it.'' Drinking opponents also expressed doubts about no-alcohol beer. They said a concoction that resembles beer won't necessarily dissuade young people from chugging the real thing. Hamilton Beazley, president of the National Council on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence in New York, said no-alcohol beer was likely to confuse alcoholics and could even make children more apt to drink. ``I don't see a happy image on Super Bowl day of a 6- or 7-year-old kid drinking a can of no-alcohol beer while his dad drinks the high-test stuff,'' Beazley said. ``Beer is not just a beverage. This is kind of like candy cigarettes. It's a poor model for kids.'' No-alcohol brew sales haven't been impressive since Anheuser-Busch and Miller got serious about peddling it in recent months. While Anheuser-Busch sold nearly 81 million barrels of beer last year, capturing 42 percent of the market, for example, the number of barrels of no-alcohol beer sold industry-wide was between 700,000 and 1.1 million. Primary markets are Moslem countries where alcohol drinking is banned, and the United States. Nonetheless, company officials claim both O'Doul's and Sharp's are off to fast starts. Bob Merz, group manager for O'Doul's, contended that health-conscious adults, a growing segment of the market, were more apt to reach for a no-alcohol beer than a soft drink or juice in certain circumstances. For instance, Merz said, no-alcohol beer could be the appropriate beverage for the designated driver at a party. Nonetheless, no-alcohol beer seems to be the most risky venture of all the diversification taking place, especially at Anheuser-Busch. The world's leading brewer has gone from Budweiser to Busch to Michelob to light beer to dry beer and several concoctions in between. Counting O'Doul's, its beer stable is now 17 brands strong. That includes a reduced-alcohol beer, called L.A., which has had limited success, selling about 100,000 barrels in 1988. But it was still beer, watered down or not. In the case of O'Doul's, will taste be enough? One of beer's plusses, after all, is its kick. Perception may also pose a problem. None of a group of six drinkers informally polled by the AP liked the taste of O'Doul's when they knew what they were drinking. One said the brew resembled mildly flavored water and another said it was like beer frozen and then thawed. But only two of the six could identify O'Doul's in a blind taste test with two other brands. Both breweries are betting heavily that its projected audience _ the premium beer drinker, primarily male, age 35 and older _ is ready for a no-alcohol beverage. Industry insiders estimate the Anheuser-Busch and Miller have spent more than $10 million each developing non-alcohol products. Similar to Diet Coke, the advertising campaign for O'Doul's stresses that ``the taste will win you over.'' The long-time no-alcohol leader, Kingsbury, a product of G. Heileman Brewing Co., definitely has noticed. ``Everything we've seen and heard is that Miller and Anheuser-Busch are going to be spending very heavily,'' said David Shield, a brand manager for Heileman. ``We've got some things up our sleeves too. We're planning on increasing our activity.'' Though it debuted nationally only two months ago, O'Doul's really has been around for several years. Anheuser-Busch began developing a no-alcohol product in the early 1980s, introducing an incarnation known as LA-X in Savannah, Ga., in 1986. In March of 1989, O'Doul's was released in six southeastern markets. Merz said the taste resembles that of Busch, without the alcohol. Like the brewery's other brands, O'Doul's goes through the same steps _ brewing, aging, fermentation _ before a final cold-filtering step removes the alcohol. Merz said current technology eliminates the heavy, syrupy taste once associated with no-alcohol beers. The brewing process used for Sharp's is a secret at Miller. Generally, the company brews Sharps at a lower temperature, minimizing the development of alcohol, said Tony Sciolla, an associate brand manager. Some beverage industry analysts suggest that no-alcohol beer is the logical next-step in a constantly changing industry. Since Milwaukee-based Miller introduced the wildly successful Miller Lite in 1973, the beer market has exploded with new choices. There are four varieties of Michelob alone, and almost every beer has light and dry companions. Weinberg said 80 percent of Miller's business last year came from beers that did not exist in 1973. Sixty-three percent of Coors' business came from new product lines. Anheuser-Busch, alone from the rest, is decidedly old-line, with only 20 percent of sales coming from new products. Budweiser, Busch and Michelob continue to carry the weight. With that power base, industry analysts say, Anheuser-Busch can afford to take a few chances. The same is true for Miller, No. 2 in sales. ``We wouldn't have gotten involved with no-alcohol beer if we didn't think the opportunity was there,'' said Miller's Sciolla.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Sunday Feb. 18

DOC.TEXT: The stock market pieced together a small gain today, showing few ill effects from the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 1.35 to 2,625.45 by 2 p.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 8 to 7 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 739 up, 649 down and 491 unchanged. Stock prices turned in a mixed showing Tuesday as Drexel, which rose to prominence in the 1980s as the champion of ``junk bond'' finance, moved to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and liquidate. The firm's demise left many questions unanswered about the outlook for the high-yield bond market and the possible effect of pervasive debt problems on the economy as a whole. But analysts said the markets took the news as no great surprise, given the much-publicized weakening that has been going on for months in enthusiasm for junk bonds and other ``leverage'' investments. Some Wall Streeters believe the waning of ``junk'' debt might set the stage for a revival of traditional financial values that could put the stock and bond markets on a sounder long-term footing. Gainers among the blue chips included Chevron, up 1[ at 69{; Philip Morris, up ] at 39[; General Electric, up [ at 62\, and International Business Machines, up | at 103~. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .39 to 183.24. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .15 at 358.60. Volume on the Big Board came to 99.30 million shares with two hours to go.

DOC.HEAD: Perrier Pulled From Shelves Worldwide; Dirty Filter Blamed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with company saying the benzene was naturally occurring but was not screened out due to dirty filter. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The president of Perrier announced today that the company will withdraw its mineral water from worldwide distribution because small amounts of a naturally occurring toxic gas passed through a dirty filter and contaminated some bottles. Gustave Leven told a news conference the company took the step because ``half measures were not possible.'' Traces of benzene have been found in samples of the water in the United States, Canada, the Netherlands and Denmark in recent days. But only part of the production will be withdrawn from the French market after a preliminary ruling by the Health Ministry that it poses no danger to the public, Leven said. The recall will affect 120 additional countries that consume the popular green-bottled water, Perrier officials said, estimating it could cost the company about $35 million. News of the problem caused the company's stock to close today at $248, down $49 from its closing price Friday. Today's announcement by Perrier's president came days after 72 million bottles of Perrier were withdrawn from the U.S. market after benzene was detected there. Benzene, a chemical used in cleaning solvents, entered the water in trace amounts when workers failed to change a pipe filter at Perrier's natural spring at Vergeze in southern France. The water and the natural carbon dioxide gas that makes it bubbly are normally separated underground, then carried up separate pipes to the bottling plant, Perrier Managing Director Frederik Zimmer said. A filter on the gas pipe that removes benzene and other impurities had not been changed in ``several months,'' Zimmer said, malfunctioning and allowing naturally-occuring benzene to seep through. ``We don't know exactly how long the filter had been there, that's the problem,'' said Zimmer. ``It was complete negligence.'' Zimmer ruled out industrial espionage and said disciplinary action had been taken against the workers involved. In the Netherlands, more than a million bottles were recalled, a spokesman for the Dutch importer said earlier today. ``Small traces of the stuff, to the extent of about 10 parts per billion, have been found in several samples,'' that have been tested here in recent days, said Herman Schieffers, managing director of Hero Nederland BV. In Denmark, traces of benzene, were found Tuesday in several Perrier bottles, prompting the importer, Peter Heering, and the distributer, Albani Breweries, to withdraw up to 300,000 bottles, Heering said. ``It was a very, very small portion (of benzene) that was found and there is no danger,'' Heering said today. A Japanese subsidiary said Tuesday that it would withdraw the water from stores because of the contamination found in the United States. Before today, Perrier had said it believed an employee mistakenly used a product containing the cancer-causing chemical to clean grease from one bottling line, whose production was destined only for North America.

DOC.HEAD: Experts: Financial Industry Restructuring To Spark Conservatism
DOC.TEXT: The financial services industry, which reshaped corporate America in the 1980s with high-risk, junk bond financing, is undergoing a restructuring that will lead to more conservative lending policies, experts said at a Conference Board gathering Wednesday. Separately, economists participating in the group's two-day conference on the financial outlook for 1990 generally predicted the U.S. economy would avoid a recession this year, although inflation would rise. The financial difficulties of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., whose parent filed for bankruptcy court protection on Tuesday, illustrated the problems facing the entire industry. Drexel pioneered the use of high-risk, high-interest junk bonds for a range of corporate financing, spurring the wave of mergers and buyouts that reshaped corporate American in the 1980s. But the firm ran into financial trouble when that market stumbled. Senior Conference Board economist Vincent G. Massaro said that in 1981 roughly 7 percent of total corporate debt was rated ``speculative'' by Moody's Investors Service Inc., the rating agency. Last month, the figure was 20 percent, he said. The percentage of companies' sales that goes toward debt payments has risen to the point where it has eroded competition within some sectors of corporate America, said Moody's President John A. Bohn Jr. He predicted the issuance of ``speculative-grade'' bonds, otherwise known as junk bonds, would plunge by at least 50 percent this year and that attitudes would shift toward financial conservatism. ``(Leveraged buyout) and takeover activity as a driving force will fade,'' Bohn said. In another area, experts agreed the United States would escape a recession this year, but said challenges on both domestic and international fronts will test the economy's ability to sustain its record-setting expansion. Thhe United States will face challenges from several directions. According to Bohn, U.S.-Japan relations will be put to the test in the coming years, and banks will be pressed to resume lending to less developed countries to get their economies going. And in Eastern Europe, ``the stage is set for a new range of East-West trade and financial incentives,'' he noted. How the United States will fare with these long-term challenges is unclear. Economic growth will continue at roughly a 2.5 percent pace this year, Massaro said, but inflation will rise to between 5 percent and 6 percent. ``I see the U.S. economy in a late phase of the cycle _ a time when prudent decision-makers will guard their flanks,'' Massaro said. The Conference Board is a non-profit network of companies, trade and professional organizations, government agencies and labor unions.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar and Gold Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CORRECT Canadian dollar quote, SUBS 5th graf. A version for AMs is planned by 5:30 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar weakened against other major currencies except the Canadian dollar in European trading Wednesday. Gold prices moved lower. Foreign exchange dealers said there was little direction in the currency markets, reflecting uncertainty about political and economic developments. They cited the apparent drawing together of East and West Germany, the difficulties of the American investment company Drexel Burnham Lambert and Japan's forthcoming general election. Late dollar rates compared with late Tuesday's quotes included: 1.6715 West German marks, down from 1.6760; 1.4920 Swiss francs, down from 1.4960; 5.6845 French francs, down from 5.6995; 1.8832 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8980; 1,242.25 Italian lire, down from 1,248.00; and 1.2062 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1995. In London, one British pound cost $1.6963 late Wednesday, compared to Tuesday's late rate of $1.6907. Earlier, in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 144.35 Japanese yen, down from 144.48. In London late Wednesday the dollar traded lower, at 144.25 yen. DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Close Higher on Soy Strength
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly higher Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade, paced by a late surge in the soybean and soybean oil markets. Analysts said soyoil futures led the advance, with support stemming from new export sales of U.S. soy oil to Pakistan and several African nations. Soybean oil for delivery in March closed up 29 cents at $19.95 per hundredweight. Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc., a Chicago-based brokers advisory service, said a government report last week indicating soy oil stocks are declining has made the market more sensitive to supply-and-demand signals. Wheat futures were mixed, with contracts for near-term delivery up amid expectations that China will tender soon for some of the 1 million metric tons of subsidized U.S. wheat offered to it last week by the Agriculture Department. A winter storm moving out of the Central Plains into the Midwest pressured deferred wheat contracts and helped limit gains in the soybean and corn markets due to the potential for beneficial precipitation in crop-producing areas. DOC.HEAD: Junk Market Holds Gains; Drexel Shops Portfolio
With AM-Drexel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The junk bond market gained further ground Wednesday following the bankruptcy filing of junk pioneer Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which began peddling its inventory of high-yield, high-risk issues to a handful of prospective buyers. A spokesman for First Boston Corp. confirmed that representatives took a look at the Drexel junk bond portfolio, but he declined to characterize their interest in it. Also said to be picking through the inventory were Salomon Brothers Inc., Morgan Stanley & Co. and Merrill Lynch & Co. Spokespeople at these firms had no immediate comment. Some traders also said General Electric Credit Corp. was rumored to have reviewed Drexel's junk holdings. Drexel, whose parent filed for federal bankruptcy court protection on Tuesday, is in the process of liquidating its government bond holdings. There has been fear among some market participants that a selloff of Drexel's huge junk bond portfolio would put downward pressure on a market that already has been battered by defaults among several major junk-financed companies in recent months. In the junk bond market on Wednesday, gains continued to be centered on high-quality, ``go-go'' issues such as Colt Industries, Safeway, and Duracell, whose prospects for paying off their junk debt are considered relatively less risky. After rising as much as $20 per $1,000 in face value in Tuesday bargain-hunting, the better issues gained another $5 to $15 per $1,000 late Wednesday as investors sought to pick up quality debt at low prices. ``People do realize that not all the companies are dogs, and that some high-coupon debt does have value,'' said Elizabeth Reiners, a vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Drexel almost single-handedly turned the market for high-risk, high-interest corporate bonds into a booming business during the 1980s, when the securities were widely used for financing corporate mergers and takeovers. Although its share of the market has shrunk in recent years, Drexel still is the dominant junk bond underwriter. Over the years, the firm underwrote billions of dollars worth of the bonds, some of which remain in its own private portfolio. Drexel spokesman Steve Anreder, while not directly confirming that the junk bond portfolio is up for sale, said the Wall Street firms ``may have been'' invited to review it. Such a move is not surprising, Anreder said, as Drexel is looking at any options to maximize the value of its holdings. Drexel never has publicly placed a value on its junk holdings, but market speculation has put the price tag as high as $1 billion. Exactly which issues are included in the portfolio also is unknown. ``People can make some serious, educated guesses about what they own, but nobody knows for sure unless they've seen the inventory,'' said one junk bond manager, who asked not to be named. ``All the issues Drexel has brought to market would be on it,'' speculated John Moran, a trader at Advest Inc. Traders said it is less important how and to whom Drexel sells its portfolio than how quickly it can unload the issues. ``Selling it as one piece may be better to get the uncertainty out of the market,'' said one trader who asked not to be identified.

The stock market eked out a small gain today, showing few ill effects from the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Stock prices turned in a mixed showing Tuesday as Drexel, which rose to prominence in the 1980s as the champion of ``junk bond'' finance, moved to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and liquidate. The firm's demise left many questions unanswered about the outlook for the high-yield bond market and the possible effect of pervasive debt problems on the economy as a whole. But analysts said the markets took the news as no great surprise, given the much-publicized weakening that has been going on for months in enthusiasm for junk bonds and other ``leverage'' investments. Some Wall Streeters believe the waning of ``junk'' debt might set the stage for a revival of traditional financial values that could put the stock and bond markets on a sounder long-term footing.

DOC.HEAD: Great Northern Seeks Buyers, Georgia-Pacific Mounts New Court Fight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES extraneous letter `a' in lede. SUBS grafs 6-7 bgng, Sherman Chao... to CORRECT spelling of `Weyerhaeuser.'
DOC.TEXT: Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. has begun looking for a friendly buyer and hostile suitor Georgia-Pacific Corp. went to federal court Wednesday to make sure it gets in on the auction. Great Northern said its financial adviser, Goldman, Sachs & Co., had begun soliciting buyers who might be interested in paying more than the $63 per share offered by hostile bidder Georgia-Pacific. Late Tuesday, Great Northern Chairman William R. Laidig issued a statement throwing the company open for bids, saying that Georgia-Pacific's $3.8 billion takeover attempt apparently prevented Great Northern from continuing its long-term plans to remain independent. Great Northern stock rose $2 to $64 a share on the New York Stock Exchange. Georgia-Pacific fell 37{ cents to $44.50 a share. Great Northern spokesman Stephen M. Hill declined to say which potential buyers had been contacted or how many there were. Sherman Chao, an analyst with the New York investment firm Salomon Brothers, speculated that the only other domestic paper companies capable of bidding were Weyerhaeuser Co., based in Tacoma, Wash., and International Paper Co., based in Purchase, N.Y. A spokesman for Weyerhaeuser had no comment on the Great Northern situation. A spokesman for International Paper said his company had expressed no past interest in buying Great Northern and he did not believe it has any interest now, although there would be no comment if any merger discussions were held. Separately Wednesday, Georgia-Pacific asked a federal judge to block Great Northern's postponement of a shareholder meeting, at which stockholders were to vote on whether to oust the Great Northern board of directors in favor of candidates nominated by Georgia-Pacific. On Tuesday night, Great Northern had announced it was postponing until March 20 the previously scheduled March 2 meeting. Great Northern also said it had amended its bylaws so that in the event Georgia-Pacific's candidates ended up controlling the board, they still would be forced to use Great Northern's ``poison pill'' defense against hostile takeovers. Georgia-Pacific filed papers in U.S. District Court seeking to restore the March 2 meeting date and asking U.S. District Judge Gene Carter to supervise the auction for Great Northern. ``There can be no doubt that GNN's attempt to restrict the power of future directors is in blatant violation of Maine statutes, and well-established principles of corporate law,'' Georgia-Pacific stated. Chao said Great Northern's attempts to resist Georgia-Pacific apparently were defeated last week when the federal judge ruled that the board could be ousted by just a two-thirds vote of Great Northern shareholders. Great Northern's bylaws had called for a three-fourths vote, but Carter said that provision violated Maine corporate law. ``A proxy fight was clearly a losing proposition for Great Northern,'' Chao said. Great Northern's executives decided to seek a buyer once ``it looked like they were going to be out of office soon anyway,'' Chao said. Hill said he did not know whether Goldman, Sachs would be seeking higher bids from Georgia-Pacific, but Georgia-Pacific's court filing accused Great Northern of planning to keep it out of the bidding.

DOC.HEAD: EC Opposes Air France's Takeover of UTA
DOC.TEXT: The European Commission decided Wednesday to oppose Air France's purchase of a controlling interest in Union de Transports Aeriens, a privately held French airline. The commission found that state-owned Air France's acquisition violates competition rules of the European Economic Community, a commission spokesman said. The spokesman, who declined to be identified by name, said the commission plans to send a formal statement of objection to Air France and the French government. He said the letter would open the way for discussions on what actions need to be taken to eliminate the commission's objections. EEC officials say Air France could be forced to shed some of the routes it acquired through its UTA purchase. Air France's purchase values UTA, France's biggest private airline, at almost 7 billion francs, or around $1.2 billion. On Jan. 17, Air France paid 3.8 billion francs for a 54.6 percent stake in UTA. Air France bought the UTA stake from Chargeurs SA, a holding company with transportation and textile interests. Chargeurs had controlled 82.9 percent of UTA's capital. Air France and UTA officials were unavailable for comment Wednesday. The spokesman said the commission's decision was based on Air France's position as the dominant force in its market. Article 86 of the EEC's founding Treaty of Rome prohibits abuse of a dominant market position by any company when it affects commerce within the 12-nation trading bloc. The acquisition gives Air France control of 97 percent of air routes within France all of the international routes allocated to French airlines. The purchase also raised Air France's stake in Air Inter, a domestic French airline, because UTA owned a majority of it. UTA has a small fleet of 19 jets, six of which are owned by its charter subsidiary Aeromaritime. UTA operates on long-haul routes, mainly to the Pacific and Africa. Chargeurs Chairman Jerome Seydoux had said on several occasions that he would sell UTA if the French government did not authorize it to operate on European and transatlantic routes.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Prices End Mixed
DOC.TEXT: A late rally boosted crude oil futures prices Wednesday but gasoline futures sagged after an industry report showed inventories rose sharply last week. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the March contract for unleaded gasoline fell 0.53 cent to 59.89 cents a gallon after advancing 0.86 cent in the previous two sessions. Other contracts closed mixed. The March contract for West Texas Intermediate, the main U.S. grade of crude oil, jumped 17 cents to $22.07 a barrel. Later contracts also posted gains. Heating oil for March delivery, meanwhile, advanced 0.79 cent to 57.64 cents a gallon, while other contracts also rose. Analysts said the American Petroleum Institute report on weekly inventories helped depress gasoline prices. ``The report showed double what was estimated,'' said Bob Baker, an energy analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. The API said gasoline stocks rose 7.5 million barrels to 238.9 million barrels in the week ended Feb. 9. Heating oil inventories were up 870,000 barrels to 121.9 million barrels while crude oil stocks fell 1.9 million barrels, the API said in its report released after the close of trading Tuesday. Analysts said concern about the future of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., a major operator in futures trading, remained in the market after the parent of the large securities broker filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection Tuesday. Drexel was said to be adjusting its positions in the energy market, assessing its obligations to other companies and determining how to meet them.

DOC.HEAD: Numbed Employees Try to Joke in Face of Tough Job Market
DOC.TEXT: Police in riot gear erected barriers as soon-to-be-jobless Drexel Burnham Lambert workers left their headquarters for lunch Wednesday, a short stroll from the New York Stock Exchange. Blue sawhorses blocked the sidewalk _ not to keep the curious from what once was Wall Street's highest-flying firm, but because Vice President Dan Quayle happened to be touring a job-training center next to the Drexel building. ``What's Quayle doing, coming to rescue Drexel?'' shouted one employee of the firm, whose collapse into Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings will put most of Drexel's 5,300 workers out of work. He and other workers said Drexel management gave no indication of the severity of the firm's troubles, and most of the staff was stunned Tuesday when Drexel announced it would liquidate most assets and quit business. ``I guess you could tell the story of numbness,'' said a Drexel ``junk-bond'' professional, who asked not to be identified because he still does not know how many more weeks his job will last. ``It wasn't gradual in terms of layoffs, and then management telling employees to prepare for a bleak future, anything like that. It just suddenly happened.'' Drexel's collapse will dump thousands of job-seekers into an already depressed securities business, and while the best will quickly find work, many others won't. ``Hey, there was a lot of talent there, and top talent will always find a home on the Street,'' said Wolfgang Demisch, the head of research at UBS Securities Inc. in New York and a potential hirer of Drexel analysts. ``But the broader message is that the Street is shrinking,'' Demisch said. He likened the plight of Drexel employees to the difficulties aerospace workers would face if a large company suddenly closed in today's climate of defense cuts. Many Drexel managers began to job-hunt quietly in December after learning their bonuses would be paid in stock rather than cash, said executive ``headhunter'' Stephanie Katris. Ms. Katris is an assistant vice president at Henner Associates in Chicago, a four-person company specializing in executive searches for the capital markets industry. Since December, Henner had received a few calls a week from high-level Drexel workers seeking sales or corporate finance work, she said. That trickle turned to a flood this week. ``There's been 30 calls in the past two days,'' she said Wednesday. ``They say, `I'll do anything.' They're ready to get into banking, or work for smaller specialty brokerages.'' One big question for prospective employers will be whether workers succeeded at Drexel because of their efforts or because of the company's hammerlock on high-yield bond financing. ``There was a time when a salesman from Drexel could pick up the phone and sell pretty much anything based on the reputation of the firm and their ability to provide liquidity,'' Ms. Katris said. Gary Goldstein, president of The Whitney Group, an executive search firm in New York, said his office has been getting up to 30 calls an hour, most from Drexel people, compared with less than 20 on a normal day. ``People are still feeling the emotional shock of it,'' Goldstein said. ``Like, `God, a week ago I signed two engagement letters _ business as usual.' All of a sudden they're getting their last paychecks.'' A continent away in Beverly Hills, Calif., where Michael Milken built a Drexel empire based on the high-risk, high-yield junk bonds, Valentine's Day business slumped at Gump's, the luxury gift store beneath Drexel's offices at the foot of California's premiere shopping street, Rodeo Drive. ``Normally they buy a lot,'' said a Gump's employee. ``But I haven't seen anything of them this year.'' The Drexel junk-bond worker said some employees were spending nearly all their time looking for work, while others tried to hold back huge waves of calls from clients trying to close accounts. Outside the corporate offices on Broad Street, the employee who joked about the vice president's visit said workers were shocked by the suddenness of the news, but were still able to trade dark asides. ``They're renaming the company `Nightmare on Broad Street,' _ starring Freddy Krueger Joseph,'' he said _ a dual reference to the burn-scarred ``Nightmare on Elm Street'' slasher and Drexel Chief Executive Frederick Joseph. ``My dad called me from California last night and said, `Son, your bedroom is still here.'''

DOC.HEAD: Deals Still Out There, But Drexel Filing Takes a Toll
DOC.TEXT: The collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert maybe another blow to an already teetering market for junk bond financed takeovers, but dealmakers are showing they still have plenty of ways to do business. Georgia-Pacific Corp. is undertaking a $3.8 billion hostile bid for rival paper manufacturer Great Northern Nekoosa Inc. and the management of Chrysler's Gulfstream Aerospace subsidiary is buying the division for $825 million. The bidders for those companies have gone back to some older, more conservative financing methods _ as other corporate borrowers that once relied on the junk market may now be forced to do. The takeover business slowed to a crawl when junk bond money dried up last fall after serious problems emerged at a number of companies heavily financed with the high-interest debt. The bankruptcy court filing late Tuesday by the parent of Drexel _ whose fortunes rose and fell with the market for the high-yield debt securities that it pioneered _ was another devastating blow to junk bond financing, once the premier route for backing a buyout. Georgia-Pacific has lined up financing from a syndicate of banks at an interest rate of 1 percent above the prime rate, which currently stands at 10 percent. That compares with the 16 percent levels commonly attached to junk bonds. Being able to do the deal without junk bonds was one of its selling points, said A.D. ``Pete'' Correll, Georgia-Pacific's executive vice president in charge of pulp and paper. Gulfstream, meanwhile, is being bought with bank financing and a combination of equity and debt financing provided by the division's chairman, Alan Paulson and the investment firm Forstmann Little & Co. Paulson said he never considered using junk bonds. Junk bonds began falling seriously out of favor in September, when Campeau Corp.'s $6.7 billion purchase of Federated Department Stores Inc. _ which depended heavily on the risky securities _ began to unravel. A number of new junk bond financings were put on hold. The junk bond market has taken a series of hits since then, and Drexel, whose biggest business was selling the securities, suffered heavy losses that contributed to the firm's Chapter 11 filing. ``Already dim prospects for takeover entrepreneurs to raise large amounts of money using high-yield bonds is further dimmed ... This is another significant negative,'' said Gregg A. Jarrell, a finance professor at the University of Rochester's William E. Simon School of Business. Morris Mendelson, a professor of finance at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Business, said Drexel's downfall ``won't kill the junk bond market, but I suspect that some firms that might have been able to raise money in the junk bond market while Drexel was alive won't be able to now.'' Bernard Black, a Columbia University School of Law professor, said the junk bond market would shrink. Drexel's problems mean ``a possible source of liquidity is no longer there.'' he said, ``There's no market maker for recently issued debt.'' Junk bonds are best known for backing big takeovers, but they also have been used extensively by smaller companies. Some of these firms resorted to high-yield debt because they could not obtain other financing and may face trouble if they need loans in the future. ``They may be slower in their growth,'' said Allen Michel, a professor at the Boston University School of Management. ``They will not be able to expand at the same rate, they'll have to pull in their horns.'' Mendelson painted a darker picture: ``You may have more firms going belly-up that wouldn't have had to go belly-up before.'' Investors pursuing buyouts are finding that the failure of junk bonds has created problems besides forcing them to look for other means of financing. Trying to get bank financing means meeting a newly toughened set of qualifications. In junk bond financing, hundreds of individual investors might be putting up $1 million _ for many of them a relatively small amount _ but a bank syndicate has a smaller number of participants who have much more at stake and therefore more stringent standards, said Jerome E. Hass, a professor of managerial economics and finance at Cornell University's Johnson Graduate School of Management. ``What they want is a business that has a cash flow capacity to service the debt,'' Hass said of lenders. Georgia-Pacific said it expects to have a debt load of $7.5 billion if it succeeds in its bid for Great Northern. Securities analysts who track the company say that the suitor and its target have strong cash flows and say Georgia-Pacific will be able to pay down its debt. Lawrence Ross, an analyst with PaineWebber Inc., said banks also were willing to back Georgia-Pacific because it ``is tremendously strong, financially and operationally,'' Furthermore, ``We're not talking here about someone from outside the industry taking over a company, somebody who doesn't know anything about the industry ... '' Ross said.

DOC.HEAD: Business Failures Decline, Researcher Says
DOC.TEXT: Business failures fell to the lowest level in more than a decade last year, as massive savings and loans flops and the real estate slump subsided, Dun & Bradstreet Corp. reported Wednesday. Business failures nationwide declined 12.9 percent to 49,719 from 57,099 in 1988, said Dun & Bradstreet, a New York-based marketer of business information. The decline was most pronounced in Texas, where business failures dropped 32.4 percent to 5,323. However, failures rose 41.9 percent in Massachusetts to 789 as New England states reported an increase in bankruptcies. Business failures, according to the report, are defined as companies that cease operations for a number of reasons, including bankruptcy, foreclosure or reorganization. Fewer failures were reported in agriculture, mining, manufacturing and the services sector as well as in wholesale and retail trade. But the finance, insurance and real estate sectors registered a 9.1 percent increase in business failures to 2,770 from 2,540 in 1988, the report said. ``The troubled savings and loan industry and the subsequent stress in the real estate sector drove failures up earlier this year, but the upward trend appears to be subsiding,'' said Joseph W. Duncan, a Dun and Bradstreet economist. The largest regional decrease in business failures was in the mountain states. Colorado showed a 32.8 percent drop, Utah was down 52.3 percent, Wyoming off 42.9 percent, New Mexico fell 14 percent and Arizona declined 13.2 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Prudential and Jones Lang Wooten Launch $2 Billion Real Estate Program
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Programme is cq in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: The Prudential Insurance Co. of America and Jones Lang Wooten are heading a group of investors in a $2 billion real estate investment program to buy property around the world, the companies said Wednesday. The Prudential Global Real Estate Investment Programme is designed to help companies acquire a real estate portfolio spread among major cities in several countries. Plans are to invest in prime real estate assets over three to five years. Eight companies have committed a total of $2 billion to the program, including: Prudential; Nationale-Nederlanden NV, the Netherlands; Australian Mutual Provident Society; Government of Singapore Investment Corp. Pte Ltd. (GSIC); and SPP, Sweden. The names of the three other companies that have committed money are not being disclosed, said Melanie Keenan, spokeswoman for Jones Lang. Robert E. Riley, chairman of the Prudential Realty Group, and Keith Douglas-Mann, chairman of Jones Lang Wooten, issued a joint statement sayig that each member of the investment group brought ``significant knowledge of its own part of the world.'' The combined experience and resources will complement each other, they said. Cities under consideration for investment include Frankfurt, West Germany; London; Paris; Sydney, Australia; and Toronto; as well as Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles, New York and Washington. The Prudential Realty Group, headquartered in Newark, manages more than $45 billion in real estate assets and has 24 offices throughout the United States. Jones Lang Wooten, based in London, has 58 offices worldwide, including a U.S. headquarters in New York. It specializes in investment and corporate real estate services.

DOC.HEAD: Troubled Bank Sells More Assets
DOC.TEXT: Bank of New England Corp. said Wednesday it sold more of its vehicle leasing business, valued at $100 million, as the banking company tries to raise cash to stem major losses. Bank of New England recently announced it sold the $350 million U.S. portion of its McCullagh Leasing unit to GE Capital, a subsidiary of General Electric Co. On Wednesday, the bank said it sold the remaining, Canadian portion of the business to GE Capital. Tom Lavelle, a bank spokesman, declined to release the purchase price for the businesses. ``This sale represents continued momentum in our plans to increase equity capital, improve capital ratios and to strengthen our financial resources,'' H. Ridgely Bullock, the bank's interim chairman, said in a statement. The bank also expects to sign an agreement soon to sell $1.3 billion in home equity loans, he said. The bank has been trying to sell $6 billion in assets as it faces estimated losses exceeding $1 billion in 1989 due largely to bad real estate loans. In recent weeks, the bank has sold its credit card business to Citicorp for $828 million, and has agreed to sell other leasing businesses to the Bank of Tokyo for a profit of $92.5 million.

DOC.HEAD: Jon Baker, Battles Image of Boring Insurance Salesman
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Jon Baker helped finance a major Hollywood movie and hosted Princess Di, but he admits there isn't much glamour in his job title _ insurance salesman. ``When it comes to a life insurance salesman and a used car salesman, a lot of people say `I'd rather affiliate with a used car salesman.' So would I,'' Baker said. ``The industry breeds mediocrity.'' If it sounds like Baker is trying to shake up the insurance business and remove its stigma as a boring profession that attracts greedy loafers, you're right. He said the system needs to change so agents will sell more policies and maintain them over a long period of time. It's part of a formula that led Baker and his former partner, John Lander, to sell $1 billion worth of insurance in 1988. ``There is no magic dust,'' said Baker, 47. He started in the insurance business in 1970, working for Mutual of New York, but four years later he formed the partnership with Lander. The two brought to this venture an assembly line system for soliciting and meeting customers, planning policies, closing deals and collecting referrals all at once, using differing workers. But Baker also had interests elsewhere. In 1978, he got Lander to join him in providing financial backing for the motion picture, ``The Buddy Holly Story.'' While the movie received three Academy Award nominations, including one for best actor for Gary Busey, and won the award for best sound track, Baker said the venture turned out to be a financial nightmare. ``The picture went way overbudget,'' he said. ``I was in constant warfare with the producer group. I'm surprised we ever got it in the can.'' The National Independent Theater Exhibitor sued Columbia Pictures over the distribution rights, but the case was dismissed. Yet the movie is still the source of litigation. Baker claims Columbia hasn't fully paid him. ``Minnows who want to get into the water with sharks and piranhas get eaten alive,'' he said. Baker admits his outside interests strained the partnership with Lander. The breaking point came in early 1989, when Baker turned his attention to the Royal Academy of Music in England. The year before, he had become chairman of a newly created foundation that would provide scholarships for Americans wishing to study at the academy. In the fall of 1988, Baker was invited to London to meet with Princess Diana, who served as president of the academy. He then planned a reception for her in New York in February 1989. ``All of December, January and February, I was consumed in this,'' he said. ``John (Lander) didn't like it. His motivations were different.'' Lander was more focused on the insurance business, and so the two parted, each forming his own company. Baker's career in life insurance hasn't always gone well. When Congress eliminated a tax break for corporate-owned life insurance in 1986, Baker estimates his firm lost more than $3 million. ``Effectively, we went out of business,'' he said. But Baker and Lander rebuilt their company, looking for new avenues to sell insurance. One fruitful idea has been to market insurance policies as a way for businesses to stem the rising cost of health coverage. Under this system, a company buys insurance on its workers, and when an employee dies, the benefits are used to help cover the company's medical costs. Baker acknowledges this scheme is a bit ``ghoulish,'' but says insurance salesmen need to find creative ways to sell their product. ``This industry is so screwed up,'' said Baker, who now oversees 18 people in his office in Wellesley, a Boston suburb. ``There's an opportunity for those who know what they're doing to generate an unlimited amount of production and revenue.'' In 1988, Baker said, this production generated $20 million worth of premiums for the two partners, which translated to $1 billion worth of insurance. Industry experts consider that a major achievement. Baker has actively sought a high-profile image in the insurance business, which is heavily concentrated in the Northeast. At a recent conference of Boston-area life insurance salesmen, he proposed lowering commissions for the first year, then raising them in following years while the policy remains in effect. That move would encourage people to make more sales and keep the policies from lapsing, he said. ``His view is from the standpoint of a very comfortable agent,'' said Jack Bobo, executive vice president of the National Association of Life Underwriters. Agents receive large first-year commissions because selling a policy requires a lot of planning with the customer. ``If they cannot be rewarded, the experience is that the planning doesn't get done,'' he said. Also, a cut in commissions could push agents out of the business. But Baker said that's exactly what the insurance industry needs. ``Failing and marginal producers,'' he said, ``must be terminated.''

DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief explanation of junk bonds and their role in the nation's financial markets:
DOC.HEAD: WHAT ARE THEY?
DOC.TEXT: Corporate bonds rated below investment grade by either Standard & Poor's Corp. or Moody's Investors Service are considered ``junk.'' That means a company's ability to pay interest and repay principal is considered speculative, meaning there is a higher risk of default. To compensate, the bonds carry higher yields _ currently, an average of 15.35 percent, compared with 9.62 percent for investment-grade corporate bonds and 8.32 percent for 10-year U.S. government bonds, according to Moody's.
DOC.HEAD: MARKET SIZE:
DOC.TEXT: Moody's estimates there are more than $200 billion in junk bonds outstanding, representing about 25 percent of all corporate bond issues. The market mushroomed in the 1980s, growing almost nine times in size. In contrast, all debt issued by the nation's non-financial concerns, which includes government borrowings, totals about $9.6 trillion. The nation's equity market, or stocks, is worth about $3.2 trillion.
DOC.HEAD: DREXEL'S ROLE:
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. propelled the market's growth and was by far the biggest underwriter and trader of junk bonds. The firm promoted the use of junk bonds to raise money for small or young companies unable to issue investment-grade bonds, and to finance corporate takeovers. Drexel says 59 percent of the money raised by junk issues from 1980 to 1988 went to finance companies' internal growth while the remaining 41 percent was used to finance takeovers.
DOC.HEAD: ISSUERS:
DOC.TEXT: They range from young, fast-growing companies such as MCI Communications Corp. and McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. to acquired corporations such as Federated Department Stores Inc. and RJR Nabisco. Federated and RJR issued billions of dollars worth of bonds to finance their takeovers by Campeau Corp. and buyout specialist Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., respectively.
DOC.HEAD: INVESTORS:
DOC.TEXT: The biggest owners of junk bonds are mutual funds and insurance companies, each of which holds about 30 percent of the bonds outstanding, Moody's estimates. Pension funds hold about 15 percent of the market, foreign investors about 9 percent and savings and loan associations about 7 percent. The S&L bailout bill passed late last year by Congress requires thrifts to sell their junk holdings by 1994.

DOC.HEAD: Aetna's Profit Down 28 Percent; Transamerica Income Jumps 31 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Aetna Life & Casualty Co. on Wednesday reported a 28 percent drop in fourth-quarter net income, attributed to higher catastrophe costs and rising costs in automobile losses, while Transamerica Corp.'s profit jumped 31 percent. Aetna, based in Hartford, Conn., posted net income for the fourth quarter of $151 million, or $1.35 a share, down from $209 million, or $1.85 a share, in the same quarter of 1988. The decline occurred despite an increase in fourth-quarter revenue to $5.2 billion from $4.35 billion a year earlier. For the full year, Aetna reported net income of $676 million, or $6.02 a share, down 5 percent from $713 million, or $6.25 a share, in 1988. Revenue for 1989 totaled $19.6 billion, up from $17.8 billion the previous year. Aetna said its losses from catastrophes reduced fourth-quarter income by $66 million and 1989 earnings by $170 million, after taxes. The fourth-quarter losses came mainly from freezing weather in December and the October earthquake in California. Aetna Chairman James T. Lynn said losses were partially offset by stronger earnings from employee benefits businesses and increased capital gains. San Francisco-based Transamerica credited strong performances in its insurance and finance businesses for its robust gain in fourth-quarter profit. For the three months ended Dec. 31, the company posted net income of $76.1 million, or 95 cents a share, up 31 percent from $58 million, or 73 cents a share, in the same period in 1988. The 1988 fourth-quarter results included $1.5 million in gains from investments. For all of 1989, Transamerica's net income was $332.2 million, or $4.18 a share, up from $262.1 million, or $3.30 a share, in 1988. The annual figures include capital gains of $40.2 million in 1989 and $10.8 million in 1988. The 1988 results also include a $36.9 million one-time reduction in the first quarter because of a new rule on accounting for income taxes.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Reports Moderate Increase in Long Distance Calls Due to Discount
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with 1 percent increase during discount period; picks up 3rd graf pvs, `The long ...' SUBS 6th graf pvs, `Ms. Newman ...' to RESTORE first reference.
DOC.TEXT: AT&T reported a slight increase in long distance telephone calls Wednesday as the company offered Valentine's Day discounts to make up for a nine-hour service disruption last month. Call volume was up about 1 percent from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m., the hours of the special, AT&T spokesman Mike Keady said. There were about 78.6 million calls attempted during those hours, up from 77.7 million the previous Wednesday, he said. The long distance network handles about 110 million calls on a normal business day. The discount applied to residential and most business customers, including credit card and toll-free ``800'' calls. A programming error in AT&T's call switching network partially knocked out long-distance service nationwide for about nine hours Jan. 15, keeping millions of calls from being completed. Lynn Newman, another spokesperson at AT&T's operations headquarters in Basking Ridge, said the discount was the only measure planned by AT&T to compensate customers. ``This is our way of saying you're a valuable customer,'' Ms. Newman said. The phone giant offered long-distance customers an average 33 percent discount off regular daytime rates for calls within the United States between 8 a.m. and 5 p.m. Discounts averaged about 37 percent off calls to 158 countries worldwide. In some states where local utility regulators gave the company permission, discounts also applied to intra-state calls handled by AT&T, she said. ``I think it's a very generous way for them to atone for any damages done,'' said Jim Furlong, spokesman for Computer Sciences Corp. of Los Angeles, a computer services company that relies heavily on long distance calling. Furlong said the company did not attempt to determine how much money, if any, it lost during the nine-hour outage. ``We're not the least bothered or concerned by that one-day problem,'' he said. ``It's a very nice gesture,'' said Roger Connor, a spokesman for Marriott Corp., which relies on long-distance telephone calls for reservations for its 530 hotels worldwide. ``I think it's more than adequate.'' Connor said the company did not believe it lost money because of the outage. Mary O'Neill, a spokeswoman for American Airlines, said her company was trying to work out compensation for the outage that affected reservation lines last month. ``Because we had a special corporate contract, we were not eligible for that discount,'' said Ms. O'Neill. She said the airlines is negotiating with AT&T to find ``an acceptable settlement.'' She said American's volume of calls was reduced by about two-thirds on the day of the outage.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Merc Eyes Eastern Europe For Growth In 90s
With AM-Commodities Probe
DOC.TEXT: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange on Wednesday unveiled a blueprint for the 1990s that foresees Eastern European participation in the Merc's agricultural markets and new sources of revenue for exchange members. But the first objective of the world's second-largest commodity futures exchange is to regain public confidence after last year's bruising revelation of a federal trading-fraud investigation, the Merc's board of governors said in a statement. ``In order to maintain our successful momentum, there must be absolute confidence in the integrity of our markets,'' the statement said. The continuing investigation of trading practices at the Merc and the larger Chicago Board of Trade has yielded indictments against 48 people, 26 of them Merc traders. Leo Melamed, chairman of the Merc board's executive committee, said the free-market revolution in Eastern Europe promises to revitalize the Merc's agricultural futures and options markets, which were overshadowed by the wildly successful development of financial futures in the 1980s. People in the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe want more meat and importers there can be taught how to protect their businesses from market fluctuations by using futures and options to lock in prices in advance, Melamed said in a telephone interview. In addition to its existing cattle, hog and pork-belly contracts, the Merc may develop new hedging instruments specifically for the Eastern European market, he said. ``We're going to make that into quite a priority because it looks like there's a demand for it,'' Melamed said. The board also proposed a new business venture, the CME Resource and Service Co., to develop products and services for market users and divide the profits among the Merc's approximately 2,700 members. Some of the ventures CME Resource may pursue include publishing, telecommunications services, accounting services and trade-clearing for markets other than the Merc, Melamed said. The venture would be modeled after Globex, an automated global trading network the Merc is developing with Reuters Holdings PLC that will return profits to exchange members. Globex will be launched in the spring, the Merc said.

DOC.HEAD: Creditors Say They Won't Push for Liquidation
DOC.TEXT: Unsecured creditors of Eastern Airlines said Tuesday they would work with the carrier to reach agreement on a bankruptcy reorganization plan rather than push for Eastern's liquidation. The committee representing unsecured creditors, a group composed mainly of trade suppliers such as aircraft manufacturers who are owed about $1.1 billion by Eastern, made the announcement after meeting in New York. In a statement, the committee said it was briefed by its financial advisers about Eastern's proposed reorganization plan, other reorganization alternatives and ``the potential recovery to be achieved in a liquidation.'' Eastern proposed only partial repayment of its debts in its latest reorganization proposal filed with the federal bankruptcy court in New York in late January. Previously, the carrier had promised to repay its debts in full. ``The creditors committee has made no determination to pursue a liquidation in this case,'' the unsecured creditors' statement said. ``The creditors committee intends to proceed with immediate negotiations with Eastern, Texas Air and the examiner with a view toward achieving a consensual plan of reorganization that is in the best interests of creditors and which provides for a viable Eastern Airlines going forward.'' Eastern spokesman Robin Matell welcomed the creditors committee statement. ``We look forward to continuing negotiations with the committee in hopes of reaching a consensual agreement,'' he said late Tuesday. Eastern's reorganization plan calls for paying unsecured creditors only 10 percent of their debts in cash when the airline emerges from bankruptcy protection, and another 70 percent over the following 10 years, without interest. In return for accepting partial repayment, Texas Air would give the unsecured creditors a 40 percent equity stake in Eastern. The plan also calls for paying preferred stockholders no more than 10 cents on the dollar in the form of new securities. The preferred holders, who are owed $1.175 billion, criticized Eastern's reorganization plans and advocated the liquidation or outright sale of the airline two weeks. The Machinists union has been on strike against Eastern since last March 4. It was joined in sympathy walkouts by pilots and flight attendants, forcing the airline into bankruptcy court protection on March 9. The pilots and flight attendants abandoned their strikes just before Thanksgiving, but Eastern has rebuilt as a smaller carrier and hired mostly non-union workers to replace the strikers.
